review_text: I originally gave this three stars, but it was so close to four that I decided not to be miserly, and bumped it up by one. If you have a kid (and when I say kid I mean a young to middling teenager, or maybe an advanced pre-teen) who likes to read scary stories, they might be into this. It had a very Outer Limits/Twilight Zone kind of feel. This is apparently meant as a middle grades book, and the storytelling style is like that, but some of the elements seem a bit too gruesome for that. (One thing in particular, which I'll detail at the end behind a spoiler tag.) It scared me at points, but my threshold for being scared by things is kind of low. I was scared when I saw The Blair Witch Project, and I'm assured that only total wimps were scared by that. Thematically, this is about friendship, not conforming to ideals of normalcy and perfection, and the temptation to try to change people. I feel like the story elements were not manipulated with maximum deftness, but they are handled reasonably well. I really liked the visual design of the book. The endpapers have a pattern of creepy bugs on them, and throughout the text drawings of small bugs appeared in the margins. There is one thing that's gross, though. I saw it coming, but I winced anyway when it was confirmed, because ew. Soylent Green is made of people! i.e., there's cannibalism here. Even if you look at it as a metaphor for how the non-conformers get eaten up, it seems a bit gratuitous. This author apparently has books forthcoming over the next couple of years, and I'd be willing to give them a try.
they didnt actually quit, they just wrote letters of complaint and telling the kid what they wanted to see change. Pretty smart really

This story follows a family consisting of a father, mother, a boy, and a girl. The kids' father becomes obsessed with his work after he was let go from his job. He spends all day working in the family's basement, and becomes furious if anyone ventures into his work area. After the father is found eating plant food and having leaves grow out of his head, he confesses that he is working on a plant/animal hybrid. The father continues to act weird and is found sleeping with dirt and insects in his bed, and the suit of his previous boss after he comes to visit. Eventually, the kids find a clone of their dad and his previous boss in the basement. A decision must be made as to who is the real dad. The girl cuts one of them who bleeds red, and assumes that it his her dad. She also knows this because he uses her nickname which the plant-clone had not been using for days. I liked this story a lot more than the first book in the series (Welcome to Dead House). Not only did I enjoy the exploration of experimenting with nature and the catastrophic results that it can have, but it also seemed a lot scarier to me. It also explored themes of questioning authority in the form of the kids' parents. I don't think that as a kid I would have been able to see through the plot as well as I did as not only an adult, but an adult who had read this book (at least once) as a kid. There was a lot of foreshadowing however, and I remembered the ending quite vividly. So while the ending may be predictable it is one that will stick with you. The story burrowed A LOT of elements of Invasion of the Body Snatchers such as the plants cloning people and hiding the humans and the clones that have little/no emotion. The biggest difference between the two books is the origin of the "plants," where in this book it's DNA mutation while in Body Snatchers they are of an alien descent. With the first Goosebumps books, I was afraid that I was remembering this series with rose colored glasses, and that although I would enjoy reading through the series as an adult, but that they would not hold up very well and I wouldn't enjoy them as much as an adult. This book seemed to put that fear to rest, and I can honestly say that I also enjoyed this book as an adult.

I don't remember reading this book in school, so I decided to give it a try. Lois Lowry is an incredible story teller. Even though it was a relatively short story, I didn't feel like there was anything missing. The story is told in such a way that you don't realize how different that world is until it is mentioned. I got to the part about  how there is no color in the world   and it felt like a bomb had been dropped because I had no idea. Terrific writing! If you haven't read this I suggest you do!

Read for the 2016 YA/MG Book Battle. This book was simply charming. I fell in love with the Penderwick family, both immediate and extended. Birdsall has a real gift for characterization that shows throughout the story, even in the most marginal of side characters (like the kindergarten twins who fall in love with Ben). I had some trouble keeping the three older sisters separate at first, but I'm sure that's because I haven't read any of the other books in the series--a deficiency I plan to remedy immediately. (Why did I read these out of order? Because I'm reading it for the Book Battle 2016 and I wanted to come at it unspoiled. The things I do for friends.) Batty, who's arguably the hero (though her brother Ben takes the narrative frequently), is shy, and one of the things I loved about the book was how life kept challenging her to rise above her shyness. The description of how she essentially made a deal with herself to be able to pass out flyers for her business was perfect--as was the way that business became something she never dreamed of. Her mental hangups, particularly her guilt over the death of her beloved dog, are exactly those of an eleven-year-old, and we see so clearly through her eyes that they feel serious even as I knew with my adult perspective that they're unfounded. I could go on with a series of "I loved"s--I loved Batty and Ben's relationships with their older friends, especially Jeffrey and Nick; I loved Batty's discovery of her voice and how it felt so precious to her; I loved pretentious Oliver and how Rosalind was the only one who didn't know everyone else disliked him; I loved the dogs and how full of personality they were. But what really struck me was the big twist in the middle: Batty overhears a conversation in which one of her sisters "reveals" that the reason their mother died of cancer was because she couldn't be treated for it while she was pregnant--that she gave up her life and all they got in return was Batty. It's a devastating secret to learn, but what makes it work is that Batty is eleven and at the perfect age to take it uncritically, where an older child or adult might question whether Skye's perspective is really valid. It hurt to see her suffer through all the days she carries the secret with her, but what I thought was truly effective was how she doesn't regain her center immediately upon learning the truth. That has to wait for a second epiphany, and that one comes through music--just as it should. I couldn't help comparing this to A Ring of Endless Light, which it faced off against in this year's Book Battle. Both are stories about family and friendship, but where I felt A Ring of Endless Light depicted an unrealistically "cool" family, with their affectations and seven-year-olds enjoying Shakespeare, this book has a family that seems incredibly familiar to me, for all it's nothing like the one I grew up in. The character voices are so authentic I found myself wishing to be part of their circle. I'm looking forward to reading more about the Penderwicks, wherever their story takes them.

I actually enjoyed this book a lot more than I expected to! It was probably a little longer than was necessary, and at times in the last 1/3 or so, it felt like the author was almost in over her head with everything that was going on. But overall it was really enjoyable and very reminiscent of Roald Dahl. The beginning reminded me so much of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, and Tabitha's parents were right up there with Matilda's parents as the worst parents ever. I loved the setting and the English mystery atmosphere. Tabitha was such an endearing character, trying her best to remain positive despite having such a miserable life! And her friendship with Pemberley was pretty adorable, too. (And I'm not a mouse person, ha.) I thought her fascination with the Inspector Pensive mystery series was a nice touch, and I even liked the excerpts from those (nonexistent) books at the beginning of each chapter. I figured from the beginning that the Countess wasn't the real Countess...she was way too psychotic and crazy. And I thought that the "ghosts" were probably people behind the walls. But the whole twin thing near the end did surprise me. (Oh, so many twins!) I really liked this charming little book and would recommend it to any fans of Roald Dahl.

Georges' family has to move from his Brooklyn home to a nearby apartment, where he meets Safer, a kid his age who runs a Spy Club and is sure that Mr. X, who lives above Georges, is murdering people in his apartment and taking them out of the building in suitcases. Over the span of a few weeks, Georges learns a lot about friends, bullies, spies, and family. Both Safer's family and his own have their own secrets, and Georges has to redefine reality and friendship by the end of the book. I read this on my Kindle and started it one night and finished it the next. The suspense was not heart-pounding or scary, but I really, really wanted to know what was going to happen. I knew from an article I read that things were not what they seemed, and that knowledge probably fueled my curiosity. This was an engrossing read with main characters I really liked. Safer is fairly agoraphobic, and that's why he never leaves the apartment building. The Spy Club thing was a sign his little sister put up years before, and he just kind of made the whole thing up as they went along. Meanwhile, Georges' mom wasn't working double shifts as a nurse during this period--she contracted a bacterial disease from a patient and was hospitalized herself. Georges is in denial of that fact and is protecting himself by pretending that she's just at work. (Review copy on Kindle from my local library)

Roald Dahl is the perfect children's author. He takes kids seriously; there are real consequences for adventures here. His books are perfectly constructed. * I can't imagine having a child and not having Dahl's complete works available for him or her. This book apparently comes under fire for being sexist, and I get that. I don't agree, though; after all, the wisest and kindest character is the kid's grandmother. And while Dahl does go out of his way to point out that all witches are women, he goes on to mention that all ghouls and barghests are men. And also, Matilda exists. * Well, almost perfectly; I kept wondering what happened to the mice William and Mary.

The first time I read this book was at the age of 12 because a close friend recommended it. The cover was colorful and the story was interesting. I remember it was fascinating the way the factory was described. But, for the life of me, I had forgotten about the Oompa-Loompas. The movie brought back memory. A certain book does need a movie so it can paint the thing readers can only imagine. What so grand about a boy who visited a chocolate factory? Duh, the factory itself. I'm not a child anymore but, I would like to go there. And that's what amazing about this book. RD had written it, especially about the factory, so vivid that I once wished it was real. Great book not just for kids but, for adult too. [READ AT YOUR OWN PERIL] 11-year-old Charlie Bucket lives in poverty in a tiny house with his parents and four grandparents. His grandparents share the only bed in the house, located in the only bedroom. Charlie and his parents sleep on a mattress on the floor. One day, Grandpa Joe tells him about the legendary and eccentric chocolatier, Willy Wonka and all the wonderful candy he made until the other candymakers sent in spies to steal his secret recipes, which lead him to close the factory forever. The next day, the newspaper announces that Mr. Wonka is reopening the factory and has invited five children to come on a tour, after they find a golden ticket in a Wonka Bar. Each ticket find is a media sensation and each finder becomes a celebrity. The first four golden tickets are found by the gluttonous Augustus Gloop, the spoiled and petulant Veruca Salt, the gum-addicted Violet Beauregarde, and the TV-obsessed Mike Teavee. One day, Charlie sees a fifty-pence coin (dollar bill in the US version) buried in the snow. He then buys himself a Wonka Bar and finds the fifth golden ticket and shows it to his parents. The ticket says he can bring any family members with him to the factory and Charlie's parents decide to allow Grandpa Joe to go with him. After meeting Mr. Wonka, the kids and their parents go inside where they meet Oompa-Loompas, a race of small people who help Mr. Wonka operate the factory since he rescued them from poverty and fear in their home country Loompaland. The other kids are ejected from the factory in comical, mysterious and painful ways. Augustus gets sucked up the pipe after falling into the Chocolate River in the Chocolate Room, Violet blows up into a giant blueberry after sampling an experimental three-course chewing gum meal in the Inventing Room, Veruca is thrown down the garbage chute in the Nut Room after the nut-testing squirrels consider her a "bad nut," and Mike gets shrunk after he tries to be the first person to be sent by television in the Television Room's Television Chocolate Technology. With only Charlie remaining, Mr. Wonka congratulates him for "winning" the factory and, after explaining his true age and the reason behind his golden tickets, names Charlie his successor. They ride the Great Glass Elevator to Charlie's house while the other four children go home after their demises (Augustus squeezed thin, Violet all blue in the face, Veruca covered in garbage, and Mike stretched ten feet tall). Afterwards, Mr. Wonka invites them to come live with him in the factory.

I must review this book now. Why, you ask? Because some of the reviews do such a piss-poor job of capturing the magic that makes this book great for young adults and a winner of the 1994 John Newbery Medal, "For The Most Distinguished Contribution to American Literature for Children." This book is not likely to blow the socks off an experienced vet of the best English literature has to offer. So don't start the book expecting to find a realistic portrayal of a dystopian society along the lines of some of the science fiction greats. Instead, expect to find a touching story of a young boy as he enters his place in society, only to uncover all the deception surrounding what he has been told as gospel. Jonas's coming-of-age ritual is to stand in front of his community with the rest of the twelve-year-olds and take his adult role. But something strange and unexpected happens, when normally nothing in his society happens out of the ordinary. Cue movie theme song: "I'm just an ordinary human..." Briefly, Jonas doesn't fit in and he is given a very special honor. One revelation after another eventually leads him to the conclusion that he can't fit into this monstrous society and he leaves, against all odds, to go "Elsewhere". Of particular disappointment to maintaining a cohesive plot is that, with 40 pages left in a 180-page book, they start killing babies. Correction. Not just anyone starts killing babies, the main character's father kills babies. He takes a newborn, fresh out of the womb, weighs it, and then kills it in cold blood, stabbing it in the head with a needle and crooning to it like some sociopath. Next up for execution: the very baby boy the family has grown attached to because it lives at their house. Yes, the book has to end somehow. So, WITH LESS THAN 20 PAGES LEFT, Jonas impulsively scraps whatever plans he had to graciously leave the community and sets out ill-prepared into the wider world to face whatever adversity lurks in God's natural world, away from climate control and Sameness. And let me tell you, the finale may hold up for the limitless imagination of a young teenager, but following any reread or the rational mind of an adult, and the illogical twists and turns necessary to achieve the required affect only serves to highlight how the author has done this to a substantially lesser degree throughout the story. There are a number of fallacies and mathematical impossibilities in the text and they probably won't be noticed by most readers because the author leads you right past them. I don't think pointing out these flaws does much to critique the story besides discrediting the author's opinion by hoping to show carelessness in the writing. Unfortunately, Keely's dissertation on the twisted political undertones of this fictional children's story and some other criticisms I've read have taken hold of me. I've been forced to reevaluate this old favorite of mine from when I understood that the author may have an agenda after all, even if it flies over most kid's awareness. The book is about social control and social freedoms, how society only gives one perspective (the mainstream) to the next generation so they can perpetuate the same morality over and over and over into the future. But nobody's presenting the real truths in their arguments. Even parents tell "white lies" to prevent themselves from contradicting themselves. It's about atheism and socialism and abortion and what happens when man plays God with his world. With a mature perspective now, I assert my wish that the author had shown more restraint in the anti-abortion symbolism and message of the finale. Jonas plays the role of mother as he nurtures the child and puts its needs ahead of his own. He is determined to keep the baby even though his parents tell him he's just acting out of emotion, while they have determined it is unrealistic. He runs away from home, trusting in faith to get him through and the memories to help him. A good old-fashioned miracle caps it all off. But I saw none of this the first two times I read the book. Younger readers will enjoy the clear, consistent writing style and the creative names and memorable expressions: "We accept your apology" and "Thank you for your childhood" and "Back and back and back". Lowry makes the big, bad world seem like an overwrought school system, with its rules and social inclusion/exclusion. Lowry captures the pleasures and horrors of life in memorable, vivid detail, all transmitted through the caring hands of an old man. And schoolchildren may rethink the war games they play on the playground. The book is about culture and society, so, even though the writing is easy to read, expect sparse description surrounding most characters. It's about troubling situations and new experiences, emotional reactions and bonds. There is just enough there to tell the story, and not really even enough words there to tell the ending. I don't think anyone will have trouble envisioning the uniform social conditioning reminiscent of 1950's America and the outlying factories and farms similar to Soviet Russia. But wait a second! No one has books in their houses but the Giver has a video screen and Jonas thinks it's completely normal. I laugh. I do.

OMG! I loved it. The stuff with Harry's dad being an animangus, and his friends too... Sirius Black & Peter Petigrin being animals too just to help their warewolf friend ! Awesome. Also the time turner, and time stuff  was soooo fun to read. I enjoyed the crap out of this book.

Another five star read from R.L.Stine. "Goosebumps" is great, like short, sweet creepypastas, who can also be funny, but still disturbing. Here a girl witnessed her father eating food for plants, a boy was grabbed by animal plants and they both so human tomatoes  - it sounds absurd, but eerie as well. Loved it. Review in Bulgarian here: http://citadelata.com/%D1%81%D1%82%D0...

This was a pretty good one. I really liked Aunt Josephine and her interest in the English language. The story focused on the three Baudelaire children, of course, but it had a lot of things to say about grammar as well, which isn't the most interesting subject, but this book incorporated it into the story in such a cleer way that it was actually interesting, what with its hidden messages etc. I really liked that, and I picked up a few things myself. I find it kind of odd, that Violet is now two years older, but Sunny is still speaking in baby language. Shouldn't he have learned it by now? :P I do hope that we won't meet Count Olaf in disguise  in the next book, since it's getting rather repetitive.

This is a story about George, who knows she's a girl, and she wants to play the part of Charlotte in the school play Charlotte's Web. I expected it to end when the school play was over but it continued and some really feel good things happened! The mom is going to work on accepting her and she got to go to the zoo dressed completely as a girl. It was really great to read how happy it made her. This book is a junior novel but will make a good quick read for older readers. This book gets a tad emotional but has a really great ending. ~Ashley

3.5 stars. But only because I think that the story line is odd, and that the adult characters don't see what's right in front of their faces. And also the fact that a 40-something-year old man tried to marry a 14-year-old girl.

For me, this book was a 3 star. But as a grown adult reading a middle grade novel, I think the middle grade me would have loved this. I love this world that Liesl Shurtliff has built. I read Rump and it is still my favorite so far this year (out of 20 others... I know it's January early to say fav...but I've read a lot). I was so curious when I started reading to figure out how Rump's world fit into this one and I LOVED it. The way the Giants are the people of Rump's world and they are in famine, which we know from the last book, but this book explains why. The idea that there are giants living up in the sky and stealing people/food/animals is crazy but it actually works really well in this story. Some of the old characters are back- Opal, King Barf,their son who I can't remember his name at all Archie? possibly, Martha, the pixies... I wanted more Rump and Red though! I'm pretty excited for the next book. I'm not a fan of Jack and the Beanstalk at all, it's probably one of my least favorite fairy tales. My son however is obsessed and loves to tell his own stories about giants and beanstalks, so I've heard quite a few different versions lol. I'll definitely share this with him when he is older.

This came to my attention when it got mentioned in a group I'm in, and it looked like something I might like. Unfortunately, it didn't quite work for me. It starts by introducing us - at length - to the four main characters and their fears. First we see them individually, and then as they start to come together. But this extended intro doesn't really add anything new, it's just the same sort of introductions to their phobia-induced quirks over and over again. We finally get to the school and meet the quirky headmistress, who calls the kids contestants and treats everything like a beauty pageant. Yeah - quirky is all well and good, but you need more than that to move a story along. For the first, heck, 75% of the book nothing much happens, the characters were more annoying than sympathetic, and Wellington is pretty much a bully. I was tempted to DNF it a couple of times, to be honest, and probably would've if I were not such a completionist. Plus I figured I could push through since it's at least short. Anyway - it did pick up towards the end and was actually marginally interesting, but it was also pretty obvious that the whole thing was manufactured to get the kids to face their fears. But, still, things finally moved along, predictable or not, and the lat quarter was probably 2.5 level. But while some things are learned, we're also told that facing your fears is a continuous process - and so the groundwork for the following books in the, I believe, trilogy is laid. I'm not sure I'll be continuing with it, though. ETA: The illustrations go well with the book, in that they are equally lackluster. (Ouch.)

I don't quite know how to classify this children's book. It isn't exactly suspense or horror, but somewhere in between. It is very dark, so I wouldn't really recommend it in spite of Sylvia Cassedy's many awards. The heroine becomes entangled in these dolls lives. The dolls actually come to life in the story, but later, when the heroine "breaks the spell," the dolls do not come to life anymore. The heroine has such a horrible living situation, with two nasty aunts and a rather befuddled uncle which helps to make the book even darker. The heroine, herself, is also not necessarily anyone you'd like to know at least throughout most of the book. She doesn't get along with any of her classmates and virtually has no friends except her imaginary "Backwoods Girls" and the dolls.

I read this book to help write questions for my local library's preparation for something called Battle of the Books. I would not have picked it up otherwise, because I can tell a "sure to trigger certain insecurities" book when I see one, and a book where the main character thinks about how embarrassing her autistic brother is for like half the book definitely falls in that category. Gets two stars only because it was written well enough to delay the "wow everyone who has ever had to deal with me on a daily basis definitely hates me" thoughts for like a day. It's now been more than a day and they are sure here now. Don't give this book to disabled kids. Just don't. They probably don't want to read about how embarrassing they may or not be perceived as.

I'm giving this book 4 stars because why the heck not? It's a good story with interesting characters and a unique writing style. Everything about it is fun. I don't quite get how their mom could have been mistaken for the Sultan, though.

I thought, going in, that I was going to love this one. The prologue was perfect, all about how violence and gore are necessary and right in fairy tales. So true! "You see, the land of Grimm can be a harrowing place. But it is worth exploring. For, in life, it is in the darkest zones one finds the brightest beauty and the most luminous wisdom. And, of course, the most blood." So I was sad that the author actually did pull his punches quite a bit. For instance, after the evil wizard rips the soul-doves out of the young girls' throats (great scene there! )and cooks and eats the bodies, the girls are miraculously returned to life when the wizard is killed. How, exactly does that happen, when the bodies are consumed? Where would the soul-doves go? Stuff like this bothers me. Liked it, but probably not enough to read others in the series.

The moral of the story is very familiar, i.e. A spoiled-brat kid learns that she can't always have her own way, and that kicking and screaming to get your own way isn't nice. The story itself, however, is quite creative. Lulu wants a brontosaurus for a pet. (For those of you who know that Brontosaurus is not an official dinosaur name anymore, that is covered in the story.) And... (spoiler from the middle of the book)when she finally meets a brontosaurus, turns out he wants HER for a pet. The beginning is a little annoying, because we are establishing that Lulu is a royal pain in the you-know-what. The ending, however, is one of the most fun and clever endings I've ever seen in a children's chapter book.

Again, this book was close to five stars. There were so many times that I was blown away by nostalgia that it was almost ridiculous. The whole time I was reading, I was trying to remember the plot to the movie, so I could guess what was going to happen next (and what was created just for the movie, which was actually quite a bit as it turns out, since they rearranged the plot to mix everything together in the movie and to keep it all in Oz, instead of this new country of Ev). I loved Ev. I love the Wheelers. Tik-Tok is my favourite thing, and Bill(ina, I guess, but that's one of the reasons I couldn't bring myself to give the full five stars--the other being that somehow Dorothy knew that the Tin Woodman's name was Nick Chopper, even though it wasn't even mentioned until the second book, which Dorothy wasn't even in, so how did she know that was his name?!?). The Nome kingdom was something I'm hoping to explore more in future books, and while I like Ozma, I still just really miss Tip  --because even though they're the exact same person, they don't seem anything alike at all, and I thought that was annoying, since Tip was pretty much just awesome. I'm hoping we see the characters of Ev again in the future books, otherwise there were so many characters that were fun, that might be wasted. The princess was definitely different in the book than in the movie (and I think she had a different name, so she might be a mix of two characters in the movie) and I'd like to see more of her. Would I recommend it? Yes. Books two and three are way better than book one, in my opinion, and deserve to be read, though I don't think a lot of people bother to continue on passed the first one. Will I be continuing? You bet I will be!

Here is the ugly truth: this series rocks. At a time in my life where I feel beat down by political rhetoric, Greg Heffley's diaries remind me that I've got a lot to be thankful for. I'm thankful a muddy hand doesn't attack me in my sleep. I'm thankful I'm not a kid walking through the locker room of a public pool, forced to see things banned by the FCC. I'm thankful my brother's pirhana didn't eat my angel fish. I'm thankful my best friend didn't... wait a minute, Greg's definitely a jerk to his best friend and deserves whatever he gets... I'm thankful I don't owe anybody $83 for fruit smoothies. I just need to take a deep breath and relax. Now, if I could only get my hands on the next one of these.

3.5 stars. This is one of those children's books that I wish I could have read as a child instead of an adult. I saw the movie when I was a child, though, and I liked it. While reading the book, I was kind of surprised that it got into the plot right away, same as the movie. We weren't introduced that well to Uncle Henry and Aunt Em, but I wish we were so that we could understand better why Dorothy wants to go back to Kansas right away instead of exploring this whole new world that she was thrown into. There were some parts of the book that I found childish, and there are other parts that I found gory such as  the Tin Man's fight with the forty wolves. I found that really brutal. Those poor wolves! And there were forty crows after that. What a waste of birds. I found the Wicked Witch's death way too quick. There was no build up to it, but, oh well. At least it's better than having a house fall on her. I think Oz is a jerk and Dorothy and her friends are extremely gullible or way too forgiving for thinking he's a "good man but a bad wizard". I mean, Oz was fine with Dorothy's group getting either enslaved or killed by the Wicked Witch of the West. That is not what a good man would be fine with. All in all, I'm glad I finally read the book, but I still say I would have enjoyed it more as a child.

I was a little surprised by this book. Based on the synopsis and reviews I read, I expected to love the story, but upon finishing, I find it stuck firmly in the "okay" section. Basically, this is "Labyrinth" for young readers, minus David Bowie and his never ending supply of too-tight pants. Girl gets mad at younger brother. Evil creatures from Below/Underground steal brother/soul. Girl follows and spends most of the story meeting strange creatures, learning life lessons and making friends one of whom turns out to be a cowardly traitor, a la Hoggle . Girl also makes liberal use of the phrase "It's not fair," but eventually passes all tests set before her, saves her brother's soul and discovers there's no place like home. Normally, I would love the dark, weird world of Below, but the book never drew me in. I never cared much about what happened to the protagonist and never worried about her or her brother. Maybe knowing where things were headed dampened its effect. Whatever the reason, I would still recommend this book to readers looking for a little creepy in their reading diets.

The text and illustrations in this Little Red Riding Hood retelling are stripped down to their bare minimum, and thus words and pictures collaborate in telling the story instead of repeating each other -- very well done! This picturebook also takes a full advantage of the page layouts, dramatic page turns and close-ups. However, I am not a fan of this particular drawing style, and the retelling itself, although entertaining and empowering, is not that original Roald Dahl's "Little Red Riding Hood and the Wolf" from Revolting Rhymes, anyone? .

"Would you like to continue our walk into the deep, dark woods?" A dapper, fox in a Victorian suit meets a peasant-duck on the street. His eyes light up. He invites her to take a walk with him. The sweet duck blushingly accepts. On every page, the story gets more intense as the fox has another suggestion leading closer and closer to the end children know is coming. After every question: "Would you care to boil some water for soup?" And the duck's innocent answer "Certainly. I do love soup!" A Greek chorus of little ducklings appears and warns threateningly:  "That is NOT a good idea!" The tension and anxiety builds and builds until finally  The duck, in a shocking twist, agrees with the fox when he suggests there is a 'key ingredient' missing to the soup. "Oh, a key ingredient IS missing." she flirtatiously concurs. And on the next page, she's screaming "YOU!" as she pushes the fox into the huge boiling soup pot and slams the lid down. The book ends with her and her six little ducklings enjoying their second and third helpings of fox soup. BOOYAH! Children are delighted to no end with this book, it is a certain 5-year-old's favorite - she can even read the whole thing to me all by herself although she sometimes struggles with the word "ingredient" and the fox's wording of things. For instance, he says, "Would you care to go for a stroll?" And the 5-year-old always seems to think it should be "Would you like to go for a stroll?" But she's getting better with every reading, of course. All children are delighted to see this book presented, ESPECIALLY if they think the grown-up reading it to them has never read this book before and doesn't know about the awesome ending. You can see them getting more and more excited as they read it to you, constantly checking your face for reactions and enjoying your anxiety and dismay that the duck is going to be murdered by this charming fox. Then they shriek and exclaim with glee when you get to the end. This book is like the Under the Skin of picture books. The "innocent female" who is "obviously" going to die (or in Faber's case, get raped) by evil, opportunistic men - is actually the predator and the one whom the "usual suspect-type predators" should avoid and fear. The book also has a kind of "silent film" theme that children won't pick up on but adults will appreciate, in which a picture is shown and then on the opposite page, a black "screen" appears with the dialogue the characters in the picture are supposed to be saying. As always with Mo Willems, a fun, engaging, riotous read that children will not only be very interested in, but will want to read again and again. Highly recommended.

Mo LoBeau is a rising sixth-grader in the tiny town of Tupelo Landing, North Carolina. She's a slick talking girl whose best friend is a boy named Dale Earnhardt Johnson III. Mo lives with adoptive parents: Miss Lana, a wig-wearing eccentric cafe owner, and the Colonel, a man with no memory of his past who calls Mo "soldier" (affectionately) and hates lawyers. Mo and Dale decide to become detectives when a local man is murdered and the only suspects seem to be Dale and the Colonel. Sheila Turnage's first middle grade novel is exciting, funny, suspenseful, and full of super loveable characters. I can only talk about the flaws in the books by mentioning spoilers, so I won't. Actually, I will here: If Miss Lana knew the Colonel's past all along, why didn't she tell him? Twelve years is a long, long time to keep that kind of thing to yourself. A few notes for future reference: Dale's father is an abusive drunk. Pretty heavy topic for an otherwise mostly lighthearted book. Actually, what's lighthearted about trying to find a murderer? I guess the best way to describe the tone of the book would be heightened realism. There's no magic or anything, but could a baby really wash up in a hurricane? Is any kid as clever and silver tongued as Mo? Would a sheriff (or any grown-up) really let kids get involved in a murder investigation? Mo is always writing her to "upstream" mother AKA her biological mother who either abandoned her or lost her. Part of Mo's journey is accepting that she has loving adoptive parents and she doesn't always need to be searching for her "real" family. Mo's super crush on Dale's older brother Lavender is completely adorable. She's sure she's going to marry Lavender and he is completely crush worthy. I absolutely adore a quirky and memorable narrator, which Mo totally is. Her voice, which is funny, clever, spunky and full of Southern charm, will stay with me. Read-alike authors (funny, clever, quirky): Frank Cottrell Boyce, Ellen Potter, Jack Gantos, Polly Horvath I loved Mo's voice so much, I went out and got the audiobook, which was fantastic.

Quick, enjoyable read about a gorilla who has lived in a cage in a mall for most of his life and how he deals with that and with his animal friends who live with him. I enjoyed getting to see the story from Ivan's point of view and the simple but compelling sentences made it easy to get sucked into the story. I loved the differentiation in the way Ivan as a gorilla remembered and in the way Stella, his elephant friend, remembered. It dealt with the important concept of animal abuse and neglect in a interesting, emotionally compelling way without it being too overwhelming for younger audiences. And I loved that the appearance of the baby elephant Ruby finally stirred him to action. Definitely one I'd recommend for juvenile fiction readers and animal lovers in general. Could be a Newbery contender as well, we'll see! Edit: I have to admit that the more I read of children's lit from the past year though, the less excited I am about this one. I think just because it's so simple. I could see it being one that kids really like, it's just missing something for me compared to Wonder and See You at Harry's.

Quite enjoyed this one, glad I got to learn more about Marco's family. LOOOOOOVE Ax soooo much. He's amazing. I want him to go home but at the same time I never want him to leave. I literally gasped when I found out Marco's mom was Visser One.. I hope he saves her and gets her home safe .

Hiccup III, as a Viking boy on Berk island, precedes these memoirs with scratchy heads of cast, list of chapter titles. Hoorah, previews, entertains, sums up. The Greatest Day of Your Life (not)....27 .. 5. Something Nasty in the Cauldron ....102". More drawings sprinkle throughout. Ink blotches, splotches; letters tip around. Arch-villain Alvin the Treacherous is back, stronger, swift at swordplay, shiny metal nose instead of wood. His mother, Witch Excellinor, plots for her son to rule the tribes. Ch "22. Red Rage" sends dragons in angry fury against former friends, even Hiccup's tiny Toothless. Witch claims her prophecy is from Grimbeard, "only a King can save you now" p 114. Hiccup owns his ancestor's "the King's Lost Things. A fang-free dragon, my second-best sword, My Roman shield" and other important stuff. I dislike oracles; the plot turns out the same anyway. Witch forces Hiccup to reveal Slave mark burned on forehead, usually covered by helmet. This negates his and his father Stoick's right to rule. He hands over King's stuff, even Dragon's Jewel. He and pals Fishlegs and Camicazi endured much to retrieve Dragon's Jewel from ancient Wodensfang that "has the power to destroy dragons" p 226. Snotlout is chief of the Hooligans. Hiccup in disgrace, his intent to free dragons kaput. Dragons are angry. "The Rebellion has begun" p 370 faced by long vicious claws dragging downward. Screech. I don't know how, but this series has everything: Furious Action, Scary Evil, Tense Sneaking Around, Silly Fun. Tenterhooks until the next book.

Having been a huge fan of A Series of Unfortunate Events (seriously; I even did a re-read and re-blog event on my tumblr), I finally decided I had to get my hands on the first book in his latest series, "All The Wrong Questions," which focuses on Lemony Snicket's childhood/induction into a mysterious organization that ASOUE readers will know is VFD . It's set to be a four book series and the first is Who Could That Be at This Hour? We meet young Snicket is mysterious circumstances, of course, as he's meeting up with the woman he's to apprentice after graduation. It's obvious Snicket hasn't had the traditional education, because he's "almost thirteen" when he graduates and goes with his chaperone to a seaside town that's no longer by the seaside to retrieve a stolen item that probably wasn't stolen. He meets some strange characters here, including a girl with a missing father and a young reporter without a newspaper. Discussing the plot of this would be pointless because honestly, you just have to read it and find out for yourself. But I will say that although this is obviously different from ASOUE (different characters, mysteries, etc.) and Snicket has said it's sort of noir for middle grade, there's still the trademark Snicket characteristics here. Word definitions, odd segues, things that are never quite what they seem. I definitely recommend this book if you're a Snicket fan or like odd little books, but readers not acquainted with Snicket's style (or who didn't enjoy ASOUE) might be disappointed and/or confused by this one.

A cute tale about growing up and being a good person. The style of the narrator and especially his inclusion of teen slang was a little annoying though. In this story, Prince a Caspian sets out to find the seven lords and the end of the world. Although he finds the seven lords and a bride it is a mouse (reepicheep) and Lucy, Edmund and Eustace who journey to the end of the world. Upon reaching it Aslan informs them it will be their last visit.

I could NOT put this down; I'm still thinking about this and trying to figure it out and twirling it around in my head. What would I have done if I were Jinny? Would I have made the same choices? Was she really being selfish and just choosing herself? I LOVE how much she loved Ess, but sometimes truly loving someone is making tough choices when it comes to that person. Maybe Jinny just didn't have the emotional maturity to make those choices? And did Jinny REALLY break the island or was it all one, big, massive coincidence? Obviously, Jinny bleeding is her getting her period for the first time, but everything else? What could all that be!? At first the characters were a blur--there's nine orphans so it took me a few chapters to sort them out--but they quickly became distinct, though some of them don't have much page time. The island is almost a character in itself, and the previous owner of all the books, Abigail, has a distinct voice that becomes clearer throughout. I really want to know more; I want a prequel and a sequel. No, strike that and change it to NEED a prequel and a sequel!

Humans waste words. They toss them like banana peels and leave them to rot. This book ruined me just a little bit. The great thing about children's books is that the authors focus on the characters and story more than trying to write beautifully and complexly, and as a result the simple reading level doesn't even matter. In this case, the story was told from the point of view of a gorilla named Ivan, so the easy language is actually beautiful. Adults and 12-year-olds could relate to him to the same degree because he isn't human, but sometimes reminds you of one. Ivan is based off of a real gorilla who was captured as a baby and who lived in a circus for 27 years away from other gorillas before  being transferred to a zoo  . The innocence of animal voices in any books from their perspective makes me sad. Reading something from the point of view of a gorilla who doesn't mind captivity so much but still has a sense of something greater out there just makes me cry. If you ever feel like taking a break from epic fantasy or contemporary romance, or whatever genre you're ploughing through, try this. This got me out of a reading rut.

It's a fun retelling - young girls will like the feisty nature of the heroine and identify with 12 year old Rapunzel's woes, but it feels cobbled together. Prince Benjamin's story feels even more so (though he seems like a nice kid, for a prince). Likely this is not going to bother a 12 year old reader the way it bothered me, so (unless you want to read spoilers) we'll leave it at: fun story, feisty heroine, nice prince, cute pet cat. While she kicks herself for not having thought of it (and so she should) ... you didn't think of your hair...really? You solved those other mysteries with no probs, Goldie! Why the blonde moment now? Two humans just climbed it! You could have gone either direction - chop it off and climb down it, or tie it and climb down it and chop it off at the bottom. But no, send the prince home to steal silk from his mother to make a rope. She's going to love you. I can tell. Fight a troll with tomatoes? Well, to be fair, this is the kind of goony theory a 12 year old might fall for... I want to see giant scary thorn bushes that you can throw a cloak over and then slide down from the top. Slide! What's that cloak made of? Magic tarp? Ouch! So, we skip forward to the party at the end: the prince is still engaged to a girl from another kingdom, I take it - I mean, why wouldn't he be. Are his parents going to let him marry this - while pretty - peasant he just rescued? At 12 years old? No, young man, I think not. Your little friend seems like a sweet girl, but she must go home to her hovel. I DID like the moment where the prince considers the man giving up his dream (of making glasses, though? wait...) to work to support his family. There are a couple other good observations like this along the way. I really liked Beauty and the Beast, so I think I'll move on to the other Wendy Mass books girls have recommended to me, instead of committing to reading every one.

It takes an animal to show you what animals human beings can be. Perhaps the worst trait in this book is to be human, the exception of course being Thornton. The book deals with the idea of taming the wild and is told from a dog's perspective. This perspective is Buck, a cross between a St.Bernard and a Scotch Shepherd - a leader amongst dogs. Buck had always been a tameable creature, and when the deceitful employee of his owner steals him and sells him off, Buck starts to go wild. From sunny California, Buck becomes an Alaskan sled dog. The majority of the book deals with Buck becoming wilder and wilder. He is taking in the far north, mostly on postal routes around Yukon. It isn't until Thornton (a man who saves him from his cruel owners) takes him in that Buck learns true love. When Thornton his friends and Buck go off east of Klondike in search of gold buck starts to hear the call of the wild. It isn't long before Buck turns completely wild and goes off for days from his master on wild adventures. But the love for his master always brings him back. One fateful day when Buck returns from one of his wild adventures he discovers that his master has been killed by Indians, it is then that he becomes a free wild animal. The bond between human and man forever broken. Buck then becomes accepted by a pack of wolves as their leader. He lives a prosperous life and continues to terrorise the Indians. The question then to ask is does Buck stand for anything more than our oppressive hold on animals? I think not. But, there could be some underlying connections there with post-colonialism and the taming of the wild and the 'savages' who inhabit such places. However, for me, the book told me more a story of how we, as humans, try to tame what can never actually be tamed, and it is only through love that we win the favour of any animal.

Hokey Pokey: a dreamscape populated entirely by children, from diaper-clad Newbies to Big Kids. A place where the sun always shines, and herds of wild bicycles roam the plains. A place where a giant screen plays classic cartoons all day long. A place where children drop off to sleep while their monsters gleam above them. A place where boys and girls are divided into separate camps, as unknowable to each other as different species. A place with train tracks but no train and an island with a hut that no one can enter. Hokey Pokey is all Jack has ever known, roaming with his Amigos on their bicycles, playing catch with little Kiki, endlessly battling the girl named Jubilee. But something is changing. He is not himself. And he is not sure what that means. I have mixed feelings about this book. The writing is beautiful, smooth and dreamy. Hokey Pokey is clearly a magical place, separate from the real world, but it has an internal consistency. Well, mostly. The trouble comes when that consistency breaks down. It's even more confusing in the final chapters, when the reader sees Jack in "the real world". We see Kiki, Lopez, and Jubilee, too. When I closed the book, I was just left with questions with no satisfying answers, like: Why does Jubilee have a brother in Hokey Pokey when no one else does? How is it that none of the kids have never noticed anyone else leaving? Since the catcher's mitt is evidently real, does that mean Jack's bike was also really stolen by Jubilee? What, exactly, was the point of this book? I'm left wondering what the point of the book was because very little happens. While this is clearly a book about childhood - with the feel of an elegy for a type of childhood that no longer exists in this digital age - it does not really seem like a book for children. Which leaves me in that uncomfortable spot of appreciating the craft that went into the book, but unsure who the intended audience is.

What can I say without just sounding horrible? I have stewed and scorched over these books. They have made me so infuriated that I can not even think straight, but as a request from my son I have read this far. I have now also deducted that my son's pessimistic behavior is an imitation of what he's read. We will be having a lengthy discussion about this particular book the first chance we get. This has made my heart hurt that a child can be this mean spirited, and not feel any remorse or guilt by serious situations in this book that he himself causes. The main character is really a manipulative bully, and tries to swindle his friend, calls the cops on his dad, and to top it all off he insults a pregnant woman at the pool(very loudly! )[image error] I think I better stop now before, I really get set on a rip roaring rant about this series!
How can such simple lines actually get me choked up? Favorite lines: "Knocking with mittens quiet" "Forgotten line quiet" "Luminaria quiet"

Those ravenous bunnies won't quit multiplying and eating up the whole goat field! It gets pretty dicey there for a minute when the bunnies think the princess is food because she can't talk back to them; but fortunately her horse can speak the language of cuteness and the day is saved! I especially enjoyed the return of Princess Sneezewort.
This was very fun to read aloud, although my husband thought it was traumatic with the owl stalking its prey and all. It's a well-paced book and very exciting, and in the end, no one gets eaten.

Ward won the Caldecott for the detailed, sepia-toned, drawings that accompany this story. Johnny Orchard lives on a farm at the far end of the valley, near a big woods. Whenever he walks down the road he notices that other barns have bear skins drying on their walls; he's embarrassed that his family's barn doesn't have a bear skin. So he heads into the woods one day, with his rifle, determined to get the biggest bear. What he finds, though is an orphaned bear cub, which he befriends with a piece of maple sugar candy. But when he brings the cub home, problems begin; and they only get worse when the bear grows B*I*G. I think children might be intrigued by the adventure of the story, but I hope they wouldn't feel encouraged to try to tame a wild animal. I was also somewhat dismayed by a scene where Johnny has to take his bear to the woods to kill it because it has become a nuisance. Don't worry, he doesn't ever actually do this, but he has every intention of doing so,   and I find that disturbing in a children's book. The illustrations are wonderfully detailed. I kept looking at them, absorbing the farmhouse, barnyard, woods, etc. If I were rating the illustrations alone, I'd give the book 4****.

I wanted to go pick up a camera after reading this one. I'm glad that Lucy didn't win the contest. That would have been too easy. The characters were solid and well drawn, the setting well established. This book wasn't amazing or sparkling, but it was quietly, solidly well built.

Okay, yeah. The books that teachers assign for homework suck. (I mean, most of the ones that I've been assigned.) Most of them are boring. They also include homework and they also come with that very strictly-graded essay that you have to write and type once you finish the book (so even when you've closed the book...THE TORTURE IS NOT OVER YET!). You have to read the freaking thing EVERY. SINGLE. NIGHT. And it's torture. (What do you expect from homework.) And yes, this book was assigned to us in my 7th grade reading class. And I thought it was going to be boring to read.....BUT I LOVED IT. And so did the rest of the class. This was about 3 years ago. I've been through English classes and quite a few classic homework-assigned books already. I've heard my class's opinions. "This is so boring." "There's a lot of homework for this." "I had to read over the last chapter because I didn't understand it." "When are we going to move on to another book?" I remember when my (very weird and crazy) reading teacher introduced this book to us. I probably didn't think it was all that exciting when I saw it. He said, "Oooooh, see the really creepy looking cover with that really creepy and depressed looking dude's face creeping out of a tree?" Sure, the cover was pretty creepy, but after the first few chapters, the comments that this book got were: "This is a pretty good book!" "This is interesting." "Can we read Among the Hidden today?" "Are we reading the next book?" "Is our next book going to be as good as Among the Hidden?" This is by far my FAVORITE BOOK that I've ever had to read in my English/Reading classes. I. LOVED. THIS. BOOK. It made me love my homework for once. (And like any other sane child, I did not like homework at all.) I ended up going to the library and checking this book out and finishing the book a couple of weeks early before the essay we had to write was due. IT WAS JUST SO AWESOME. I haven't read this book in 3 years, but I remember it! It was about Luke (forgot his last time) who lived in a world where no family was allowed more than 2 children. And Luke was the third child. So he was hidden, and he wasn't allowed to go outside, and he couldn't do any of the things that his two older brothers did. Actually, in World Geography in 8th grade, we learned that China is a little bit like this. Except families are only allowed ONE child (because the population is so huge and there's not enough room or food for all those people). Most of the people wanted boys because when the boy grew up and got married, he'd be able to continue the family name. When GIRLS got married, they'd have to leave the family and change their name, and their family's name would forever cease to exist. So everyone wanted a son. Daughters would be given to orphanages and stuff. BUT GIRLS ARE SO MUCH MORE AWESOMER THAN GUYS. (Yeah, just a.....fun fact.) Anyway, he meets Jen, another third child that had moved into one of the new houses that were built near theirs. And Jen was teaming up with a bunch of other hidden children to fight against the government. This book includes suspense. That's just why I loved this book. SUSPENSEFUL SUSPENSE! That's what kept me reading! I didn't want to have to wait for reading class to read this book! The big spoiler is this book has a sad ending . I never got a chance to read the second installment of this series but I really should! Anyway, if you're looking for dystopian suspense that's easy to read and is so good that you'd even be willing to have this book for Reading Class homework, I really think you should consider THIS BOOK!
Absolutely adorable! My only complaint is that  Claire should have been made a pirate as well, in the end! Boo! x-(

An enjoyable read, but I think I missed the essence that effect so many people who read this book. The world building was excellent, and I could understand and imagine the hows and whys for most of the story. A few things didn't add up for me  such as why/how they can't see colours, how they climate control everything despite Jonas being able to travel outside and encounter things such as hills and weather again, or how the memories are given/received  . I also found the characters quite flat, which makes sense in relation to the world, and helps add a feeling of creepiness and something being amiss. The end also frustrated me, I assume we are supposed to imagine what the actual ending is, and it seems as though Jonas has probably died in a happy memory, and it is all a big metaphor for being free and happy than safe but unfeeling, but I still felt a little cheated, I wanted to know what happened for certain . Jonas was a good enough protagonist, and the story was interesting, and I really enjoyed the ideas bought up in the book, but it just didn't quite work for me, though I think this would have had a bigger effect on me as a younger reader, which of course is the age it is intended for. Well worth a read, I just didn't connect with the characters or their plight enough to become emotionally involved.

These books are so cute and I love them so much. I just, it was taking me a while to read and I love these but I didn't really feel like finishing it. Maybe another time when I can whip through it faster, but I found I wasn't following the plot or really caring about the characters. I love this series and this concept and even the characters, but apparently not enough to finish it. Strange, but I am trying really hard not to judge my reading urges very much for the books that aren't super important to my Very Elitist Literature Education.

This was fantastic! I read it over the course of two very busy days (otherwise it would have been one sitting!) I loved all of the characters and how they grew. Figuring out which characters were what was pretty fun as well. The Russian folklore that was included was quite enchanting. The only reason that this is 4 stars is because I wasn't crazy about the ending. This was such a great Baba Yaga retelling. Those are hard to find.

I would have liked a bit more plot and a longer story, but still a good read. I thought it was kind of sad that Harold's relationship with new friend Bunnicula bloomed at the expense of his relationship with his old friend, Chester. It seemed like Harold went along a lot with Chester and then broke with Chester all of a sudden. Maybe if he'd been stronger-willed, to match Chester, he could have talked Chester out of his scheming and saved their relationship in the process .
A bit of a recon mission goes haywire. and Jake becomes a Controller!

The illustrations and message were glorious and on-point. I loved the retro feel to the pictures, the rich colors, and the added details they gave to the story. The message of the story also couldn't have been more perfect: I think I stopped reading and clapped my hands when I got to the point where Interstellar Cinderella  REJECTED the offer of marriage in favor of being the Prince's Chief Mechanic. Seriously. My only hang-up was the slightly forced rhyming that skipped over some seemingly important bits of story. Every so often I'd flip the page back feeling like I'd missed something. Otherwise I'm a fan.

I really enjoyed the part where Violet and Klaus switched roles and Violet did the researching and Klaus did the inventing . However the series is getting extremely repetitive and I'm sort of hoping things will change around a bit as the series goes on but I have a feeling it won't. It might be bugging me a bit though considering I've read all four of the first books last night/today...

I really enjoyed this book and its non-formulaic ending. The entire book the main character, Arthur, is caught in the "doldrums" as his parents won't let him out of the house because of grandparents who were adventurers lost in Antarctica. He speaks (and hears back!) from the taxidermic animals that live in his house. Arthur seeks adventure with his new found friend next door and eventually they meet a girl with one leg who moves from Paris to his boarding school in London. I really loved at the end how he found that solving his problems of having the doldrums was better solved by making friends than having to go on some crazy adventure. I also enjoyed how Oliver's worry about undertaking the adventure reflected the reality that British children would not be journeying to Antarctica on their own.

I got an ARC of this book from Book Expo America. This is a companion book to Wonder, and it's really three short stories/novellas from the perspective of different characters in the book. The first is Julian's Chapter, and I was really hesitant about this because it felt like it could go horribly wrong to do a "from the bully's perspective" sort of thing. It could just be too cheesy to show that the bully was abused or something and that's why he picked on kids, etc. But it wasn't like that. Yes, in some ways the story "redeems" Julian, but it really felt like more of a realistic perspective. He's always had horrible nightmares about deformed people/monsters. And his mother does what she does because she can't stand to see her child hurting. It doesn't make either of them right, but it does explain some things. And in the end Julian does come around. The next story was Pluto, and it's from Christopher's perspective - the boy who August had been friends with growing up. This was probably my least favorite of the three stories, but it was still good. Christopher got on my nerves a bit because he's clearly entering that annoying pre-teen phase - doing things like calling his mother by her first name and just being generally rude. The ending felt a bit cliche, but all in all it was a fine read. The final story, Shingaing, was probably my favorite. It's from Charlotte's point of view, whom we see briefly in Wonder. She has plenty to deal with outside of August. It's nothing super crazy, but shows a lot of the typical middle school drama. It's very well written and realistic - at least realistic to my own middle school years 15 years ago. I remember that girl drama all too well, and Palacio captures it here. While the story itself wasn't wildly special, I thought Charlotte was a really cool character and that's what made me enjoy it so much. In some ways she's a typical middle school girl, but in others she's different - she's nice to (almost) everyone, hard working and dedicated, and into musicals and dancing. All in all I thought these were really enjoyable stories, and anyone who read and enjoyed Wonder should like these as well.

Have you ever seen a hastily made cash-grab sequel? They are often straight to dvd, have an entirely new cast, and although they seem like a carbon copy of the original characters and plot, they are devoid of the heart and creativity that made the original special. Snowpiercer 2 is that straight to dvd sequel. The story does not pick up where the first one ends, I guess those fictional characters were busy on other projects or where outside the production budget. Instead, the two main characters Proloff and his bald chick are simply referenced with the added bonus of a sound bite that was probably edited together from the first book. The story was confusing, unnecessary, and completely unbelievable. In true Hollywood fashion, there was less substance and more explosions. we don't need logic we have BOOM! The characters followed the same formula, with our bad ass male protagonist and his privileged love interest who is pretty much a non-entity. There are the obligatory baddies who deceive the poor just for the fun of it, The TV host is a puppet? Why? If you were trying to be shocking or clever you failed, it was not at all surprising, just stupid. Why would they go through the trouble of creating a puppet TV host? and rich people who chomp down on caviar while chilling in first class. What really didn't make sense to me was that this story followed a completely different train also known as the Snowpiercer. Snowpiercer 1 didn't know about 2 but they were on the same track for like over a decade? What!? This isn't making any sense! Half of this didn't make sense the other half was too boring to care about it making sense. There might have been something lost in translation but mostly this was just stupid. Overall, this had no redeeming qualities I wish I didn't waste my time.

Another one-shot released in the Locke & Key universe. The grindhouse story is a depression era story of three gangsters stumbling on Keyhouse. It is a brutal tale with some unflinching language and violence. Joe makes you hate the villains immediately. As always in this series, its all about the keys! The reader is always clamoring for new keys, and that is where this story falls short. The "Bitey" Key is used in this story but no explanation is given. I think its only previous appearance is in the drawing Bode did in the "Guide to the Known Keys". No backstory on the key is given. Nor any explanation of how Bode knew about it. All in all a fun story, but it doesn't add a whole lot to the mythos. Also included is the Guide to Keyhouse. Joe in an introduction makes it clear that the detail provided here is all about Gabe. I had no idea so much detail and care had gone into the architecture of the house. This is a fascinating look at the creation of one of the main characters in the series. Check out this one-shot if you can, or wait until IDW combines this with Guide to the Known Keys and other one shots in 2012.

Was not expecting that ending! Just when I thought I wanted the whole thing to be over, the last few pages when by so fast and I found myself wanting more! Tha cliffhanger though... I didn't think Meiko who bite the dust, especially with the news that her father was making a trip to Bitch Planet to build whatever he was going to build   That was a sad pill to swallow. Regardless, I really like DeConnick's work - It was rather slow in the beginning and only seemed to pick up near the end. Some pages had a top tier panel spreading two pages, while others didn't, so I think that was one of the few parts that added to my confusion. And the names...thought I somewhat connected with the prisoners, their names (except Meiko and Penny) haven't stuck, and neither have most of the names of the government workers (except the creepy priest). Final Verdict (7/10): It was a satisfying cliffhanger with lots of development in the last little bit. That's the shining moment of Bitch Planet. Everything else was just...average to me.
Definitely a great amount of movement to the plot, but what really bugs me is [major spoiler]  how do the gods NOT SEE that Ananke is f**king with them!! Inanna is my favourite character. Hands down.

Good conclusion to the main story. These are lots of fun, but they're just too short! I feel like the plot goes too fast and ends up being kind of superficial, even though the concepts are solid. The characters are really great, though, and I really want to spend more time with them! I was right about Alex! Dickhead.

While I love the premise of this series, I don't super love the execution. I'm specifically getting fatigued with the Doctor/Bodyguard/LastMan dynamic as they face wave after wave of bad girls. And why does 355 need the whole conflicted love issues? Can't she just be a tough girl without devolving into an angsty lover? However, I do like that the final chapter in this volume gives us a glimpse into the world of Beth, Yorick's girlfriend off in Australia.

tw: rape Can we talk about how horrible the Governor is????? Ugh. He is horrible! The Governor from the show looks like a decent person now. Also, can I please have some strong women characters?? That would be great.

Story: 4 stars Art: 5 stars Fish Girl is a middle grade graphic novel about a mermaid who is held captive in a boardwalk sideshow by the owner, a former fisherman who impersonates Neptune the King of the Seas to entertain paying audiences. But Fish Girl is the main attraction of the aquarium, and she believes her captor really is Neptune the God. At least at first. But Fish Girl is clever and observant in her search for truth, freedom, and humanity. She has help along the way by an octopus, who has been her loyal companion since she was a baby, as well as a new female human friend and a magical ocean. Spectacular full-color art. While Neptune is a manipulative and creepy adult male who is imprisoning a young girl, the fantasy elements make this story a gentle way to introduce this seedier, tragic aspect of life to middle grade readers. The loving friendship between Fish Girl and Octopus is heartwarming and palpable, despite the fact that neither can speak. I just wish the ending was more conclusive, given the targeted age group and all that Fish Girl has endured. While Fish Girl clearly breaks free of her bondage, where will she go now and how will she survive? Fish Girl walks off with Livia and her mother, but Livia's mother doesn't believe her daughter about seeing a mermaid; will she agree to help Fish Girl with her monumental adjustment to human life that is ahead of her?

Dan Slott has been tearing up the track with Superior Spider-Man since issue 1. Superior Spider-Man: Necessary Evil is the first pit stop this title has taken since the start. Slott, Stegman, and Camuncoli still deliver a first-rate collection with Volume 4, but it is probably my least favorite so far. Spider-Man 2099 makes a guest appearance and has a run in with Spidey. Otto doesn't have the have the advantage of Peter's memories after deleting him from his brain in the last trade, so he doesn't remember meeting future Spidey before. This, of course, leads to dueling wall-crawlers. This is probably the part of the collection I was least impressed with. Personally, just not that interested in 2099 as a character. Watching Otto squirm while dealing with Pete's day to day was still fun though. Spider-Man's next run in is with the Black Cat. Not the typical game of cat and mouse that these two usually play. Man, I would not want to be Peter when he gets his body back. He'll be lucky to get off with a kick in the nuts. And the soap opera doesn't end there. MJ tries to get back in the dating pool, one of Otto's old flames comes looking for a little pay back from our friendly neighbor widow-maker, and Otto continues to get a taste of what it was like for the original when he has some problems at school. Green Goblin, who is calling himself the Goblin King nowadays, continues to resurface from time to time. No doubt preparing for what is going to be a hell of a showdown with Spidey sometime soon. And I gotta admit, I'm interested as to who's wearing Goblin's mask. Is that you under there Normie? The art is as consistent as ever. I missed Ramos, but Stegman and Camuncoli both do impressive jobs. With Slott providing the scripts and a talented line-up of stellar illustrators producing some to the most consistently good pencils in comics, Superior Spider-Man keeps me coming back for more.

Usually, I'd try to find something to compare to this because it's a comic book instead of a novel and it's a modern Marvel instead of a vintage DC--but, honestly, I can't think of anything to compare this one to. Normally, that would be a good thing meaning it's creative and well-written, but it just didn't hit the right tune this time. I was first introduced to both Moonknight and Brian Michael Bendis in Bendis' Ultimate Spiderman Volumes in 2005. It was when "ultimate" was the hit word for Marvel and several of their characters were being rewritten to a modern flavor. It was smooth, engaging story-writing that, sadly, I'm having a hard time finding in comic books currently being written today (Deadpool: Suicide Kings and Batman: Noel are good examples of lazy comic book writing--sorry guys). The flavor of this Moonknight volume is definitely Bendis. The characters are realistic but funny in a dry sense. They aren't overly poetic like Alan Moore and I like that. Nice twist. Last time I saw Moonknight in Spiderman he had a little girl and a violent man as his personalities. That's why I was surprised with the Spiderman, Captain America, and Wolverine personalities :D . However, these characters didn't stick for me. I felt disconnected from them. Yes, this is a comic book not a book-book where we have the freedom of being in the protagonist's head. I'm not stupid, I understand that. Part of it could be that we don't sympathize with Marc Spektor. Because he's friends with his split personalities, he isn't in any danger, so there's nothing to be concerned about. I'm sure if I give it some space and then pick it up again later, I'll like it more the second time around. That's usually how it works with me...I just don't write about it often.

Ugh! So disappointed! What I thought would be a great storyline Buffy's pregnant! Who's the father?! Robin giving Buffy advice on what it's like to be the child of a Slayer! Spike and Buffy growing closer! was undermined by going in a stupid "she-was-a-robot-the-whole-time"  direction. Gah! What a cop-out, writers.

3.5 Stars Fish Girl is beautifully illustrated, the prose is simple, straight-forward which is good for younger readers, and for me, it was okay, a little flat and awkward but it gave enough of a story (still I think the art did most of it for me). In this story, we meet "Fish Girl" (a mermaid) who is later renamed by a new friend to "Mira", whose been living in this aquarium ever since she was "rescued" by "Neptune". In Fish Girl we see the bonds of friendship - with Mira and Octopus and her new human friend, we see Mira discover the truth, and begin to explore the world around her and begin to make her own choices. The ending was a little abrupt (since I don't know what's going to happen with her now, given her circumstances) but I'll just call it an open ending and say they left it up to us to imagine what would happen next. I think more could've been done in terms of the actual story, but the art was lovely and well worth reading just for that. As a side note there are some underlying themes  Abduction, Abuse   that parents may not be comfortable with sharing with their children (I am really not sure what age this book is geared towards). Parents may want to read the book first, just to see if it's something they are okay with them reading (if they would like to read with them) or not.

Dear Fables: welcome back! When the war against the Adversary ended and we caught we first few glimpses of Mr. Dark, I was excited about the new directions Bill Willingham was taking this series. But then the Mr. Dark story dragged and dragged and just... ended, and I admit that I somewhat lost my fate in this series. But suddenly you have "Cubs in Toyland" and everything changes. Ouch. This was a hard one to read! poor Darien... I admit that I never really payed that much attention to the individual cubs, they were always just a unit, even after the last volume where Winter was crowned the new King of the North, but now I'm actually sorry I never took the time to get to know them better, maybe to even re-read vol. 17, so I could get the full effect of the prophecy revealing itself. So Winter is the first child, Therese the third, Darien the fourth and Ambrose probably the seventh, from what we see in that last story. Therese's journey was absolutely creepy (the tale of why the toys were sent to Discardia was especially hard to read, as was Therese's journey into the dark side), but it's Darien's story, the hommage to "The Fisher King" myths that really grabs your attention. Since I had never heard of that myth, I had to google it and then re-read the story to get the full impact, and that's when it really hits you. He was truly the leader of the pack. I can't wait to see what happens next, now that Therese has returned to the Mundy world, all grown up, to reveal the fate of Darien. The next story arch will be all about Snow White, so I'm hoping we'll keep on the right track.

Beautiful art? Check. Likable/lovable + precious characters? Check. (Hagita. Just--yes. xD) Engaging, heartwarming +tearjerking story? CHECK. Read this book! It's definitely worth it. After putting it down (from only reading 1 chapter), I picked it up again, and I literally couldn't stop reading it. The only complaint I have (non-spoiler wise) is that I wish this story was longer! I don't think I'll be ready to part with the characters with only 27 chapters. >~< However, I do think that if a story does not require a lot of chapters for it to be a complete story, then it shouldn't have a lot of chapters. I like how the story tries to encourage you by sending the message that despite how hard you find it, it's best to not leave any regrets, because you can't do things over again. You only get one shot and it's in your best interest to not let that change slip away. You will feel embarrassment. You will get flustered. You will be lost and think: what do I do? What can I do? It really touched me in that sense.

"Someone was screaming, high and terrible... like a cloud passing before the sun... against the bleak grey sky swayed a tall tall prince in black armor with only half a skull." Yes, I admit, the first time I saw the book in the bookstore I screamed in my head 'stop writing these stories and please finish The Winds of Winter!' However, my pain for the original books aside, this is a really good story, I really enjoyed it! And to be fair, this appeared as a novella c.2005, so it's not really a new story. Set about a hundred years before the original series, the story follows Dunk, a hedge knight (a knight without a Lord), and Egg, also known as Aegon - one of the Tagaryen Princes who later ascends the Iron Throne. He's also the Egg that Maester Aemon used to talk about! And I've just realized that he is also Jon's great-great grandfather!
