At least in the books, in the TV Show I think they skipped a generation and he's just Jon's great grandfather. The plot itself is strong enough, but that's not really why I loved the story so much. I loved the story because of the lore and history that it gives us about the Seven Kingdoms and in particular on the Tagaryen family. They're my favourite house, some my favourite characters are Tagaryens, and they have such an interesting history and relationships with one another. I also enjoyed that the characters were all thought out and established. It also made me realized that, although he has his shortcomings, GRRM is a good writer. This particularly stood out to me as I am watching the TV Show at the moment, and the more they move away from the source material, the more clear it becomes that for the most part the writing is lacking, and that the greatness was in GRRM's story and words. Egg stole the story for me, but I expected that from what I heard and knew of the character and his life. We meet him as a child, for whom the Iron Throne is even further than a far away dream because he is the fourth son of the ruling king's fourth son. Can't get further on the line of succession, and yet it's great to read his story and realize that this hot-headed young prince eventually become King Aegon V! And Dunk is pretty great too; he clearly has a set standard of morals that he refuses to break, and he's a really good knight that protects those in need. And again, so interesting to see how this hedge knight would eventually become Lord Commander of the Knigsguard when Aegon takes the throne. So while I may complain that the original series is not yet finished, I do enjoy learning more about Westerosi history and the complicated relationships of its people. I didn't read the novella format of the story but the graphic novel was good, no complains here. The art I enjoyed and it had no weird panel transitions as it sometimes happens with fantasy books adapted into graphic novels.

So it's the end of an era. I was mildly disappointed that we didn't get to see a ginormous battle  but with only one volume left, I don't see how they could have done that justice so perhaps it's best this way. There's quite a bit of closure so if you like that stuff (e.g. Me! ), you should be happy. I do have a lingering question over the "story" aspect of the Fables universe that kind of destroys the epilogue, but I suppose I'll just have to ignore it.

Hulk gets shuttled off planet Earth because ... well, apparently the Hulk has no friends on Earth anymore. * They all suck, particularly Reed Richards (ha, like that's a secret). But the Hulk lands not where he was supposed to - instead he lands on Sakaar, a planet with a prophecy that a figure called Sakaarson will come to save and unite the people (multiple actors here - pink humanoids, bug creatures, shadow-people silver humanoids, etc). It gets very Dune-esque from therein. Like any good epic, the Hulk goes through multiple trials on said planet to eventually defeat the Red King ... who clearly deserved it because he's a dick with little regard for life. In the first Gladiator-esque challenge, Hulk makes fraaaands with Miek (bug), Korg (Kronan - love those rockheads), Elloe (pinkie), Hiroim (shadow person), Brood (bug). Oh, and the Silver Surfer makes a brief appearance, is freed, does from freeing. You know, surfs, too. It's forgettable. By the end, Hulk eventually even marries Caiera (the Oldstrong Shadow first serving the Red King) when he becomes the king/emperor. But then Mr. Fantastic's ship fucks everything up for the poor Hulk; the warp core explores and kills his new alien lady love/empress. Back to square zero, I guess. Thoughts/questions in no particular order: 1) Did Miek just level up like a Pokemon? Weedle-to-Beedrill? 2) This run has both the Maw (several mentions) and threshers (one mention) ... seeing something in that. Also, the creature Hulk frees ... totally a overgrown varren. 3) Why the hell does Caiera there only start calling Hulk "Holku" in the last few issues, to verbalize endearment...? Meh. 4) What's that last reference in #105, "The Eye of Anger. The World Breaker. Harkanon. Haarg." ... that a Dune reference? Looks like Harkonnen to me. I doubt it, but I seriously don't understand the last epitaph in this run. Haaalp? Last thought: Who was narrating this entire series? A mystical voice on high? *Cho. I know. I get it. I didn't forget. I just don't care?

As you can see from the cover, Illyria enters the picture. I really loved the crossover from Angel. I felt she enhanced the plot and the character interactions were glorious. I also love that there is a consequence of magic leaving the world. Dawn fading from existence would be a huge punch in the gut to Buffy. I can't wait to see how they are going to really fix this.

The Joker is insane! This was a great book and so far, from the comics that I've read, only Batman: The Dark Knight Returns showcases that insanity better. I really enjoyed reading about his origins to becoming the best Batman villain of all. Alan Moore's writing is fantastic and the artwork was great. I'll be reading this one again. The Joker shoots Barbara Gordon, paralyzing her from the waist down and takes pictures of her, stripped down and half-dead. He kidnaps Commissioner Gordon and takes him to a freaky carnival, chaining him up completely naked and forcing him to look at pictures of what he's done to his daughter. He does everything he can to drive Commissioner Gordon insane, seeing how much he can endure. Batman realizes that the only way for his relationship with the Joker to end is in death... one way or another, one of them are going to have to die at the others hand. Their relationship is one I look forward to reading more about. They are the perfect contrast of each other.

Fear the Hunters wasn't my favourite volume of The Walking Dead, but the fact I knew about the major moments beforehand really served to lessen their impact. I must try harder to keep away from Wikipedia, but it's to Kirkman's credit that I'm so damn anxious about the survivors that I need to check up on what's ahead for them. I think this volume's biggest problem for me was plausibility and emotional resonance. And I know, I know it's set in the zombie apocalypse so griping about realism is silly, but I'm going to do a little of it anyway. As Kirkman acknowledges in the letters pages, the twins have hardly even spoken throughout this series. We see them in the background stood with Andrea and Dale quite often, fair enough, but we never really see any bonding between them as a family unit. So when one murders the other and is in turn killed by Carl, it's hard for me to buy Dale and Andrea's grief. Her heartbreak over Dale's death felt believable, natural and appropriate, but it's hard to envision her as a bereaved mother, because she's never really been depicted as a mom. So there's that, and then you add in the cannibals... it's not something I really bought in McCarthy's The Road either, though Kirkman almost had me with the group's explanation for their actions. It's just really hard to imagine that so much food has been looted they need to eat their own kids. Eeesh.

I liked this second volume more than the first! The world is wider and there are more characters. I had forgotten stuff from the first volume, though, like what is the dream Tim-21 had that the robots keep talking about?

The Collection starts off with a touching story of an old love (can't write more without spoiling) but we also find an element that is just a little too far-fetched for me to actually enjoy. The Moment when they finally reach their house, after encountering grave difficulties, only to watch a plane crashing into it (while beeing the only house for miles and miles) It could have been a welcome punchline in a totally different story - it just didn't fit too well in this one. The second part, that was a bit stressed in my book was  the point when Shunka goes on his rampage - the motivation for that comes a little bit out of nowhere to me. Still the story centered on Shunka is a pretty good and enjoyable one. Especially the element of the gay-indian-issue is very well done. While my problem with this one is the slightest in this book, the one in the main storyline is my biggest. It really made me going "Aw cmon, don't start getting cheap on me when  Dash shook his drug-addiction in a way like those characters in other stories who travel to Japan, only to come back as full-fledged ninjas after two weeks or so So maybe this sounds a little overly critic and gives the impression that Vol 7 is not a enjoyable book. This is not my intention, because it is and Scalped is still one of the best reads in Comics I encountered yet. (I dont give four stars to books I don't like) But Jason Aaron has established such high quality in his storytelling, that the standards he has to meet now to satisfy me, are a tad higher than in other books.

"So much was destroyed during the war. And yet some cities rebuilt themselves...as if nothing happened. Too bad people don't rebuild themselves that easily." True rating:4 1/2 stars I've only read a couple of stand alone graphic novels but had a desire to start reading more graphic novel series. The obvious starting point seemed to be Saga, Volume 1 but that one has so much hype around it I didn't feel up to it. Monstress is a wonderful place to start if you want to get into graphic novels. +1 star for the plot. The story unfolds in a beautifully crafted way that is wonderfully formatted and has a pace that keeps you interested but not overwhelmed and it all takes place in a world that was well built by the author. +1 star for the characters  I felt immediately drawn to the characters of this story. The "good guys" had me caring from the start and the "bad guys" had me intrigued the entire way through. In spite of this though I never felt like I had the characters all figured out, which to me is wonderful because it means the author has created strong characters without making them walking tropes. +1 1/2 star for the artwork  As much as I love the story of Monstress I would honestly buy this graphic novel for just the art itself. Its so stunning and different from other art styles I've seen. It's a wonderful mix of eastern and western art that really made me even more captivated in the world of the graphic novel. -1/2 star for some lack of explanation  It honestly may be an issue on my part but it took me a lot of the book to keep track of the terminology used to describe the different species living in the world so I wish it was said clearly what each species was and did. Also the whole limb thing was unclear to me. Why eat just the limbs and not the whole bodies   However, I do see myself rereading the beginning of the first half of the book and probably gaining a better understanding which will boost my rating to 5 stars. In conclusion, I'm so happy to be getting into graphic novels now and will definitely be continuing in this beautiful series. Edit: I changed it to 5 stars because the story and even art work has stuck with me so much and I need the next volume immediately.

The princess saves herself in this one. Enough said! Except, not. The spectacular plot is conveyed in beautiful art and disses many stereotypes. There is the idea that monsters can be nice too. The dashing righteous heir to the throne is a Person of Color. I liked how a homosexual relationship was casually mentioned, without making a big deal about it. And no, the kickass princess is not exactly a tomboy either. She likes her dresses and makeovers and wants to fight too. Yes, women like that do exist and I need more such books! Highly recommended! Note: I received a free copy of the book from the publisher.

Heehee! "...the avatar and the fire lord." "The fight choreography was top notch!" So many meta-jokes! Argh...I want the next one! But still enjoyable as a middle story. So Noriko, Norem's wife is totally Ursa, right?! And maybe since she knew Ozai was intercepting the letters, she planted the letter about Zuko's parentage? Ok that ones a little bit out their. But Ursa totally went to the Forgetful Valley, met the face spirit and got a new face and then married Norem's, right? I wonder if the Mother of Faces is like, the opposite spirit from Koh?

As a series, Locke and Key is a beaut. Unique and gripping storyline, catching artwork. Everything you could ask for, and definitely the best graphic series I have ever read. This particular entry in the series was not my favourite. Don't get me wrong, I thoroughly enjoyed it, but not only is it the end of a great thing, but it wasn't the strongest end I could've foreseen. It felt a little bit rushed, like perhaps they reached the climax of the series and suddenly decided, "Ok, now let's end it." The evil plot reveal was for instance, solid, but not that big a twist. The whole novel was quick, brutal, and irrevocable. My only artistic complaint is that, although I really liked how the ghost-talk was misty and difficult to read, I really wish it were just a bit more legible. And perhaps this was just my copy, but.. as the story progressed I was able to read less and less, until the last ghost scene where I wondered why it was even written at all if I couldn't read even a single word of it. (Anyone else?) And that left me right with Duncan when he says, "I lost him a little while back. Right after he said, 'Hi, Mom.'" How did he get his body???? Anyways, I sincerely hope that this pair writes a spin-off, a sequel, a prequel, or an entirely different series. Something to continue the beauty they can create. Netgalley read.

Mmkay, so I need to get the entirety of the Death of the Family series so I can fill in all the holes. Though I didn't need them to understand what was going on, I REALLY want to know what the hell was going on. Plus, I don't know the DC comic lexicon, so I have absolutely no idea who Damian is, and why he's Robin and Dick is Nightwing, it's just all very confusing. The entire Joker story arc here was amazing. His face in every panel was so intense, so freaking creepy. Really strong ability to take your breath away and possibly give you nightmares. In related news, the art for this book is far superior to the art for the first 2. Not that they weren't good, but this one blew that work out of the water. The James back story was intensely disappointing, though. The story arc was great, but as far as villain origin stories, wah Mommy didn't love me enough  is played out. Sigh. The ending to that was amazing, but doesn't feel like a real ending. I guess I'll see in the next book. Speaking of which, WTF is with Commissioner Gordon? I mean REALLY. You see a Bat person holding your wife rather than, I don't know, slitting her throat, and your first assumption is she's a bad guy who must be arrested for murdering the psychopath that you raised? Gimme a break. Lastly, CATWOMAN! Who, for some reason, looked like Heidi Klum. Interesting. Also, LOVE HER. And yay for more on the Talon storyline. I love Mary, and want to know everything about her, and I want her to be a good guy eventually. On to the next!

Studetns may need a lot of guidance when reading this book as there are a lot of heavy themes that even the MC can't process. The story lays out the situations without judgement (even though the MC uses the word 'slut' without fully realizing its implication, her younger friend points out that it is sexist. The authors do a good job of making it a conversation instead of saying one of the other is right or wrong, leaving the reader to decide what he/she thinks)  and plainly illustrate what it is like to observe something without fully understanding it. However, this leads me to wonder if students who pick up this book because they are the same age as the MC will be thoughtful enough to ponder these moral and emotional dilemmas.

Snyder wraps up the Court of Owls battle with some crazy shit! Almost goes without saying that I devoured and loved the hell out of it. In City of Owls, Batman's defeat of the current Court of Owls assassin, the Talon, leads to the Court deciding to up their game a bit. The end result is the flood of assassins unleashed on Gotham with only the Batfamily to try to protect them. The fight feels suitably crazy and epic, with Batman and Alfred facing off against a mob of Talons in the Batcave while the other Bat allies are trying to hold the rest off from throwing Gotham into chaos. And yet...it just gets crazier. I will admit that I in no way expected the twist with Lincoln March that never fully gets resolved. I loved that you never fully get to know if he really is Thomas Wayne Jr or just brainwashed and crazy. And that final showdown...just so fucking cool! I'm incapable of reasoned arguments here so someone who's not totally in love with Batman may see flaws but I just saw glorious Bat vs Owl showdowns and couldn't stop drooling. Holy shit I loved this. And just gotta say...don't you dare kill Harper Row, Snyder. She's adorable and I really wanna see more of her. At this rate, I'm gonna be devouring New 52 Batman in a matter of hours but I can't stop now. Snyder is doing a fantastic job with Batman and I'm so very glad I finally decided to start reading them. Can't wait to see Joker in the next one!

This is a fantastic example of how a graphic novel can be an extremely powerful method of telling a story. Bechdel's illustrations are rather straightforward, but the juxtaposition of her illustrations to the words just hit me in the gut at times. It really hurt to read some of the passages, and I ached for that little girl and the young girl. I read her literary references as her attempts to try to make sense of what was going on in her life - and in her father's/family's life/lives. I don't think there is any pretention about the literary references (as some reviewers seem to think). She has the background. It's part of her life. I picked up this book after reading an article (I think it was in The Guardian) about graphic novels one should read. Books without illustrations can move me. This is one with illustrations that really moved me. The very last frame and its build-up choked me up and brought out some tears. The depth of the clear language and the straightforward illustrations is what makes the book amazing for me and what earns my five stars.

I am not enjoying the Amazons - how long has Hero been an Amazon, anyway? is there some sort of initiation ceremony where they spill all their secrets really quickly? - but the very last page of this is fantastic, and I'm really excited to pick up Y: The Last Man, Vol. 3: One Small Step.

Volume two of Saga picks up right from where the first volume ended with Marko's parents making the surprising introduction of Alana and Hazel and not taking it well at all. They're clearly thrown off by the off match and not friendly to Alana at all but she can throw it straight back at them. When they've finally established a little peace they decide to travel to meet the author of the couple's favourite book and introduce Hazel to the great man. On the other side, The Will and Prince IV are still searching for the abnormal family but The Will has an unwelcome partner pushing him along to find Marko and get revenge. The Will and Prince IV are both deeply troubled by their past and they're unstable most of the time. Then there's little Slave Girl, saved by The Will, with an odd gift of feeling items of power and speaking to them. This volume was an excellent sequel to the first one and it was all over far too quickly. Luckily I just so happened to get the third volume come in today because I was going through a major withdrawal after I finished this one. The illustrations were fantastically detailed again with so much colour and attention to detail and the writing was brilliant but filled with anguish for the reader. All I know now is that I need to read volume four because yes, I've already finished volume three! Favourite Quotes... - "So glad I got to do this in a towel." - "This is the best book I've ever read." - "I was giving Hazel a bath and part of her just fucking fell off." *Spoilers Below* It was sad to learn that Barr was dying because I really pictured them as a happy family exploring the galaxy but I've learned by now that Saga is anything but idealistic. It is mean, sad and heartbreaking! But I wouldn't have it any other way. I still think it was a complete shame to have him die so quickly but it did make me much more sympathetic to him and really focus on the little moments he was in the comic. One of the best things that happened was all the awesome clothes he made them and the adorable ones he made Hazel! It makes me so sad to think of them wearing them and growing out of them over the years and losing the last piece of him! It also softened Marko's mother and allowed Alana and her to bond in a small way. The meeting between Alana and Marko was odd and exactly how you think it would go with them meeting in a jail cell and her taking the phrase "hitting it off" to a new level. I hope there is a few more flashbacks in the series, maybe their wedding! It was a great scene when she was reading him the book before they decided to run away. Marko saying, "Please. Keep reading" should be on a poster on everyone's wall. I think Alana's love for her book is so, so similar to every reader of this series and it's also an excellent way to bond with her character more as she yells NO SPOILERS! It also leads them to the author of that book and we learn that it's not just a silly book but a book with real opinions about war and a hope for love. I would totally read this book about a couple that hangs out and play board games but also sometimes eat sandwiches at the movies! Then enters Gwendolyn, we remember her from volume one as the ex-fiance of Marko and the woman he stole their wedding rings off. It doesn't exactly sound like she'll be giving him hugs when she finds him and with the help of The Will she will find him. Prince IV also makes an appearance where he interrogated the author and basically tells him to kill him. He's clearly suffering deeply from his time in the war and is still having some dark reactions displayed prominently on his face-screen. We still don't know a whole lot about him so I'm hoping his story unfolds more. Also, I again was completely in love with every page with little Hazel on it. She is just the most adorable little girl and it was so hilarious with Alana thought she broke her when her umbilical cord came off! I hope she stays adorable forever but I really want to see what she looks like all grown up!

The dialogue remains the best thing of this series. It's consistently top notch and real. Some of the best I have ever seen in the world of comics. Highlights of this update: seeing Hazel growing up. The authors gave her some personality already, although at first I didn't realize so much time had passed. Then the return of lying cat was cool although it was way too short, dammit. The best thing was the appearance of King Robot... Man that was hilarious (and awesome) !

Tumblr Blog review: http://theliteraryinsomniac.tumblr.co... I'm a fan of Gaiman writing for several reasons: One: it's fantasy without the pretension. He crafts the most mesmerizing worlds and concepts and presents them so simply that you can't believe you've been immersed so quickly. There are no complicated apostrophied, hyphenated names to learn, no rules to watch out for. No fuss. just fantasy. Two: It's character driven without sacrificing the world building. because way too often it's one or the other. With Gaiman, you get both. Three: there's always a moral. I don't think of it as genre fiction. His books always involve a moral conflict and characters striving to do the right thing. Four: It's fun! plus it has that fairy tale quality that you can't get anywhere else. Five: It's entirely original. No new spins on an old story, he's the guy other people copy. He's got one of the most vivid imaginations in history. The sandamn is one of his landmark works. The grqphic novel series has won several awards and became a stple in the diet of any comic book fan. You can read it in one of the following ways: -In 10 separate volumes that begin with preludes and Nocturnes and progress in this order. or -In the new version with five super volumes collecting all ten. the absolute sandman. The story follows The trials of sandman, The king of the realm of dreams and nightmares and his imprisonment by an order of maegi. and his subsequent escape and revenge. This first volume only explores the very basics of the sandman world. I get the feeling this is just an introduction. I'm looking forward to the following volumes in this series. 4/5 stars.

Hoooooly shit, what was THAT. I thought I'd be able to write something, but I can't. It's gonna need another reread, and a long think. Suffice it to say you need to pick this up, and you absolutely have no idea what you're getting yourself into when you do. I don't know how to comment on the book any further unless I take notes while I go, which is pretty much how I use Goodreads half the time anyway. I feel a little bad about it this time around because Wrenchies is so new, so as much as it feels kind've silly I'll bracket off my notes as spoilers. Lame. (Followup: by the time I finished my notes, they became an article unto themselves. Don't bother clicking the link unless you really, really want a really, really detailed play-by-play of the entire book.) CHAPTER 1: SHERWOOD AND ORSON (p7) More of a prologue than a full chapter, this sets up the tone and associative page layouts Dalrymple will use later in the book, and also hearkens back to his work in It Will All Hurt and excerpts of Delusional. Although the panel sequences are relatively linear, there's also a tendency to guide the eye around the page rather than through it, and the voiceover will often fragment into glyphs and symbology as it tells the story. Here, the two boys from the chapter's title are running through a forest in what seems to be a modern, real-world setting. They wander into a sewer tunnel, where they're attacked by a Night Creep, a well-dressed vampiric monster whose race serves as one of the main antagonists of the book. The creature seems to live in some kind of treasure den, complete with medieval-looking weapons and magic items. The Night Creep inserts its fingers into Sherwood's eyes and seems to corrupt him somehow, while Orson finds a sword and lops off the monster's head. As he recovers, Sherwood finds an amulet that is speaking to him from the floor of the creature's cave. As he looks through it, Sherwood is transported into a floating negative space. CHAPTER 2: THE YOUNG WRENCHIES (p30) This section feels the most like what the PR on this book suggests you're getting into. Here, we jump into a strange post-apocalyptic world populated only by ruined cities, giant robots rusting into the earth, and warbands of children battling zombie hordes across the wasteland. A strange living shadow floats across these landscapes, and resurfaces throughout the book as a silent guide through the story. Our focus is on The Wrenchies, a small tribe of child-warriors who've named themselves after an old comic book (Wrenchies #1). They're one of the toughest and most well-known gangs -- they maintain a secret lair that shelters other gangs during the day, and are able to hold themselves against the zombies (called Shadowsmen) and rival gangs like the Zekes. Although this section of the book is quite long, it's mainly action and world-building. One evening, the Wrenchies survive a raid on some kind of underground rock concert in the desert by the Night Creeps, who seem to use robots to absorb older children out of existence. (Barch and Belf, a pair of bickering mice from some of Dalrymple's other works, make an appearance here.) When the Zekes are wiped out following the raid, the Wrenchies save their leader, Shakey, who takes them to the underground lair of The Scientist, a mysterious entity the Wrenchies have never heard of. At the Scientist's lair they met Olweyes, another child who explains to them that Wrenchies #1 actually contains secret codes that, when deciphered, can unlock a world of superbeings who will wipe the Shadowsmen from the earth. Olweyes offers to take the Wrenchies to the Scientist to discuss the matter further. CHAPTER 3: HOLLIS AND THE GHOST (p108) Another abrupt shift, and this section changes direction to focus on Hollis, a young overweight boy living in a modern city who is always dressed in his homemade superhero costume, and who lives in a bit of a dreamworld. Hollis has been featured in several of Dalrymple's short comics, but in Wrenchies his bizarre inability to connect to the real world is more apparent. It's not just that's he's unpopular among his peers; Hollis also seems both emotionally and mentally stunted in his understanding of the world around him. His main concern is displeasing God because of his developing sexual desires, and he spends much of his time talking to Him, and/or narrating his own day-to-day. Hollis' most recent obsession is his next door neighbor Sherwood, a single adult man who lives alone. Hollis believes that a ghost lives in Sherwood's apartment, and this ghost (a white version of the shadow being we saw in part 2) comes around to hang out with Hollis quite often. Hollis is also intrigued by his copy of Wrenchies #1, which seems to both fascinate him but make him feel strange and ashamed. After destroying a copy of the comic, Hollis steals a second one from the grocery store. Soon after, he's spying on Sherwood's apartment when a magic amulet (the same amulet we saw in part 1) appears to him. Hollis dons the amulet and falls into the comic book world of The Wrenchies. CHAPTER 4: THE SCIENTIST AND ORIGINAL WRENCHIES (p146) This section is mainly exposition, but the background for a story like this is so strange and idiosyncratic that it still clips along at a good pace. Here we meet the Scientist, a giant gray automaton that has assembled Hollis and the Wrenchies to enact a ritual that will bring the "original Wrenchies" (we'll call them the Originals) to their world in order to stop the Shadowsmen. The Originals are a group of adult warriors from Wrenchies #1, and when the group successively summons them through the Scientist's Bryson Vortex Tunnel, they also call through a swarm of Vortex Bugs, which the Scientist insists they must kill before they grow into nightmares. As the expanded group sets to the task, the Scientist fills them in on what's led to their being brought together. The Scientist used to be a man named Herzog Duke, who at some point in the past found himself a part of a group imprisoned on a "space vessel" with Sherwood and Orson, among others (more on this much later, or in It Will All Hurt). Sherwood and Duke became friends, though each would eventually escape the ship: Sherwood will return to Earth a few years after the events of Chapter 1 (implying that the amulet may have transported him to the "space vessel" at the end of that section), while Duke arrives centuries later, having transplanted his mind to the body of a robot and finding his home planet plagued with demons. By this point in Earth's future (the Scientist explains), the human race had been reduced to children, raised in space incubators and deposited on the planet's surface as a food source for the Shadowsmen. When the Scientist first arrived and sequestered himself in an underground sanctuary, he also constructed a radio that was able to tune into messages from Sherwood, who explained the downfall of both the planet, and himself. After his return to Earth, Sherwood had grown into a paranoid man, convinced he would bring about the destruction of the world. In an attempt to combat this fate, Sherwood spent years writing and drawing Wrenchies #1, a comic designed to summon those who would fight the oncoming evil. Sherwood also performed magic on a set of strangers who were then dropped into an alternate dimension to train for their future lives as these heroes. These strangers would become the Originals. Sherwood's predictions of doom eventually came true. The world collapsed in war and environmental disasters, and a meteor struck the planet and opened the gates to Hell, bringing forth the Shadowsmen, a race of dark elves. Sherwood's dying body, full of magic and extradimensional energy, became the source of their power. Now, the Scientist has called upon the expanded Wrenchies to walk to the dark elves' lair and destroy Sherwood. He gives the group a final tour of his underground compound, and offers them performance-enhancing drugs, then says, "Soon we will truly be hauling ass. Prepare for our ascension to the surface!" CHAPTER 5: THE QUEST (p188) This section is narrated again by Hollis, and documents the Wrenchies journey to find Sherwood. Along the way, four of the Originals and a few of the children are destroyed, maimed, or lost. Koole from Pop Gun War makes an appearance as a minor baddie, and the plot's associative looseness becomes a full-blown existentialist creed, as the characters spend just as much time dreaming and considering their mortality as they do fighting Shadowsmen and other assorted horrors. A child who has appeared only as a part of the background in several early scenes appears in their travels as a haunt of some kind; his name and significance will not be revealed until part 6. The white formless ghost appears again to Hollis, who in turn finds himself among a group of friends who like and accept him for the first time in his life. This may be the strongest and most evocative section of the book, although there's not much to detail in terms of plot, and much of the chapter is simply riffing on earlier images and scenes. The Wrenchies' path leads them to an abandoned cardboard box which contains a forest, which contains a shack, which leads to a basement comound full of deactivated robots in which each character must walk their own path, facing various threats both physical and psychological. After those who survive this ordeal regroup, the band descends to a cave where Sherwood's body hangs suspended in space, surrounded by a glowing green orb. CHAPTER 6: SHERWOOD PRESLEY BREADCOAT (p234) Finally we return to the end of chapter 1, as young Sherwood floats in a negative space surrounded by bubbles. Each bubble seems to pop him into different points of his life, in some sort of Dickensian review of his sins. Although the narrative actively fights against explaining itself in sequence, it seems that after several years fighting demons alongside his brother Orson, Sherwood was abducted by aliens at age 12. This led directly to Sherwood meeting Herzog Duke, and having a series of adventures which culmnated both in Duke's death in a lab experiment, and Sherwood's escape from the alien ship. Upon returning to Earth, Sherwood spent years working on and off for the government as a secret agent, but also suffered years of depression and malaise, and looked desperately for some kind of spiritual enlightenment. As an adult he met a man named Fortune Scepter who reminded him of his brother Orson (who he'd left onboard the alien vessel as a child.) He also dates a woman named Marsi (Marsi is also one of the young Wrenchies), who leaves him after his obsession with magic consumes him. After creating Wrenchies #1, Sherwood seems to lose his mind -- he casts a spell on his amulet (which will eventually lead it to Hollis) and kills Fortune. As a white ghost and a dark ghost (the shadows we've seen throughout the book) leave his body, Sherwood watches in horror while a horde of Night Creeps finally come for him. From this, we cut back to the Wrenchies standing beneath Sherwood's suspended body in the dark elves' lair. As the group fights off an army of Night Creeps, Hollis throws the amulet at Sherwood, uniting the white ghost with his corporeal body. The white ghost was Sherwood's soul, traveling through time and space to find him. The demons turn to ash and Sherwood regains consciousness. Moments later, the dark ghost arrives -- this is Sherwood's death, come to claim him. Sherwood begs forgiveness, and the Scientist crushes his skull. EPILOGUES (p280) Hollis and the Scientist return to explain that the Wrenchies continued their adventures in smaller groups, alluding to events in Dalrymple's other works, including Remainder and Supermundane. The amulet returns to the beginning of Chapter 2, where it is found by Barch and Belf. Through the amulet, we see Sherwood and Olson recovering from fighting the Night Creep in Chapter 1. Sherwood claims he had a dream where he tried to change future, but is already forgetting it. "They know us now and are coming for us," he days. As they turn to leave, a Vortex Bug lands on Sherwood's eye. On the astral plane, Sherwood and Marsi laugh about the ridiculousness of the whole affair. "You were obsessed with your own personal story...with your own pain," Marsi says. "We're over it now." And they disappear into the void. FOTOGLOCTICA (p289) The book ends with this early story that originally appeared in MeatHaus, and through it we can see many of the kernels for Wrenchies. The story is mainly a first draft of Chapter 1, and more explicitly details Sherwood and Orson's youthful incarnations (including a reminder that Orson appears as a regular in Supermundane. In this version of the story the boys dispatch the Night Creep rather easily, and as it dies a group of Night Creeps on a city rooftop sing ominously to one another. My real review follows. If you've ever taken a peek at Grant Morrison's The Invisibles (and there's no reason you need to, except if you want to know what's up when someone asks you if you've read The Invisibles, and anyone who asks you that is a blowhard, so fuck it), you may know that his intent with that project was to enact a magic rite that would echo across both his own works and others, "a hypersigil to jump-start the culture in a more positive direction." (wikipedia, natch) And this is a terrible and patronizing idea, and Invisibles is a terrible and patronizing book, not least of all because its painful illusions of grandeur. But that doesn't mean there's not something interesting about the concept behind it, both in being aware of a one's own cultural impact, and of the strange energies that come out of cross-textual worldbuilding. I would posit that if you've ever used terms like "Buffyverse" to describe Joss Whedon's body of work, or "Diniverse" to talk about superhero cartoons, or even been aware of the intentions behind Stephen King's Dark Tower series, there's something about hypersigilism that's being invoked. Shared story universes are the bread and butter of comics, of course -- a meta-detail that is assuredly part of the equation for The Wrenchies, as its own narrative leaps across worlds, realms, and dimensions of time and space -- and includes characters from throughout Dalrymple's past comics. As in superhero stories, there are notes of religious concern at play here as well, wrapped up in the question of God-as-Author. But rather than lose itself in Morrison's auteurish pompousity, Dalrymple's thought process works more honestly as a somewhat desperate search for self. Instead of basking in the aggrandizement of storybuilding, there is an attention here to the real human-being-people who make stories -- who do so in an attempt to find self-worth, to find community, to find inner peace. In The Wrenchies, one person might be a superhero, a secret agent, a paper pusher, and a comics artist all in a single lifetime -- but there is certain fragmentation, a trauma in all that calamity. And while there is a very real awareness of the Big Bad World outside fiction's walls, the focus of The Wrenchies lies in what happens when a person becomes too lost and broken to be able to even access that world, much less find their place in it. Such a tragic figure exists at the literal heart of The Wrenchies, and also echoes throughout its supporting cast -- the post-apocalyptic child-warriors that are the book's namesake, the rudderless kid in a nameless modern city who hopes to join them, the isolated adults cast into a land of magic without a true understanding of their own agency. The questions of existential meaning that surround these characters feed the meditative concerns at the center of the book, and their mounting paranoia about the hopelessness of their futures looms as large as the fantastic monsters that pursue them across the strange landscapes in which they find themselves. I'm not saying The Wrenchies is a perfect work (although I might be), and I'll concede that it demands no small amount of patience and a certain suspension of disbelief to be enjoyed in the first place. But I do believe it's an incredible testament to what can be done by one person in the field of comics -- and it's made my bookshelf a hell of an exciting place to be in 2014.
Why yes, I plan on reading all of these. Ugh, "Sweetie." Gross.

This was a great story, and very applicable. I could see this being taken up by gun rights activists as an example of white might happen should certain freedoms be taken away. That being said, I felt that the story was well written and the action was done very well. I rarely feel an emotional pull from comics, but this one got to me a little although  Goliath's death  didn't mean much to me due to not really knowing that character very well. It was nice to read this before Captain America's next movie comes out, although I do know that the stories are going to be drastically different, I still think that they will try to pay homage to the source material in some way and I like to be able to catch that when it comes.

Well I did not expect this story to break my heart. I was honestly rushing to the end, so I could say I'd finished it and moved on. At the beginning of volume book the epic conflict of the story resolved relatively quickly and quietly. I was expecting a lengthy denouement, acceptable for a long-running series such as this one. Boy was I wrong. The last chapter of this book, in my admittedly very hasty assessment, is what makes this a science-fiction story well-worth completing. Other observations, including spoilers: - MAJOR props to Bryan K. Vaughan for keeping up the 'is it science or magic' plotline throughout. The explanation even kind of justified the dream-link stuff. If this is world where there's such a thing as genetic resonance, there's definitely telepathy. - I was totally caught off-guard by three-fifty's death. And y'all, it broke me. And just abruptly ending on Yorick crying, then jumping to 60 years later and explaining everything over clips from all the saddest, inevitably tragic moments of Yorick's horrific life. I need a hug. Though let's be real. If Yorick's life was anything other than tragic the story couldn't be called honest. - Good lord, the art and layout of these books improved dramatically by the end of this series. I was really blown away by the framing of some of these panels.

I picked this book up for 2 reasons. 1) Because I needed a Graphic Novel/Manga book for Emily's Reading Challenge. 2) Because I have enjoyed the show on AMC and kept hearing about how it differed from the comic books and wanted to see for myself how it was different and if I liked it better. I'm not really a comic person, but I enjoyed this book. It is very different from the show, but not unrecognizably different (the timeline is the same for both it seems). The pacing is much better than in the show, something that takes 5 or 6 episodes in the show is told in 5 or 6 pages. The book also gives you more characters than the show and more backstory on the characters. I am not saying the show should be more like the book (in fact there are several very disturbing scenes that I do not think would ever be featured on TV  such as Carl killing Shane  )but I think fans of the show would enjoy the differences in the book. Though I enjoyed this book, I doubt that I will read the rest of the series or that I will start reading graphic novels/comics/manga regularly. Its still not a format that I find appealing. I would rather have a book full of text for my imagination to run wild on and not have someone else's pictures in my head while reading. (By the way, it seems that the show was spot on for casting just looking at the drawings in the book.) I don't judge people who enjoy graphic novels, its just not for me. Genre Bingo: Graphic Novel/Manga Paranormal Scavenger Hunt: Zombie

I'm sorry to say I'm a touch disappointed. I'd been looking forward to finally getting the backstory on Shepherd Book--as only hints of it were ever mentioned in the original series. Book is such a sagely paternal character, and his presence rounded out the crew of Serenity with a quietly powerful temperance. Yet, it was clear he wasn't always the man he'd become. This graphic novel telling has a harsher cast to the art style than others in the series. Deep colors and hard shadows add grit but--for this reviewer at least--detracted from both the beauty and the ability to clearly discern between characters in a few scenes. The story itself is told in a series of flashbacks within flachbacks, creating a jerky narrative effect that felt disorienting to this reader on several occasions. The content itself was intriguing. The idea of Book starting out as a runaway from an abusive drunken father, surviving for a time as a volatile petty criminal, had a strongly viable resonance. That he'd volunteer himself as  a double-agent for the Independence movement back before the war with the alliance even began was a fascinating twist. In essence, he was an uncaught mole trapped behind enemy lines; forced to stay there once his cause was crushed. Lost and alone, lacking a true identity, he becomes a drifter and a drunk. Until some combination of head-trauma, the kindness of strangers, and divine revelation awakens him to a new path and purpose. Really it isn't so much the content itself as the execution that fell a bit short. Side Note: The telling also seemed to reinforce what was repeatedly indicated in the TV series--that while Shepherd Book seems blatantly intended as a theologically-educated, Bible-toting representation for Christianity, his professed version of faith is ultimately works-based rather than grace-based. It's hard to say if that denotes a lack of understanding on Joss Whedon's part, or an intentional modification. Either way, one doesn't get the sense it's a malicious misconstruing. But those who actually subscribe to the Christian faith could understandably find this aspect frustrating.

This review is also posted on my blog. I remain unsure about how exactly to review these manga volumes, especially now that Sailor Moon Crystal has entirely finished the Black Moon arc and it is only just starting here. It is further proven that Sailor Moon Crystal is an exact replica of the original manga (entirely unlike the 90s anime), give or take a few minor changes - and most of those I didn't even catch, since it's been many months since the beginning of the Black Moon arc has passed on the show. But there was one difference that I have to say I liked better - instead of Ami playing Berthier in the chess match, like she did in the show, she completely went on the aggressive and confronted her immediately without even beating around the bush. For the time being I have complete access to all the volumes in this series from the library, so I'm hoping I'll be able to get to all of them relatively shortly and pass the current point in the show so that I may move onto new content, and maybe be able to write a better review. I don't exactly watch the show with the intent to review - just to enjoy - so I can't say I remember what my first impressions were. All I can say, in regards to the content of this specific volume, is - FINALLY CHIBI-USA I KNOW WHERE YOU COME FROM NOW I HAVE BEEN WAITING SO LONG TO LEARN YOUR STORYLINE AND HAVE YOU INTRODUCED PROPERLY AND NOW YOU ARE INTRODUCED AND THE STORYLINE IS JUST STARTING AAAHHH~ ~ *cough* Volume four will get picked up tomorrow. I hope I'll be able to read it soon. :3

The story was captivating as usual, and even more explicit than the first. The way the mom treated her father in law felt pretty rude to me at first, but I liked how her relationship with him improved. The grandfather's death was really sad ;-; We finally got to see Gabriella, and it looks like more drama is coming up~ The narrator's words about breakups were really sad, especially the underlying reference to the war, and the bitter tone. And the little girl finally got rescued, yay dYZ%0dYZSdYZ+ That picture of her after she said her name creeped me out though dY~u ...And it seems that some characters have nine lives, apparently... I really like how it ended dY'oe, it gave me a sense of victory, even though their enemy was waiting downstairs.

This volume wasn't as exciting as some of the previous volumes, but still very good. It was essentially one giant  battle between Eren and Reiner and Bertolt. Reiner and Bertolt capture Eren and Ymir and we find out that Reiner and Bertolt are working towards a common goal of returning Eren to their hometown, even though we are unsure of why they have that goal. Overall, even with the  giant battle  , this volume basically serves as a means for dialogue to further the plot. Not bad, just not as intense and gory as the rest of the volumes.

Giving this a 4-star, mainly because enjoyment-wise, this volume wasn't something I enjoyed all that much compared to the previous volumes despite all the secrets dropped on us. Wow, Kureno. Can I give him a title like "The Person Who Shall Reveal Secrets"? Seriously, this volume's biggest plot twists came from him. I remember the first time I read this and I was like "HOLY SHIT THAT DID NOT HAPPEN!... *a few pages down* OMG THAT DID NOT HAPPEN!... *a few pages later* DAMN IT KURENO HOW MANY PLOT TWISTS ARE THERE?!" First we learn that Kureno has a relationship with Akito that goes beyond the zodiac bond, then we learn that he's no longer bound by the curse, and yet HE REFUSES TO MEET OUR DEAR UO-CHAN, and then WE LEARN THAT AKITO IS A GIRL (!!! ), but was raised as a boy thanks to her mother (WTF?). Wow. Let me pause and let that sink in. *breathes deeply* It's no wonder Tohru reacts the way she did after learning about everything... And then we readers get to know things from Shigure's side (!!!) that Tohru doesn't know (yet?). And WTF Shigure, did you just sleep with the person your love hates the most to spite her for sleeping with another guy ??? This is so messed up, like he points out himself. And yet at the end of the volume Shigure sleeps with Akito. What. The. Actual. Flying fish. Veering away from the Sohma family drama, I love the scene between Tohru, Arisa and Saki. (Does anyone wonder why they call Tohru Tohru, but Tohru calls them by their family names...? So polite, our protagonist.) That is one of my favorite points of this series: that there's many friendships forged. Me love some sisterhood! (Although, poor Uo-chan. *pats* He'll come around, someday.) That scene of Kyo and Tohru just unleashed my inner fangirl. (KYA! KYA! KYAAAAAA!!!!) Kyo, it's SOOOOO obvious you lurve her. Fortunately (or unfortunately?) Tohru's too dense to realize it. That flower scene is just so sweet I feel like I just poured sugar into my mouth, but it's definitely worth it. *goes to fangirl* We also see a development in Yuki and Machi's relationship, and what seems like a budding romance between. A girl running after you just to say hi, when she doesn't seem all that impressed by you just a few volumes ago? Cute. I like how they're slowly discovering each other, seeing each other beyond the facades that they portray consciously or unconsciously to others. Too bad I'm not really all that invested into that relationship. Takaya needs to show more from Machi to really make us readers root for her. All in all, not a bad volume. Not one of my favorites by far, but the huge plot twists and the cute Kyo-Tohru scene make this worth it.

Same great writing and wit as season 8. The characters looked less like their tv counterparts in this one than season 8, except for the cover art pieces, those were much more life like. Willow got a snazzy new haircut though and she's handling the world sans magic surprisingly well. Must've been all those lessons in meditating from Giles (Season 8 Spoiler C'mon, someone in Buffy STAYING dead?? Let's not start with Giles. ). Lots of returning characters, Xander is very him but Dawn is all grown up which definitely has a different dynamic to her and Buffy's relationship (which is not even a subplot but worth saying). Spike continues his hero role and is featured in a good little short story at the back of the book, written by the humorous and talented Jane Espenson. I think Buffy was acting a bit childish at first and some whining about wanting to be normal but she got her shit together when it counted. We'll see about the next issue, especially after the bombshell at the end of this one... (no spoilers or even hints of spoilers here!) And new characters! Some I liked more than others. Buffy's new roomies were meh. We have some cop interaction here too and that pushed the plot into thrill speeds. Sev is a mixed bag, but his background really highlights some of the fallout from the magic going poof and the fallout ramifications are kinda the core to this whole issue. Finally, Eldre Koh. Badass demony dude. Can't wait to hear more about him. And he makes for a good straight man to Spike's sarcasm too. Overall, great start to season 9.

Dammit. It was like the anime. I cried! I actually cried, because aaagggh my favourite characters! They were so innocent! They were tricked! They were too good and too cute and now they are deadddd! The last chapter of the book felt so random and out of place, but it was funny and soothed my grieving heart for a while. I actually love Lizzie's character and really ship her with Ciel, and Prince Soma and Agni are super amusing. This whole series just has the cutest, coolest, and/or most unique characters ever, and I love love love it.

A standing ovation for this final volume of the series! I was on pins and needles about Bobby and Buddy and no only breathed a sigh of relief, but almost teared up. Who knew a little woodchuck human hybrid could be such a heartwarming character. I don't want to spoil anything, so I will just say that your questions will be answered and you'll say goodbye to some good characters. Yet you'll also be hopeful, and you will be reminded of the bonds of friendship and family. DNA has nothing to do with it. Be respectful of nature. Oh, and one more thing: don't make ancient gods angry .

The previous installment didn't do much for me, but I guess it put everything in place for this one. Points off for the Bennet sisters killing and eating a unicorn  but otherwise I was pleased with the reframing of the story that took place here.

3.5 stars Well...that escalated quickly. This book is violent and bloody, but it doesn't ever feel gratuitous or over the top. Duncan & Maddie make some TERRIBLE life choices, though, and I kind of want to shake them both. I'm also not sure why they didn't try to escape together each time one of them escaped at the end. It felt weird to me that Maddie escapes and Duncan stays and then HE escapes and she stays. I also really appreciated the author note at the end about how they were very intentional about making sure that all the violence and poor decisions had consequences for the teens. Overall, I thought this was a well written, beautifully drawn book that does a good job introducing these characters and the world they live in. I want to know where Maddie goes from here!

This was an ok story, very Cindy centric, a several of the Fairest stories seem to be. She's called in to investigate after a murder, since Bigby is currently unavailable. Speaking of which, this book definitely has some spoilers for the main Fables plotline, with no inkling given in the book itself where it falls within that arc. My biggest issue with the story, I think, is that the artwork changes every couple of pages, and it's wildly inconsistent. Some of it is weird cartoon-realism, and some of it is ultra-cartoony and not great quality, while some of the middle-range realism that the series, as a whole, tends to use (which is my favorite). It got to where some characters weren't even recognizable from one panel to the next. Also, the story itself is semi-moot because you know they're not going to kill off some of the main characters in a random off-shoot. I wouldn't recommend this as a starting point for people into the Fables world, unless you don't mind spoilers. Hell, I wouldn't recommend it anyway just because it's not the strongest stories and relies too heavily on familiarity with the characters as opposed to really introducing them, though it does give a smattering of backstory on some we may not have seen before. Not a bad side-story in the Fables world, but far from a necessary one. * Not only is in unclear, aside from reading, where this falls into the Fables timeline, it's not even clear where it falls on the Fairest line. The book-page I'm on tells me this is Fairest #5, except Fairest #5 is actually Fairest, Vol 5: The Clamour for Glamour, and this stand-alone GN was published between Volumes 2 and 3 of the Fairest series.

Liked the humor, the characters and the show of a unexplored culture; disliked the art and some plot points her getting the powers out of some fog, like wtf and why only her was affected; that whole villain bird thing wtf .

I honestly had no idea this was a graphic novel. I just saw that Marissa Meyer had another book come out in the lunar chronicles and instantly bought it! I was pleasantly surprised when opening it. I've never read a graphic novel before and I'm glad this was my first. I forgot how much I missed everyone. Iko is seriously so funny. As well as Thorne, his witty charm is hilarious. especially the part when he saw his own android hahaha Well done Buddy read: https://www.goodreads.com/topic/show/...
I took a star away because I can't understand why the girl didn't just cut herself free. The reaver left her a knife, right there, for that reason. That  made no sense to me.

I received this copy in exchange of an honest review, for so, none of my feelings were affected or biased by the author or publisher. If you'd like to read this review on my blog. Updated: 12/18/2015 Rating: 2/5 stars. In tortured life, we hear about the story of Richard, and how his life slowly turned bad by his very special gift. Now, at his lowest point, an even occurs that gives him a new reason to stay alive, and actually, fight to stay alive. When I was looking for new graphic novels to read in NetGalley (because honestly, they're so easy to read) and I saw this, I was really excited. It sounded like something that I could definitely like. But, something that I've come to realize, is an indicator of a possible bad story, is that the blur doesn't really talk about the plot. It talks about general storyline. When I read this, I wasn't sure of what was coming, but if I had known it was going to turn into this? I would have saved time and just don't read it. I was expecting some fun, adventurous, filled with paranormal story. Instead, I got an unnecessary story, with unnecessary fillings and one hell of a weird out come. I swear, if I had read the final part with the first half, I wouldn't have guessed it was the same. The story of Richard having a gift to see how people die sounded awesome, Sad for him, but awesome for me to read. But that wasn't it. There was also a weird plot about a weird ghost-avenger who wanted to kill him just because. And then the ending. The ghost was himself? And he was a clone? Of a guy who had a twin? Or was it the twin the ghost? Or was it the combination of both? All the same, the ending felt really rushed, and it felt like it hadn't been planned out at all, but rather a spur-of-the-moment kind of word-vomit. It was all over the place, and I'm not sure it made complete sense. Also, it was really grotesque. But like, really, unnecessary grotesque. It had people's brains and guts flying all over the place, and blood pouring out of the paper. And it was like the author knew his story wasn't that good and decided to stick all that blood so that people would stay. Don't get me wrong, I normally don't complain about that. The realest the better. And when I started reading this, I felt it might be that way. But then it just got ridiculous. The art style wasn't exactly pretty, and at times I wasn't sure of what the surroundings really where. Other than that, it was an enjoyable piece of work, without the guts. Even thought all this, I did enjoy some of this. It wasn't a complete and total disaster. It was fast paced, at least the first part, and kind of gripping. I don't think you should waste much time with this. And not everyone likes all this gross blood gutsy. Nah, I've wasted time. Initial Reaction Meh, I didn't like this. It had a good premise, and I only expected it to be adventurous and fun. But it had a really poor execution and nothing really happened. Also, it was confusing and had really grotesque scenes everywhere, that just became unnecessary. Proper reviews in the morrow.

3.5 Stars for this graphic novel! It was a rather quick story but it wasn't bad. Initially the creepy dude with the swirly face from Chester's that hangs around the Dreamy Eyed Guy is causing trouble, slurping up parts of peoples faces and then leaving them in a vegetative state. People start going down all over with missing facial traits so Mac and Barrons(reluctantly) decide to help with the case, especially when it hits close to home with Mac. In this one we get a bit of back story with the Unseelie King and how he was tinkering around with trying to find the song of making for his beloved concubine. Once upon a time the UK and the Fear Dorcha were companions... then it all changed. At the back of the book in the spoiler section it mentions something interesting about Barrons. Supposedly because of Barrons ultimate freedom, he is the Unseelie King in the making. Which raises the question, since the UK abdicated his rule, does that mean Barrons will be the next Unseelie ruler? We also learn something about Mac that I had a feeling about but was uncertain of until the Fear Dorcha looked at her. When the Fear Dorcha looks at Mac he sees her with big black feather wing. Which means that somehow, be it by eating Unseelie flesh, having survived her brutal gang-rape and pri-ya time which includes an unfathomable overdose of fae magic by Unseelie Princes for hours. Not to mention the many months Barrons, the Unseelie King in the making, was using his unknown magics on her to regain her sanity, has turned her into the only Unseelie Princess. Did Barrons somehow change Mac into an Unseelie Princess? He can destroy them, so if he really wanted to, could he create one? I would say it's highly likely. In the Character notes, it states that Jericho has wanted Mac since the beginning and that he has been ruthlessly altering her to make her suitable for him. Perhaps that is foreshadowing that he means for her to change not just on a mental/emotionl level, but on a physiological level as well. I think he wants a she beast who likes to shack up in the swamp! Earlier in the books Cruce wasn't taunting Mac when he called her Princess, he knew that she had changed into one. Just like Cruce being the only UP to have wings because he was the first, so does Mac for she is truly the first Unseelie Princess. Hot Damn! As the art in the book goes, it looks really good! I like the different or perhaps true take on what everything looks like, but in my head quite a few things look waaaayyyy different. This comic won't change my mind but it was refreshing to see what someone else envisioned. The only complaint I have with the art is that all the female faces look pretty much exactly the same. The guys look a bit constipated too but other than that it's good! Overall I found it to be enjoyable! Has some nice back story. Plus Barrons. Need I say more? It's definitely worth checking out!

Series review: This was very fast-paced and an engaging read; I could not put it down! I loved how strong and courageous Yuri was, and I loved how dedicated Kail was to her. This had a good cast of characters, and the author wasn't afraid to kill one of them off, if it fit the plot. Also, the last volume is mostly an extended epilogue. Yay for epilogues! Some complaints: -How come pretty much everything bad that happened to the couple could be traced to Nakia? There were plenty of things in their lives and relationship that would cause trouble for them; it didn't need to always be a plot by Nakia. But defeating her did give the story a great climax at the end in a way it couldn't have if she wasn't the whole story's villain. I just got sick of "Oh, no! It's Nakia's black water!" all the time. -How in the world was a 16 or 17 year old girl (who had lived an average, peace-filled life for 15 of those years, and had never had any military/strategy training) fit to be the commander of an army? I could see her being the motivational leader of the army ("Yes! We can do this because Ishtar supports us!") but not the actual leader of an army that has to fight (& win) major battles with the armies of other countries. This seemed completely ridiculous to me. -I wish there had been more about the culture and land this takes place in. This focused much more on the romance and political -In typical manga/anime fashion, Yuri could fix at lot the trouble she got into (although not all of it, thankfully) by being feisty and a compelling speaker. To which I say: Really? I would think politicians are used to smooth-talkers.

I'm going to be honest: I didn't go into this book expecting too much. I truly expected that it would be almost completely devoid of substance, whether that substance be negated by overuse of humor or overemphasis on an exciting plot. I could not have been more wrong. Certainly there was humor, and there was an exciting plot, but both of these served the greater purpose of exemplifying the resilience and overall altruism of humanity. The following quote isn't necessarily a "spoiler" per se (it is essentially a sumation of the theme found on the final page), but I'll hide it just in case. ...every human being has a basic instinct to help each other out. It might not seem that way sometimes, but it's true. I'll admit, it did give me pause to find that the broad theme was explicitly stated on the final page (definitely seems like a red flag), but, to my surprise, it actually works! It works for the same reason it works throughout the entire book: The sections written as logs by Mark Watney follow something of a stream of consciousness structure, and thus directly shows his own realistic realizations! I would explain that specific issue further, but it would definitely spoil the ending as if we didn't already know how it was going to end . So, instead let's examine Watney's humor. For about the first third of the book, I loved it. It was dry--it was ridiculous--it was pleasing to me. After that it began getting a little old. I've realized that there's more to it than simply how much I laughed, however. It's more about how much Watney laughed. It is just another illustration of the human spirit. This assertion may seem difficult to believe, even ridiculous, if not for the fact that Watney exhibited other emotions as well. In fact, he proved to be a rather multi-dimensional character with the humor as simply a mechanism to suppress these feelings and make the best of a terrible situation. Furthermore, all [most, rather] of the logs written by Watney would have been written a short amount of time after the fact--after he'd had time to collect himself. The setting also gives opportunity to so many possibilities--extreme isolation/loneliness, hopelessness, self-reflection, etc. Weir effectively touched upon all of these without making melodramatic garbage! Furthermore, there is the broad range of emotions of those on Earth and the other members of the crew. And in addition, it is an interesting plot! It is somehow eventful despite the amount of downtime and "technical description." The problems and solutions are intriguing, "out there," and yet somehow realistic and believable. I cannot believe I'm saying this, but holy buckets there was so much suspense (despite the fact that everyone knows how the book ends). It was just wonderful. Naturally, there were some instances where it didn't work. A lot of the plot twists/solutions were rather sudden and coincidental. A lot of the humor in the latter half of the group was rather "eh." A lot of the information (not to mention the themes) seemed rather spoon-fed to the reader (if I had a nickle for every time I read a phrase resembling "Hey, remember this detail that I touched upon a couple of pages back? Did you catch that because that's about to become important now!"). Having finished the book, though, I found all of this somehow very forgivable. All things considered, I'm hovering around a four and a half stars. I really want to say five stars, but I just can't quite bring myself to do it. Nonetheless, I absolutely recommend this to just about anybody. It was enjoyable, and it essentially lifted me from a month-long reading slump. What more can I really say? I just really liked it for some reason.

"Seven half-bloods shall answer the call, To storm or fire the world must fall. An oath to keep with a final breath, And foes bear arms to the Doors of Death." I just want to say that I think solangelo is beautiful, and that even though the finale was a bit unsatisfying (mostly because I am a very bias person who just wanted more Persassy Jackson and was denied) Nico's confession scene remains one of my favorite scenes ever. Also, the 'not my type' memes? HILARIOUS. Nico is beautiful, Nico is wonderful, Nico is my everything. also can we just talk about the fact that Percy freaking Jackson, one of the greatest heroes of all the greatest heroes, literally wakes up the mothereffing Earth because of a nosebleed?? I died. Only Percy Jackson. *slow clap* That is all. Now I can finally start Trials of Apollo! "Our desires reveal us. They show us for who we really are."

Blood-Kissed Sky picks up where Darkness Before Dawn left off. Dawn wakes up to find that her world has changed, although not in the way that she'd expected. I think she was upset that she didn't wake up a vampire after feeding Victor. The events during the teen party she organized, in an effort to get more blood donations, have had the opposite effect. Now, she's hopping on the night train for LA in an attempt to learn more about the Taint and the Day Walkers. She believes she's going alone, so she's a bit surprised when she finds some stowaways have tagged along. "As the world turns, vampires fear the day, and humans fear the night. But we Day Walkers fear nothing. And soon, they will all fear us." Dawn has a tendency to jump into any dangerous situation without fear for herself. She's the first to jump in front of her friends and take all the risks herself. Admirable, but she doesn't think before she acts. Never the less, she has an uncanny ability when it comes to fighting vamps. Her relationships with Michael and Victor are changing. I'd hoped for more interaction with Victor, considering his new position. But, I liked how Dawn & Victor now share a unique connection. I really like the post-vamp/human-war world that Rachel and her son (together they use the pseudo J.A. London) have created, however there are aspects of the books that feel bumpy to me and much of the story is predictable. Each book ends with a bit of a cliffhanger, which keeps me coming back. Although I can probably guess where the story is going, I look forward to reading the final book in the trilogy, After Daybreak, later this year to see how they will wrap things up.

"When the world owed you nothing, you demanded something of it anyway." Inej Inej Inej, I will miss you girl! 4.5 stars I am surprised by how much I liked this sequel. In fact, I like it enough to now look back at Six of Crows with nothing but fondness. I don't care that 17-year-olds are mafia kings anymore. They are Kaz and Inej to me, I am invested and how! Every time I picked up this novel in metros and buses, time sped up and slowed down, I was transported to Ketterdam following this ragtag crew and their narrow escapes. I was so satisfied with the ending, the things that were resolved and those that weren't. I wonder if anyone else was reminded of Lisbeth Salander in the Pekka Rollins episode. I am selfishly glad that the only casualty involved Matthias and Nina, two characters I didn't care about much anyway. It was a bit random though as if the author felt compelled to kill at least one character to raise the stakes. Overall this duology was such a pleasure to read and experience. Now that both the books are here, I definitely recommend a reading marathon.

No,no,just no. i don't know why i always come back to young adult fiction even though i almost always get disappointed. maybe because of the obvious reason that i'm young or that i did not read many fiction books during my teen years. whatever it is, the fault is mine. the thing about Maggie stiefvater is that she is good at romance. she's good at making up romantic yet cool dialogues, what she is not good at is the other stuff you expect in a paranormal or fantasy book. i mean after four books she could have tried to juice it up a little( i don't like this phrase but can't think of anything else at the moment, flashback to Joey Tribbiani: "juice this puppy up a little!") things were not slow in this book although it wouldn't have bothered me if they were, but they were not intriguing either. i kept on reading these books because let's be fair they have some good parts and i like the characters and their development, but if you're reading a book only because of its characters or even one favorite character and you can't seem to care about where the story is going, the writer is not doing a good job. speaking of our raven boys: i should give credit to Stiefvater. the boys are fun and interesting and even a little bit mysterious( still only Ronan comes to mind) , but as i mentioned, their mysteries are not enough for a whole book and not even near enough for a final installment. all this search for Glendower and that pathetic excuse of a dead body at the end? now the romance parts: i hate it when an author makes us wait such a long time for something as little as a kiss and finally goes like: and they kissed!! that's it? really? there was such a hype around the quote :" i wrote two kisses in this book", well i have to say you did not do a very good job of manifesting them. even if we look past the Ronan/Adam parts that were somehow better, the parts about Gansey and blue were disasters, i barely got a small "Aw" out of me during the whole book. all things considered, this book was just okay and that is only because i refuse to think of it as anything other than romance. not satisfying at all.

Seriously guys, this story is sooo intriguing. I never read anything like it before and I fell in love within the first few pages. The main character of this book is Alice. THE ALICE, who put herself into an Asylum in order to get hold of her sanity, after the events that occurred in Wonderland. She receives a job offer from a man called Van Brunt who brings her to New York in the 21st century and introduces her to the Collectors' Society. A group that tries to protect the worlds living in famous books. In order to find the ones that want to destroy her precious Wonderland she has to slip into different literature worlds together with the help of her new partner Finn, or better known to people as Huckleberry Finn. Throughout the book we get to meet different characters that we know from famous literature and I'M SO EXCITED to be continuing with this series I'm not even kidding. I NEED THAT NEXT BOOK NOW. Alice is such a kick ass heroine and Finn. FINN. Omg I don't even want to start.... I do wish that they would have travelled through more worlds though. Just Mansfield Park and Alice's Adventures In Wonderland seems too little for me but I'm sure we'll see more of that in the next few books. I CAN'T WAIT GUYS.

Actual Rating: 2.5 stars I picked up this book because I thought it would be related to greek mythology, which I love, especially Poseidon. Although, it had nothing to do with that, I still enjoyed this book. It had mermaids or Syrenas or whatever you want to call them. After my obsession and years of wanting to be a mermaid, I would say that I love them almost as much as Greek mythology. The plot was interesting. Anna Banks managed to create another world and perspective for her readers. That being said, this book was very...strange. I wasn't really feeling the characters in this book. In my opinion, the characters, besides the plot, are the most important part of the story. They should be likable and easy to relate to. The only two characters I actually liked were Toraf, who was a minor character, and Chloe, who died in the first few chapters. Emma was too emotional and rash. She didn't really handle the given situations well, with the exception of Chloe and the shark. She often let the her anger get the best of her. I mean, I have a horrible temper too, but you don't see me throwing people out hurricane-proof glass walls. I'd say that's a little too far. She got upset over some little, irrelevant things. However, I did like her feisty attitude. She had some standards and managed to make me laugh. I disliked Rayna for pretty much the same reasons as Emma. She was too impulsive and rude. She treated Toraf like trash in the beginning. That would have been somewhat understandable if she didn't like him, but she did...so she was hurting him on purpose. Galin was alright. His hatred to the human race in the beginning was kind of a turn off, but he kind of grew on me as the book went on. I kind of expected the twist at the ending. With all the hints in the book, it became kind of obvious. Still, I'm definitely interested to see how the next book plays out.

Brandon Sanderson does it again. He completely blew me away with the ending. I can never see things coming in his stories. This book was pretty plain overall, but damn that ending! Everything connected so perfectly in the end and I feel so bad for Wax. Poor, poor fella. A good sequel but Alloy of Law was better. This book contained more references to original trilogy than the previous one. There were also some old characters that returned. Nostalgia was strong in this one. Even so,  I'm so disappointed in Sazed for what he did to Wax. If it were Vin or Kelsier instead, I would've expected it. But I could never expect such kind of ruthlessness from Sazed. He knows better than anyone how it feels to lose your beloved, and yet he put Wax in the dark regarding Lessie. And Lessie, oh I can't put it into words how shocked I was to find out that she was actually a Kandra and the villain. Wax was justified to lose it there.
