I'd be surprised if Wax ever recovers from this kind of betrayal. Steris really grew on me in this book and I think she will make a good wife for Wax. Of course if it were up to me I would still go for Marasi and Wax, but lets be realistic, it could never work out between them. Marasi lives a dangerous life and if anything happened to her during her duty, Wax would again think it was his fault. Plus there is that age difference. No, Steris is nice and they would make a good couple. Branden is following the same strategy with villains as he did in original trilogy. What with each villain being stronger than the one in previous book. Lets see how Wax unfolds the mysteries around him. I have a feeling his family has more secrets than his uncle lets on. Its a good thing next book is coming this month. Can't wait to read it.

Rating: 4 Stars I enjoyed reading this more than the first installment, because of the suspense surrounding it! There are only 4 things that I didn't like by the way: first, Katy, dear, DEE doesn't deserve to be treated that way :(((( ; second, WHY DID THEY LET BLAKE (I hate Blake btw) GO AWAY WTF ; third, Katy was kinda annoying?! Yeah I totally get her why she'd rather do some things her own way, but she easily believed Blake? She should've stopped talking to him right after that knife throwing incident  and lastly, Daemon should've went after Will  . I swear, I want to pay attention to my other books but this series won't let me. I can't wait to read the third one x What I liked the most The Story - totally okay. The unexpected turn of events, as well! In here, we learn more about Bethany and Dawson too.

I did a re-read of the first one, and was SO ready to hide in this book for a few hours, and hallelujah Keira Andrews did it again. The first one was a big surprise for me, the premise was weird, BUT awesome. This one starts up on the boat and Parker is really growing up and becoming an AWESOME character. (He wasn't that bad in the first one, but he acted more entitled and he was kinda all over the place, until they came to the resort) Here Parker is strong, capable, a 'reasonable' voice and cautious (in the GOOD way in a freaking zombie apocalypse). And Adam, OOOHHHH Adam is just wonderful! (And thankfully a werewolf!) I think they make an awesome couple in this book, and they work together without too much drama. (Yes, there are discussions/fights, but I think that makes it more real) None of them have more power, they are equal, and I think that works really well, they complement each other. They meet Craig, Abby, Lily and Jacob when they rescue them (I love Parker's irritation with people trying to survive the apocalypse by being on a boat, when they can't handle it. That is freaking funny) And they become a sort of family, even though it is really hard for Parker to trust anybody after the resort (in book one) and the attack on the boat when Adam was on a supply-run! I loved what Craig and Abby added and I hope that Jacob will get a book of his own, I think he could be an awesome MC This is very much a zombie/apocalypse/horrible world. And for fans of 'The Walking Dead' I think this will be a hit, but beware: there is fisting, which was tasteful (as much as that can be), sex where Adam is half-shifted and an assault on the boat where I really feared for Parker  There is also love, a developing mature/adult relationship and being a team for each other and other people. They make it to Salvation Island, and the Island is written like it can be AWESOME, but also like you don't know what's going to happen. I got a vibe from Connie and Bethany, and it will be really nice to see where the 'world' is going to end up. I don't know if it's because I really sympathize with Parker, or if Keira Andrews is really, really good at creating tension. But IMO the Island could hold some secrets! I am really REALLY looking forward to book 3. I am very excited to see where this is going, and book 3 will be pre-ordered as soon as possible!

I said the previous book in this series was the first one that I didn't immediately think was better than the one before it. Well, by that standard this book got things back on track. This volume has all the things I love about the series: Interesting use of previous characters, Morgan and Dresden being forced to work together to prove Morgan's innocence, and good use of the Alphas  development of the Black Council story line, although the reveal of the secretary as the bad guy was a little anticlimactic, and this arc really needs to start moving faster  and new supernatural threats the skinwalker . I really don't know how well the author has plotted out the whole series, but it feels very cohesive to me. This has got to be the longest series I've read where I can still say that. Certainly keeps me coming back for more.

Another book from that Humble Bundle that had a bunch of Simon and Schuster YA books. This book was OK. Not my cup of tea, but not bad. As I said in my status updates, Ms Black is pretty good at subverting my expectations. I'll get back to this in a moment. For someone who could not really care less about "the fey" as fairies are apparently called, especially if they're spelled "faerie", I've ended up with a lot of fey books via various bundles. So there are lots of tropes I'm not familiar with, like the fact that faeries are apparently deathly allergic to iron. Why is that? Does it have to do with why we don't see faeries now? Because of the iron age of humans? Luckily, this book was written for people were a little less familiar because it explained things like changelings, kupies, and the iron allergy. Between reddit, Goodreads, and other forums, I've seen a lot of debates about adults reading YA. Frankly, I think a good story is a good story. My current position (subject to change with experience and age) is that the only annoying thing about YA can be the fact that the older you, the less tolerance you have for teenage BS. My traditional example is rooting for Ariel in Disney's Little Mermaid as she rebels against the authoritarian regime of her father's rule vs watching as an adult and realizing she's a spoiled little brat who's lucky as eff she doesn't end up dead or sexually used and abused. What's often neat about YA, by contrast, is that it's often pushing the boundaries of storytelling. Adult fiction is so staid...so risk-averse like the movie industry. Meanwhile in YA we have lots of women protagonists, people of color, LGBT people, etc. Unlike Middlegrade books, the characters can also be a little more realistic and a little less black and white in terms of morality. This often leads me to have some caveats on my reviews when it comes to the fact that some parents are more liberal and some are more conservative. Some authors are like - YA == teens and teens have sex so everyone needs to be boning. When it comes to this book - I have to say that I disagree slightly with Jilly's (a GR friend) review. While this book's main character (Kaye) is not a good role model for teens, I have some hopes for her as a character. What are her flaws: she actively skips school, she smokes, she relishes the attention her best friend's boyfriend gives her and does not stop him from kissing her. All very mild by YA standards. But I think there isn't much glamorized about her faults and even Kaye is often disappointed at where she is in life. No goodie-two-shoes kid is going to read about Kaye and decide to be like her. What I do hope is that if some kid who's on the same track as Kaye reads this book they can see themselves in the character and perhaps become life-long readers (which will serve them well in life) and/or change course. Of course, there's also option 3 - a kid who's never going to act like Kaye, but can live vicariously through her. Just like I don't have any misconceptions about the evils of killing, but it can be fun to act in cartooney violence in Team Fortress 2. So, let's get to the story itself. The story initially sets itself up the same way as Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland. Kaye used to play with faeries as a kid, but hasn't seen them since her family moved out of Jersey. Her mom is in a band, rather than perhaps asking the grandma to watch over Kaye (or some other stabilizing situation) turns her into a roadie. So Kaye becomes a bad girl...although, as I said above, VERY TAME compared to the kids I knew in school. Sure, I ran with the goodie-two-shoes kids, but I had friends all over school and if even half of what they claimed to do was true at the time, Kaye's pretty mild. Shoot, she doesn't even do drugs, she just smokes. Things go awry and Kaye and her mom move back to Jersey to temporarily live with grams. Kaye hooks back up with her literal trailer park friend and they get up to teenage mischief, including going to an abandoned building where Kaye almost gets raped by her friend's boyfriend. The faeries make an appearance and we learn that Kaye wasn't just making things up as a kid. I'm going to stop here in case you actually want to read the book. Because Ms Black has quite a few twists and turns that were entertaining for someone like me that is such a trope nerd, he barely ever gets surprised watching TV or movies. I think a good book subverts my expectations at least once. This book does it multiple times, including one almost Fight Club-level twist. (I'll admit some of this could be due to me not being a fey nerd) What things did I really like that aren't spoilery: -There's a gay character who isn't a stereotype. In fact, until he reveals that he's gay there's nothing to betray that fact. I'm of the opinion that when it comes to non-standard characters (non-white, middle class male) what's best is to have a character that is in most ways no different than a standard character except for a few things that are informed by the difference. For example, an African American character doesn't have to have ghetto-speak or even come from the wrong side of the tracks. But perhaps, especially in today's environment, he could have a slightly heightened suspicion of authority. The gay character in this book is like that. There are some things that are informed by the fact that he's gay, but he's not a walking stereotype. -Kaye feels very conflicted about her near rape. I'm not female bodied, so I'll never had the same understanding of rape as a woman, but from what I've heard, some girls/women end up feeling extremely conflicted about the emotions and bodily reactions. Some feel weird or shamed or guilty if some part of them enjoyed it or even feel betrayed if their body was willing (I'm going to leave it there to not get too explicit here) and Kaye is no exception. Especially because the rape doesn't happen and her teenage hormones, it makes sense. -Related to that, I like that Kaye feels unsure of how she's reacting with her best friend's bf. I think this can persist into adulthood (to a stronger or weaker degree depending on the person), but as a teen, it can be hard in the moment to override hormones, desire, etc if someone's in your personal space. Since the guy is actively going after her rather than the opposite, it makes it even more complicated. She's not doing anything to make this guy pursue her so there's less guilt compared to if she was actively trying to steal her friend's man. Also, given her nomadic lifestyle and self-described weirdness, maybe she's extra jonesing for some intimacy because she hasn't had much/any? -Again, without getting into spoilers, I really like that there's a lot more shades of grey with the motivations of many characters, especially the fey. I get this is a bit of trope with fey fiction, but other than the one Discworld novel that dealt with faeries, I'm not used to them being anything but Tinkerbells. Wow, this review really ballooned beyond where I thought it would go when I started writing. So, who do I recommend this to? If you're an adult who's not REALLY into YA, it might be a bit too kiddie for you. But if you really like YA and like faerie/fey stuff, jump right in. If you're a teen - it's going to depend on whether you're into faerie stuff and/or Kaye's life seems authentic or not to your experience. If you're a parent - I personally think this is one of the mildest YA books I've read in terms of objectionable stuff. (Shoot, the kids I grew up with who went to church 3 times a week did more sexually than Kaye does) I'd only avoid if you're one of those super religious people who don't let their kids read Harry Potter. If your kids are less than teenage, but advanced at reading - you might want to have an open dialogue or offer an open dialogue with your kid so they can talk about anything that makes them uncomfortable. Although Kaye and someone she ends up in bed with don't do anything other than kiss - there is the fact that she's sharing the bed with someone she's attracted to. Also, there is the death of one of her peers

Forget hype , I always love when a book lives up to its cover. I really loved this book, I found the MC to be interesting and relatable. This book does contain a few overdone YA stereotypes (i.e Love Triangles, Insta-Love and "The One" MC) however none of that was an issue for me. I never really have a problem with love triangles, altough I do prefer for even contenders, which was not the case here. Although really if there had been more than one guy who  didn't hit women in the face  perhaps the battle for Kricket's heart would have been more even. I thought that the world building was pretty cool although it was a little odd how some things were exactly the same as Earth ( like courting customs) and yet the technology was completely different. I guess when I picture aliens, I don't think of chaise lounges and eighteenth century etiquette. Overall though, I did have fun with Kricket on her journey and cant wait to find out what happens next. Buy, Borrow or Bin Verdict: Buy (unless you hate the above YA cliches) Note: I received this book for free in exchange for an honest review.

I'm really struggling with what to make of this book. Based on the synopsis and genre it should be something I really got into but there is just something off with it. The writing isn't terrible, although reading some of it did really stretch even my cheese tolerance  like this "Brent was holding me in his arms. When I closed my eyes, it felt like he was physically next to me and I was in his warm embrace." Or this gem "Its leaves blazed with color that could have inspired a sonnet; I wished I were a poet and could capture its beauty in words." but I couldn't shake the feeling that the book felt like a story written by a 16 year old for creative writing homework. While the book was very, very descriptive and clearly attempted to create a strong atmosphere I felt lost quite often with what was going on, the story jumping suddenly from describing how wonderful the landscape was to  a hurried battle. I could never quite connect with the characters properly. Especially Yara; it didn't feel like enough of her background was explained or what being a Waker actually meant. I found it difficult to care that she was embarrassed by this "crazy" part of her family or  how hot she constantly finds Brent - really it was no surprise whatsoever when they admit their feelings for each other. The love story actually felt really frustrating and disjointed. With Brent  obviously his character changed after Thomas took over but he never felt fully explored either. Thomas' real back story and the story of Pendrel also feel unfinished It may be that almost all my negative points are due to in part because this is the first part of a trilogy so things won't be explained fully in just 290 pages. But I'm not sure I found this book interesting enough to actually carry on the series, which is not something I say often because I tend to hate leaving trilogies and book series unfinished. I'm still unsure, I want to like it...but there is just something holding me back from giving it a full 3 stars, unfortunately Goodreads don't allow half points so on record it's roughly a 2.5 but I'm giving it 3 stars on here, maybe it deserves the benefit of the doubt.

Ok, I liked this book, but I give it 3 stars for the sake that there was way too much convenience in the story. I spent the whole book hoping that Sage was not really the crown prince in disguise, and was disappointed in this. It all felt too contrived at the end with everything coming together in a nice and neat ending perfectly tied with a bow. I felt tricked that the author hadn't allowed the reader into the confidence that Sage and Jaron were the same person and felt the need to make it such a ham-fisted reveal towards the end of the book. The way that she would leave out large chunks of the story and then later conveniently make them work out in such nice and convenient ways was just too hard to look past to me. The big reveal at the end of the book was too contrived, too convenient, and rather cliche. That being said, I did enjoy it for purely escapist reasons. This is a great middle school aged read. I think kids will enjoy it immensely as it has some good intrigue and is a good way to introduce characters to such thing as an unreliable narrator (that sometimes switches to an omniscient 3rd person which is kinda sloppy on the part of the author, but it is minimal and thus forgivable), as well as some fairly decent moral issues. The bad guys are a little 2 dimensional, but there are some times when you're not sure who the real bad guy is, which is something that can drive you along. Sage is a fairly good character, but he's too smug and has waaaay too much figured out for a 15 year old... but again, that's forgivable for the sake of the story's progression. That's the main thing that bothered me, Sage is never surprised for any real length of time, he's able to outwit everyone with absolute ease, as if he has a sense of prescience that allows him to know exactly what will happen and again is never surprised when things go exactly how he foresaw and is able to roll with the punches way better than a person who's gone through as much emotional turmoil and suffered abandonment issues and other horrible things that our hero has undergone. For all the tragedy and awful abandonment that he's gone through, Sage is amazingly well adjusted and entirely too trusting of people around him. Again, though this review doesn't really show it, I did enjoy the book. I felt that it had some merit and it taught some good morals and was definitely worth my time to read it, and I plan to read the subsequent sequels as well. Its' apparent flaws are mostly absolved when you realize that this was a book meant for very young adults and, when read on that level, is a very enjoyable read. This felt like I was reading a book written by the writers of a Disney Channel special, enjoyable and fun but not much substance.

This was fun and cute, with a town of dog shifters led by their Border-collie sheriff, Lance, trying to figure out what's up with new all-human arrival Tim. Tim gets into town smelling of marijuana, with no money, only a few seeds and tools, and a lie about his name. In the isolated small town, the possibility he's going to grow pot is strong, and Lance feels compelled to investigate. A lot. Often. Sometimes in Border-collie form. Maybe the compulsion comes from something other than his suspicions about young, geeky and perplexing Tim. I enjoyed their interactions, and I could see some readers loving the fun of this one. I had a few chuckles from it, and it was a smooth, easy light read. I'm a bit picky about shifter stories. I want to believe the paranormal ones, or have a magic wild enough to wash away the need for belief. This humorous story was set firmly in the contemporary, and required suspension of belief in many ways, not least the fact that "quickened" dogs somehow became adult humans with a full vocabulary and understanding of the human world, and without arousing suspicions...  ... whatever. Suspend. I'm awful at that, and it was a distraction. Lance was hot, Tim was sweet, the secondary characters were almost the best part of the book, and there were some fun little touches to the dog-component of the story. I did enjoy it. But it's not an Easton I'll reread. I bet opinions will vary, because humor is, I think, tougher to capture universally than angst or sweetness.

I love magic and superpowers, but I'm not a fan of historical fiction and that's why it was crowding my tbr shelf for so long. The MC Evie is painfully stupid, she did all the dumbest things trying to call attention and drained all my energy with her idiocy. The love square is ugly. Mabel, Jericho, Evie, Sam I want more superpowers and there is a sequel, but I'm not in a hurry to read it. The audiobook is good and saved my sanity through this long book.

Pure and simple, this was mind-drillingly boring. I felt like a high-schooler again, forcing myself through just to say I finished. Although I've always been a book lover, I was a pretty poor student of literature in high school because the significant but torturously dull classics I was forced to read weren't even of my own choosing. I was having flashbacks to senior year with D.H. Lawrence. "I've got to read 20 more pages tonight because teacher said so, but I don't wanna!" Constant checking to see "How much longer?" Crossing my fingers that "The next book I read has to be better than THIS." So bored that I couldn't even carry the plot sometimes, and had to go back and figure out what had just happened. Basically, my attitude towards this book (before, during, and after reading it) is that of a petulant teenager. Given how much I liked Out of the Silent Planet, I'm genuinely stunned that I one-starred book three of the same trilogy almost on boringness alone. When a book is so dull as to fail to retain even a shred of interest from [this] reader, how can it even hope to engender any remarks about thematic material or allegorical messages? I mean, I recognize that they were there but given that they failed to scrape a second star for That Hideous Strength it almost feels like a waste of my time to go into it because obviously they weren't compelling or well-framed enough to take this poor book from one star to two. But as I said, this book makes me feel moody and combative. It was probably doomed as soon as this trilogy took the linguistic fascination I had in "Out of the Silent Planet", reduced it to intriguing but flawed biblical allegory in "Perelandra", and turned the lens inward to Earth for "That Hideous Strength". As soon as I knew the focus of this book was staying on Earth, I knew we were gonna get into heavy morals and WWII commentary. Once the story didn't offer me any more than a bear with a hilarious name, the Space Trilogy lost be completely. As for the "Fairy Tale" byline, that's pretty genuinely confusing to me, unless we're looking to imply that there's a moral to the story and it's nine-tenths about gruesomely punishing the wicked. Love thy neighbor, lest ye be stomped to death by an elephant.

4 Stars. Frostblood was a fun read, with lots of adventure, drama, a little dash of romance and a dark undertone with really made this book fascinating. Certainly, I was reminded often of other elemental and blood-linked magic books (I'm looking at you, Red Queen), but this didn't hamper my enjoyment of the book at all, and in fact, made me like it more. The focus on two elemental powers was interesting - Frostbloods and Firebloods - and I have a feeling this world will be expanded on in future books. The real strength in Frostblood is the constant action and big build up to the arena stuff in Part 2 (yeah, which reminded me of Red Queen again). Something was always happening, and I found it really intriguing to read as the characters were thrown again and again into more dire situations. The arena scenes in particular where both harrowing and empowering, especially as the level of cruelty is explored properly and thoughtfully and not condoned or simply utilized as a plot point, referring to the violent entertainment of Ancient Rome. How the author revealed the mythology was really fascinating and unusual  absolutely adored how this was achieved for the reader - yes, Ruby already knew, but revealing it through the scene with Ruby running away and overhearing a camp of people telling the children the stories was great. Further, that this then resulted in Ruby returning to fulfil her responsibilities was extra wonderful   and whilst I won't deny it was a bit of an information dump, I didn't overly mind it at all. That being said, it was a little hard to keep track of all the names and such, even with only two elements in play. I also really appreciate that this story arc is completed fully, and that a new arc will begin in the next book, rather than a full, blown-out cliff-hanger. I love cliff-hangers, but it makes for a nice change. The characters were all interesting, especially the MC, Ruby. She was wild and passionate, like her fire powers, but whilst I won't deny I found her a little abrasive at the start, she grew on me and I really felt her emotional struggles at the end. Arcus was suitably mysterious and grumpy, and the other characters managed to become favourites even with short page time. Brother Thistle and Marella certainly became favourites. The romance was a hate-to-love relationship, and I can't help it, I always love those relationships. At the start, the hate between Arcus and Ruby felt a little overdone, but then suddenly it clicked and I was so happy for them to get together. Sure, there was a little wobble and hint of a love triangle, but I wouldn't even consider it a love triangle at all. I can't wait to read more about their love unfolding. Frostblood was fascinating, had a strong MC, romance, magic and lots of fight scenes, and would certainly be a favourite for reader's who love Red Queen, Burning Glass, Air Awakens, Snow Like Ashes or any other elemental magic stories. I can't wait to for the next instalment! *Thank-you to Hachette Australia and Net Galley for this ARC. I received this ARC in exchange for an honest review*

Reads like the novelization of a Michael Bay movie. Like Transformers, but admittedly much better. The standard elements of a made-for-teen-boys Michael Bay film are there, however. The absurdly hot girl love interest who is also absurdly bitchy. The awkward teen boy, who despite being awkward is also a bit of a Larry Stu, loved by the good guys and possessing mad skillz. Secondary characters who are quickly sketched archetypes: the plucky comic relief; the sage warrior; the tech wizard; the team leader with a mysterious past. The story gives itself a convenient "out," with regard to characterization, stating that team members shouldn't know much about each other because of the risk of capture and death. There are big explosions and car chases and all things action-y, and yet, in order to keep the story PG-rated, expletives are limited to made-up (and lame, lame, lame) words like "sparks" or "Calamity." Of course, unlike Bay, Sanderson doesn't seem to be intentionally and overtly serving his audience a shit sandwich, and laughing as they dig into the brown, gooey feast. Steelheart has heart, just not enough to overcome its obvious yearnings to be a feature film. The premise is cool. About a decade before, a strange light/star called Calamity showed up in the sky and soon after, ordinary humans started to develop super powers. Along with great power, these Epics acquired an inclination for megalomania. Basically, all the suped-up humans became supervillains. A few people, The Faithful, believe that a good Epic will someday save the day. Steelheart begins in a bank building in Chicago, where a much-younger David and his father are about to have a fateful encounter with Steelheart, an invincible Epic who can transform non-living substances to steel. The encounter leaves nearly everyone in the building, including David's father, dead, but not before David's father somehow wounds Steelheart. "I've seen Steelheart bleed." Through a bit of dumb luck, David survives and grows up in the transformed world of the Epics, where chaos reigns, and where what little order that exists is due in part to Steelheart's iron grip (heh) on the city of Chicago. David carries the secret of Steelheart's possible Achilles's heel and is driven by the overwhelming desire to avenge his father's death. When word comes that The Reckoners, a shadowy group of freedom fighters who kill Epics, have come to town, David makes it his mission to joy them. As one might guess, he joins the team, meets Megan, the girl of his dreams, and stuff blows up in a manner that feels like something straight from a director's notes. It's fun. But it's also superficial. David falls into insta-lust with Megan, the supermodel gorgeous girl, who as per formula is perpetually bitchy and humorless. (Apparently, strong women can't be funny.) All the supporting characters are one-note but I found Megan's character especially annoying because his relationship with her drives his character arc. The relationship forces David to think about something (or someone) other than revenge. In short, it should deepen his characterization. Except Megan is utterly "bleh," and David's fixation no more than a teen crush, which gave me no reason to care about either character. In fact her death was a high point for me, because it meant the end of their painfully forced romance. And no more of Megan's two expressions: scowling or blank face. Anyway, despite my issues with this book, I haven't given up on Sanderson. Mostly because I have another of his novels on my Kindle. Bought it; must read it. My impression is that Steelheart isn't the best entry point into his writing.

My Rating: 4.5/5 stars I loved that Changeless shows what happens after the "happily ever after." Readers are given a pretty good look at what married life looks for Alexia and Maccon and let me tell you that it is just as steamy and full of bickering as their courtship. It is refreshing to go into a series where the romance ends in marriage in the first book, but the story continues and deals with some of the complications of married life. This is very much a side plot, so don't be worried that the romance completely takes over. THOUGH THAT ENDING!! I'm not going to lie and say that I didn't expect a baby at some point (because I have read Prudence), but I was a bit pissed at the way Maccon took it. What I really enjoy about this series is the way that plots to kill, spies, discoveries about the world/paranormals, and the etiquette of the time all interact. I just find it funny how Alexia doesn't really care if people are trying to kill her... everything is just handled in stride. It's like the dramatics are set aside (though they definitely still exist through Miss Hesslepenny) when the important things happen. And there are just so many twists and overlapping motives/plot lines. While some of the twisty elements were slightly predictable, others were surprising and sometimes the way things are revealed isn't exactly the way you might think it would be. As a series, these books have done a good job of wrapping up enough mysterious elements to be satisfied with how a book concluded, but then leaving enough things unresolved to be compelled to read the next book. Bottom Line: This series is so refreshing for me because while it isn't young adult (Alexia is in her later twenties), it is just as compelling to read as some of my favorite young adult series. I just love how the paranormal, historical fiction, steampunk, and romance all collide. It's definitely a genre bending kind of series, and I've loved every minute of it. I think it's the best kind of crossover book for adults who love YA, but would like a steamier book with an excellent urban fantasy plot.This review was originally posted on A Bottomless Book Bag

Okay, I'm going to start off this review by saying I'm a linguistics major (one of two majors) at uni. This means I know my basic phonetics, phonology, syntax, semantics, morphology, sociolinguistics, etc. I don't expect anyone else who has read this book to know any of the above, nor that they're a linguist themselves. So bear with me when I get to a certain part. Also, I apologise for the length of this review. You can tell me to shut up next time, guys. Shadow and Bone is about an orphan girl named Alina who has a special power that may help save Ravka from a section of darkness called the Shadow Fold (or the Unsea) that cuts across Ravka. Or in layman's terms: girl has special power, destined to save realm. I'm going to be reviewing this in sections (not because I have a lot to say for each, just so that I can collect my thoughts in some sort of cohesive manner). Alina Alina is an orphan who grows up under the guardianship of a duke, Keramsov, with a bunch of other orphans. I have minor issues with Alina, which I'll get to, but the biggest issue I have is that she is practically without personality. When I truly and honestly think about it, I can't really describe much about her because there isn't much to her, even though she's the "saviour" and whatnot. She's not really a character that I'm rooting for because I like her so much; I'm rooting for her because she's trying to do the right thing. Other problems I have: - Alina, though we are told wasn't treated that much different than a peasant and had to do chores at the Duke's house, pays zero attention to any of the servants when she is taken to the palaces. You'd think she'd feel badly for them or sympathize with them, but no and no. Basically, they don't exist for her, which is odd because she was in the same kind of position back in the day. - She also speaks her mind or with snark, even to people who rank much higher than her or are more powerful than her. Except she's also inconsistent with this. She's all fire-and-brimstone, let's-be-sardonic when it comes to the Darkling (who she has often said frightens her), but as soon as she's near the King and someone speaks ill of him, she's all, "Holy crap, that's treason!" WHAT. - Alina sometimes comes across as entitled, especially for an orphan who's ashamed of being an orphan. Sometimes she says things, and I'm just like, "Gurl, you should just be happy you have that, etc." - Finally, she's the weak and clumsy female protagonist that we always seem to get in mainstream YA these days. Of course, she's weak, tired and clumsy because she's been suppressing her power for her entire life and gets better when she finally lets it out, but still. And seeing how she's in the Army, I don't see how they could even let her serve with that kind of ineptitude. (I know she's a mapmaker, but they don't keep people who have no training/they train all the personnel.) Females Hoo, boy. There are three kinds of female characters in this book: the beautiful ones (who tend to be Grisha), the ones who want to be beautiful and try really hard to be with what is basically magical cosmetic surgery, and the (assumed) plain ones (because nothing about them is mentioned). The Beautiful Ones This group of ladies encompasses only the Grisha. Alina keeps telling us that only Grisha are sexy, sexy babes so she can't be because she is Plain Jane . Okay, but these pretty people are not only "special" because of their magical powers, they are also horrible. Zoya, a minor character who shows up a couple of times, is hot stuff, but she is only there to be disdainful and snobbish. We also have two female summoners who are also (in Alina's words) "snobbish" and talk shit behind people's backs. Alina seems to have no regard for these women, she is either jealous or spiteful or blase towards them. The Ones who Want to Be Beautiful This group consists of the Queen and her cronies lackeys handmaids? Whatever they are, they didn't think they were beautiful before so they got a Grisha to fix up their faces. These people are not fun either; typically envious of the beauty of others and force Genya (the Grisha that fixes them up) to only beautify them. The Plain Ones Who knows, we don't get to hear anything about them. They essentially aren't worth note, but I assume they're all genuinely nice people. The Exception We have one exception to the three categories of female characters here: Genya. She's naturally beautiful, but chooses to adjust her face with her own powers to perfect it. She's super sweet, confident, incredibly helpful and sassy in a fun way. She's Alina's BFF in the palace and  how nice that we're seeing a great person who also is beautiful. What a change! But guess what? Genya is in love with a gangly, lean dude and everyone hates her because she uses her powers to fix faces. Head-desk. The Darkling I am honestly confused as to what kind of vibe Bardugo was trying to give off with him. What I was getting up until chapter 14 was that he was an old (but still young-looking and hot), wise, mentor-type guy who felt like he was modeled after Dumbledore but failed at it. That's really what I thought. And then he flirted with Alina and groped her palm and kissed her and I was physically disgusted and mentally dry-heaved a bit. I've seen from some other reviews that people love this guy. I don't. Maybe because he wasn't the kind of character (villain)  that I like -- I like mine charismatic and crazy (basically, Loki or the Joker), but I would never want to make out with/bone either of them . Botkin Botkin is the weapons/combat trainer for the Grisha and he comes from the Shu Han (what is essentially Northern China/Mongolia). He is a goddamn caricature of an East Asian. Normally, I'm fairly used to East Asians portrayed as kung fu/karate geniuses and having bad accents in Hollywood or mainstream TV in North America -- though I do want to thank The Walking Dead for making Glen the complete opposite of that. I admit I've become complacent with it because it doesn't seem to be stopping anytime soon and getting riled up doesn't feel worth my time. (I should mention that although I have one of the whitest names of all time, I am in fact half-Chinese and have grown up with a large Chinese cultural influence.) I make an exception for Shadow and Bone because I can't even explain in ALL CAPS how much of a slap to the face this debasement was -- it depressed me more than it angered me. It made no sense: the Fjerdan characters (based on linguistic data, I'm guessing Scandinavian) could speak Ravkan with no problems, just a teeny accent. Botkin, the only real Shu Han character (if you can call him that), gets the choppy syntax and the shitty verb morphology. He's also seen as a brute. That is not okay. Writing Not too bad for a debut author, but some of the things I read should have been edited to hell and back. e.g. "The Apparat was looming over me, his flat black pupils lit with peculiar intensity." "The cold was like a hand, gripping my body in a relentless, icy grip as I tumbled through the water." I can see my TAs scribbling "awk" beside those. The last thing about the writing is the boo-urns tone shift at the beginning and end. The prologue and the epilogue are third-person and the main narrative is first-person, but the tone overall was so drastic a shift that I was like, "Huh? What? I don't know if I like this." I got used to it though, so it clearly wasn't that big a deal; it was just jarring. Linguist Says No In the Acknowledgements, Bardugo writes that she did some research on Russian culture because Shadow and Bone is based on it. I don't think she did enough, if at all. The fifth page in we get the first of her mistakes: Alina's last name. It's Starkov. I've never studied Russian nor do I know much about Russia, but even I know that female last names have -a endings. Because of this misstep, I decided to research a couple of things myself. I got this out of it: - Ilya, a name given to a lady (based on the last name -- which does have an -a ending -- what?!) is actually a male given name, meaning "My God is He". Just because it ends in -a doesn't mean it's automatically a female name. - kvas, I assume, is based on kvass and isn't classified as alcoholic because there is less than 1.2% alcohol. So why do the Ravkans get super drunk on it all the time? Wouldn't it just have been better to say they were downing vodka the whole time? (This leads me to mention that a lot of the Ravkans are straight-up stereotypes of Russians: drink a lot, dress for cold weather and prickly dudes.) - Russians from the interwebz have said that the name Ana Kuya, a super minor character, means "Why the fuck?" when pronounced. No Russian or speaker of Russian will ever take that seriously. (Upside, I know a Russian swear word now!) - Lastly, one Grisha is named Marie. Marie is not a normal Russian given name. There are like ten different variations of Mary in Russian (e.g. Maria, Marija, Marika, Mariya, Mura, Manya, etc. ), but Bardugo gave this character a predominantly Czech/Danish/Norwegian/German/French name. It sticks out like a sore thumb. (All my info came from a quick Google search.) The linguist in me weeps for this misuse of language. I know this won't bother those of you who don't speak/are not Russian or linguists, but it bothered me, so there you go. Things I Did Like Now, you may look at this lengthy, most likely boring review and say to yourself, "Why did you give it three stars since you wank on and on about it so much? Sounds like you hate it!" Well, you're wrong; I liked it. I thought the plot was good, I didn't think the story dragged (even though there was a large chunk of the book that was basically Harry Potter at Hogwarts)  and the main romantic interest was neither a douchebag nor (grossly) possessive. Huzzah! Actually, I really liked the romance (not the deflated love triangle that wasn't really a love triangle) . I thought it was cute and developed well. I still had some small problems with it, which I won't go into detail here, but I could bypass those easily. And I loved that the romance wasn't a central part of the story. The story was about Alina growing into her power and self, not some sappy, make-me-roll-my-eyes-until-they-fall-out kind of story. I also liked how it ended (even though I thought the ending was a little rushed). And it wasn't on some dumb cliffhanger! Nothing makes me happier than a book that wraps itself up even if the entire series plot arc isn't over. I know the last section is minimal compared to the above critiques, but there really isn't another way I can say I liked this book, problems and all. I can only say that I will definitely be reading the second one in this series and I'm crossing my fingers that it gets better and kicks more ass.

As someone who is watching the HBO series while reading Game of Thrones (A Song of Ice and Fire), I would recommend those who are just watching the show need to read the books as there are obvious differences - the books have a ton more characters so there are tweaks between what happens in the book compared to the show  different people die so when watching the show I would notice it but it didn't affect how good they are The one thing I thought that would annoy me would be the length of the descriptions but somehow the way GRRM writes them just further adds to atmosphere and makes it more realistic and easier to image and feel part of the world that is Game of Thrones (A Song of Ice and Fire).

At first, I was a little skeptical of the tone of the book because it just felt like a darker version of Good Omens. And it was to a certain extent (I can now more clearly divide the Pratchett whimsicality from the Gaiman somberness in that book). But it was definitely an independent entity that I found myself really enjoying. It almost felt like I was reading a cleverly entwined Stephen King plot, and that's something that I've never really experienced in a Gaiman book before. The concept behind the book was intriguing. Instead of gods being controlling, all-powerful beings, they're only strong when they have the faith of followers. Otherwise, they can weaken and even fall from existence given enough time and neglect. I thought it was really cool to also see how gods from various cultures were now being pitted against gods of the new world (e.g. media, internet, stock markets). Shadow was such a cool character - compliant and malleable but still strong willed and tenacious. I think he was a big reason that I enjoyed the book so much. Overall, it was just a really satisfying story with a nice balance between character development and plot escalation. There were a few small things that didn't tie up as nicely (Shadow gave one rousing speech and completely stopped the war that had been brewing for the whole book? Okay...)  but it was still really enjoyable.

Saw a brief mention about  John Scalzi inspiring a story from the line "unicorn bukkake"  and was intrigued. The result is a darkly humorous horror novella about Lovecraftian unicorns that won the Hugo last year. I also didn't realize this takes place in an established series, but found no barriers for newcomers. Nor have I ever heard/read of Cold Comfort Farm , so I missed those references, but definitely makes for a weird mashup.

I wasn't in love with Halo but I liked it enough to give Hades a try and I gotta say I'm happy I did! Hades was a much better story because the pacing was perfect. Things didn't move too fast and I found myself happy with Bethany's character. I must admit that things happening in Hades didn't really add up for me. The way Jake handled Bethany didn't seem right. He's a demon so I thought he would have done more to her, even if it was against her will. I also thought that Bethany being able to communicate with Xavier was really cute but it didn't seem like that should be happening and I thought it was kind of annoying that she could. Don't get me wrong I'm glad she could but I don't like it when the main characters always can do these extraordinary things. I remember reading a description that made me think I would judge Xavier's loyalty or not, but I honestly never did. I understand he got upset and Ivy and Gabriel had to set him straight sometimes, but I think for a teenage boy that's normal. What I was not expecting was the whole Gabriel and Molly thing. I'm really anxious to read about them in the Heaven! Overall, I found myself really liking the book and I liked that we got to see a lot more of Bethany's family, Ivy and Gabriel. They're nice characters to read about and I'm glad we learned more about them. I must say I definitely didn't see that ending coming and I don't really think it made sense - Xavier never acts so spontaneous like that. But it made me eager to find out what Heaven's all about!

A great addition to the Eugenides storyline! Full of the usual twists and turns you've come to expect from these books, I did guess some of them, but not others so there were still fun surprises to be had. It did not conclude the story though, so I imagine there will be another one along one of these years. ;) We once again get a view into what's happening in Attolia with the kind and queen, which is always nice, brief though it was. I liked seeing Eugenides holding court from Kemet's point of view and how he is making a reputation for himself among his own people for being so clever and ingenious. Much better than when they thought he was an idiot. I also liked how he finally worked out the sand in his food dilemma. It was interesting to learn more about the Mede Empire that we've had looming over the story for the last several books and to get some more insight into Kemet's character as well. I almost wondered if she was trying to do a romance thing with her bromance between the Attolian and Kemet given that I know she writes some novels with alternative lifestyles. There was enough there I think that if you were looking for that kind of romance you'd find it, but if you weren't you'd just assume they were good friends. I'm wondering who the mysterious "southern gentleman" was that kept helping them. Was it really Ennikar? I wasn't sure if he was a god or not... also liked how the god at the well said to Remember Ennikar and Pay the fastener...then the escaped slave who helped them was named Godeker which meant fastener...  I liked how they kind of "rode off into the sunset" at the end, implying there were more adventures to be had just like the Ennikar and Ic...whatever his name was....

3.5 stars. Good sequel. I especially loved the developments with Dorian. He seems to be a much different person in this book and I LIKE it! Here are my two gripes:  We don't have enough background/info to understand WHY Chaol is so loyal to that treacherous king. We are left wanting to punch him in the face because he keeps putting the king first, and the king is obviously enemy #1. Why does Chaol, who is otherwise a good man, want to serve that viper? If there were some sort of backstory to explain it (like maybe the king saved his homeland Arielle from those crazy mountain madmen; that would work) we would have felt the conflict within Chaol MUCH more. Instead we just scream in our minds for him to stop causing problems because of his dumb loyalty! Okay, second gripe. If Celeaena is such an amazing assassin, WHY DOESN'T SHE EVER TRY TO KILL HER ONE TRUE ENEMY (the King)? The whole purpose of her existence is to defeat him, and yet she doesn't ever explain why she can't use her chosen career to get the job done? The author again could have put some work into creating why that wouldn't be plausible (maybe the King's magic ring makes him immune to poison makes it so he doesn't need sleep--I don't know). Good pace throughout; Celaena is still bloodthirsty and the big reveal at the end we could see coming all along, but it was still exciting. I'm frustrated that my library doesn't have the third book and it came out months ago! Grrr.

Oooh... a wonderful retelling of Bluebeard and his wives. (The reason I put it behind a spoiler tag is that it's not quite obvious when you read the blurb/first start the story.) "What if it's all my fault?" I look at my sister and ask for answers to a question that has plagued me for years. ... "The sun rose on those days," Amina begins. She leans on her garden hoe for a moment. "There was a fox in the garden the morning Karis disappeared, possibly the day that the accident happened too. I sneezed those days. What ripples we see are not always causes." She shakes her head. "We can look for patterns, and we might even find them. There were a lot of acorns this year, and the snow was heavy. Are they related? A fawn died of hunger after I chased it from the garden, and our sister died. Were they related?" Really loved the writing - again, I think I need to investigate Melissa Marr's other books. Reading these short stories/novelettes on Tor is helping my TBR pile grow taller... and taller... and taller... Not that I'm complaining!

Full Review & More - Paws and Paperbacks ARC received through NetGalley. A lot of people have raved about Gilded Cage, but I, for one, couldn't figure out what all the hype was about. First of all, this book was much different than what I had expected. I'll dive into more on that later but I think that was a big part of my dislike, along with high expectations due to all the raving five star review (when will I learn? Gilded Cage is a dystopian novel, but what sets it apart from all the other YA dystopian novels is the plot. Not only is it intricate and complex, but it's different-a good different. The world building was strong. It took me a while to get used to this type of dystopian world, similar to how I was when I read Red Queen, but once I got into it I was impressed by the world the author had built. One issue I had was the pacing of the book. At one point, less than three-quarters of the way, I realized that six months had already passed since the start. Six months, and yet I knew absolutely nothing about most of the characters, including Abi, who I had assumed was one of the main protagonists. I was 75% done with the book and had only read two chapters from her POV and had no clue what her storyline was or anything about her character. The combination of the pacing and the multiple POVs led me to feel unconnected to any of the characters and like I was reading about strangers the entire time. The one character I did really appreciate was Gavar. He seemed the most complex, and his struggles were interesting and complicated. I wanted to read more and more from his perspective. He is clearly going to end up as some sort of antihero and I could not be more on board. There's definitely more to him than we know and I'm dying to know more about what happened between him and Leah. Also, his love for his daughter, Libby, was so pure and precious. Especially considering how easy it would be to despise her. If I continue with the series, it will be for Gavar alone. The romance was basically nonexistent. It's not usually a deal breaker for me unless the story is lacking, which I thought it was. I thought I would be all about the Abi/Jenner pairing, but I honestly wasn't all the involved in their story. Probably because it was very rushed and there was way too much telling instead of showing. The romance was basically nonexistent. It's not usually a deal breaker for me unless the story is lacking, which I thought it was. I thought I would be all about the Abi/Jenner pairing, but I honestly wasn't all the involved in their story. Probably because it was very rushed and there was way too much telling instead of showing. All of a sudden there were these intense feelings between them, but since we only had Abi's POV two or three times throughout the whole book, we never get to see any conversations or interactions between them, and never get the chance to see these feelings develop. And now the thing that bothered me the most: I felt so misled going into this. This was a very different story than what the synopsis suggested. Don't get me wrong: the plot is strong and unique, but it was not at all what I was expecting to read. I get more in depth about this on my blog. All in all, unfortunately I wasn't too impressed by the book. I gave it an extra star because the basics of the plot were pretty interesting and different from the usual young adult dystopian books, and also because Gavar.

I was happy with the verbose prose. I rather enjoyed the descriptions and world-building actually. And ahhh an oriental setting mixed with fantasy mixed with steampunk = YES! The highlight in this novel was, without a doubt, Buruu and Yukiko's relationship and their funny conversations together. Yukiko's strained relationship with her father was well-done and made my heart ache a little heh. The plot was interesting until Yukiko goes to court... and then it became boring. There was no political intrigue... just Yukiko swooning over Green Eyes...   and I don't even want to think about the romance in this novel... it was awful. Ok, I'll think a bit about it. Firstly - instalust (CRINGE) for random soldier just because of his eyes (ok admittedly green eyes are nice but) there is ZERO CHEMISTRY BETWEEN Green Eyes and Yukiko. A bad romance is just completely off-putting to me. Now, if Green Eyes wasn't a love interest, and it was ONLY Kin, then that I could bear with. A slow build-up from friendship in the sky ship, to betrayal at finding out his identity, then eventually slow buds of romance *sighs happily*  Unfortunately, that wasn't the case. And unfortunately, I'm not in the mood to tolerate even a hint of a love triangle right now. The villain. Yoritomo. Kristoff did a good job at making me feel absolute disgust for him. But... I find it really difficult to believe a 13 year old madman/boy could stay on the throne for so many years without his unhappy courtiers or even the guild already disposing of him. A dislikeable villain, but also a boring depthless villain...

Although this book was quite quick to read not too much happened. There is a fight going on between Bishop and Amelie and throughout the book all Claire and her friends seemed to be doing were running around Morganville. Claire and her friends seemed to accomplish very little in this book. There was quite a big cliffhanger at the end. In this series, I feel no connection to the characters. I don't hate them but I don't love them the way I do with some characters. Shane told Claire that he loved her and normally I would be really happy for the character but I really didn't care, there relationship has never seemed very believable to me.

A fantastic sequel! My only complaint is that I saw the plot point involving Vin controlling the koloss  coming from very early on in the book. Otherwise filled with great twists and character development, as all Sanderson books seem to be. Highly recommended.

The long synopsis doesn't do justice to the book. The Name of the Wind is a unique novel, a triumphant debut from a hither-to unknown author. The level of mastery the author has displayed is rarely found in a debut novel, and in this light, I like the novel very much. When judging the book by the hype that surrounds it, however, I find it lacking. it is slow to start, and Kvothe's motivation for revealing his story to the Chronicler is is surprising given the effort he has put into disappearing. In this way, I found the set up of the novel, a story within a story, is executed well after this point, but getting there seems sloppy. Once Kvothe starts telling his story, however, it is difficult not to lose yourself. He is a masterful story-teller, and Rothfuss has captured his 'voice' well. His adventures make you want to laugh, cry, rage at the fates, and generally capture your imagination. The narrative does have a few lulls and slow points but for the most part it is riveting and carries you along like the swift current of a river. I like Kvothe a lot - he is a good protagonist and narrator. Hearing a man tell of his journey from boyhood to adulthood is always exciting, and Kvothe doesn't hold anything back. He is brutally honest about his experiences and feelings, allowing the reader to empathise with him easily. He does keep saying things like "If you haven't experienced this, then you don't really know / can't imagine what it's like" which sounds very patronising. I also didn't understand why Kvothe, being familiar with poverty, would squander what little money he has without any thought. He should have learnt to save some money for hard times, but no, he keeps spending it and finding himself at the edge of poverty frequently. With the notable exception of Denna, there are no exciting female characters in the book, and certainly no strong ones. Even Rela only makes it into the story when she is needed for a plot device, and otherwise largely ignored by both Kvothe and the author. Denna and Kvothe strike me as the only two fully fleshed out characters, while the others are pigeon-holed into stereo-typical roles, to be pulled out when the plot requires. The Name of the Wind is certainly worth a read, and if you like fantasy then you really can't miss it. Patrick Rothfuss has proved that he is a force to be reckoned with. I have the second book of the trilogy already, and will be diving into it eagerly at the next available opportunity. Read more of my reviews here.

This book was amazing. It had everything I wanted: lots of danger and injury and desperate wanting and angst and a different paranormal take and very good writing and an excellent plot and strong, individual characters and conflict and on and on. I LOVED it! If you like M/M paranormal romances, go read it. This one is fabulous. I liked that they used a condom even for oral sex. That's important and so many books omit that part. I really like how Leif puts Dan's father's death into perspective. (medium spoiler) He doesn't blame the depression or condemn the man for suicide; he says, "The man had a responsibility to his kids, and if he couldn't live up to it, it was his duty to get some help and not lay it on you." He also says that he usually doesn't judge suicides. I'm the first person to defend the suicidal but I, as a mother who has been suicidal in the past, completely agree with Leif here. It's so refreshing to read about a character who is mad at the right things not at the disease itself. I really hated but liked, too, because it was realistic, that (big spoiler) Leif's body responds to an evil ex-lover because he used to love him. I particularly hated that we hear this several times. Only once was necessary, but in places the author goes into WAY too much detail and I was really upset. It was awesome how when going into danger, Dan didn't promise that he would be back but that he would try his best. I hate when characters promise things they have little control over. Nitpicks (because what is a Kelly review without them? ): Virgil is grounded at one point then the next day or so is still allowed to go out. The dead have flesh hanging from them, even if they've been dead for a century and a half, such as a confederate soldier. With only the burial technology available then, the body would be completely decomposed other than the bones. One bad guy is able to do something that an equally powerful bad guy with the same resources wasn't able to do in the past. But forget those silly things because the book is so good. Five plus stars. This is one of the best self-published books I have ever read.

This book doesn't hold your hand when you first start it. I was just thrown into a world of weird vocabulary and randomly capitalized words. But once I got past the confusion I kind of fell in love. By no means is the book perfect (our main character, Darrow, is a classic Gary Stu) but all in all, I thoroughly enjoyed it. I more or less spent the last quarter of the book with my eyes glued to the pages. There's just something so satisfying about Mr. Perfect Gary Stu kicking some major ass after being fucked over so much. I'll definitely be reading the rest of the series and thanks so much for sending me the book!

I feel like I have some explaining to do. As a true potterhead I admit that my expectations towards this book were way through the roof, so the disappointment was inevitable. This is NOT the eight Harry Potter book, firstly because it is a play, and without Rowling's compelling narrative style, without all the descriptions that created the truly magical atmosphere in the other books, it just doesn't resonate with the reader as the original series did. The characters are rather shallow and predictable, it is hard to identify with them as we don't get to know them as well as in the original Potter saga (which can also be explained by it being a play and not a novel), and the old characters are rather one-dimentional, for example  Ron, who seems to have very low IQ and acts like a 17 year old while being a husband of the Minister for Magic . Secondly, the whole story reads rather like a piece of fanfiction than a continuation of the saga. However, if one looks at it as fanfiction from the start, it is not all that bad. We can find a reference to Voldemort's lack of nose, a completely mental twist involving the Trolley Witch from the Hogwart's Express, time travelling and, perhaps the biggest surprise, offspring of characters whom I cannot imagine in bed without giggling. So in the end it was a rather enjoyable read, hence 3 stars from me.

As far as I can remember, this is my favourite book in the series. *I don't remember what day it is most of the time, so that's not really reassuring I guess*Because, we get to learn about Li Lei's past! Now you may be asking yourselves, what is it so exciting about an old woman... Let me give you the spoiler She burned the sheets with a dragon. Literally... or maybe figuratively.. hmm that brings some questions. Anyways the moral of this little brainfarting is that, she did wild dragon dance with an actual dragon. . If you ever reach to that level of coolness, you'll get to turn your nose down at Li Lie. Which is never. Aside from The Grandma, there is more information about dragons and their meddling ways. And shiny lupus politics, which are quite complex in its simplicity. And silent. So basically you need to guess what others will guess you are guessing and act according to that guess, which is doing neither the opposite nor the exact actions of the guesses but finding a middle ground that makes you look both powerful and caring. Yeah... Lily is kind of irritating. She's such a stuck up, I need to have a logical reason for everything person. Which is okay in little doses but after awhile it's grating on nerves. Her voice turned into a high pitched, annoying voice in my mind. But she has her moments. Cynna is getting lovelier each book. I can't wait to see her and Cullen as parents again. They are cute. Oh and the plot was executed nicely. Not one boring moment. Very different villians. That's one of the alluring points for this series. Neither characters nor the storyline gets stale.

Wow! I finally was able to put 'Red Rising' down after hours of intense reading, but only after I reached the last page! This is very exciting story! While this novel is book one in a trilogy, thankfully it can be read as a standalone. It ends, though, leaving you, gentle reader, wanting to know how things are going to turn out. Similar to the YA books Divergent and The Hunger Games, 'Red Rising' teens are forced into military competitions where they must kill or be killed. They also can win big rewards if they are the last man standing if the Society overlords had not been secretly corrupted! However, I think 'Red Rising is a more sophisticated read, bringing in some metafictional themes with deeper and more adult literary references, specifically from ancient Greek and Roman literature. But if you know nothing about ancient literature, that will not be a handicap at all in enjoying the action and thrills of this science-fiction dystopia. I think 'Red Rising' is way far superior to the other novels I mentioned above which are somewhat similar but were published earlier. But those who find military strategy a bore may not enjoy 'Red Rising' since it is a primarily a thrill ride of murderous political and military games after the opening pages which introduce the reader to the harsh world of the 'Reds'. The fictional games appear to use real-world problems of leadership and team-building to me, and I enjoy seeing how such challenges allow extremely smart, and not-so-smart, individuals to operate on several psychological and military levels in demonstrating strategy skills while at the same time dealing with extreme danger. However, girl soldiers are mistreated with additional tortures common in war specifically, rape, along with the other usual dangers of combat,  , so people who get triggered will want to avoid this novel. None of the competitors are supposed to die, but the combatants are told accidental deaths cannot be avoided given the brutality they all are otherwise permitted to use in defeating each other. The novel is based in a future where artificial social classes have been created by extreme technology access. The rich - Golds - are able to manufacture very strong handsome physical bodies, while those who are without money must make do with ordinary flesh and very little food or goods - Reds. Darrow, a Red, is recently married, loves his wife Eo, and he has great hopes for his Clan. He has no idea that his life is soon to be smashed into pieces. Reds are impoverished miners who live deep inside caves and tunnels on Mars. They never see the surface of Mars and they work at the hard dangerous labor of mining without pay. Their access to goods, information, freedom of movement and education is tightly controlled, so they are unaware of how they have been manipulated into this work, or the truth about what is beyond Mars. The miners have been taught the Earth is radioactive, and the reason behind their sacrifice of starving unpaid labor is to hopefully terraform Mars one day so that cities on the surface may be built. It has been this way for 800 years.... I caution readers who dislike gore and violence, and who prefer their heroes to pick humane options first instead of expedient ones ensuring survival. Traditional morality by necessity takes a backseat to personal ambition and Big Picture goals. Many readers who are uncomfortable with Realpolitik ethics may balk at seeing the decisions which must be made by characters in this fast-paced, well-written book. Readers who enjoyed the novel Ender's Game primarily for entertainment should definitely give this novel a try; however it falls short of the literary depths Orson Scott Card reaches in his Ender series. Pierce Brown writes with greater heat and intellectual blunt force compared to Card's multi-dimensional intellectual cool. Brown's universe has considerably more of a wrong-turn-taken aspect for humanity as well.

2.5 stars. Vika packed the clay from the former pitcher in her hands. It hardened into a ceramic cannonball. "I don't fancy dying." Her father emptied the bottle of kvass. "Then the only option is, you cannot." I think "bittersweet" is the perfect word to describe this book. Both with how I feel about it, and the general tone and atmosphere of the story. Set in historical Russia, you can tell the author is passionate about the history and sticks very close to what is real, even if she adds her own twists to it. Vika, trained by her loving father Sergei, has lived a secluded life on Ovchinin Island, training to one day become Imperial Enchantress. Nikolai, an orphan from Kazakh and a fan of fashion, has also been training to become Imperial Enchanter under the wing of cold, unloving Galina. Vika and Nikolai do not know each other, and would never have believed that one day they would be battling each other in the deadly Crown's Game for the same position they both desperately want. With the Ottoman Empire and the Kazakhs threatening invasion, the Tsar needs a powerful enchanter by his side. As royal heir, Pavel Alexandrovich Romanov, known as Pasha to his friends, knows that one day he will take the throne and rule the Russian Empire. But that's not what Pasha wants, and his life is filled with frivolities as he tries to enjoy his freedom whilst he can. "Commence the Crown's Game," she said as she retrieved a small but heavy chest from the hidden compartment. It looked, amazingly, like it had been painted and lacquered yesterday, as if the magic repelled dust from its shiny surface. In fact, it probably did. "Give Russia and Imperial Enhanter, Father, so we can fight if we need to. Do it for Pasha, for his birthday, even if he does't know." As the enchanters face-off in a once in a lifetime battle of power, Nikolai and Vika know that only one of them can live. Only one of them can end the game. At the end of the game, one of them will die. "Tell me." Nikolai restrained himself from reassuring her not to be afraid. He needed to know what the leaf meant. "The jagged one represents... death. You were born of death, and..." "And what?" "And death will... follow you, always..." The Crown's Game is very well written, steeped in history and with many details that truly brought historical Russia to life. However, it was also a let down. Maybe I'd set my expectations too high, and maybe I went into it with a one-track mentality, but I was seriously expecting assassin-like turns, where the characters would try and one-up each other at every turn, and that they would at least do their best to kill each other. But no. Instead of a battle to the death, we get very soft magic. Bearing in mind that the competitors only have five turns each before an Enchanter is chosen, I wasn't impressed by Nikolai's redecorating skills or Vika's dressmaking ones. The main problem was Vika. She was so spoilt and mean and she got on my nerves a lot of the time. So many times, in fact, that I had to put the book down after the first two chapters and really think it through. Thank God for Nikolai's and Pasha's chapters because they redeemed this novel by 110%. If it hadn't been for them, I would've probably DNFed. Vika is the sort of person who knows she's perfect and shoves it in everyone's faces. She holds herself higher than anyone else and disregards people and their talents because they're not her, and therefore not good enough. At least, that was how it felt to this reader. Although the romance is very subtle, the fact that it's suddenly there and all up in your face was the most annoying thing of all. Suddenly, after a masquerade, everyone's in love with Vika. Nikolai is, although he tries to hide it, and so is Pasha. It made for incredibly frustrating reading and didn't fit well with the rest of the novel. At least not in the way it was showcased so suddenly. However, it's not all doom and gloom! I absolutely adored Nikolai and Pasha's friendship. It truly was the kind of friendship that could have transcended ages, if it weren't for Vika getting in the way. She destroyed everything they had, and even had the gall to be upset when neither of them would look at her... Vika noticed that Pasha did not look at her. It was as if he didn't know her either. Had she imagined the past two months? The dancing at the masquerade, the near kiss in the maple grove, the carriage ride after her father's death? Everyone had forsaken her. If it's not about Vika, then it's not worth her thinking about. I really felt for Nikolai as a character. A boy borne from nothing, struggling to survive in the shadow of his best friend who also happened to be the heir of an empire, and needing to win the Game so he could one day serve and protect Pasha the way he had always dreamed. I even felt for Pasha, a boy born into royalty who wanted nothing more than to be a "normal" guy and enjoy life the way it is, without all the added benefits of being a prince. The two struggled in their own ways, but they always had each other, and all that is forsaken in the name of a girl who couldn't care less about either of them. Unfortunately, The Crown's Game just wasn't for me. I highly recommend it for fans of fantasy, but not fans of the Throne of Glass series who might expect something from this book that it just cannot provide. After reading: An Episode of Inside Aly's Brain! Man, I've missed writing nonsensical, ranty reviews that are more like word vomit than anything else. I will surely post a better, more coherent review once I've untangled my poor braincells. I think "bittersweet" is the perfect word to describe this book. Both with how I feel about it, and the general tone and atmosphere of the story. Set in historical Russia, you can tell the author is passionate about the history and sticks very close to what is real, even if she adds her own twists to it. But here's the thing, and I hate myself for it, I believe magic should not have played such a huge part. When I requested The Crown's Game it was because it promised brutality and an edge-of-your-seat story that would have my heart burst out of my chest and my eyes leak excess water. I mean, it's right there in the summary! Unfortunately, I didn't quite get that? I mean, it's weird, because it should have been that way. My expectations weren't ridiculously high, but it's the logical conclusion. Instead of a battle to the death, though, we get much magical prancing around decorating Nevsky Prospect and creating enchanted islands and benches that let you dream (which is cool, but shouldn't be a turn in a duel!). Where is my death? My heartache? Where are all the impossible decisions? I was seriously expecting assassin-like turns, where they'd try and one-up each other at every turn, and that they would at least do their best to kill each other. But no. It isn't until they're forced to that it actually happens. My main problem, I think, was Vika. She was so spoilt and mean and so lardy-dah-I-am-better-than-that-pesky-Nikolai-because-I-can-use-the-elements that I had to put the book down after the first two chapters and really think it through. Thank God for Nikolai's and Pasha's chapters because the two of them 110% redeemed this novel for me. If it hadn't been for them, I would've probably DNFed. Vika is the sort of person that knows she's perfect and shoves it in everyone's faces. She holds herself higher than anyone else and disregards people and their talents because if they're not her, they're not good enough. I may be wrong, but that's what I took from her. And okay, the romance is very subtle, but the fact that it's suddenly there and all up in your face was the most annoying thing ever. Suddenly, after a masquerade, everyone's in love with Vika. Nikolai is, although he tries to hide it, and so is Pasha, and it's so frustrating because no. Bros before hoes, or is that too much to ask for? I absolutely adored Nikolai and Pasha's friendship. It truly is the kind of friendship that could have transcended ages, if it weren't for Vika getting in the way. She destroyed everything they had, and even had the gall to be upset when neither of them would look at her? I mean, this is literally the paragraph after she thinks about how much she wants to hurl herself at Nikolai: Vika noticed that Pasha did not look at her. It was as if he didn't know her either. Had she imagined the past two months? The dancing at the masquerade, the near kiss in the maple grove, the carriage ride after her father's death? Everyone had forsaken her. NO. No one has "forsaken" you. They're all too busy grieving. For the love of all that is holy. I really felt for Nikolai as a character. A boy borne from nothing, struggling to survive in the shadow of his best friend who also happened to be the heir of an empire, and needing to win the Game so he could one day serve and protect Pasha the way he always wanted to. I even felt for Pasha, a boy born into royalty who wanted nothing more than to be a "normal" guy and to enjoy life the way it is, without all the added benefits of being a prince. The two struggled in their own ways, but they always had each other, and all that is forsaken in the name of a girl who couldn't give a rat's ass about either of them, to be completely honest. I seriously hope this isn't a standalone, because the last 20%, although way more interesting than the entire book, are not enough for me to be happy with. Selfish, I know, but I need more explanations than that. It's very rushed, and Vika is far too easily forgiven and Nikolai too easily forgotten, and that's not okay. My heart cannot deal. Please let Nikolai be alive and for him and Pasha to be BFFs again and Vika to disappear. PLEASE.

Well that was certainly some ending. Here's hoping for some miracle resurrect the dead from ashes cure in book 5. . I like this series. I like that Merit tries to do what is best for her house and city, not necessarily what is best for her or the GP. I like the group she has around her, they all bring something to the table even in books where they stay mostly in the background. I'm not fond of the fact that every hot guy/supernatural seems to fall for Merit, but that is fairly common in UF. I like the bits of Chicago that come out in the books, like the food in this one. It will be interesting to see how human/vampire relations play out in the future.
