That is to say, that when Sayuri and the Chairman finally "got together" there were only a few chapters left. And that was even cut short because of Sayuri's move to New York. I understand that this book is supposed to focus on her life as a Geisha, but I still felt short-changed. When I finished, I can't say I felt satisfied. It appears that Sayuri is happy, or at least content, with where life eventually brought here but I wasn't satisfied as a reader. That's probably because I wanted Sayuri and the Chairman to be together forever, as the cliche goes (even though I never got of the ridiculous age difference. Creeps me out a little)  but even as I write it I know that's just not how the Geisha culture is. Overall, I can happily recommend this book. It's a great book and even though I'm not sure I actually liked it I appreciated it and the storyline.

Potential Spoilers!! Unless you are some kind saint, this book will PISS YOU OFF=( I loved how this story was going up until the last 100 pages or so, then it just fell to pieces and left me saying "Huh?" after every turn of the page. The Heroine acknowledges that she loves the hero and even feels really sorry for him, yet she goes on and on determined to get her revenge on him through an elaborate public humiliation. "Oh, I love you terribly and know you've been mistreated, but I simply MUST destroy your life anyway." WTF? It's like she has some kind of personality disorder or cognitive dissonance. Then, she changes her mind when he apologizes by telling her--wait for it!! !--everything she already knew! Wow. You just up and decide to change your mind because he laid it out neatly? What a moron. Then, the villain. Good grief. I don't know if this is an English thing or what (since Balogh is from Whales), but this whole "turn the other cheek" thing really should have its limits. I was so frustrated with how the villain was just getting off that I felt almost physically ill. <> The Hero was falsely accused of rape years ago, thus completely destroying his life. The poor guy had to flee the country and live in exile for 9 years. And why? Because the woman who accused him was a lesbian and would do anything to avoid getting married. Oh! That makes it okay! Yes, let's all just forgive her for something that quite possibly could have gotten an innocent man killed just because she was too much of a coward to refuse marriage on her own. Instead, she had to destroy an innocent man who had nothing to do with her personal problems. And the other characters are all like "It was nine years ago. You need to forgive. Don't fill yourself with bitterness...." Unbelievable! People say that hatred is a poison, but you know what else is a poison? Having the entire world brush off the fact that you have been betrayed and having to listen to them tell you to get over it. That will shrivel a person's heart to nothing. I was reminded of one of Balogh's earlier novels - Lord Carew's Bride - in which the terrible villain gets what's coming to him by being beaten to a near pulp. THAT is satisfying. THAT is reality. Not this sentimental "turn the other cheek" crap that does not work with normal people. We are not saints, and neither are realistic characters in novels. =(

I've already fallen in love with the first book in the Turner series, and I'm not even halfway through! Why, oh why, didn't I read it sooner? Why did I get such a wrong impression from the second book? Mark Turner is definitely more interesting in this book than in his own book(the second one: "Unclaimed")...HOW? A little bit of spoiler....Ash never suspecting that Margaret could actually bring him down to his knees... the Bam and the Whap.... :D :D :D Ash is literally crumpled on the floor....Oh, how I admire Margaret, and how I love Mark for confounding/tricking PLUS teasing his brother this way! I am grinning right now because of that, and I need to get back to that situation, as I'm currently reading this book and am only on page 85... ^__^ After finishing the whole book, my initial love has faded... Nope, I'm still too much taken with the Brothers Sinister series, no other historical romances can match their stories, apparently. Sigh. 2.75 stars. If I were to give a different rating to it, I would be lying. We can't help liking or less liking something, can we? The way the conflicts were solved near the end, they were ok-ish, but nothing quite surprising as Courtney Milan delivered in her other books. There is one character who I wanted to like so much, but he couldn't be fully redeemed: Richard. Well, I can hope he will change gradually... Having read Ash's and Mark's stories, I'm afraid to expect more for Smite.... It's the last chance. I want to like Smite's story, I really do. Don't get me wrong, I do adore the bond among the Turner brothers, it's just...with Unclaimed and Unveiled, what happened is this---I feel elated at the start, feel good throughout the second part of the journey, then the third portion tends to drag on, and the end comes a bit late, even though the end leaves no loose ties. I just can't connect with the romance as the story comes to the third part, they feel a bit too good and hastened to be real. I connected with the romance initially, but then, after a point, I couldn't connect anymore. It was just too easy. Especially after both Smite and Mark found out... And the way Ash acted after finding out. I'm sure there will be other readers who can connect with the romance till the end of the journey, but I couldn't be one of them(I tried.) For what it's worth, I liked Ash a lot for his bond with his brothers. Now, the only hope left is the last brother, Smite's story and the novellas. I have to reign in my expectations and see what happens.

I think it has the makings of a great trilogy, and it's a pretty good book. Isabel is not on fire for the revolution or for the Tories--she's on fire for whoever can keep her alive. And while that might not make her as conventionally interesting, I think it's a lot more realistic. I think the best thing that Anderson did for Isabel was not having her absolve Lady Seymour for being a "nice white lady." As Isabel put it--a person doesn't want to be bought and sold like a basket of eggs, even if the person cracking the shells is nice.

Dear Colin, PLEASE GO FUCK YOURSELF WITH A RUSTY SPOON! Ugh. I was really looking forward to this book. A spinster? A gossip column? A charmer? Yes, please! But, no. Colin was just..... such a dickhead! When he found out about Whistledown his reaction was extremely overblown and ridiculous. And then he's just like MARRY ME RIGHT MEOW. Wut? And Penelope straddled the line between having a spine and not. I mean, she definitely discovered bits of herself along the way but she put Colin on the biggest pedestal in the world and it was grating at times to hear her wax poetic about HOW GREAT HE IS when he was being such an asshole. Blerg. Overall, more disappointed than anything because I really wanted to know more about Penelope. And Colin's "secret" was dumb and he acted infantile at times because of it. *** I'd probably give it more stars if I weren't so cranky ***

Hmm, this book felt awfully familiar and I can't help but wonder why. Maybe because it was more or less the same damn plot as THIEF OF SHADOWS, book four, in the Maiden Lane series. Oh there were obviously enough differences that it wasn't word for word the same, but ultimately (and literally) it was the same conflict but with new characters who happened to have some differing backstory. I almost convinced myself that Hoyt had to have this story follow Winter's due to the chronological order but like.. two years have elapsed between this book and the previous. So even that excuse doesn't hold water. Neither Godric nor Meg were very compelling characters. Mostly because they were both going through the motions of mourning and feeling guilty over their dead loves as they navigated the strange circumstance of being married years earlier in order to prevent Margaret from the shame of having a baby out of wedlock. It was a situation that might have been made interesting, or at least sympathetic, but neither character (either individually, or as a unit) interested me. The story was made worse by the fact that we went through the same motions regarding the Ghost of St Giles that we had just experienced and the big 'surprise' over the conspiracy from book four, which has a resurgence here, left me cold. Leaving me to wonder.. Why did we need to go back to this? We learned nothing new, not really, and overall I just wasn't interested in anything about this book.. except the thread featuring another character, who, in Hoyt's trademark way, will rise to prominence for book six. I'm very curious about Artemis and naturally it doesn't take a genius to see who she'll be paired up with. Nor what his secret is. There's been quite the trend on these "big" reveals and I'm hoping, maybe after book six?, we move on to something new because the revolving door of heroes playing the Ghost of St Giles is getting kind of tired now . Didn't think I'd rate a book lower than the 2.5 (rounded to a three) I'd given to book one after the whole Lazarus and his long silver hair disaster but 'lo and behold this one just didn't work for me. And had it not been so similar to book four I might given it a pass.. but the storyline and thematic repetition made it that much harder to find much of anything to like.

Very enjoyable and different from what I've been reading (and it is so nice to switch it up sometimes). Some of the coincidences were stretches for me to believe, but I liked the characters and the wit. I think I should read more in this genre actually and that's a pleasant surprise. I hope James finds his way into future books. I enjoy their interactions and the romance was not too heavy handed though they did kiss at an inconvenient time. I'll try to write a more thorough review over the weekend (though I have a few that need writing)
I really enjoyed this - would make a good movie, and the ending was surprisingly satisfying. Though I could have done without the super-depressing coda about Frederick .

Entertaining light read. As seems to be common with the Essex sisters books, a great deal of time is spent checking in on various sisters - in this one (as the last), on Imogen, which is interesting and well-written but does take a lot of the emotional energy away from the romance we're reading about and put it into the romance we will be reading next. Imogen is busy swanning around and making everything about her - and the author is kind of doing the same. I also didn't love the plotline surrounding Rosy. It was cliched and really sad and far too easily resolved to feel realistic in the same way that the rest of the book feels realistic. And yes, this book, like many romance novels, is not really realistic - four sisters with horses for dowries have romances with handsome, eligible, wealthy peers! - but the emotions, and the emotional resolutions, feel realistic. The characters feel like real people, even if the plots don't seem like anything that would ever actually happen. Rosy, and what happened to her, and what happens to her, is straight out of a Gothic romance from the 1970s, and this kind of glib use of trauma to a minor character, and "solution" to same, is discomfiting.

Initially I was very unimpressed with how the author using Death as an narrator because I thought it was cheap and gimmicky, but it worked. Overall an interesting book though I would have expected the main character to have stolen more books considering the title of the book. I nearly ragequit when nearly everybody dies at the end.

Dear Lisa See, This is a pictorial representation of how I felt while reading your book: Shanghai - Angel Island section: \(^o^)/ San Francisco, the early years: (-_-;) Joy grows up: "(o`Min 'o)no It started out so well. Sure, Pearl and May were sheltered, spoiled and selfish. But that's the start of a heroic arc, yes? A character has to start low so when she becomes mature and generous, it is clear how far she has come. The attack on Shanghai was terrifying and horrific. I loved how the Chin matriarch had more backbone and intelligence than either of her daughters ever dreamed she possessed. I very, very much liked the Shanghai section of your book. I'm not saying that I liked reading about the horrible things that happened to the Chin family. But the novel had a sense of urgency and drama and potential that it quickly lost once the girls got to America. Ms. See, I know the tragedy of Chinese immigrants for far too much of the 19th and 20th centuries (blatant, persistent racism that extended into the lifetimes of those still alive today) is near and dear to your heart. But there is a place between dogma and silence where subtlety lies and you have not found it. There are certain scenes in the book that are not part of the organic stories of the characters. They are there because you want to SHOW the reader another aspect of white racism against those of Chinese descent. Example: Pearl gets a job in a department store. This is good, because she has spent far too much of her time in San Fran whining and refusing to move beyond her porch. Her English is perfect and she is apparently a natural born saleswoman. Of course, she hits a glass ceiling because she's Chinese. A paragraph later, she's left her job. Why? It's never explained. Probably because your point is made: Chinese were discriminated against in employment. Now that you've shown that, Pearl never again uses her perfect English (or any of the other languages she's fluent in) or her apparent innate selling skills, even when the family is in need of money. This happens again when Pearl and Sam want to enroll Joy in a white school. The kindergarten teacher is a racist and poor Joy is so mercilessly harassed they give up and move her to the local Chinese school. This could be a normal plotpoint, but it was so brief and random it felt more like another message: Chinese were discriminated against in public schools. I'm not saying that you aren't writing about important messages. I'm saying that shoe-horning in messages whether or not they are natural to the characters and storyline leaves a bitter aftertaste and actually distracts from what you are trying to say. I am also sad that you managed to waste Sam. He is the perfect set-up for a romantic hero: (1) even Pearl admits he's handsome and he's buff from all that manual labor (2) he has a tragic backstory (3) he loves his daughter and cares for Pearl (4) he is patient, kind, loyal, hard-working and good. But, no, he is male and therefore can never develop into a full character. Can you PLEASE write a male who is not a place holder or a prop? I know you are all about sisterhood and female friendship rah, rah, but you can do that AND have a romance. I WANTED to fall in love with Sam and have Pearl and him have some real connection, but after his tragic backstory confession he doesn't really do much again until the end. If you need some ideas for how to write good romantic interests, try Isabel Allende's Daughter of Fortune, because I was ready to marry Tao Chi'en myself when I read that book. Also, what is up with you writing such annoying protagonists? Pearl is Lily all over again. Pearl and Lily are the same selfish, passive-aggressive, cold, bitter, whiny, obstinate woman. Is Pearl actually Lily reincarnated? I would have much rather have had May as the narrator. She might've be flighty and selfish, but at least she did more than mope around, feel like a martyr and complain. This applies to Joy. I know she was your representation of the entitlement and rebellion of first generation Chinese-Americans. But am I SUPPOSED to want to bitch-slap sense into her? She takes after her mother in the whining department, but instead of being annoyingly passive she is stupidly naive, which makes her brash. I hope she DOES feel bad about what happened to Sam! And how am I supposed to like a character that throws away the college education her parents scrimped and saved for, on top of stealing her family's life savings? I actually hope she is a victim of Mao's Cultural Revolution. It would serve her right to be killed because of her own stupid fantasies. I cannot believe there is a whole other book on Joy. Why? Why?!?!?. I would declare that I won't read it, but I can't promise I wouldn't be lying. I got through almost all of Philippa Gregory's Tudor series despite raving about how horrible they were (well, The Queen's Fool was pretty good). I like to finish what I start, whether that's wise or not. And please, for the love of God, please kill the term "the husband-wife thing." I accepted it with Lily, who was a sheltered country girl. Maybe that's the term they really used, I don't know. But Pearl was loudly and proudly cosmopolitan. She had American friends and watched American movies. She had perfect English. She would know more ways to allude to sex. "The husband-wife thing" makes my skin crawl, because it sounds like the speaker is not all mentally there. I think you are a talented writer, Ms. See. And you have probably already forgotten more than I will ever know about the history of China and Chinese immigrants. So I hope you can expand your focus a little, throw in some romance (or at least a male character that's more than "the husband"/"the father-in-law", etc.) and not show your work so much. I have high hopes for you. Your humble reader, Bonnie

Sometimes I have to re-taste foods that I don't like to see if my opinion has changed. I have done this twice in the past week, with ketchup and celery. I have avoided both for years. Then, well. I guess I needed to remind myself that I hate ketchup, and I hate celery, and that I am correct in avoiding them, and that I should continue to avoid them. I think you can see where I am going with this. I guess I am in a "opinion re-calibration" mode. And to be honest, I have found in every case that my opinions were fine. I do, in fact, dislike sprawling epics with heroic characters! I do (yes, currently) dislike wordy, detailed descriptions! I do dislike romance! I do dislike boring, Mary Sue-ish characters! I do! I do i do! So I really had to force myself through this book, because I stupidly decided it was going to be the book club read for this month. I really, really disliked it. However, I honestly don't think it was a terrible worthless POS. I do honestly think it is a really weird book, like surprisingly weird (why did no one warn me about the magic-healing-erotic-dream-drugged-sex-fight? I mean. Ok, whatever rocks your boat. I just haven't seen the "magic healing sex" trope done like, seriously in years. Here's a quote from that TVtropes article: "In Fan Fic parlance, this is often called the 'magical healing cock' and mocked, as it is often Narm (or deeply offensive) when, as all too often, the magical healing cock is used as instant therapy for a rape victim." I read a TON of slash fan fiction. So I've been aware and wary of this problematic (I know, the word is overused, sorry) romance cliche for years, and seeing it show up here was like, uhhh wut. Even at the book club meeting, another woman brought it up as being the only part of the book that made her truly uncomfortable, before I had mentioned anything. ), with scarily intimidating online fans. But the book seems to be a good example of what it is. Sprawling, romantic historical epic with attractive, sexy heroes and detailed world building. I should continue to avoid them.

This is one weird book. For about the first 60% it was feeling like the best I'd read this year, but having finished, my feelings are mixed. The narrator, Rose, works a typist in a New York City police precinct in the 1920s. When the precinct starts cracking down on speakeasies, a new typist is hired: the glamorous Odalie, who seems to be Rose's opposite in every way. Rose is an orphan who rents half a bedroom at a cheap boardinghouse and lives a solitary life, and she quickly falls under Odalie's spell, though she realizes Odalie's behavior deviates from her own strict sense of morality. To say more would be to spoil it; though between the extensive foreshadowing and reading reviews beforehand, I found the story to develop as I'd predicted it, the plot still kept me enthralled. So, the good stuff. The book is very well-written, with a strong voice, and the obvious unreliability of Rose's narration is engaging and keeps the reader guessing. The author keeps the tension simmering even through fairly mundane events, and while the pacing is on the slow side, it fits the story well. Rose and Odalie's relationship rings true, though it's evident from the beginning that it's not as healthy as Rose would like to believe. It's quite an atmospheric book, bringing Prohibition-era New York to life: the speakeasies of course are fun, as is seeing how the police station operates. The characters and settings are vivid; I'm inclined to call the book cinematic, although not in an entirely complimentary way: with the exception of Rose--who has enough complexity to share--it never felt like there was much to the characters beneath the surface. Even Odalie seems more glamor than substance, although perhaps that's intentional: she's likely sociopathic, incapable of affection, remorse, or change, and therefore inherently hollow. Unfortunately, some of my interest was lost when Rose and Odalie spend several chapters vacationing at a socialite couple's seaside mansion; I find rich people throwing parties to be one of the most boring subjects ever, although I realize that's idiosyncratic and if you're interested in this book for the Great Gatsby-like setting, it won't bother you in the least. And then there's the ending. It's a puzzle, and if you like endings that throw the entire book into question, you'll eat it up. As for me, I prefer the sort of unreliable narrators who allow readers to figure out what's going on by reading between the lines, and the possibility that Rose was delusional or lying the entire time just left me baffled. Neither of the most obvious explanations for the book really make sense. One is that Rose and Odalie were either the same person all along or that Rose made Odalie up. Which I don't much like because it throws out the entire story, most of which is about Rose and Odalie's relationship, and much of it featuring the two of them in the company of others, who do in fact behave as if there are two different women there. The other is that the story did mostly take place as Rose narrated it, and Odalie set Rose up. But then, how to explain those weird scenes where Rose seemed to be turning into Odalie? And if Rose's face was splashed all over the newspapers as "Ginevra"/Odalie, surely someone who knew one or the other would've come forward to point out the mistake. In the end, I'm glad I read this, because it's well-written and I found the story and its narrator captivating. And I would read another book by this author--I just hope it makes a little more sense!

Her Royal Spyness #10... I normally really enjoy this series but this one didn't move me like the rest of the series has. There was a LOT of repetition and chatty dialogue but there really wasn't any adventure or action like there normally is. It was just kind of boring and the whole Queenie-the incompetent maid, the always broke & homeless Lady Georgiana & the continuously delayed wedding to Darcy thing is getting rather old. If Queenie's stay with Lady Oona becomes permanent or at least straightens her up and if Georgiana & Darcy FINALLY tie the knot, I will be a very happy reader! It is past time for a change- spice it up and give us some new material please! *I read this for my 2016 Halloween Bingo: ~Genre: Mystery~ square  BINGO!

After making a review of Bridgerons #8 (On The Way To The Wedding), I was appalled, yes that's the right term, to realize that I haven't read Francesca's story, and upon reading it's blurb, I know why. It was a little taboo in a way that might cross the borders of cheating...And though I do read taboo stories(as long as it aesthetically written), I hate it to be accompanied by cheating, especially that John, Francesca's deceased husband was obviously a good person. I hate cheating in stories... It's my pet peeve, I know I shouldn't coz it's somehow common in Romance but it does bother me. And my Psychologist and I have been talking about it actually. I really weird about it, I mean not normally. Anyway, Michael and Francesca proved me wrong. Their story is actually one of the best in this series. Both characters are relatable. I felt Farannie's pain and grief. And Michael. I actually teared more than few times, everytime he was hurt. I just can imagine how awful, how hard it is to be in his shoes. It was very painful. Even after they get involved sexually and get married , one might think finally he'd be happy somehow. He's still hurting. But he has no choice but take whatever he can get from Frannie, no matter how little it is. I totally understand why Frannie couldn't jump into Michael's proposal, or even to the idea of being involved with him. Maybe most of us don't know, or we want to think that we do but some widows, especially the ones who had a perfect relationship with their late husband, might feel like Frannie did. It was normal for them. Also, I was laughing at the chapter where Michael was courting Frannie. It must be frustrating in Frannie's part but it was funny to the reader. ANd the sex scenes....Wooooow!!!! Seriously Julia Quinn....In a good way...this is the first time I read something from this author with a nonvirgin heroine and I must say,,,GOOD JOB!! !..I think it was just fitting that their sex scenes were way too hotter than the others. Of course, Michael is a rake and Frannie isn't innocent about it so... *grin* ANyway...I love this one sooo much...

This is an excellent, excellent book, and one best discovered without much information going in. If you are intrigued by the synopsis, and like to read about vivid characters, strong female friendships, and/or desperate stakes, I highly suggest you give it a try. Some people report being bored by the beginning, which involves a lot of descriptions of flying, but I was hooked from the first page. Verity's voice leaps off the page at you, and only grows stronger as her narrative continues. The rest of my praise is going under a spoiler tag. I really suggest you don't click unless you've read the book. Based on the reviews I'd seen, I was expecting some huge revelation halfway through. Well, yes. Sort of. But I wasn't actually that shocked to hear Maddie had survived. No, what got me was the slow unraveling. The little details, the hints that Julie's account wasn't as straightforward as it seemed. I actually noted the underlining as I was reading, but I didn't see how everything would come together. When I finally did, it was beautiful. Oh, and then there was the plot twist that took my heart and stomped all over it. So, 1/2 I guess. God, there's so much to love about this book. Julie and Maddie do make a spectacular team, and Wein absolutely nails their voices. The time period, too - I really felt like I was immersed in WWII-era Britain. And the tension is sky high - especially in the second half. Not a moment drags, and the sense of danger is palpable. And I almost cried when...well. If you've read it you can guess. Let me finish with this, because it's unusual for me. When I'm watching a movie or TV show, I cry at the drop of a hat. As soon as a character I like starts to tear up, I'm tearing up with them. But books? I rarely cry while reading. I feel emotions, sure, but it's extremely rare for a book to make me laugh aloud, and no book has yet made me cry. Code Name Verity came very, very close.

I really wanted to like this more than I did. I had high hopes in the beginning, because the leads didn't meet and immediately want to jump in bed. It took them time to fall in love. However, in doing so, they were incredibly dull. Hardly anything interesting happened in the story, and by the last few chapters, I was more than ready for it to be over. Usually I don't mind if the leads don't communicate, but for some reason it really annoyed me here. For example, when Eve encountered her former lover, John, a man she was supposed to marry, Aidan sees them together and begins torturing himself about how Eve must long for the affections of her lover. It was too much angst. Later, John vows to have Eve again and then that whole thing is just dropped. I just thought it was pointless drama. I'm sad I didn't like this more, as it put me off reading about the rest of the Bedwyn clan (although I think I'll make an exception for Wulf, if only because he's super icy).

http://www.joannabourne.com/blackhawk... On a dark drizzly fog London 1818 night, why does Justine, shopkeeper (few years retired French spy) collapse on home doorstep of Sir Adrian Hawkhurst, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of..., long years Head of British Intelligence Service? She bleeds to death from poisoned knife owned by aforesaid lord. Hop back decades ago, at the height of their hormonal heat and beginning of their espionage careers, two teens from opposite sides collide. Owl, Paris aristo forced whore, enlists Hawker, slum Rookery killer thief, to rescue Caches, children trained by French torture to infiltrate England as moles p56. Pax plays backup; three (one later called Jane Cardiff  stay behind; seeds of 1818 trouble are planted. X-rated, "There was no feeling sweeter than a fine pair of lockpicks between the fingers. Except maybe a girl's breasts. Maybe the flower between her legs. That was the sweetest toy in the world" "on the job" p63. Bunny-like, couple hippety passionately, powers professional and personal rise higher to climax that tears them apart - (tumbles and) saving Napoleon. Timeline hoppetys. But author is appropriately named (Bourne spy thrillers - books and films), this goes beyond standard romance, historical, or suspense. Thus despite her creations resemblances, I love their representations and sharing their excitement, on the page. Persiflage attends every encounter. Midway, Adrian catches Justine visiting her sister, adopted into England p101. J: "You will let me go, of course. I am not spying upon all these fields of cows. .. Do you think agents do not take holidays?" A: ".. there's no way to tell whether you're lying." J: "What use would I be to my country if any passing British Service agent could tell I was lying? I will admit it puts me at a disadvantage when I happen to be telling the truth." A: "Fortunately, that doesn't happen often." The first night she offers tea and comfort p111. J: "It is my wish to spend the night with you, in your bed." A: "It is a dull day that doesn't bring some surprise." J: "You are said to be a young steed in bed. I stayed in an inn in Milan run by two widows." A: "I offered to marry them both, but they didn't take me up on it." A minor English diplomat falls to his death, clutching several hairs of his killer, for overheard words "La dame, le fou, la tour" and an imminent date. They must solve this riddle to save Napoleon, but the ensuing bullet drives them apart until 1818. Another puzzle asks what mastermind plants Hawker-initialled knives into (former?) French spies in London? ( The only possible mastermind gets the best possible end, well-deserved. Sneaky political Military Intelligence rival bought Cache Jane Cardiff at 11, abused and enslaved her will. Our heroes find, decode, and use appropriately her journal. Surprisingly Pax was earlier Cache, and Adrian deals creative merciful justice. ) Typos: p244 "that first day I opened the door or my shop" to "of my shop" p254 "He could have been a savage on one of the far islands of the world who had never been clothed" grammar misplaces clause, denudes island, to "He could have been a naked savage from one of the far islands of the world". Keeping "on" hints undressed only on island, maybe modest elsewhere. If "He could have been a savage who had never been clothed, from one of the far islands of the world", even with comma, clothes may originate from island. Amusing to imagine giant sizes hat, shirt, pants, or dress? suitably distributed on stony outcrops or vegetation, gloves wave on palm trees? boots protrude from underwater reef? Islands were "never clothed"; suggested image is incongruous and impossible; original meaning was already clear. But grammar can be fun play. You can probably find misplaced clauses all over my own writing too. Our brains naturally make sense of what our eyes see. Because Black Hawk is a finalist, I may check out others at http://dabwaha.wordpress.com/category... or four others Bourne likes Heart of Steel by Meljean Brook A Lot Like Love by Julie James The Rose Garden by Susanna Kearsley Fate's Edge by Ilona Andrews on her blog entry http://jobourne.blogspot.ca/2012/03/d...

Really torn on the rating. On the flip side this is a solid book, I enjoy the characters and the author's writing. However... 1) The theme (a serial killer that rapes and tortures children) didn't appeal to me, this is by far the darkest book in the series. 2) Two rather big plot points are left unresolved at the end of the book. One of the killers still hasn't been brought to justice, and the death of Lady Jarvis is strongly hinted to be murder. In hindsight, I wish I had waited to read this book until the next one came out.

It was slightly below par for Amanda Quick (JAK). I'd already read Desi's review: At one point they took turns all three of them calling the heroine's sister brilliant (for making quite an obvious suggestion), one after the other, forming an irritating chorus of redundant praise. Surely every character need not repeat the same silly compliment? ), and really laughed out loud everytime that occurred (more than once!). But, I still think the author did a fair enough job. My main quibble is,  she's managed to not drag any OW into the main story in any of her previous books. And for the main villain/associate to be the OW is a cliche that's been overused in romance mysteries. I never expected JAK to take that route. She does a good job of it, but I'm taking off one star for the hackneyed stereotypical plot, and one star for... oh, just because I expected much better.

I liked this one better while I was reading it than after I was finished, if that makes sense. While I was reading, the pacing was brisk and the writing humorous and interesting, and there was still some hope that some of the logical inconsistencies might be explained. I mean, the character-training-to-impersonate-a-noble trope is fairly well-worn territory in fiction. In most versions, though, the character is taking the place of a person that either no one else has met before, or hasn't seen for years and years. In this story, however, we have a girl taking the place of another girl in a high-ranking, public position, interacting with people who last saw the girl she is replacing a few MONTHS ago. How, exactly, is that supposed to work? They look superficially alike in hair and eye color, and they seem to rely on the fact that the original was supposedly sick and our new girl is thinner and people attribute some of the difference to that, but...really? A person who has lost a few pounds in a few months doesn't look like a totally different person. What's more, do none of her close friends and associates know her voice? Her mannerisms? Her interests? After reading it, I was left with the fact that, although some people had figured this out, a lot hadn't, and this wasn't going to be addressed. Not only that, one of the people who had figured it out immediately, the princess on whom Peggy is waiting, was apparently going to take her back on as a Lady-In-Waiting, but as herself. Perhaps I read wrong and she is keeping up the facade of this other character, but it didn't read that way. How would that work? "Here's this girl who we've been passing off as your old friend, but she's not, she's this other girl. We're sure she'll remain a great spy, because why wouldn't all of you trust a person like that with your treasonous secrets?" I'll probably read the next one for fun, and to see if they ever try to straighten any of this out, but I'm not counting on it making a great deal of sense.

First off I loved Scarlet! I couldn't wait for this book to come out, but I couldn't find it as enjoyable as the first one. Maybe it's because I listened to the the first one as an audiobook and read this one,idk. I found it hard to understand what she was saying sometimes. I had to reread many part's. I also liked that the first one had more of the band in it. Which is the best part of any Robin Hood story. Also Scarlet's stubbornness, and actions started to annoy me at times. I also found some stuff unnecessary Like really did they need to cut off her fingers? and where did this sudden PTSD come from? If he had it, wouldn't it have been noticeable in the first one as well? I did love that there was more of Scarlet and Rob's love story, because I was really upset they didn't even kiss by the end of the last one. It took me awhile to finish this one,because I couldn't shake off the feeling of impending doom. It turns out I was right! I couldn't believe it ended like that. It was so depressing! How could they kill off John? Especially before him and Rob could fully make up! I was even a little saddened by Guy's death. The book made me feel sorry for him in a way. Even though he could be a real bastard at times. I knew they couldn't end it with everybody happy,because there's still another book. It still really upset me though.

Eh. I liked the characters, but I thought... the friction between them in England felt forced. Also, if someone left me mourning their death for, what, 4 weeks? And then walked into a room where I was oblivious and drinking tea, like nothing had happened, they'd be dead for real. But she barely batted an eye at it - she was mad and over it so fast it was utterly unbelievable to me. So this overall gets a meh. That said, I'm still curious about the ring. So perhaps I'll press onward anyway.

Dorrie is a 30 something African-American hairdresser in Texas. One of her favorite clients is Isabelle, a 90 year old white woman. Dorrie considers them to be close but it is quite unexpected when Isabelle asks her if she can drive her to a funeral in Ohio - tomorrow. Dorrie is having problems of her own with her family and decides that a few days away might be good for everyone. Once on the road Isabelle shocks Dorrie by starting to tell a story about her romantic relationship with a black man in Kentucky in 1939. I listened to this on audio (partially during a road trip through Kentucky) and it was very well done. There were two narrators; one for each character. The production was great. That being said - For the love of all that is holy, don't listen to this book on audio! Seriously, you'll thank me for that advice. Here's the problem. If I had been reading this book I probably wouldn't have put it down. It would have been a page turner for me. But when you listen to it on audio you can't go any faster. It is going to take 13 hours no matter how much you want to know what happens. The book is suspenseful. You know any book talking about a relationship between a white woman and a black man in Kentucky in 1939 isn't going to be all sunshine and roses. I found myself saying "Oh, this is bad" a lot. I also found myself driving through Kentucky yelling into my voice search on my phone trying to find out how this books ends. I was still going to listen to it anyway but I wanted to know a few things because my nerves were about shot. There are no spoilers for this on the internet that I found. I've very annoyed about that. Sometimes you need spoilers for your own peace of mind so I'm putting a minor one here. If you are looking for spoilers in a panic because you need to know if it is going to be slightly ok before your next stop - you're welcome. Robert does not get murdered because of his relationship with Isabelle. I liked Dorrie and her story. I liked her reactions to thinking that she was doing a favor for a nice old lady and suddenly finding herself swept up in this secret from Isabelle's past. I wouldn't have been as patient as this character was in finding out what happened. (See "yelling into voice search in Kentucky"). I found the young Isabelle to be very naive and because of that she was annoying at times. A lot of what happened might have been lessened had she made more of an effort to stand up for herself instead of passively going along once things got rough. Overall it is a sad book because of the damage that was done to everyone involved with Isabelle because of the tension between black and whites in Kentucky. I highly recommend it.

I first heard about this book from my father who read it when it first came out (read it on his Palm Pilot, so yeah it's been a while). Over the ensuing decade or so, I had heard on and off how great this book was. So I was a little disappointed upon reading it. First of all, it's not really about Galileo's Daughter which was rather disappointing. Maybe I should've known better, should've realized that it's really a biography of Galileo, but I didn't. So here I am for the first part of the book waiting for all the interesting things about Galileo's daughter and nun life and all that. Except it never really delivered. I mean, as a biography of Galileo it's good I suppose though there were times I felt like the author assumed I knew more about the scientist than I actually did. But it was disappointing to me because the letters from Souer Maria Celeste and the explanations of some things behind her letters and her life in the convent were the most interesting parts to me, but they weren't delved into with any depth. And then you get to the end and it feels a little rushed. Maria Celeste dies abruptly, followed shortly by Galileo and it's like "oh, ok." So if you know some things about Galileo and want to get a little more into his life then by all means, read this book. For me it wasn't the best book I'd read and it was difficult for me to finish.

I devoured this book. Sophia has come to Russia to claim the Russian throne and Prince Peter's heart. But what happens when Sophia finds that Peter is not who he seems? What happens when Sophia finds herself falling for someone else, a doomed romance? I'm so glad I was given the opportunity to read this. It was simply amazing. There are no other words to describe this. Everything fell into place to create this awesome story of Catherine the Great. I loved Sophia's story. It was so interesting to learn about her life, past and present. The Russian court was simply amazing as well. I've always loved books with a Russian theme, so I couldn't put this book down. Sophia herself was an amazing main character. She's so strong. She's smart and cunning. She's caring. And, yes, she knows that men think of her as a possession-something to own. But does she ever bend and break to it? No. She outsmarts them all. I found my heart breaking for her many times. I also found myself rooting for her. She deserves happiness and real love. She is definitely one of the best MC's I've read in a while. She really stayed true to the real Catherine the Great. Her character was very historically accurate as far as her personality goes. The royal court side to things was also very interesting. It reminded me of a soap opera with all of the drama that was going on. I know that there was always scandal in royal courts, but jeez. Anyways, I liked it. It kept things interesting when things were starting to get a little bland. The steps to becoming a suitable bride was also really cool to read about. The romance.. wow. I feel like I should hose myself down with cold water after reading this book. The romance was so intense. I could practically feel the passion seeping out of this book. And it was even a gradual love (yay). There is a love triangle in this book... or more of a love square if you want to call it that. There are three possible love interests in this book. I felt like all three had really good chances of being "the one" and I was really torn in half of who I wanted Sophia/Catherine to be with. NOT Peter. He was a jerk. But Alexander? Ugh, he was so mysterious and brooding. And Serg... he was so kind and compassionate. However, I am content on who she "picks" at the end, although it was sort of bittersweet. UGH. This book was just too perfect. How will I ever come down from this book high?

What a strange book. I bought this back in 2007 or so and quickly gave up on it because it was so BORING. At times, when action occurred, this book was great. The travel sections were beautifully written, and I nearly missed my stop on the train twice because I was so engrossed. Sadly these exciting travel sections were interspersed with dull historical background - I could probably have skipped those bits and not lost anything. It was all too easy during those dull sections to become distracted and spend twenty minutes staring at the photo of the author on the back cover and wondering what the story was there - why is she wearing her Queen Victoria cosplay? One question which I had at the end. Does the plot actually make sense? Why was Dracula giving the books out to historians, only to dissuade them from continuing their hunt for him once they'd become interested? If all he's ever wanted is someone to catalogue his book collection, surely this is the most ineffectual recruitment method in existence? Actually, one further question: why do we never know the daughters name? Ten years later, and I am glad that I've finally ploughed through it, partly because that means I can remove it from my home. I'm going to give it to my mum, because she reads really quickly and doesn't seem to take much in, so she should quite like it.

I enjoyed The Good Earth, particularly the first half. The story did not go where I thought it would and from about the time that Wang Lung takes a concubine  to the end I was feeling frustrated, but in the end I think I started to appreciate what Buck was doing, and the story, which had gotten too big, in my opinion, got even a bit bigger, and that saved it for me. (I really don't know what the hell I'm talking about and clearly I need to think a more about this book. Apparently, it is the first in a trilogy, but I'm hoping it's more a thematic trilogy as there were no characters I wanted to read more about left alive by the end. ) The prose is deceptively simple. I found myself riveted by the details of daily life and work and land and less so by the parts of the story that dealt with internecine relationships. I've been having a hard time deciding if being irritated with the main character throughout much of the book is a testament to Buck's writing or not, but I think probably it is. By far, my favorite character is O-lan and  I really missed her when she was gone; for me she was the moral center and heart of the story. I listened to the audiobook read by Anthony Heald, who did a fantastic job. I was even wondering if perhaps the book would have been harder for me to get through during the second half if I had been reading a paper book. I might have gotten sick of another bad, selfish, stupid decision made by Wang Lung   and given up. It was the perfect book for the summer, too, and it reminded me of a summer a few years ago when I was listened to the entire Laura Ingalls Wilder series while I was working on a labor intensive quilt I was putting together for a friend. The work was long and monotonous, but compared to what the characters were struggling with, it was nothing. The Good Earth, as Buck would perhaps write, was "such an one."

I loved Lilian's spunk and laughed quite a bit. I wasn't sure I would enjoy a volume with Westcliff as the love interest as he was a bit of a stick in the mud in the first volume of the series but in this volume and behind closed doors--hhmmmmmmm! And I ordered the next two volumes today! So saying that.... The ending left me wondering how Kleypas will manage to redeem  Viscount St. Vincent after he kidnaps Lillian and has her handcuffed in a carriage to force her to marry him in Gretna Green. I mean, he was painted as a rake but not one who would kidnap a girl by drugging her with ether to marry her for her fortune. Especially a girl he'd already been on friendly terms with. Buy this book at Powells Books.

I don't read many m/f romances these days, but the blurb on this one caught my attention. I love the concept of a caveman and a modern woman. Fortunately, the book did not turn out to just be a great idea with mediocre execution. I enjoyed the story and felt the deep love of the two MCs, though at times it was difficult to figure out exactly what was going on with the 'future' woman. I was of two minds about whether or not we really should have seen more of the female's POV. On the one hand, as I mentioned, sometimes things were just confusing without it because the caveman could not fathom what was going on so his descriptions were not very helpful. For example, the description of the device the father arrived on and later the 'black rectangle' that she kept items in. What was it? The fact that it was so 'magical' made it seem like she was from a time far beyond our own. . On the other hand, there was value in the reader staying as confused as the caveman in the story and being fully in his head. I'm not sure if a modern girl would really choose to stay in a world without TV, shopping malls, cell phones, and, like, people to talk to. But Ehd was very sweet and I was willing to roll with it. Very unusual and romantic. Recommended.

My gut reaction upon finishing this was to give it five stars, but I might have to bump it down to four, for lack of character development. Also the ending is kind of blah...I remember having that same issue with Between Shades of Gray as well. It sort of lacks the emotional punch of all that comes before it. Plus, I wanted Joana to find out  that Lina was still alive and also conveniently married her love interest! I'm not sure why I have such a strong reaction against either of these relationships. After all, the only thing that makes me marginally less sad when I think about The Book Thief is my fantasy epilogue in which Liesel and Max get married. And I squeed when Rose Under Fire confirmed that Maddie and Jamie DID get married after the end of Code Name Verity. But Joana and Florian? Wasn't feeling it. I think it comes back to that lack of character development. There are four different narrators here: the aforementioned Florian and Joana, a soldier with a secret and a nurse, respectively. Then there's Emilia, a Polish girl on the run after the Russians attacked Nemmersdorf, and sailor Alfred, who has an over-inflated sense of self importance. I figured his stupid ass would be the only one to survive, and I found his death morbidly satisfying. You kick some xenophobic ass, Emilia! Emilia latches onto Florian when he rescues her from a Russian soldier and they quickly meet up with Joana and a group of refugees, include a shoemaker, a lost boy, and Eva, who's a filter-less pessimist. Alfred is aboard the Wilhelm Gustloff, which is where the other 3 are headed, trying to escape the Allies' inevitable invasion of Poland and East Prussia. It's interesting to see the war from the Axis side. In this case, the Allies are the enemies (to be fair, it seems to mostly be Russians, and I've never been clear what side they ended up on, truly). Also, did you know that the sinking of the Wilhelm Gustloff was the greatest maritime tragedy, worse than Titanic or Lusitania? Because I sure didn't! Seriously didn't know this boat existed until I heard about this book. And Sepetys doesn't really have much of an explanation for WHY. I suspect it's the same reason no one knew about what happened in the Baltic nations until decades later. I mean...there were 10,000 people on that boat! It was built for only around 1500, and ten of the lifeboats weren't even on board. Only a thousand people survived. It's horrific and yet no one has heard of it. It's certainly an emotionally gripping story, and the chapters are all very short, so it moves quickly. But I feel like the horror of the situation is doing a lot of the emotional heavy lifting. It's gut-wrenching to read about what the refugees in that harbor experienced before even getting on the doomed boat, and once the Wilhelm Gustloff states sinking, it only gets...gut-wrenchinger. I'm horrified and emotionally affected because the situation itself is horrifying (so many babies getting thrown and not being caught), not because I'm emotionally connected to the characters (Unless you count a strong desire to punch Alfred). I will say that all four narrators do feel distinct. I had very little trouble telling them apart, but for some reason I just didn't feel that connection. This is still a great, fast read, and I am definitely planning to add it to my shelf for my next round of World War II novels.

Since I adored Code Name Verity, I pre-ordered this book almost immediately after I learned of its existence. It's sort of a companion to Verity, in that it takes place (at first) with the ATA female pilots (and we get to see Maddie again and she's still a badass), but really you could read one without having read the other. I feel like I appreciate some of the early plot points more, having read Verity (Maddie and Jamie get married and live in a castle! Now I just need Marcus Zuzak to write some kind of Book Thief companion wherein we learn that Liesel and Max also got married and lived in a castle and my life will be complete! Anyway. This time our protagonist is Rose Justice, an American pilot working for the ATA in Britain, with our favorite badass lady pilot Maddie. Time-wise, it takes place after all of the events of Verity, and while Maddie talks a little about Julie, Wein is able to refer to the story without giving away too many of the major plot points. I like that it's sort of a sequel in that we get to catch up with Maddie (and she gets the happy ending she so sorely deserves), but it's clearly Rose's story. Rose's father trained her to fly from a very young age, so she's a skilled pilot even though she's only 18 years old. On a routine transport to Paris, Rose is captured by the Germans when she makes the mistake of trying to knock a doodlebug (a pilotless bomb) out of the air. She's more or less successful in that particular endeavor, but in tailing the doodlebug, she becomes lost and eventually runs out of fuel. Since she's American, in a British plane, in German territory, officials naturally suspect the worst and it isn't long until Rose is transported to Ravensbruck, a concentration camp primarily for political prisoners. Oddly enough, this is what I had assumed would be the plot of Verity (I still have no idea where I got that particular notion), so it was incredibly compelling to see it laid out here. Wein frames the story of Rose's time in the camp in the form of a journal, which she writes after her return to Paris, safe and (mostly) sound. It's a really interesting framing device, in that Rose is a bit scattered at first -- she's safe, but she doesn't remember what it's like to be safe, and she's having a hard time dealing with some pretty crippling feelings of guilt. It's a fascinating exploration. Most of the novels or survivors accounts I'm familiar with deal with the time in the camp, but not with what happened after people returned to the world. And Rose is faced with a world that doesn't want to believe her stories. I think there was quite a bit of denial at the time -- no one wants to think that humans are truly capable of committing such atrocities against one another. It's far easier to believe the survivors invented their stories than that their captors actually did such things. Wein shows Rose wrestling with all of those emotions -- what does she say to her family? How can she put on a happy face for her mother and her aunt when all she can think about are the women she left behind, and the ones who were never able to escape? Rose spends around two weeks in Paris, writing fiendishly to get all of it down --the writing seems to have a calming effect. She's been tasked to tell the world what happened in Ravensbruck, but she can't seem to actually talk about it. Writing it down sort of frees her from having to tell anyone, but provides a record nonetheless. I like that throughout, Wein has Rose frequently reference the fact that she's writing a story (she knowingly leaves out details that are too hard to recall, or too boring, and she's honest when she legitimately does not remember something). Upon arriving at camp, Rose is savagely beaten by the guards, and tossed into what basically amounts to solitary confinement for a week. She manages to make friends with the French girls in her transport, and one -- Elodie -- remains her connection within the camp, even though the two never see one another after their initial two weeks together. After leaving confinement, Rose ends up in Bunk 32 with the group of women known as Rabbits. Though Rose is not a real person, the Rabbits and the experiments performed on them are horrifyingly real -- Wein apparently used survivor accounts and testimonies to peice together the Rabbits' stories (and she uses many of their real names). Much like Mengel at Auschwitz, the doctors at Ravensbruck performed horrific experiments on a small group of women who came to be known as Rabbits. Most of the "experiments" involve simulating various leg injuries, ostensibly to help the troops injured in combat. Wein spares almost no detail in describing these injuries, and the women in the camp are fiercely protective of all of the Rabbits -- it is their story and their wounds that will finally tell the world the truth of what happened in Ravensbruck. The lengths to which people will go to protect them are incredible -- at one point, a group of women spend an entire week underneath the tile in the bathroom, after their numbers are called for the gas chambers. I cannot even begin to wrap my brain around that level of desperation, and Wein has such skill in describing it. Though I liked Rose well enough as a character, the supporting cast make the story here. Rose finds a family of sorts within Ravensbruck, and the relationships between all of the women feel both real and gut-wrenching. They latch onto Rose's poetry (both her own and the poems of Edna St Vincent Millay, which she has memorized), and Rose's own poetry is scattered throughout. Someone of these poems are poignant, and some are a little overwrought, but the importance of poetry to the women is incredibly clear. Rose makes up a counting rhyme to remember the names of the 74 women who were Rabbits, and it is this poem that is the basis for the drive to "tell the world." Her other poems she must craft and then memorize and pass along to the others, without the aid of paper. It's almost heartbreaking to see her reaction in Paris, when faced with her original journal -- a little like Ren in The Year of the Flood, who spent her childhood memorizing lessons and finds writing eerily permanent, Rose struggles initially with the permanence of her words on the paper. Writing the story is like re-living it. The ending was a little unbelievable, but given that we know she gets to Paris somehow the fact that Rose breaks out of a camp is necessarily a surprise (I had assumed she was part of a group who were liberated). I find it hard to believe that three half-starved women were able to clandestinely steal a plane, but I suppose you can chalk it up to the fact that, by that point in the war, the camps weren't being run with the same sort of organization (I feel like in...Night, maybe, it's mentioned that once the Germans knew they'd lost the war, the guards basically just abandoned the camps and left the prisoners to fend for themselves? Am I making that up? ), so no one was around to notice. And given that both Rose and Irina are actual trained pilots, I have no trouble believing that, once they were on board, they were able to fly the plane (unlike the freaking hot air balloon escape at the end of The Dark & Hollow Places). Teaching a Holocaust unit every other year, and having read several Holocaust novels in my life, I had reached a point of...not fatigue, exactly, but a sinking feeling that there wasn't much new to be said. I remember after reading The Twelve, I thought Sarah's experiences sort of mirrored a Holocaust novel, and felt like a lot of the others I'd read were starting to blend together. I'd worried that there was only so much to write about, and that the stories would start to lose their poignancy. Wein renewed my faith in this particular subgenre, and really in historical fiction as a whole. There is indeed, a way to write history without it feeling like a history textbook. Wein is even able to weave in details about flying and air combat without dragging down the narrative. As I said, I like that Wein focused not just on life inside the camps, but on what happened to survivors back in the "real world." I wish more Holocaust novels took this track. In all, this novel has pretty much cemented me as a Wein fan -- as long as she doesn't jump on the paranormal romance trilogy bandwagon, I will read pretty much anything this woman writes. Hopefully she continues her quest to give historical fiction a better name. I'd love to see what she'd do with the roaring twenties...

Read This Review And More Like It On My Blog! This was very, very good. I was surprised by the level of my reaction to this: I was invested near immediately never wanted to put it down and was sad to finish reading the last page. I don't read a lot of "time slip" historical fiction (read: any before this), but if they're like Mariana that rule might need to change. ASAP. First up on that list: every other such book by this author. I was very impressed with both parts of the narrative and the strength of the voice shown throughout the novel. Though Mariana is a bit lengthy at near 375 pages, this suspenseful and affecting tale never bores. For a detailed, immersive read but not one that is exactly an action-packed historical, that is saying something indeed. The strength of the book largely lies in the eponymous character Mariana - both in her 1660's body/life of Mariana and as more modern Julia Beckett. That's not to say that the rest of the characters aren't interesting and diverse; they are but it is Mariana herself who makes the novel special. Though the two POV's present are both first-person and both largely the same in tone and voice despite the centuries between them, both Julia and Mariana are fully dimensional, rounded characters who provide a rich, full narrative to dive into. She's charming and detailed as a narrator: Exbury, both past and present versions, definitely carried the feel of an old, full-of-history English village. Though there is quite a lot of focus on the romance angle of the novel, I wasn't turned off or frustrated; Mariana's and Richard's courtship is actually quite charming and I found myself rooting for de Mornay and the spirited commoner. This paragraph might get a bit SPOILERy so be warned and stay away if you don't want to know! Seriously, people. There's a mystery at the heart of the novel, but it's not the most involving or mystifying. Even the secondary subplot of treason lacks the emotional pull of the characters themselves; this is truly a character-driven novel. Even some of the surprises lacked the oomph that could be expected -(Johnnie! D: John?!) because I was so keyed in on the main characters of Mariana/Julia and Richard/?? themselves. I have to side with Julia in that the past has a lot of allure here in this version, and her attraction to Richard going back to it is very understandable. Love, destiny and fate all play a key parts in the meanderig plot, and the characters but it doesn't feel forced or hackneyed. Mariana comes off with a sweet but not saccharine aftertaste. I did think the camouflaging of Richard's soul was well done - only the hints of Shakespeare really made me sure of who he was in the present . Mariana is an engrossing and rewarding, lengthy read - fans of time-slip historicals will love and even new-to-the-subgrenre people will find a lot to enjoy about this alternate 1660's and modern of reincarnated love. Susanna Kearsley is an impressive and detailed storyteller - I look forward to reading more of her books very soon. This is one that went above and beyond any and all expectations I had before starting.

If I only had one word to use for this awesomely delicious adventure, it would be 'revelatory'. I've caught myself surprised numerous times in my reading, which, needless to say, is thoroughly wonderful and satisfying. I was already more than halfway in lustlove with Colin and I already held Minerva dear, dear to my heart in ANTS, but AWTBW elevated that love for them to new heights. Er, not spoilers really, but under the cut for now nonetheless. Seeing these two lose their equilibrium as they discover and explore the truths uncovered about each other made my heart ache. We are treated to see beyond the facade, and suddenly I was seeing the imperfections and/or insecurities they attempt to amend, and there they were, authentic and heartrendingly real. I love Colin for all his good intentions and fierce protectiveness and genuine affection for M, and I love Minerva for her bravery and fierce loyalty and for allowing herself to live her life for herself. Oh, these two. They may have seemed to be an unlikely pair in the beginning, but discerning minds know it is no coincidence that these two people gravitated towards each other; theirs is a cleverly matched alliance formed in the beginning, turned to a deeply loving allegiance that can't be shaken in the end. I'm so glad to partake in this grand adventure to see two genuinely beautiful people flourish and shine, as individuals and as partners. A Week To Be Wicked is the second book in the Spindle Cove series, and it will be out on March 27, 2012. I've already pre-ordered my copy, but I've been very fortunate to have been given early access to the book via Edelweiss. The third, A Lady by Midnight, will be out this September. I've been waiting for their story too, since ANTS. Heh. :D

I usually adore books by Joanna Chambers, they are the rare one that makes me emotional. This one had all ingridients for the needed catharsis, but unfortunately there was one moment that spoiled the ending of the book for me. After the big relevation talk in the inn in Truro there was no closure between Nick and Ward. The break-off was too fundamental for them to return to their happy-end relationship after Godfrey's death without aknowledging it somehow in the last chapters. I didn't believe in HEA, not for strong willed Nick and Ward who is obviously bad with social interactions. I wouldn't have asked so much from any author, but Joanna Chambers spoilt me with her flawless human studies in Enlightenment series, so now I expect only perfection from her.

First and foremost, trigger warnings should be mentioned and noted before reading this book/this review. TW: drug abuse, self-harm, suicide, anxiety. I don't know, y'all. I decided to sit on this review and think about it but in doing so, I've nearly forgotten about the whole thing because it was just so awful to me. I think I've pretty much blocked it out of my brain. I want to erase it. Okay, so I will tell you some things about it. I'll mark spoilers below. The book starts out with our protagonist, Audrey, who is in high school. Audrey has a panic attack one day and decides to tell a DISGUSTING lie about a classmate to her two best friends. What they don't know is that one of her friend's sister is outside of the door and decides to tell their mom who tells someone else who tells someone else and becomes a full-blown gossip story. Which everyone immediately accepts as absolute truth. The lie ends up being the downfall of this classmate. So, Audrey has to live with the fact that her lie caused so much tragedy and altered the lives of people she both knows and doesn't know. I don't know... sounds a little familiar to 13 Reasons Why, doesn't it? It's not the same but similar. And I haven't read 13 Reasons Why and I won't because of the very problematic aspects. Well, I see the same problematic aspects here. I just need to rant about the lie for a minute because it deeply upset me and set the tone for the rest of the book. MAJOR SPOILERS: Audrey, without blinking an eye, or without taking it back immediately, tells her two best friends that she saw her classmate Ana having sex with her own father. As in incest. Do you see what I mean by utterly disgusting now? I do NOT like this as a plot point and it made me very uncomfortable. It made me even more uncomfortable that the novel tries to right the wrongs of Audrey and turn her into somewhat likable when the basis of this plot is that she made up such a revolting lie that caused the death of Ana. AND ANA IS MADE TO BE THE ONE TO BLAME IN THIS SITUATION SOMEHOW. AND THEN, to top it all off, Audrey pursues a romantic relationship with Ana's boyfriend... who she meets at Ana's funeral. And goes on pretending that everything is jolly and this relationship is healthy. How could I ever root this on in any form? AND AUDREY HAS A BOYFRIEND ALREADY. Who she has been close with since birth pretty much. She is not a nice human! And the entire "romance" is not what love is or should be. And I do NOT think this should be considered a romance book. It's a book about a terrible girl who told a terrible lie. And the ending... dear Lord, it was awful. Just plain awful. I could go into an entire new rant on that alone. It was TERRIBLE. Look, I know that some books are morally grey (I just wrote a review about one that did it well! ), but this is something I couldn't get on board with. Every part of it made me feel disgusted. Besides the awful plot, two characters were used as absolute filler for drama (Candela) and to promote another relationship (Duck), and many of the other characters just fell flat and didn't feel real at all. Audrey's decisions made me really angry and her self-loathing over creating so much calamity also made me roll my eyes. Because YEAH WHO DOES THAT. Even with the panic attacks and anxiety (hello I've dealt with this all my life), I just couldn't relate. None of it felt very realistic. There's just no redeeming qualities to her. AT ALL. But I will say that the book ended very fittingly. Especially for such deeply unlikable characters. Wolves in sheep's clothing, like in the blurb. At least Leav seems to be aware of that fact. This book just wasn't my cup of tea. At all. I need something to root for. I don't think there are good messages in this book, and I don't really think it's appropriate (or healthy) for teenagers to read. I'm just looking out. I think a lot of what's written in here is super dangerous territory. I would hate for the "lessons" in this book to be taken to heart by young people. I do not recommend this book at all.

There was no logical reason why I chose Hamlet to be the next Shakespeare on my reading list, but I'm glad I did. Polonius irked me from the beginning in fact, I was cheering Hamlet on when he stabbed him. And how stupid he was for giving away his position in the first place! I think that Rosencrantz and Guildenstern reflect the snakes that enter everyone's life at some point: cowardly, selfish backstabbers. Poor Ophelia! I realize that Hamlet had other things on his mind, (like which family member to kill first) but couldn't he have at least admitted to his love for Ophelia before she was six feet under!? I wanted to slap everyone for trying to use her as a pawn. And I rather enjoyed her eerie songs while they lasted. Is it weird that my favorite scene was in Act V when Hamlet was playing with skulls and talking to the gravediggers? Up until Act IV, sc. vii, I would have rated it five stars  however, I docked a star because Shakespeare killed off Ophelia, but didn't kill off Laertes and Claudius soon enough. I liked this much more than Julius Caesar and Romeo & Juliet.

Despite the three star review, this was one of the best works of poetry I've read in a long time. It might have resonated with me more if I had been actively grieving over something while reading it. But I enjoyed Porter's style, specifically his use of onomatopoeia and his mixture of verses and small paragraphs. From my understanding, I thought Crow was the embodiment of grief; he came uninvited, reminded the father and the children of the fact that their mother was gone, etc. But what I found a little disconcerting was the way that Crow (read: grief) became the protector of the family. He fought the demons at the front door, he felt sorry for the children, and towards the end became the father's companion. Sometimes, I felt as if I got the whole point wrong and maybe Crow was supposed to be symbolic of the father's work, considering that Crow left when the father's book was fully written. It is a beautiful thought--that even when you feel so alone, grief is always there with you. But I've always thought of grief as a dull, pulsating headache that you can't get rid of instead of a hand on the shoulder. And I think that's where Porter missed the mark. Then again, grief is different for everyone, and perhaps this is just one of its many manifestations. What I did glean from this book was that grief is something that comes uninvited, but you have to give it permission to leave. And if the point of a work of fiction is to make you think introspectively as well as abstractly, then this one has definitely fulfilled that purpose. I think it'll stay with me for a long time.

This book started out so yellow that it turned me off for a while. But I think I ended up getting some of it. But I'm not sure yet. There's something about existence and the lingering effect of things, actions, occurrences. About longing and erosion. But I seemed to not care completely about any of this. The language made me keep a distance from what was being said. But some things inevitably remained. Specially how blue fucking can be. Some passages that I had to write down: Perhaps it is becoming clearer why I felt no romance when you told me that you carried my last letter with you, everywhere you went, for months on end, unopened. This may have served some purpose for you, but whatever it was, surely it bore little resemblance to mine. I never aimed to give you a talisman, an empty vessel to flood with whatever longing, dread, or sorrow happened to be the day's mood. I wrote it because I had something so say to you. "We're only given as much as the heart can endure," "What doest not kill you makes you stronger," "Our sorrows provide us with the lessons we most need to learn": these are the kinds of phrases that enrage my injured friend. Indeed, one would be hard-pressed to come up with a spiritual lesson that demands becoming a quadriparalytic. The tepid "there must be a reason for it" notion sometimes floated by religious or quasi-religious acquaintances or bystanders, is, to her, another form of violence. She has no time for it. She is too busy asking, in this changed form, what makes a livable life, and how she can live it. That the future is unknwoable is, for some, God's means of suturing us in, or to, the present moment. For others, it is the mark of a malevolence, a sure sign that out entire existence here is best understood as a sort of joke or mistake. For me, it is neither. It is simply the way that it is. Whether this accident be a happy or unhappy one is probably more a matter of mood than anything else; the difficulty is that "our moods do not believe in each other" (Emerson). One can wander about the landscape looking for clues, amassing evidence, but even the highest pile never seems to decide the case.

My first brush with Blake was through the impeccable poem London more than a decade back. Since then, I'd got to read more poems of his, all carefully chosen by the academicians, quickly putting him in my list of favorite poets. Then before I reached my twenties, I read this little collection, and liked it immensely. Songs of Innocence was what I was looking for, with its naive outlook on life, the idyllic pictures of innocence I was unwilling to leave behind on my trek to youth. I was enamored (and still am) by the introductory piece: Piping down the valleys wild Piping songs of pleasant glee On a cloud I saw a child. And he laughing said to me. Pipe a song about a Lamb; So I piped with merry chear, Piper pipe that song again-- So I piped, he wept to hear. Drop thy pipe thy happy pipe Sing thy songs of happy chear, So I sung the same again While he wept with joy to hear. Piper sit thee down and write In a book that all may read-- So he vanish'd from my sight. And I pluck'd a hollow reed. And I made a rural pen, And I stain'd the water clear, And I wrote my happy songs Every child may joy to hear. To me, this was that drop of amnesiac honey that helped me get over the agony of the house-shifting we'd done that summer more than a decade ago, from a lush green safe township in the corner of the city to a closer-to-the-city, concrete-laden, greenery-starved, space-crunched area. It wasn't all that bad either, as I discovered later, but none of the former beauty of greeting the morning sun flanked by luxurious trees amidst the warbling of a dozen different birds remained. Suddenly, I was waking up to a harsh sun with no shady trees, and hardly any birds. Gone were the little gardens that every small home had. Now we had a larger home, with barely any space for even potted plants, let alone a garden. So yeah, poets like Wordsworth and Blake with their lyrical beauty and pastoral happy images and bleak city images were very much resonant with me. Now so many years later, while retaining my nostalgia for that magical place that had been my h(e)aven for many years, I am better capable of judging this collection from a newer perspective - one that has been shaped by reading many more poems since then, and has also gotten over the shift from innocence to experience, and values both equally. The first section of the collection, Songs of Innocence, now seems to me too simplistic with little exquisite craftsmanship that Wordsworth or Coleridge or even Browning still retains for me. They sound more like little elementary rhyming structures instead of that breath-taking exhilaration I want when I expect nostalgia to sweep over me. Only occasionally do I see those powerful streaks of thought, as in the little piece The Divine Image: And all must love the human form, In heathen, Turk, or Jew; Where Mercy, Love, and Pity dwell There God is dwelling too. Songs of Experience, however, fared better. There were glimmers of the pain that comes with experience, but also a sense of enlightenment that you wouldn't exchange for anything in the world, not even that former unblemished and profound innocence. But those bright powerful streaks ended soon, like a comet - blink-and-miss.
