I mean I understand the mother's situation but the way she took it, the lengths she went through, it was all at the expense of her daughter. Towards the end of the book she didn't even deserves Kasienka's love. I'm really glad that William didn't turn out to be trash like almost everyone else in Kasienka's life. Long story short, this book made me angry with how unfair it was and her mother's a blind mule like Kasienka's mother said.

Wow! I was a fan of Nabokov's prose thanks to Lolita but that book has nothing on this one. Pale Fire is many-layered, many-framed and at times makes my head spin. I wanted to knock off a few points for some incomprensible passages, but I finally decided that's a fault of mine and not of Nabokov's. Pale Fire starts with a long, long poem that takes almost 1/3 of the entire book. From the advice of another reader, I skipped the poem and dived right into the meat of the actual story, which is commentary on the poem. Now, one can say that reading a commentary of a 1000-line poem sounds boring and I would even say that if I hadn't just read this book, but trust me, it's awesome. Nabokov's prose is so lyrical, so wonderful, so funny sometimes that it makes me turn green with envy. For example, this part, where the narrator was complaining about being invited to a dinner party where his hosts knew in advance of his vegetarian eating habits but still tried to serve him meat: "I revanched myself rather neatly. Of a dozen or so invitations that I extended, the Shades accepted just three. Every one of these meals was built around some vegetable that I subjected to as many exquisite metamorphoses as Parmentier had his pet tuber undergo." How can one not fall in love with such a masterful command of language? Pale Fire is certainly a book that requires a dictionary or even an encyclopedia to fully enjoy. It's hard work to read through, but it is so, so worth it. And the double entendres overflow this book if you're into that sort of thing! What Nabokov excels at most is his descriptions of people and their situations. Take this one for example: "One finds it hard to decide what Gradus alias Grey wanted more at that minute: discharge his gun or rid himself of the inexhaustible lava in his bowels." How can diarrhea sound so good? Because it comes out of Nabokov's pen. Pale Fire blew my mind on several levels, but one of the biggest explosions in my mind came at the end when our narrator realizes that the poem he wanted so much to be about Zembla actually isn't. He ends up crestfallen that his beautiful country won't be immortalized on paper through this poem. But the mind-blowing part is that it actually ends up being immortalized on paper through his commentary on the poem. It blew my mind in the same way that I Love Lucy is a successful television show about a woman who tries unsuccessfully to break into show-biz. So meta! A spoilered discussion of the plot follows. If you haven't read the book but are thinking about it, please, please don't read the spoiler. It will tarnish the experience of reading it for the first time. It becomes obvious early on that Charles Kinbote is the often-mentioned escaped ex-King of Zembla. Even before he starts hinting at it, an astute reader can easily figure it out. How else would someone know such fine details of the king's life? Although I had fairly solid suspicion this was the case early in, what really sealed the deal was Kinbote's comment about being a vegetarian himself. Even before I suspected Kinbote as being the king, I suspected he was in love with Shade. I think this suspicion grew in parallel with my suspicion that he was gay, which probably led me to the suspicion of him being the King. It's too coincidental to have two flamboyantly gay characters in a Nabokov novel, no?

Um, so apparently there's not one but two film adaptations of this. Wtf? One is a 75 minute documentary from 2011 and the other is a Disney-style animated narrative from last year. Maybe I should finish reading it before watching the animation, but I probably won't. My mom liked this a lot during her rebellious phase, back when she read Salinger--the first I ever read of it was in her little old journal that she didn't realize was stashed with the rest of her books. Apparently, my mother really identified with the Fat Lady soliloquy at the end of Franny which was at once goddamn shocking and hilarious to us. Once I found a very aged/mildewed copy of one of Gibran's other works that included an equally aged advertisement for this book. I was tempted to take it with me, as it was part of someone's apartment bookcase-dump, but my arms (and bags) were already overflowing with other items (some of which I passed out freely to any and all passers-by) so I left it where it was. The mildewy books which I ended up bringing home were plenty for my mildew-y Desi system. Eventually, I'll relocate to Malbazar or Berlin or Irving, Texas; leaving my own conglomerated library on the sidewalk too.

Many say that this is nothing more than an overrated, incomprehensible bunch of words about sex, alcohol and drugs. And they are right. But poetry is not about words, it's about the feeling they are capable of evoke. And Howl evoke a lot of feelings, at least for me. The eternal search of the meaning of life, the conflicted relation between the fear and mystification of death, the wonders and terrors of growing old. "I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness, starving hysterical naked, [...] who threw their watches off the roof to cast their ballot for Eternity outside of Time, & alarm clocks fell on their heads every day for the next decade, who cut their wrists three times successively unsuccessfully, gave up and were forced to open antique stores where they thought they were growing old and cried, who were burned alive in their innocent flannel suits on Madison Avenue amid blasts of leaden verse & the tanked-up clatter of the iron regiments of fashion & the nitroglycerine shrieks of the fairies of advertising & the mustard gas of sinister intelligent editors, or were run down by the drunken taxicabs of Absolute Reality." If you want to change the world but don't know how, if you want to leave your mark but fear you can't, if you are afraid of waking up one day with your dreams and ideals long forgotten and trapped in the mundane routine of the world. Then, you can relate with this "overrated, incomprehensible bunch of words about sex, alcohol and drugs", and that's all that matters. "We're not our skin of grime, we're not our dread bleak dusty imageless locomotive, we're all beautiful golden sunflowers inside, we're blessed by our own seed & golden hairy naked accomplishment- bodies growing into mad black formal sunflowers in the sunset." Leido para el reto 12 months-12 classic: Julio.

This was kind of a mess... I had many issues with this book, it all started with the first 'huge secret/reveal/plot twist', it's so bad, I still can't imagine how someone would do that and why? Audrey, the protagonist, starts telling us all about a lie that she had told her friends, a lie she had never expected to blow up or impact anyone's life. Actually, she imagined she would be able to tell her friends years from then that it was all a lie. Nothing real. And that lie was that a girl they all knew, Ana, was having sex with her father. Yap, you read that clearly enough. How can you believe that saying such a lie would impact no one? Then it gets a million times worse, the love interest is presented and we have a serious case of emotional cheating and then physical cheating too. I could understand what she meant when she said it was hard for her to break-up with her longtime, since-childhood boyfriend, but still it took her so long. Also, her love interest is the ex-boyfriend of the girl who commited suicide because of the lie she told. And she has little to no guilt when it comes to it. I hated how the only characters who seemed to have depth were Audrey and Rad and the others were one dimensional, even though at some point I would have preferred to read about anyone else. I would have liked this book a lot more if it didn't feel like it's trying to soften its characthers' mistakes, like I could do just well with a morally grey character that admits to it. But Audrey feels sorry for herself all the time and is whiny about it and likes to think that she's better than anyone else and just ugh. Also, her boyfriend, Rad (ex-boyfriend of Ana, the 'dead girl') killed Ana by accident and then staged a suicide. He was forgiven by Audrey, however, and they ended up together, being the power couple, yikes. The only characters I liked were Lucy and Freddy and as expected they didn't end up well. This book was totally not for me. Just too problematic.

I grieve that I must give the Bard a mediocre rating for a play rich in critique of justice and thick with dramatic tension [I believe it was act II or III whose final scene made me go "WHOAAAAAAAAAAA"] but there are more problems with this Problem Play than just categorizing it as a comedy or a tragedy [or even a "romance" as I've sometimes seen, would not accurately describe this play]. I mean, after the mid-way point, the play starts to fall apart a bit; perhaps a trend with Shakespeare, as I felt the same way about Richard III. And Act V's "big reveal" of the Duke sentencing everyone to scare them and then marrying them off instead [except maybe Comic Relief Man Lucio who may be getting married and then executed? I wasn't too clear on that.] did not come off quite as well as it could have. I found it unbelievable that the Provost, who was in cahoots with the Duke/Friar throughout, would not have instantly revealed Claudio's still being alive at the threat of losing his job... And where does the Duke get off wanting to marry a woman who has been all about becoming a nun from Act I? BUT, problems aside, the poetry is (as always) beautiful, the sex jokes amusing, and as I said before Measure For Measure can be a real thriller up to about Act V. I suggest reading it, but only if you're already a fan of Shakespeare's work. It's not his best, from an entertainment perspective.

I really loved this one. I need to read it again. Every poem was beautiful, and the heartbreaking feeling of being so permanently "new and different" is captured beautifully. I loved the search for her Father, and thought the outcome, although sad, was almost to be expected, given the way he had almost run from Kasienka and her mother. Speaking of the mother, her and their neighbor? I was rooting for them the whole time  . Kasienka's relationship with William developed wonderfully; it seemed natural and (in many respects) just the way middle schoolers should behave when they find themselves falling in love.

DNF @ 20% I'm not going to give this book a rating, simply because I didn't read that much of it, but I truly cannot bring myself to read more than I already have. In the 70 or so pages I read, there were some things that I didn't click with: - So much  telling  . Page after page of telling instead of showing things that happened, which made it difficult for me to get into the story. - Insta love . Normally, I'm willing to give it a chance, but here it was just too  insta  for me. Because everything was  telling  I really didn't understand how they could feel something for each other, which led to me not caring about their friendship/relationship at all. -This is I guess a personal issue, but one all the same. I couldn't connect to any of the characters, especially Audrey. They all come off as spoiled rich kids with substance abuse problems and bad parents. I couldn't bring myself to care about them. -The way it was written. When it wasn't long-winded paragraphs, it was stilted dialogue. I didn't see an ounce of personality in these people's conversations. Here's an example: "So how long have you been together?" "Since we were kids, basically. But we have literally nothing in common." "No?" I shook my head. "We disagree on just about everything. I can never play my music out loud around him. And he's not really into books. But I suppose they say opposites attract." "He doesn't read books?" said Rad. "No. Well, actually, there's a book he's reading at the moment. I think it's called Yes - Now What's the Next Question?" Isn't that a self-help book?" "Yeah, something like that." "I suppose you prefer fiction?" I nodded. "Definitely." "What's your favorite book?" I thought for a moment. " The Land of Laughs,  I think." "That's a good one." ... and it was like that the whole time I was reading. I did like the exploration of panic attacks, and the way they were described. There was also hints at a f/f romance, but that wasn't enough to keep me motivated to go on, sadly. In the end, this may have been more of a "me" problem, because there are a lot of people who really liked this. I know a lot of people love this author's poetry, so I'll try probably try it one day. Thanks to Netgalley for providing me with a review copy. Trigger Warnings for:  Suicide, Vivid descriptions involving blood, Self harm, Possessive jealousy

2.5 stars Let's just start with I agree with all of the overall themes book gave out, and perhaps because I'm prone being picky when it comes to how sentimentally "deep" a book is, this book was not for me. I love poetry, and perhaps this book is nice and fresh for some, but this felt like beginner's level poetry for me. I did however LOVE the illustrations in this book, and if they were a separate book I would have given them five stars alone. To me, most of these poems were just a collection of scattered words and random metaphors. The pattern of the few poems I did enjoy were a bit longer than the rest of the poem, and I realize if Kaur had developed some of her messages I might have actually enjoyed more of her poems. I really appreciated the messages Kaur attempted to spread, but when a poem had six words, and three word breaks, it just felt more in the format of a poem rather than being an actual poem. There were some poems like: "you are your own soul mate." Again, great message, but if I knew this is the poetry that has been such highly praised, I would not have picked up this book in the first place. And then rare poems like this, which was probably my most enjoyed poem (If only the novel included more of these): "you tell me i am not like most girls and learn to kiss me with your eyes closed something about the phrase--something about how i have to be unlike the women i call sisters in order to be wanted makes me want to spit your tongue out like i am supposed to be proud you picked me as if i should be relieved you think i am better than them" The message of this one was not only so clearly conveyed, but it was well developed, unlike many of the other poems. "but for some overrated poetry there is bound to be unpopular opinions and maybe because i have them it makes me different from the rest but in all fairness i will not apologize for being different" -- me Huh, maybe I should write a poetry book. *also wanted to add something to this review. I've read many comments saying that this book doesn't deserve a low rating because the author poured her raw feelings into this book, and so it shouldn't be judged. Most authors do that. If you were to rate a book based on how well you think the author put their feelings into a book when they wrote it, I would give all the books I read five stars, because I'm aware on how hard each author works when they write.

Hamlet is, perhaps, the most tragic and dramatic literature character ever created. Well, arguably, since other authors such as Dostoyevsky always clung on absolute tragedy, turmoil and disaster for their characters, but you catch my drift. There are so many things to say about Hamlet, and yet I can't seem to find the correct words to define him. He's somewhat reckless and yet cautious, courteous and yet impolite, tender but barbaric. He grieves his father's demise with absolute despair and abjection, and yet when he's responsible (directly or indirectly) for someone's demise e.g. Guildernstern's, Polonius' , he shows no remorse at all, let alone any feelings. Hamlet is so kind hearted, and yet he's such a flawed man. Not that a flawed person cannot be great, but Hamlet is just something else. He's vicious, reckless, barbaric, hateful and yet he's still able to be our tragic hero. Why? His father's death changed him, that's for sure. Perhaps he turned hateful and barbaric because the obliviousness of his father's death, the fact he didn't know enough, drove him insane. Perhaps his heart was heavy from sorrow because of his father but didn't feel remorse for others precisely because his father's demise made him lose sense of himself, of life and everyone else. I believe on the first act, part II, Hamlet describes how great his father was; loving towards his (Hamlet's) mother, a formidable king, a great man. His description of him shows how sorrowful his remembrance of his father is; he basically forges a godlike image of him. Did he really love his father that much, that honestly, or did his death and the enigma of his demise simply affect him to the point of canonising him? Not being completely certain and speculating about it is what gives beauty to this play, not only because of the opaque feelings Hamlet has towards his father, but because the entire play itself is an enigma. Characters such as Polonius (self-absorbed and hypocritical), Horatio (sceptical and intelligent, but warm and caring) and Ophelia (gullible and foolish) are all complex characters that give you too much to think about. Horatio is my favourite character from the play, because of his kind heart and good humour, he reminds me a lot of Dostoyevsky's "Dmitri Razumikhim" from "Crime and Punishment". I just love the depth and ambiguity of the personages. This play is profound despite not being very long; not only does it contain a rich extension of the English language, but the characters of the play itself are quite interested in the language themselves. I've never been a fan of Shakespeare, I have always respected him as a good poet and master of words (in my own subjective way) and that's about it, but I do give him the credit for Hamlet; it is a beautiful, profound and colossal piece of work. Way ahead of its time.

*Pick it for me freebie reads #14. Thanks for voting* See this review and more on my blog Lilybloombooks 1.5 stars Honestly, I don't even know where to start with this book. Due to the fact that the few books I read before this one were awesome, I was hoping I would continue on my "Good Book Roll". Sadly, that is not the case. Falling for the Ghost of You could have been a great book, hell--even good, honest. But there are several different reasons why this it wasn't and just didn't work for me. The only thing going for it was its humor. There were parts that I legit laughed my butt off. The rest? No. I'll start with the writing. It had this weird.. vibe to it (I'm really at a loss for words how to describe it). Like I was reading this girls diary vs living out the events with her. Considering that this wasn't the intention, it didn't work. It's very bland and underdeveloped. It was choppy and lacked even a decent flow-- it was just all over the place. To put it straight, it felt like the VERY first draft. Not only was I laughing at the funny parts, I was also laughing at the unbelievably ridiculous things that came about randomly and others that left a bad taste in my mouth. Violet being a best-selling author (to pay for her Mom's medical bills) and her,"Yeah, no big deal I'm just a bad ass" attitude. The whole situation with her best friend and the relationship with her teacher. This isn't something to just say, "oh shit" about a brush off. Nor is it in good taste to have her end up pregnant with all the nonchalance in the world. That is serious shit right there, people. . The fact that Zane's "secret" was so unrealistic. He is supposedly this very famous singer/actor. You are telling me that just changing hair color and contacts would keep the media in the dark? How about the fact that he was her FAVORITE singer and she didn't KNOW!? C'mon, now. Could you BE more dense? The plot holes were so big it was unreal. Violet is probably one of my least favorite protagonist, ever. For one, she is very immature and judgemental. Everyone was a slut, or a ho or a whore. Let me take a minute to point out that the one person that could be considered a "slut", was Zane. For the first week she stayed with him, he had a different girl/woman over every night. Did this thought cross her mind? Nope. I guess a "hot body" gives him a pass. She was a horrible friend. Sure, she gave her a car at the end but what about all that drama in between? She was so selfish and obsessed with her "relationship" with Zane, she couldn't see what was happening with her best friend. Speaking of; the "romance" was boring. I will admit, I did kind of  like their banter in the beginning (VERY beginning) but once the feelings came into play, I just couldn't give a rats ass. It's always hard for me to believe that a guy that has a different woman over every night just gives that up for the girl. (Especially Violet). Did those women not know who he was, either?! I mean, let's be real here. The ending was... sad. Not boo-hoo sad, but "I didn't think things could possible get worse" sad. My eyes were hurting from all the rolling. Honestly, I could go on and on about all the reasons why this book didn't work and all the things that were NOT OKAY. But I wont. My Peeve~ I'm sure you could guess, but if not... pretty much the whole thing. The only reason why I didn't mark as DNF is because I needed a good laugh. Overall~ I didn't like it. I wish I hadn't put this one on the poll and damn sure wish I hadn't "purchased" it. Thank goodness it was free. Sure, I was entertained by the humor and ridiculousness but this just proves that-- Some books are great; some books are good.. and some books are... not.

look at this cuz' Royally Screwed is the third book i waited for publication in this year. and guess wat. a disappointment. it was good, and it was going to be perfect but- it was a cure but like it was 50 mg zendor although i need 100 mg xanax. again a book with the beginning absolutely perfect but the middle taking long and the ending abso-fucking-lutely bullshit. ok, middle was funny, sexy, a little sweet idiot and lots of spicy BUT i was like *meh* after a while. and that end. i have no words. a character, a man like nick could not do this, can not do dis. it's against to his nature, against to nature itself! he is Nicholas Arthur Frederick Edward Pembrook for fuck sake! I still understand why he did something like dat, i dont give a fuck how Emma explain in book cuz this one was the last ring of the chain I hold. i dont give a fuck either what he had done after he fucked up. on the other hand, i loved dis book, i loved nick and olivia and even the queen and others but there are "somethings" i couldnt name it truly. even i dont like the way they fuck. dont get me wrong, they were great until i get there:  he is prince and he always using condoms, so i expected no-condom-sex will be the greastest fuck in book but it was not. this scenes was right after nick shaved her pussy. stop writing breast-fuck sex as the hottest and most intimate scene. there is more way to write an intimate moment or doings while having sex. dont be a "sex sells writer". anyway i'm still getting wet when i read his name xoxo iko

I was waiting to read this one from months and finally....read it today. Just finished it...! And Ms Mallery rocks.....as always..!! Her Fool's gold series is the best series I have read so far and I hope it never stops...I want romances from Fool's Gold indefinitely. Coming back to Three Little Words, a good, entertaining read!! I loved all the characters....Ford, Isabel, Kent and Consuelo. As we were already familiar with the main characters from previous books, it was easy and smooth to read! I loved the connection between Ford and Isabel and enjoyed their funny and sweet conversations. I would have loved to give it excellent rating but, for me the problem was the end..i felt it was abrupt....Isabel should not have forgiven Ford so easily, it was Ford who left without a word when Isabel declared her love...and when he comes back and returns her feelings, she just jumps into his arms...hmm that was very sudden...and in next page the book was over...!! An epilogue would have been nice! Anywas, read and enjoyed...waiting for next releases!

So, I have really mixed feelings about this book. On one hand, it was a worthy sequel in my opinion. But on the other hand, I'd hoped for things to be different for Lara Jean. (I think.) There were some lines in the book that were beautiful and right on point though, and this one just moved me. There's a Korean word my grandma taught me. It's called jung. It's the connection between two people that can't be severed, even when love turns to hate. You still have those old feelings for them; you can't ever completely shake them loose of you; you will always have tenderness in your heart for them. It was a good book. And I liked it. I just wish we'd gotten more. More of Chris. More of Margot. More of Josh. Well, we can never get enough of Kitty. She's my favourite character in the book. Also, I really hoped that Lara Jean wouldn't end up with Peter. Like how we have some perfect relationships and we just move on? I wanted to see that, I guess. But we got that with Margot and Josh, so maybe not. Also, it probably didn't help that I was rooting for John Ambrose. It was sad to see that he was reduced to side character. I'd really hoped there would be more story given there. But also, I loved Jenny Han handled Lara Jean's friendship with Genevieve. That was beautiful and so real. How some might never be friends again. So all in all, I would recommend everyone to check out both of these books because they're great and well-written, and also because of Kitty. She's amazing. I really liked the book, and I think it lived up to it's expectations. I wasn't disappointed at all. But I wasn't a bundle of nerves after I'd finished it either.

This was a cute contemporary romance. I loved the setting in Paris. I liked the characters for the most part. I was not a fan of St. Clair being a cheating boyfriend and Anna being okay with that. I get that she was trying to not like him for several reasons, the obvious one being that he has a girlfriend. Her friend also liked him. But I like my characters to have flaws, so this didn't take away from the story for me. Anna's reasons for forgiving her best friend were kind of weak, in my opinion. I think forgiving her because they've been friends for so long would have attested to the strength of their friendship more. Her forgiveness was more "well I couldn't help myself with St. Clair even though he had a girlfriend, so now I get that she couldn't help herself with this boy I like back home. Forgiven!" That was kind of weird. I think I would have been more upset about the friend lying about it. Regardless, I still liked these characters. I really loved Anna's love of cinema. That was a fun addition to the story. Enjoyable summer read! Challenges: 2017 Goodreads Challenge

So I read this book about a week ago and now I feel like I can write this review. All the crazy emotions I got from reading this book have faded so no I can write with a clear head. I just thought that for a book like this it was very important that I do this so that I can get across all of my thoughts on this book. This was a really good story. Short and simple and very interesting. I loved everything about this book except for  that  one thing When someone who has lived in a bubble falls in love for the first time you really want to know how that is going to work out. You just want to know how they live, period. Because of this, Madeline became quite interesting all on her own. I read the blurb and I thought..wow..this is something different  Madeline suffers from SCID so she has been living in her bubble for 17 years. When a boy moves in next door and they become friends, everything changes for her and soon what used to be good enough for her is no longer enough. She wants more, to experience the world like a normal person and spend time with the boy she loves. She decides to do just that and everything is great  until it's not I loved how this author made this book short and simple, you can enjoy and finish this book in a day. There were no unnecessary additions in this book. It made the book fast paced and so much more fun. Every detail in this book felt important so I never got bored. I didn't want to stop reading. Maybe if I hadn't had other things to do I would have been done with this book in a few hours. The characters were all good. Everyone was important and there wasn't that many characters which made more sense because a girl who never leaves the house doesn't know that many people. At first I thought Olly was really weird, in fact I still think he is a bit weird. I am not an energetic person so if you are always jumping up and down and doing all sorts of weird ninja moves I would probably look at you like you have just grown two heads. It was kinda funny though. Who the hell visits a person's house for the first time and starts climbing walls without permission. I have tried to sympathise with Madeline's mom but I can't. Many people lose their loved ones everyday and they don't do anything  that  crazy. Instead of going for therapy she decided to ruin her daughter's life ???? what the hell !! I really liked Madeline, she is really funny. I liked everything she wrote in her books and those spoiler alerts. She is really sweet and didn't deserve what happened to her, no one does. Her relationship with her mom is definitely amazing, most teenagers won't even give their parents the time of day. I wanted to scream when she left the house but I guess I'm glad she did. The illustrations in this book were great too. Really funny and they just made the book more complete. I took my time with all of them because they were one of the best parts of this book. It was even believable that Maddy drew them, they just had that feel to them. Now the one thing I didn't like about this book was the plot twist  what made me read this book was that Madeline had SCID. Her not having SCID just destroys the whole point. I really wish the author would have come up with a different plot twist here. Or none at all. I really liked Made You Up by Francesca Zappia because it was about a girl with schizophrenia. The disease made this story different. It brought something new to the YA table. This book did that but the twist sort of ruined it as well. I would have wanted to know how they were going to make this relationship work while she lived in the bubble. I won't lie, for a plot twist it was a really good one. No one could have seen that one coming. It also made for a sort of happy ending I guess because now they can be together. I can't help but think this is why the author did this. For an easier ending. It still disappoints me though. I did highlight a lot of things on my e-reader but I'm only going to use a few. " He tastes like salted caramel and sunshine. Or what I think salted caramel and sunshine taste like." Why anyone would even try to think what sunshine tastes like is beyond me  prom*ise ('pram@s) n. pl.-es. The lie you want to keep. [2015, Whittier]  I just really liked this definition. INVISIBLE MAN BY RALPH ELLISON Spoiler alert: You don't exist if no one can see you. this made me feel bad for her. I really enjoyed this book and I will be looking out for more of Nicola Yoon's books in the future. I totally recommend this book. Even if you are too lazy to read, this book is really short so reading it won't be a problem. Now I really want to see the movie. xx fayetino

Enough is enough .....This series started brilliantly and had me gripped until around book 6 .I was becoming more annoyed but went with book 7 & 8 begrudgingly,but this ...this is pathetic. Suddenly Ms Black is no longer a real threat despite Mel repeating throughout the series "You don't want to mess with Ms Black". Your readers are not stupid Ms Ward ...this has become so unbelievable its no longer funny and I could actually FEEL you stringing this out to make another killing on your readers.So short it wasn't worth the wait. Why you persist in this whole Avery may be a call girl scenario is a mystery.Avery has become TSTL and despite constant references to her being "overworked" by Miss Black she's never ACTUALLY slept with a client other than Sean thank god . She's technically slept with one guy a few times and you want her to do how many fingers ? :o Yet another badly badly thought out scene. I'm done

I found Slide pretty absorbing and interesting but ultimately it left me empty. I wanted to like it more than I actually did. I think the basics of the story were good and the author succeeded on several levels, however I think ultimately the plot was too complicated to really execute correctly. Clearly this is meant as the first book to a series and I liked the characters enough to continue with the books I think but I can't help wishing this first book lived up to its inherent promise. It's still a worthwhile read in my opinion but it's not the stunning great read it could have been. That failed expectation was the last impression of the book and thus my disappointment weighs heavily and prominently on my mind when evaluating it. It's a book I'd recommend, but with some qualifications. The book is essentially about the relationship between Ash, a former homeless addict that has cleaned up his life with the help of his lesbian best friend and became a tattoo artist. He moves in with a roommate Pete, a big-hearted paramedic, and the two eventually fall in love. Their relationship is not easy as communication is a word neither man has heard of nor has any interest in and Ash's mental status is often dubious at best. The story is told from both Ash and Pete's POVs mainly to depict Ash's mental deterioration and how someone who is madly in love with him, and even a trained medical professional, can miss important signs. This is definitely an angst filled story and I thought the author did a good job connecting with that emotion but never overwhelming the reader. Ash's childhood was clearly traumatic, to say the least, and his shaky mental status offers no real relief. His relationship to Pete is an obvious grounding force and I liked the two men together. They seemed genuinely in love and happy to be together. However I couldn't help but think they were also two very typical men in their early twenties. They rarely talked, at all or about anything. They mostly let everything slide, which I thought was the motivation for the title. They literally would realize something is bothering the other person or was a sore spot and they simply "let it go." For almost the entire book their relationship seems based on the ease with which they live together and great sex whenever they happen to have it. Considering Pete's paramedic job had him working constantly and seemingly always changing hours, the two men weren't together all that much. When they did have a rare night off they usually played video games or hung out, which is fine but it was pretty rare and definitely did not involve communicating to further their relationship. Not that all relationships need extensive communication but considering the near constant problems Ash dealt with, it was clear to see why Pete never really understood Ash and missed all the signals of Ash's mental decline. That said I thought the depiction of Ash's deteriorating mental health was really well done. It was honest and somewhat heartbreaking that everyone around him was so careful that they ignored all his clear cries for help. It shows an honest portrayal that is not always comfortable but genuine nonetheless. The chaotic and often shifting patterns of Ash's speech and mental musings definitely made sense and worked to show the disconnect he had with people and various aspects of life itself. I think the story did an exceptional job in this area and absolutely did not need the overly convenient plot devices about the abuser/baseball bat guy and the sister. Likewise I loathed the epilogue. The entire book sets up this confrontation at the end with Ash realizing he needs help and finally able to ask for it. Then the book jumps a year to show that all was well and includes some pithy lines about how it was hard work to get there. Really? After the entire book shows Ash's slow decline into needing help, then the solution is to say he got some therapy and all's well? I'm sorry but what a cop out. Write a second book if you want to make him well because just skipping ahead has totally reduced any emotional impact the book could have had. It lost me entirely with that cheap shortcut. Overall I quite liked the story and the narrator did a decent job. He acted out the story to my amusement. The narrator would read the line then do it if it was an action he could. For example every time someone would sigh, the narrator would read the line "Ash took a deep breath." Then the narrator would breathe deep. It made me laugh because it was just so ... jarring for lack of a better word. But that's a minor point to be sure. I liked the secondary characters even they never really made much sense - Joe is a total mystery and I've no clue why he was included in the story in the awkward way he was - and the characterization wasn't always consistent. However I found these to be minor issues for me and didn't bother me much. Mostly the lack of communication and horrible ending were my biggest issues but I'd still recommend this one. The audiobook version is pretty absorbing too.

Going through Rainbow Rowell in backward order on audio. I'm starting to feel like Rebecca Lowman (reader for RR's books) is my personal friend. I liked this one -- it was quieter than Fangirl; it only got plot-intense for me at the end. (And Christiana, I think I found the easter egg!!!) After so many teen books, which are about the "firsts" of relationships, I appreciate a book about that very adult truism that a commitment is a choice you make over and over again. Incidentally, I loved all the descriptions of snow. Favorite quotes: "And she hadn't gotten to say "I love you"--Georgie always said "I love you," and Neal always said it back, no matter how perfunctory it was. It was a safety check, proof that they were both still in this thing." "Seth, however, had never let himself go. If anything, he'd tightened his grip. He looked like he hadn't aged a day since 1994, since the first day he and Georgie met." When she imagines telling Neal the future on p. 163-164 -- "We stay in California. You hate it. But you grow your own avocados. So that's something." "Neal didn't like to be asked things. It made his jaw tense. He'd give you a flippant answer. Like, whatever you were asking, it wasn't any of your business. Like nothing was anyone's business. Like nobody should ask questions that didn't absolutely need to be answered." "She thought of...the way he never made her feel crazy, even when she was acting crazy, and never made her feel like a failure, even when she was failing." "Neal wasn't happy, and Georgie was why. And not because of anything she'd ever done or said. Just because of who she was. Georgie was Neal's anchor. (And not the good kind. Not the happy anchor that keeps you safe and grounded, the one you get tattooed across your chest.) Georgie was . dead weight. Okay. Now she was being melodramatic. This was why she never let herself think about this. Because her brain would dive and dive and never touch bottom. She didn't let herself think about it. But she still knew it. Everyone around them knew it--Margaret must. That Neal wasn't happy. That he hated California, that he felt alternately lost and thwarted here. Trapped."

This book was exceptionally good. I love when the characters are described in a way in which I can actually picture them. Each scene was detailed enough that I felt like a voyeur. I was a little bit bothered by Ellie's defiance. I guess it confused me because she kept denying that she was submissive but that's exactly how she was described. Nothing about her behaviour prior to or during her interactions with Kayne hinted at a dominant personality. I understand not accepting or wanting the hand that was dealt to her, I just believe she could have fought against it in another way. I knew it!! I knew Kayne was hiding something. I had a strong inkling that he was an undercover good guy. I appreciate getting his POV because I would fail to realize how wonderful he truly was if his character had to rely solely on how Ellie perceived him. I feel really bad for him in the end. I hope Ellie quickly realizes how unappreciative she has been in the next book. Glad Javier met his maker. Damn bully!! Anyway, these two love each other so I hope book 2 has more romance.

This review first appeared on I Heart Romance & YA Midnight Alias is the second novel in the series and I enjoyed it for the most part. This time, it's one of Morgan's men, Luke who is undercover and he fell for Olivia, a mob boss' girlfriend who is also a stripper. Although I enjoyed the plot, I still think it wasn't one of the best ones that I've read. There was potential but I was a little annoyed with Olivia. I knew her reasons for stripper were legit and I applaud her for that, but what she did afterward caused Luke to be captured and injured was just stupid. PLUS it also resulted in almost getting herself raped, which was really stupid! Read the full review on I Heart Romance & YA

People conserned more about the topic of this book than the actual story. That's what I basically see in every second review. What are you thirteen year olds? Don't you tell me that you were never attracted to someone besides your partner, I won't believe you ever. It's like saying you never watch porn. You miss the glory of this book, while being too preoccupied with judging and branding characters. This book certainly has flaws, but they have nothing to do with how the love triangle is handled. Coleen Hoover has a very addicting writing style, i flew through this in a matter of hours. The basic idea was treated differently, in a fresh, non-annoying way, which pleased me. It always nice to see another side of the old trope. Characters were quite likable, fleshed out, had their own things to worry about, besides their growing attraction towards each other. They are kind of starting to forget about their worries in the second part of the story, but so do you, it's not bothering. I thorouthly enjoed the love interest in this one - Ridge, he was overall a nice guy, very sweet, dedicated, a talented musician. I love how carefully Hoover treated his deafness, how she didn't make a victim out of him. He was very comfortable in his skin, and he had his agency. You don't have to make your character a douchebag, anyone can fall in love with somebody else. My favorite character though is Maggie. She's an absolute hero! And I was pleasantly surprised that unlike the other girls she was treated normally. It's a solid, emotional read. In the end a little bit overly dramatic, but still worthy of your time.

4 Stars: How to Handle a Heartbreaker by Marie Harte is the story of how Abby Dunn (a witty, loyal, and intelligent woman with shaky self-worth) finds Brody Singer (a goofy, playful, and sincere guy who tends to hide his problems from everyone rather than reach out for help). It is the second book in the McCauley Brothers series and while it could be read alone, I recommend reading The Troublemaker Next Door first since it contains a fair amount of character building for Abby, Brody, and pretty much everyone else you'll encounter in the story. I was pleasantly surprised by Abby in this book. For a heroine who struggles with self-worth due to some past emotional abuse, she grew in a way I wasn't expecting. I know personal growth is usually a given in contemporary romance, but it so often revolves around the hero and his ultimate acceptance. In this story, however, I knew Abby Dunn would find her happiness, even if it didn't include our hero. Several cliches of contemporary romance made an appearance (love them or leave them), but it also had several unexpected moments for me, which I loved. I tend to expect a hefty dose of the "man box" in stories like this (ie obsession with sports, no crying allowed ever, and calling each other pussy). While the men in this series definitely live in the man box, they are NOT assholes about it (so refreshing)! And every once in a while Brody breaks the mold in an adorably sweet way: "And I really, really want you to come live with me. If you play your cards right, you could be the lucky Mrs. Brody Singer. Unless, of course, you strike it rich. Then I'm okay to take your last name. Brody Dunn has a nice ring to it too." This was my second book by Marie Harte, so I was curious to see how she would write another set of characters with distinctly different personalities. I thought it was done very well - Brody and Abby were definitely NOT just Flynn and Maddie reincarnate from The Troublemaker Next Door. I hope this trend continues with Vanessa and Cam in Ruining Mr. Perfect. Overall, I really enjoyed this book for what it was, a relaxing and charming romance with some sexy times. It goes especially well with a cup of cocoa and I'm planning to read it again once the holidays roll around. Some Particulars HEA? Yes! Love Triangle? Nope Cheating? Nope Explicit Sex? Oh yeah... Steam Rating: 3 out of 5 Not as much as in The Troublemaker Next Door but there is plenty to go around! Consent? Crystal clear every time :) Trigger Warning? Perhaps a very, very mild one. Abby and Brody each have some emotional and/or physical abuse in their backgrounds (no history of rape or physical sexual abuse). I thought Marie Harte did an excellent job of integrating their pasts into the story without making me feel trapped in the more upsetting parts. It is evident the whole time that both Abby and Brody are surrounded by people who love and support them.

This is like a sexier, less realistic The Royal We, and I basically read it in one sitting. I'll probably pick up the sequel. I have to say, though, that it seems really silly to me that Nicholas ends up following through on abdicating. You'd think the country would prefer having a Crown Prince who has spent his life training for that, even if he is married to an American, rather than the dude who was just arrested for coke possession. Maybe that's just me.

I didn't read the first two books in the series ("Between the Lines" and "Where You Are") because I hate, hate, HATE love triangles and I wasn't interested in the whole Reid-Emma-Graham drama. But I thought that a story about Reid after he "lost" to Graham sounded like a potentially good story. Apart from that I have a weakness for the popular-guy-good-girl-storylines. And Reid is extremely popular. He's a Hollywood star, legendary womanizer and known to find trouble wherever he goes. That's the reason he and Dori meet in the first place. He has drunkenly driven his car into a house front and the following court order was for him to help with the rebuilding of the house - a project that Dori is in charge of. I didn't like Reid in the beginning, mainly because he was acting like an arrogant jerk. Even though I gave him some slack for at least being honest about it and for the fact that he is a Hollywood star and a bit of his arrogance might be founded. When people are constantly telling you how great you are it's only logical. But still, it doesn't change the fact that his behavior left a lot to wish for. He's well aware that Dori is a "good girl", she takes love seriously and stays true to her values. But still he's going after her because he likes the challenge, while still hooking up with other girls. Call me stuck-up, but that's one of the meanest things a guy can do in a situation like that. But for me as well as Reid there was a big turning point in this story. I'm not even sure when it happened, but suddenly I felt like he showed some genuine interest in her, like it suddenly became more than just the thrill of the chase. After that the book turned more beautiful with every page. The way Reid tried (and succeeded ) to become a better and more deserving person for Dori's and - what's even more important - his own sake was touching and so wildly romantic that at times I had problems to control my inner fangirl. I felt like squealing happily more than once and I don't do that, ever! I had some problems with the writing style at first. The story is told from ever changing POVs (Reid's and Dori's), there were parts of the book where every third page was told from a different person's POV. It made it hard for me to really get into the story and made me feel a bit restless, but once I got used it I wouldn't have wanted to change it for the world. They were both ruthlessly honest with themselves, so the insights we got into both of their feelings were extremely valuable for the development of the story. The only thing I REALLY didn't like was the whole story arc with her older sister. Maybe the author thought that making Dori's sister and best friend fall into a coma that left her as an unresponsive invalid for the rest of her life was important for the development of the story and Dori's and Reid's relationship, but if you use a character like that to generate some drama (which I hate in the first place), why do you have to make her find the love of her life just before the accident? The whole thing was so heartbreaking I actually had tears in my eyes and more than a few of them were out of anger. That part of the story was completely unnecessary! Apart from that I couldn't have been more delighted with the story. Dori's and Reid's relationship developed with a natural pace and I could understand all of their actions and decisions. They didn't mindlessly rush into anything, but at the same time there was a pull between them that made it almost impossible for them to stay apart. This was a beautiful and touching book about growing up, showing strength in the face of disaster and staying true to yourself through all of it.

This is one of my favorite "smutty" read. I really feel more in love with Luke in this installment. He is really a prince charming. I love the wicked Luke and loving family man Luke and the sex god Luke with the  "monster member"! He definitely know how to use it. Ems is so lucky! . LOL. This is more like the longer epilogue of AOP. Team Luke all the way! :D

I didn't quite enjoy the first book of this series because it didn't match up to my expectations from when I first read its synopsis. But still, I was willing to give the whole series a try. Now that I'm done with the second book, I can say that the story did improve but it was still lacking something for me. Is it just me but this book in the series SORT OF reminded me of Stephenie Meyer's Breaking Dawn. Yes, that fourth book in the Twilight Saga. Which part? The part wherein Guy marries (or proposes to) girl to save her from his family or kind . What I like about this series is that it is very different from all the romance novels that I have read. It tackles a peculiar kind of relationship, one that most people today won't agree to. What they consider as cheating in a relationship is very unusual too. Sooooo... If you're curious about the synopsis, read it! If you like stories that involve a boss-and-intern relationship, read it! If you like rich book-boyfriends, read it!

I got this book for free from the author so I could review the second book in the series. I am reviewing this Like I would for the book that come next in the series. This is a book told from the point where the relationship (romance is just starting the MC's Collin and Tanner are already friend and have been since they first met when they went to the same college. Collin is the youngest child of a widowed single mother who has a strong religious bent and of the conservative religious tradition. Tanner's parents are divoriced broadway people. Conner doesn't realize he is gay but has issues since he is sure his mother would not take it well and disown him. they have a closeted relationship for a while but Tanner kisses Collin at a movie and Collin freaks out. They have an argument because Tanner want to be open about it and kiss Collin whenever he feels like it but Collin has some hangups. They separate for the weekend when Tanner decides to visit his parents in NYC. They make up on Saturday and Tanner Catches a train back to college and Collin picks him up. On the way back to college, A deer cause Collin to crash the car and tanner is injured because he just finished making out and blowing  Collin and hadn't buckled back up. Collin's mom come into Tanner's room as they are Kissing and tell Collin he is going home with her and that no son of hers can be Gay He stands up to her and Calls Tanner his boyfriend both make the statement about not saying something they cannot take back Collin's mom when Collin tell her he is gay and that Tanner is his Boyfriend. and Collin when his Mother say that If Collin doesn't comeback with her now that he is no longer welcome at her home.

"Aut viam inveniam aut faciam tibi. I will either find a way or make one." Oh, those three star reviews... I really did like this book, mainly for the somewhat unused idea of a male lead with complete amnesia. And the name Logan tattooed on him. I thought the fact that Ashlyn was a student headed for a PhD and writing her thesis on amnesia sort of fell by the wayside after it was used as an excuse for them to meet. There really wasn't a lot of it in the story. I thought the little twist toward the end was a great surprise and oh, so angsty! Seriously...that's what was going on? What a great OMG moment  when we figure out who Logan really is. The most enjoyable part of this story is how Logan gets to learn all over again how to live and what he loves. He gets to look at the world and everything in it with fresh eyes, untainted by sadness or hate or prejudice. "Logan, with no memory of his own life was teaching me how to live in the moment and enjoy mine." I must be a bit immune to super sexy steamy scenes because I really don't see this a being all that erotic. There were a couple of somewhat descriptive love scenes but to me, erotic means that sex takes over much of the page time and that was definitely not the case here. There was a lot of story. All centered around how Logan and Ashlyn have this somewhat taboo relationship. I was surprised that more fuss wasn't made about how she, a student, became involved with him, a suspected murderer with amnesia. That seems to be quite the faux pas, but no one really seemed to mind all that much. A very enjoyable read, just not a huge standout among the hundreds like it. I listened to the audiobook and the narrator did a great job. I will likely continue the series, as I liked this author's voice.

**ARC provided by Netgalley for an honest review! *Quotes may differ upon publication* 3.5 STARS! Still it's not enough, She's given me so much--her body, her trust. Yet I want more I want everything she has, everything she is. And I will have it. Eventually. For now, I;ll keep pushing for--and taking--everything she wants to give me. Part 2 starts right after part 1 and it's basically just sex and orgasms. looootttsss of sex. Sebastian wants to show Aria what it feels like to be in control yet lose control at the same time. When Aria caves and pleads for his touch, he's more than willing to give everything to her. After being satisfied sexually, Aria finally realizes what she's done. After seeing the marks Sebastian left on her body, memories from the past come pouring in and the tough girl facade Aria puts up is suddenly gone. Sebastian realizes the change and is determined to discover the cause of the change one way or another. HEA? Still gotta wait for that HEA haha!

The basic premise of this book (good girl meets bad boy) is one that had been done countless times, and yet it is one that I've recently grown rather fond of in this new adult genre. Ever since buying it, I've been anxious to pick it up, but I had a few more books that I had queued to be read before getting to it, even though this book kept catching my eye and demanding to be read sooner rather than later. I've glad I gave it and pushed this book a little higher on my schedule. It was only a week before reading it that I realized the actual seriousness of what this books back blurb slightly hints at. I was looking for books with serious and real life situations on Goodreads when I came across this book in the top ten on of a list I was surfing through. I thought maybe I'd bitten off a slightly more darker story then I had first anticipated. Tammara Webber's Easy starts off with every persons worst nightmare. I admit I wasn't expecting the confrontation straight off the bat, but it just concludes and adds to the fact that even though this particular story is a work of fiction, this kind of thing can happen at anytime and anywhere. Even when diving straight in, I knew I was going to really enjoy this book. It seemed to feel so much more real and truthful depiction of teens and young adults then what authors usually portray. These seemed like real college students. I for one, am extremely grateful for the main character actually not being a virgin. I can only take so many 'good girl virgins'. I ended up not only liking and loving Jacqueline, but admiring her too. The secondary characters contribute to making this story feel real. I really loved Erin, not only for attitude and witty lines, but also her unwavering support for her best friend. I enjoyed every passage that she was in. I loved the small doses of Benji, and I freely admit that I liked the presence of Jacqueline's ex not quite leaving the picture. I needed to know what would happen to Jacqueline, I couldn't leave her world alone. I read through the whole thing in just over a day. Easy hits on some hard-hitting truths, and I'm very grateful that the author decided not to gloss over it or sweep it under the rug. Not only does it show the truth that rape can happen to anyone, but also shows it can be carried out by people you presume to know. Not only does it touch on the physical and emotional wounds of rape, it's also based strongly on the emotional effects of forgiveness, self-doubt, and hope. Briefly, it even touches on what some people are willing to do to cover the word 'rape'. Most importantly, Tammara Webber shows us that, no matter how the situation comes into play, non-consensual sex is rape, and rape is never your fault. Moving away now from the more serious aspects of this book. I want to say that I really loved Lucas. I didn't find him at all creepy or stalkerish just because he had already drawn pictures of Jacqueline. I love an artistic type, and if you've read any of my reviews before, you might know that I have a certain fondness for damaged characters. Whether just small amounts of trauma, to shit hit the fan crazy psychological scarring. I admired Lucas' need to protect people, even if it was just by volunteering at self-defense classes. That one bit, right at the very end, after Buck's failed third attempt at assaulting Jacqueline... When he sort of crawls towards her and holds her. It just felt powerful for me, like I knew that he hadn't been able to save his mother, so this time she needed to be ok. I'm grateful that Tammara Webber took the time to write this book, and she should be incredibly proud of what she has achieved with her novel. I knew from the very beginning that this book deserved 5 stars and I'm not glad that I can give it so freely. Easy will stay with me forever.

OH MY GOD I just noticed that this book came out EXACTLY two years ago. February 10th. This is awesome. Wow!! Great start to romance week! That felt like a really long journey. I wasn't so engrossed in the romace at the beginning, what kept me going was mainly the plot and Lucas' memories. However, the last 100 pages were like an emotional roller coaster! I loved the ending a lot. Despite the sci-fi elements of it, the story felt very realistic to me. To be honest, I didn't like the beginning at all. I didn't like Juliet and Lucas' instant love and their realtionship, but as the story progressed and came to the point where Lucas lost his memories and became sort of 'different' I began to miss the old one too. It was all very eerie and heart-wrenching. Even though I realized they would break up, as he told her in the past, it still made me sad and frustrated. I loved the jump in the years and that we got to see Juliet's life later on. Honestly, the scene where the phone rang in her office and her assistant was talking about a hospital in Germany broke my heart. I was like OHHHMYYYGOOODDDD It's happening. I'm glad Lucas hadn't died. I wish we could have seen their reunion, but I also like that it's an open ending. I mean, we know that she's flying to him, but we are left to imagine the rest... I don't know why, but bittersweet endings don't make me as mad as I think I should have been.

As is usual lately, this is one of my stream of consciousness reviews: It's making me cry and not where you'd think. Well, there, too. There's a LOT of talking in this. There's telling through the talking, big paragraphs. It's moving really slowly now. I don't need to know everything they're talking about when they're just chatting. It's realistic, yes, so is me trying to explain to my 14-year-old why it's important to leave voice mail if you want an adult to call you back, but no one wants to read about it. Heck you've probably stopped reading this review now because it's so boring. Not breaking a lot of ethnic stereotypes here: Latina maid, evil crazies were in South America, white people are the wealthy and perfect owners of the house. Dweeb? That's so 1956. That is used WAY too often in this book. This is doing a really good job of showing how difficult it is for Zach to function and how inconsistent he is in behavior. It's not all simplified like in a lot of books. The erratic behavior in particular is rarely acknowledged and it's so common. Every once in a while a Britishism squeaks in. If it were the same character who used it, I'd assume that person were British, but it isn't. Is the author Brit? We don't put "love" at the end of sentences. We don't say "git" unless we watch too much BBC America and Red Dwarf, smeghead. Where are they in Colorado? In the mountains of the Rockies and Cascades, the water is completely safe to drink because it's snow run off. So where are they? Thank you for getting this right: People don't pass out from pain. Certainly not at the level people pass out from in books. Pain is your body trying to give you signals to get away from whatever is causing the pain. People pass out because they have a head injury or have lost too much blood or they looked passed out because they've gone catatonic from shock. The human body can endure incredible amounts of pain in order to stay ready to run. Why would scars made more than two years ago still look red? Even if they were from reparative surgery, he's been back 8-9 months now. Great description of a severe panic attack. Zach correcting their grammar is funny when he made glaring adverb mistakes along the line of "go slow" and "it felt real good to me." No, he will never put this completely behind him. But he will grow from it and it won't run his life or be present in everything he does. He'll get to a point where he doesn't think about it all the time, every day, or maybe even every month. He'll get to a point where it won't define him. But it will never be completely behind him and it really wouldn't make sense for it to. It's changed him and his life and his choices and his future irrevocably. A little too much sex but it's hot and varied. Really hot. I don't like the psychiatrist. He mostly says the right things but it feels so condescending and too soft which isn't something someone like Zach would respond to. People need to relate to their counselors in some way, if only on the surface. For example, if someone laughs a lot and uses humor to deflect, you wouldn't give that person someone somber. You'd set them up with someone with a positive personality that could model appropriate humor and help the person understand inappropriate times for making jokes. That's just an example; it's not like I deflect with humor. Or sarcasm, no, that's not like me at all. It's realistic that Zach started to run away when David was hurting about Jerry  and great that he then went back and even sounded like he understood what David was upset about. A man as smart and well read wouldn't need to study for the GED and certainly not intensely. The five tests are really only English (including writing) and math, and if he can correct someone's grammar and read those heavy scientific books, he's set. (The other tests, history and science, aren't knowledge tests; they're reading comprehension using passages in these subjects. You read a passage about something historical for example and the answer questions about what happened in the passage. The reason that these are hard for people is that these are areas where someone might have difficult comprehending the text because they don't understand science or have a mental block and just automatically hate history or something.) It's creepy that they call their home a compound, especially since the paramilitary org that took Zach probably called their base that, too. Zach's progress once he and David finally got together was ridiculously and unbelievably fast. I can never find chairs that are high enough to wedge under a door knob. Have you? Instead I get a handy seat to be first in line to watch any intruders storm my castle. (Oh that's vaguely sexual I think...or not.) I keep waiting for something exciting to happen since that's how it started, like maybe Estoban  comes back from the dead as a zombie to enact his revenge, but instead of brains, he wants balls. (You know you have to give it some kind of twist.) I don't get why having a long distance relationship  will help. Maybe doing it for a few months, or maybe they shouldn't move in together right away . But this way it just sounds like it's setting them up to fail. I don't buy that it worked out perfectly as planned. Overall it was good. The action and peril and hospital scene were all in the beginning whereas I prefer it at the end, and it dragged in places, but the description of the various mental health issues was done really well. (Yes, PTSD is a mental disorder and so are panic attacks. People need to stop with the stigmatizing of mental illness.)

I absolutely love this book. I randomly picked it up from a bargain book stack at a bookstore and have read it about a half dozen times and still find myself wanting to read it again. The story is quite heart warming and exciting at the same time. I found Heath and Anabelle to be amazing characters and quite lovable. I expected to hate Heath at first glance but he most certainly grew on me even though he did play quite the hard ass at first. I also liked the romance between  Porcia and Bodie. I thought it really gave a deeper look into the crazy that love can bring out in all of us just on a grander scale. I was a little disappointed that  the ending showed Heath as a broken person   but I guess that was necessary so I can't say too many bad things about it. I would recommend this book to anyone who likes a good read. It is the second to last book in a series but, like me, you can start with it and fall in love with the entire series from there as all the books are just as excellent.

An absolutely heart warming read! I listened to this on my Kindle for part of the time because I had things to do and couldn't stand the idea of putting the book down. Johnny Rayne is a rockstar at the top of the charts but he's been there 15 years and he's tired and wants a family, so he leaves his band and moves to the mountains of West Virginia. His first day there, he meets Sheriff Virgil Grissom. Johnny has always denied his feelings toward men and never explored them but Grissom wakes him up to what he's been missing and makes him realize how much more there is for him when the person is truly right for him. They make a great couple. Johnny can be a bit of a princess, but hey, he's been a famous, beautiful rockstar for the past 15 years so what do you expect. But not annoyingly so. He's trying VERY hard to be anonymous in town. Grissom can be very pushy and know-it-all at times but not in a mean way and usually he's doing it just because he enjoys baiting Johhny who readily rises to the occasion. The sex was hot but not too much aside from the... ahem... fisting scene... ahem... :o)   Johnny has a strong desire to adopt a child and Grissom helps in this regard. Suffice it to say they make great daddies. This was the first book I read by this author and I will most definitely be looking for her other books. The writing was solid and well edited. Great plot that unfolded at just the right pace. This book gave me the warm-and-fuzzies many times over. A definite 5 star read! One you should read if you've not already ;0)

I loved this. It was sweet and funny and kind reminded me of TJ Klunes At First Sight series in that regard. I got annoyed at the main character, much like I did in Klunes books, but they kinda grew on me in the end. I didn't actually know this was set in Australia funnily enough. It was nice seeing places I've been to, and the start of this was written in a way that I didn't know where it was set until someone mentioned Melbourne and then finally a bridge in Sydney. Overall it was hella sweet and some moments had me teary eyed (at the gym after the trainers comp, god I felt sorry for reed that must have been so confusing and hard for him) but I didn't like the ending. Mainly because it made me sad not happy he proposes, gay marriage is legit going through a postal vote right now, next week or so it starts I think and all I'm thinking is how cruel it is they can't get married.

I was waiting for this book for a very very long time (I still feel guilty for liking Royals that much). However, I expected this book to be: 1) lame in the oh-all-that-highschool-drama way, 2) predictable in the I'll-pretend-to-be-your-girlfriend-for-no-good-reason-though-I-dislike-you-for-no-good-reason way, 3) stereotypical in the prince-meets-cinderella-and-falls-in-love way, So, yeah, I was dying to read what I expected to be a cliche book. And I'd lie if I said that it wasn't. It was. It had everything one can expect - a pampered pop music star, an orphan cinderella that takes care of her little brothers, an ex that was not worth the main heroine and a HAE in the end . Why 4 stars then? Because it was good. The style, the characters, the romance - everything felt so right. I can't find better fitting word. It was natural. Easy. I immediately felt for the main heroes, because they weren't perfect. I have to admit that the chemistry between them sometimes lacked something (on the other hand, it's an YA book and therefore I understand why there were no... you know... *get's embarrassed and looks around* those scenes. Oakley and Vaughn are portrayed as... well... normal people? They kinda become friends and the falls in love. No magic, no sparks flying around. No "The only one". More "It's real between us and lets be happy about that for now". I liked how calm and civilized the process of falling in love was. I know it's unusual to say so, but this was... refreshing. I loved that the characters were good hearted, too. I'm sitting now here and thinking "What a nice book". Weird.

Reread June 2017. Still 5 stars. The MCs Evan and Matt are remarkable. They continue to grow and develop throughout the book. Initially Evan is overwhelmed by a fear of being labeled and judged, and acts like an asshole. However he is able to deal with some of his baggage and makes an effort to repair he relationship with Matt. Their love and respect for each other deepens and with their four children, they have built a strong, healthy family.

Anger, loneliness and self-blame. Grief and dark past... A messed-up bad boy and a shattered girl. An unexpected friendship... Wow, that sounds even more cliche than the book was! O.O It really was a bit cliche. Very emotional (both for the characters and for the reader. And in was emotional in a good way - believable and not forced). I loved that I actually could believe in characters' decisions. I didn't need to cling my teeth while reading some nonsense - the author made some reasonable choices, so the story, emotionally heavy and pretty complicated, was nonetheless persuasive. I really liked how the characters interacted in the letters. The letters definitely were the strongest side of the book. Their real live relationship wasn't that interesting, but, again, I give the author credits for making it believable. Believe me, I know something about judging people without knowing them, so... I was a bit surprised by the calmness of Declan finding out about Juliet and vice versa. A lot of similar books make it awkward and silly - I just can't stand it. But Letters to the Lost succeeded to both show the reconciliation in this very calm matter-of-fact way. I'm a bit tired of fake drama (okay, of drama in general), so I was surprised by the fact that they admitted it so easily. On the other hand, it makes sense. They needed each other so badly, so why to complicate everything even more?

I received a copy from Netgalley, in exchange for an honest review. Actual Rating: 4.25 I enjoyed this read. This book was better than the last book. Also, I thought the characters were developed more in this book. Vincent was everything I wanted him to be and some things that I didn't want him to as well. Kirsten, although a bit annoying, made me understand her character more. I think the new characters are great. They add more to the story. Their relationship depicts the everyday relationship that has ups and downs. I was surprised because  Kirsten found out she was pregnant. Also, when Marty, Kirsten's ex, bringing a gun and threatening to kill Kirsten and Vincent  . Overall, a great read.

Wow... I really had low expectations for this book. However, this exceeded them and surprisingly was a pretty decent read mainly because the writing was so well done. They way the story was paced and how the events unfolded naturally really helped sell this as a book that makes you want to keep reading when it so easily could have failed. This book can be described as The Bachelor in a castle with a dash of The Hunger Games because its set in post World War 3 America. I really ended up enjoying this book because the protagonist, America, was a genuinely likable character. Considering this story could have easily just turned into a vapid beauty pageant, it was really refreshing to have a heroine that wasn't a whiny brat. Yes, it's super romancey and there is a lot of talk about dresses and cat fights but America is someone you really don't mind. She's super relate-able and is someone you would want to be friends with. I felt the build of a relationship between America and Maxon was actually handled well. Definitely wasn't insta-love and wasn't overly antagonistic to add needless drama. Overall, it felt well paced and sweet. Ok, I admit that her an Maxon's first kiss was super SQUEEEEE worthy. What can I say, I'm a softy at heart! There's a love triangle because of course there is. There always is. America is obviously confused as to where her heart and head are but she's not whiny about it! (Seriously, her lack of griping saves the day for this story!) Again, I felt the writing was particularly well done in describing the two different relationships. The pacing and America's personality really helps the whole triangle thing to not be hideously annoying. They have a side plot involving the political intrigue of the new nation. There is talk of rebels and attacks throughout the country. They also hint that the royal family may be hiding some of the truth about their rise to power and other secrets from the people. However, they only hint at these things. It would have been interesting to cover more ground on that front. The story mainly focuses on the competition and the romance. If more of the political aspects were addressed I may have given this 5 stars. Since they weren't I had to take away 1 star. Maybe they will be more prominent issues in the next book? Overall, Kiera Cass is a very talented writer. This is usually a book that would be a DNF for me. However, her writing and characters were so well done that this turned out to be a surprise hit for me. Will continue with the series.

Hadley 16 hates flight to London for weekend, father's second marriage, until she misses first flight, sits next to Brit Oliver. She falls in love. She realizes he attends father's funeral near Paddington station, finds church, flees at sight of Oliver's ex. He comes to wedding, dances, meets family. She reconciles with father she hasn't seen all year, nice new wife. Title tells all. Too drastic reversal, unbelievable switch from hate. Couldn't she love boy and not dad?

I received a ARC in exchange for an honest review. First let me say I was so very excited to receive this ARC as I have anxiously been awaiting the final steps in Lorrie and Hunters story. The Wrecked series is truly great and gives the reader a chance to see how ultimately love DOES conquer all. It also shows the trials and one goes through with the terrible debilitating disease MS. Small spoiler:  When Hunter appears at Lorrie's Aunt and Uncles and confesses about his MS and begs her to work through their issues together.... well I was on the edge of my seat! It was heart wrenching at times to see how strong Lorrie was trying to be not just for Hunter, but herself and at times found myself crying right along with her. Although I wish there more to the story, untimely the HEA is every so sweet!

3,5 stars Problems I had with this last installment *Sort of deus ex machina plot twist. *I already expected what happened. Not exactly as it happened, but I was expecting that kind of twist, so I wasn't that much impressed. *Evie changed a lot, and it seemed to be a different character (or rather too OOC). *I wanted another ending. I admit it, I didn't want a HEA. *Lack of communication was a hugetastic issue. *Henry was some sort of creepy idiot. No, really, what the hell? His plans of getting Evie back were... Ridiculous?

Hero(s) rating: 3 stars Heroine rating: 3.5 stars Sexual tension rating: 3.5 stars Sex scenes rating: 3 stars Sex scenes frequency: 3 stars Plot rating: 3.5 stars Dialogue rating: 4 stars Storytelling rating: 4 stars Story ending rating: 3 stars Other woman/men drama: Yes Cheating: No Cliffhanger: No HEA: Yes Overall rating: 3.5 stars

First of all. The writing in this book was beautiful. I actually cannot think of another book where I stopped in the midst of reading to admire the author's work with words.
