I gave this three stars BECAUSE OF the marvelous, almost artistic writing. If it had not been so beautiful and witty this book would have received a two. That is what writing should be. Artistic. Now onto the main part of the book. The story. I am still still not sure how I feel about the story. Their love in a way reminded me of the love in Crash by Nicole Williams or Beautiful Disaster by Jamie McGuire. It is a desperate kind of strung out love that in my book is no where near healthy. In this book the MC understands that and yet sticks with the love (which is explained in the book by her 'daddy issues'). Honestly when the broke up I thought that the book was going to be redeemed. It could be like a real life romance where the guy she fell so desperately in love with was the asshole he seemed to be and after a horrible shitty break up, you have the chance to remake yourself. I would have loved this story if that had happened, and she had not ended up going back to him in the end. Maybe if they had bumped into each other later, when she was happy without him and not angry. Just accepting what he was to her, that he changed her, and that they could never have a healthy relationship. But, whatevs that is just my take on how the book should have ended.

With a page count of 416, I expected way more out of This is What Happy Looks Like. I'm convinced that even with 300 pages, the story would've had adequate room to breathe. In fact, I expect a whole lot more depth out of a thicker book, especially when it's Contemporary. There's little world building required in Contemporary, so the complexity needs to lie a lot more in the plot and the characters. Sadly, I didn't see that complexity that I expected. Somehow the characters, while not one-dimensional per se, didn't hold my interest for long. The initial email exchanges were cool and kinda funny too since it turns out Graham has a pet pig but once the book transitioned to "real life", there wasn't all that much left to hold my interest. No twists and turns. Just an introduction of conflicts in the first few chapters that were all resolved in a very predictable manner towards the end. Most of the chapters in between read like fillers to me. The least that could've come out of this would've been a sweet romance that leisure unfolded between the pages. Alas, that didn't happen either. Despite all the time in the world that could've been contained in the middle chapters, I have to cry out instalove! I mean, come on! Graham already planned to spend his week-long break from filming with Ellie practically the moment he laid his eyes on her. Sure, they had emailed each other for a couple of months and so it might come off as though they had known each other a while. All well and good. But the basis of their real life relationship didn't solidify much over the course of the weeks, so what was the point of it all, I ask! I don't mind reading books where readers mostly experience characters' day-to-day lives and no crazy plot twists happen. They don't all need to be issues book with heart-wrenching stories. Neither do they have to be so hilarious, I can't hold my laughter in. I do however require depth in those cases. I want to see what makes those characters tick and why they make the choices the way they do. Even if a book is meant to portray a sweet romance, there has to be something more than just that. There has to be more to the characters and the plot. Doesn't help that a third through the book I thought, "Here's a good place to end. I don't need to read the rest to know what happens anyway." That's why I decided the book just wasn't for me. It was light-hearted yet so incredibly long-drawn and these two things don't go well together for me. If a book is light-hearted, then it shouldn't waste too many words to get to the point. If it's long-drawn, it better be because it's building up the suspense and makes the wait worth it. The combination of these two only makes sense to me if a good measure of philosophising is thrown in or good measure. That obviously wasn't the case in This is What Happy Looks Like. It could've turned out to be a nice little tale to while away a couple of hours like The Statistical Probability of Love at First Sight but for that I found it too thick a book. This review is also available at dudettereads.com.

huh - this one is tough to rate. It is probably a 2.5 stars because I like some of my 3 stars and might read them again. This one I will not. The story was ok and I sort of liked the H - when he was not inexplicably distant or unavailable. But the dialogue was really immature. The voyeurism manage-"ish" scenes were really strange for me and annoyed me. Mostly because of the lack of communication and agreement BEFORE anything happened. Awkward! . The drama at the end was pretty shocking and a bit out of no where. I felt it was added to simply check a box, rather than it being critical to the story.

Oh. My. God. Simon Parker put his arm around me! Like, in front of everyone! Wait, this wasn't high school. This wasn't even my high school. But that didn't stop girls from throwing eye daggers at me from all corners of the room. I smirked a little, preening with my shoulder candy. I really liked this book, it was everything that made the first one so good, the characters, the writing style, the comedy. However while a really enjoyed it I didn't loved it as much as the first one. I got a little angry at Caroline sometimes  like when Simon starts cutting down his trips and all, I was like, seriously? Your insanely hot and sweet boyfriend wants to be home a little more and you don't like that? What was wrong with her?! But she's still a great female character and I enjoyed being in her mind for a while. I enjoyed reading again about all the gang and that dramas between them, it is always hilarious while they're together and damn I really want Caroline's life, like I can totally picture myself being her lol. I really didn't liked the epilogue  I don't know maybe because I'm a more of a dog person but I just found kind of ridiculous that it was from Clive's POV, and OMG did they really kept the five cats?! And well as for Wallbanger, there's nothing I enjoyed in this book more than him. I really liked that we got to know him a little better, going into his past and stuff, meeting high school Simon and all of that, seriously I loved that damn high school reunion! And he's one of my favorite male characters. Simon excused himself from who he was talking to and started toward me, Trevor and the apostles in tow. I know it's not logical; I know it's not even physically possible--but I swear on all that is holy, they walked in slow motion. Like in some kind of action movie. Simon took point, Trevor just off to his left, and the rest slightly behind, like geese in a V. Everyone stopped to watch. It was like the sexiest train wreck ever; no one could look away. Was this sequel necessary? No it wasn't. Did I enjoyed it? Hell yes! I was laughing out loud in most chapters which is something that I loved from this series, I love Alice Clayton because she has like the most ingenious ideas ever and always makes me laugh my ass off. I'm giving it a five stars because well I can't give Simon any less than that! And Gosh while like I mentioned before this sequel was not necessary I totally enjoyed getting my Wallbanger fix!

I really loved this but the ending annoyed me a little. It's the one thing I hate about contemporary YA. when they leave things open in a "you can imagine on your own how it ends and how their lives pan out" kind of way. If I wanted to imagine I would've written the damn thing myself. I want YOU, the author to tell me exactly what happens. I don't want a HFN I want a HEA where I know exactly how their lives pan out. Sorry, random rant that I just needed to say. There were a few times when I would think "hmm" and there were times where I kinda felt like I just needed more (besides the ending, just more of the story I guess? ), but I won't deny that this held my attention from the very beginning. Also the drawings were really cool and really made me wish I had a physical copy. But besides that I'm really happy I read this. I'm excited to see the movie tomorrow, I already pictured the actors as the characters in my head (whoops) so it'll be extra fun to see it reenacted on screen.

Well, this book probably deserves more than a three star rating, but going by Goodreads' guide, 3 stars means 'I liked it', which, in a nutshell, was exactly what I did. I enjoyed this book - it had an interesting main character, large cast of varied side characters, and some really cute and quality scenes - but there were certain aspects of it which drove me just the slightest bit crazy. In the grand scheme of the book, these probably weren't big things at all, but maybe they'll just always be that little something with Kiera Cass's storytelling that rubs me the wrong way. In The Heir, a couple of those things were: The political aspect. The problems the royal family are now facing in the aftermath of abolishing the castes felt really stupid to me and just like the author was trying to invent problems. I understand that in any government there's going to be problems and conflict, but this just didn't work for me. Also, the way Eadlyn and Maxon kept generalising all their people into one 'they' was very annoying, seeing as every story they heard clearly had two sides to it. Oh, and - just a tiny thing here - the introduction of a character named Aspel. I don't usually have a problem with unusual character names - authors should be able to name their characters whatever they want (for example I'm totally fine with names like Gunner, Ean and Fox, not to mention Cass's apparent obsession with names beginning with 'A'). But really. Really? You already have a main character called Aspen, then you introduce one called Aspel. I'm sorry, but that just felt really strange to me. I'm definitely not saying Kiera Cass is a bad author here - it's just that this book presented a lot of problems for me along the way. I think was expecting a little more from this book, but it was still enjoyable and added a new dimension to the series, which was pretty cool. I would say if you loved the first three Selection books, you'd enjoy this one. If they were all just 'meh', you probably wouldn't.

3.5 stars, because I have mixed feelings about this book. On the one hand, it's a rather complex exploration of a sexual assault survivor claiming her sexuality that includes a lot of hot sex scenes. On the other hand, she characterizes her struggles with sex after sexual assault as her being "broken" and basically gets "cured" by a good man (who has struggles of his own). As books go on this theme this is one of the best I have read, in terms of it's complexity, which isn't saying much really. I honestly feel that this theme is better off as literary fiction as opposed to romance, but damn do romance writers love it. Cured by love, or cured by sex with the right person is a huge theme in so many romances and I would really like it to end. Trauma doesn't work this way. The main character seems to not really have any trauma symptoms outside of the impact on her sex life, which feels unrealistic. Despite this, I did really enjoy the dynamic of these two characters. I liked watching their relationship build. I liked each of them individually. I cared about them and their own growth arcs, and I rooted for them as a couple. This book holds a lot of humor and hotness and I liked that, especially given the central theme. As fantasy arcs for survivors go, this had some satisfying pieces to it. That it felt like it could hold that much complexity and still honor the hard stuff shows how very talented this writer is. Trigger Warnings:  detailed description of sexual assault and the way victims get targeted and blamed, detailed description of child witnessing intimate partner violence in the past, detailed description of child physical and emotional abuse in the past, detailed description of adult child survivor of child abuse still locked in abusive dynamics with his abuser, references to intimate partner violence in the present, coercive control tactics by abusive parent, physical fight with rapist's defender, trauma symptoms, sexual assault cure storyline.

Have you written a review that you probably don't even know how to express your feeling or what you felt while reading it? Whelp this is me right now. Writing this was hard for me, not because I have being through this. It was mostly for the emotional and private part that Colleen tried to incorporate in. Which for me gets difficult to comment or even say my thoughts of the book. So, let me say first that this book was a wreck of emotions that are not even mine but I cried like crazy reaching at the end of the book. When she explains the story behind it. Lily had to face on an early stage of her life seeing her dad abusing her mother physically which really sucks  And she tries to be calm and a big girl to face what was happening with her parents, and for a girl at that age it was to much to handle. Spending time at her room and taking care of her mother every time something bad happened to her. One day she sees through the window and sees movement in the other house which is suppose to be abandoned. Little did she know that the person she saw on that house was a kid in her school. A kid that every student on the school hated. Not Lily, she took the first step to help him a little. I don't really know what to describe more, neither I'll give more details. But what I will say to all the ladies out there, that are going through tough times like this, SPEAK UP. Stand up for yourselves and your for the sake of your children. Don't ever let your fears or feelings for a person be the one thing that brings you to a grave or a hell in life. Be brave and strong. I've known women that had being on a hell of a journey with this kind of thing. This is for sure a book that all the women's on this earth need to read, and reflection it more than one time.

Actual Rating - 2.5 stars I think I'm outgrowing Abbi Glines books. This being the 12th book in the series it was way too predictable. Completely predictable actually. I was able to figure out the entire story right after the first chapter. Then again that's just me. When you have been so loyal to an author since her very first book you just tend to to want to read the rest. Yes, I've read 29 of her books since 2012. Now to the story. It was a bit too abrupt. Things just kept happening way too fast. For Example: ***SPOILER ALERT*** (not exactly, but keeping to goodread standards *winks*) Time taken for the reader to figure out Addy and Rose are the same person. Introduction of Franny to Captain. How quick leaving,, forgiving and forgetting happened after Captiain revealed his past to Addy/Rose And the good thing in the book. Something I actually liked... was that there was more story than... you know what.. I found it increasingly too much in Abbi's previous books. So good thing. Short, Quick read? This is it. *grins* UPDATE: I've listed it as dual pov, but there were one or two chapters by people other than the mains. OK bye. enjoy

3.5 stars -- I'm a huge fan of Laura Griffin, but this story was a stretch, with an unnecessarily elaborate plot by the antagonist. MINOR SPOILER: The question of why the antagonist went to so much trouble to frame Scott is never answered.

Easy is what the author calls a Mature Young Adult or New Adult novel. I'm really liking these stories that feature college-aged people, but that's technically not really YA, so I agree with the author's categorization. I definitely wouldn't recommend Easy to, say, a 12-year-old (due to the subject matter--I'll elaborate below, but I want to put a trigger warning out there because the book deals with issues such as rape and other types of violence against women, which I didn't know going into the story but which some people might need to know upfront). Easy is about Jacqueline, who has somewhat romantically but mostly foolishly followed her high school boyfriend to the college of his choosing. She's a musician (upright bass) and while she should have attended a prestigious music conservatory, she has chosen to go to his college to be near him. Okay, not the end of the world...until said boyfriend dumps Jacqueline because he wants to "sow his wild oats" while he's still young, before pursuing his political aspirations. What. a. douche. Needless to say, Jacqueline is unnerved and stunned by the breakup--they'd been together for three years--but what I love about her character is that she doesn't allow the breakup to consume her. In other words, Jacqueline doesn't go all Bella Swan and stare at a spot on her wall for three months straight. It helps that she has an awesome best friend (who's also her roommate), Erin, who offers Jackie a remedy for her heartbreak: Operation Bad Boy Phase. There's this totally hot guy (aka Lucas) in Jacqueline's economics class who's been making moony eyes at her lately (it helps that she's no longer tethered to her ex, who's also in the class). Erin's advice: rebound time! Go for it! So your own wild oats, girl. Time's a-wastin'. (And here's where my review gets all spoilerish and gushy.) Erin convinces Jacqueline to attend a Halloween frat party, and when Jacqueline goes out to her truck to leave, this complete jerk Buck tries to rape her. She fights and tries to get away and is saved when Lucas shows up and beats the crap out of Buck. Okay, at this point I got slightly annoyed because I hate it when our heroine is a damsel who needs saving, but the book is SO MUCH MORE than that. The plot is very much about sexual assault and female empowerment (self-defense classes are always a good idea) and Jacqueline is actually a strong character who really develops over the course of the story. There's also a subplot that's very reminiscent of You've Got Mail, in which Jacqueline engages in email exchanges with her econ tutor, Landon, who may or may not be another Totally Hot Econ Guy--she's not sure because she's never met him. Okay, if you've seen You've Got Mail, I probably just spoiled this part for you, but if you don't pick up on who Landon is by the first email, you're not paying attention. Lucas. ah, Lucas. Such a tortured soul with secrets of his own. oh, and he's an artist, smart, funny, covered in tats, and...yeah, I support this Jacqueline + Lucas pairing very much. There are quite a few steamy scenes (and I mean STEAMY, which is why the book isn't appropriate for younger YA readers). Lucas is an awesomely written male character. He's not some stupid jerk alpha male who constantly needs to piss on his woman's leg in public to stake his claim on her. Lucas has his issues from the past (the revelation of how his mother died is heartbreaking) , but he doesn't treat Jacqueline like crap. He's incredibly considerate and kind toward her and encourages her to take charge of who she is, to empower herself, and not stay a victim. I was pretty sad when I finished Easy and found out that there's no sequel. I really would've loved to revisit these characters, who show significant development and who are a pleasure to read. I didn't find myself rolling my eyes constantly, the way I do sometimes at other books (*cough*Slammed*cough*) and the dialogue is believable. I appreciate that Lucas isn't one of those perfect Adonis dream guys with no flaws whatsoever (although Jacqueline does wax a bit [okay, a lot] poetic about his appearance from time to time). Likewise, Jacqueline actually grows over the course of the story--she starts out dependent on others, but by the end she's kind of fearless. Something I also appreciated--the attraction between Lucas and Jacqueline is intense, but I didn't get the sense it's "insta-love" at all, which is far too common in YA novels, I find. In fact, I really feel that there is room for more to the story...hint hint, please write a sequel, Tammara Webber! Your fans would love one! Update May 2014: She wrote a companion book from Lucas's POV! It's called Breakable. *rejoices*

By the time I reached the half way point of the book, I truly believed there would be a book four, as I couldn't see how Catherine Doyle would resolve all the events with roughly 200 pages or so left. And, as I feared, the ending did have a rushed feel about it, rushed and even worse, not very realistic. [But what am I saying? This is a YA Mafia centric novel, so realism was never a part of this trilogy anyway]. Once again, I have to praise Millie, for me, the BEST character in the entire trilogy. To use a Britishism, she's brilliant! I just loved her personality (loyal, fun, smart, determined) especially when compared to that of Sophie (drama queen, unrealistic boy/girl flirting topics, self-pitying, a real drip). Why oh why couldn't the main character have been Millie?! That alone would have elevated the trilogy and earned more stars from this reviewer. But, we're stuck with Sophie, who, especially in Mafiosa, seemed to act more like a mafia princess, than BE a mafia princess. I understand her character was still reeling from the events of the previous novel, but Sophie seemed to be all over the place here. She veers between living the life of a normal teen girl (school, school dance, boy drama, occasional bratty behavior) and that of a Mob "soldier" (vengeful, hate-filled, thoughts full of violence and weaponry). And in both, she fails. I never really felt Sophie belonged in either world. She wasn't born into the Mafia life, so seemed to playact living in one. Then too, given her reality now, it was unbelievable having her continue to live the life of a normal girl. If Catherine Doyle wanted to portray a teen girl torn between two lives and two realities, she did a poor job of it. I didn't notice it in the first novel, but the British spelling of certain words (colour, favourite, tyre, etc.) makes me think the author is British. If so, it's a huge FAIL for me that British spelling and expression ("you want to give at me"?!) was used in a clearly American setting, in this case, Chicago. Almost all the characters in this trilogy were American born and raised, so it really took me out of the book when encountering Britishisms in this trilogy. The publisher should have edited those parts precisely because the characters and setting were not in Britain. So like I said, FAIL. Finally, although I liked the HEA ending, it was so eye-rollingly implausible, as well as utterly predictable. Did anyone doubt for one instance that M. Flores would turn out to be Evelina? C'mon, it was apparent the instant Sophie's father told her she could go to Colorado and someone there would help her, that the "help" would turn out to be the long-missing wife of Felice. Then too, of course I was rooting for Luca and Sophie to leave the Mob life and find their happily ever after fulfilling all their dreams, but the practical side of me says there's no way that can happen given what transpired in Mafiosa. When Luca decided not to go on the yacht, his explanation to Sophie came across as very spur of the moment. So how exactly would he and Sophie live? Where is their income? How would they get jobs? Did Sophie graduate from high school? Did they need to obtain fake documents for their new lives? So many unanswered questions, all legitimate. But no, we're treated to Sophie being surprised with tickets to see Phantom of the Opera as a birthday gift from Luca - and in Chicago no less! I always had the sense Sophie could do with more brain cells, but I didn't think Luca would be dumb enough to ever return to the scene of the crimes(plural!). The final novel and the trilogy as a whole left me feeling unsatisfied. I wanted more, and better character development for Sophie and more realism in showcasing how people could break away from a violent lifestyle. The only reasons I'm glad I read this trilogy were Millie and Luca. Everything/one else was meh to crap. Ultimately, I can't recommend this trilogy, even for Millie and Luca, fabulous as they were. These two weren't enough to overcome the problems throughout.

Nila Weaver has just had the most successful night of her couture career. The fashion show went off without a hitch; the clothes she hand-sewed herself have been sold for thousands of dollars. She's a success. But there is something missing. She has lived a tightly controlled life and she has never really known why. Her father and twin brother Vaughan, argue it is all to keep her safe. Less than an hour after the show, she learns the truth. It's because she has always been pledged to another and he has shown up now, to collect. Jethro Hawk is the kind of man she'd have no trouble going with normally, but he hints that she won't be coming back. And her extra protective father just hands her across to him. She and her twin brother know nothing about all this. And then Jethro tears her dress off to make it easier for her to get on his motorbike. Nothing is what she thought it was. I don't get why this woman would be twenty four, an international designer who travels overseas and has a full professional life - and she has never had sex - other than the drunken fumbling of one guy. And she doesn't believe in self pleasure... huh? Why not? What other options does she have? Also, she has never even seen or held a cock. I repeat... she's twenty four. And works in the fashion industry. I'm going to go with ... how? She has her phone. She has friends and workmates. Her family (of two) cannot possibly stop her doing or seeing anything. Also why would you protect your daughter to then hand her over to these guys. It makes it almost worse. And it makes no sense. Photo-shopped evidence isn't real evidence. Not when they have cut and pasted Jethro's head on her father and brother - the only guys who have been near her. Weak. But it's enough to convince her. And I guess that is all they need. But it is one of those kind of stories where it just won't make sense and you can't expect it to. This isn't BDsM it's a slave story. There are no safe words here. The only way to remove her new collar is through death. The Weaver women are not here under any sort of meaningful consent; its duress over several generations. It's 'run away and I kill your whole family.' Note: running away might have actually stopped this at some generation. They can't enforce the deal without the women to enforce it on. And it also squicks me that the Hawks are all proud Englishmen and the Weavers are of Spanish (?) origin. So it's white men beating up blue-black haired ladies with dark skin. No. Just no. I am lawyer. I cannot believe that there would not have been some attempt by some of the last seven generations of the Weavers to fight this ridiculous contract. Contracts don't last forever even if they say they do. Her constant brain flips of 'I'm enjoying this I must be a whore' etc are frustrating in their ignorance. A rapist can give you an orgasm - it doesn't mean you consented. Orgasms are a physical reaction. It ends in a cliffhanger of a sort. There is no way she can run away naked, with no shoes from inside the Hawk family grounds. She doesn't even know how high the walls are. The hunting dogs have personalised electronic collars. And Jethro wants to hunt her. How silly are you, girl? This hits my squick buttons. I don't like the constant abuse stuff. They force her to do stuff and then thank her when she does, as if that replaces her consent. I know that works for some people, but not for me. And Jethro isn't her saviour; he brought her here. Why does she think he might care about her? And clearly 'kite' her phone sex dude is a member of the same family. Kites, hawks and eagles are all the same bird family. Jeez, Nila - Google it. 2 non consenting stars And 'observeillance' is not a word. Stop using it.

I love this series. Or I loved the book before this and really liked the ones before that. This one didn't totally do it for me, though London and Luke are both nice enough characters and the authors always write really well. I just couldn't really wrap my head around some of the plot points (I really hate the we-can't-date-because-friend/brother-will-get-mad-at-us plot. What kind of friends/brothers are those? and why would anyone listen to them? Unless there's something else going on it just makes everyone involved seem immature and the plot seem forced. ). London was a kind of cool character with her feisty independence, but Luke was something of an enigma. The history between him and the other women in the series was confusing and got in the way of seeing him through London's eyes. Worth reading though--

Damn, this was such a fun ride!! After the disappointment of the second book, The One brought me back the excitement I felt while reading The Selection, with a few disappointments as well. America stopped being such a whiny girl who couldn't choose between two amazing guys, and Thank God for that, but she still put a lot of barriers between her and Maxon and she really got on my nerves when she couldn't tell him she loved him. She felt that way, she could have said it. Christ. When Maxon finally found out about her and Aspen I just put the book down and ran away from it. I hated that moment profoundly. I actually cried with frustration, because this whole love triangle should not have existed. And then he got mad, and he had the right to be, because America kept postponing telling him, and then the rebels came, and CELESTE DIED!!! Like how is that okay? Mrs. Cass spent the entire book trying to exonerate Celeste and make her seem like a normal person with feelings, and then she died, and America barely gave her a second thought?! Ugh. Why? Anyway, this was a really, really fun ride, I finished it in one day, and my tablet let me down as it ran out of battery and I felt betrayed, but... well. I loved it. Truly.

** spoiler alert ** (Thank you to Jeannie Moon, Tule Publishing and NetGalley for the opportunity to read an ARC for an honest review) His Forbidden Princess is a novella by Jeannie Moon and book four of the Royal Holiday series. A forbidden and second chance romance, the book stars Sophie and Ian who meet while Ian is a graduate fellow in England. They're in love, but when the truth about Sophie being a princess is revealed, they're separated until years later. After eight years, Ian is now a special agent who has volunteered to protect Sophie from terrorist during her visit to the U.S. After her family is attacked, he takes Sophie to his family home where they spend time together and reconnect. His Forbidden Princess is a cute short story that moves along well especially with the added action. I also liked the fact that Sophie loved Twinkies! :) The whole scene with Uncle John and him telling Sophie what a Twinkie was amusing. Overall, a must read for anyone who likes royals and second chance romances. Or for anyone for a quick read that has a happy ending.

I think I'm starting to realize that I like romances that include parent-child relationships, but I don't care for romances that are about parent-child relationships. This is definitely a book that let the actual "romance" take a back seat to the "suddenly acquired child," and it just wasn't my sort of book. First of all, this book is shelved as an M/M romance here on GoodReads and Dreamspinner is widely a romance publisher, but this book really isn't a romance at all. In fact, despite being together since high school, Hen and Sam don't even really seem to like each other all that much. They're downright mean to one another most of the time! They seem a lot more like friends or brothers than lovers, broken only with Sam wanting to play with Hen's "pecker" once in a while. This isn't all bad--there's a sense of intimacy about them. They've always been close, always a twosome, always Hen-and-Sam, and I think that effortless connection is well-written. But we just never got the idea that they made a very good romantic duo, even if they made excellent fathers. The drama of two gay men trying to take care of a young disabled child in the conservative South is not lost on me, but it didn't feel like something I haven't read before. It feels like an exercise in futility--Hen has to bite his tongue and turn the other way at the endless abuse, homophobia, racism, and Islamophobia of his town because he wants custody of his nephew who, it turns out, it also his younger brother due to his deceased father raping his sister when she was 13 . He subjects himself to mass because of his faith, but the church (save for a kind nun) just shuns him at every turn and makes him feel unwanted. It's more a story of "let's see how much we can make these men suffer" than anything. Maybe I'm just jaded. Maybe I'm exhausted by it. But is anyone else just tired of these narratives? But just because I didn't like the story doesn't mean Wilgus is a bad writer. He has a great knack for dialogue and setting. Even when his minor characters make me want to scream, they feel real, and there's a deprecating sense of humor about it all. I feel like it is distinctly southern in a way I will never understand. This isn't my favorite read of 2017, and if you want a light romance with a no-strings-attached HEA, this won't be for you. But the writing quality is decent enough to warrant checking out the author.

Today I was watching Rafael Nadal play (and annihilate -- sigh) my homeboy Milos Raonic in the Rogers Cup, and I found myself unable to stop contemplating his ass. The boy fits his shorts well, I tell you. Nummy. The rest of Rafa does not work for me, though. The headband, the hair, the nasally voice. In fact, I can't think of one tennis player who entirely does do it for me -- bits and pieces, yes, such as Rafa's ass, Roddick's legs, Djokovic's style, Federer's money... (This does make me a jerk. If I heard a guy saying this about women, I'd probably get in a fistfight.) Nope, only one that's appealed is Jonathan Rhys Meyers in Match Point. But J. Kenner (and apparently Woody Allen) gets the potential of tennis players -- what the combination of rock-hard calves, fierce determination, and millions of dollars in winnings can do to a girl. Hence Damien Stark, former tennis star, current billionaire, always gorgeous. This is the third and final instalment of Kenner's Stark trilogy. It begins with Damien on trial for his coach's murder well after the fact. Nikki is begging him to reveal his history with his coach, assuring him it will solve all his problems (not entirely sure how...), but Damien's adamant that he wants his past kept very, very private. The trial is destroying both of them. The rest of the book is, like the other two, basically just angst, sex, repeat. Lots of angst, tons o' sex. Like Sylvia Day's Crossfire series but with more sex, I swear to god. Normally I'm totally on board with that, but -- and I can't even believe I'm writing this -- I did get to a point where I said, "Geez, again? Really?" Although the sex stayed interesting, so I kind of got over that. The angst, not so much. Maybe I'm just tired of Nikki and Damien and all the bloody drama. (Once again, much as I am with the Crossfire series.) I've never been a huge fan of Nikki, although I've tried. I just don't understand how she gets anything done ever, nor Damien for that matter. And she's so judgy when it comes to her friends. Always judging. Damien's too much of an enigma for me, so I can't get into him either. Fans of the series will probably enjoy this, as will fans of lots and lots of sex. I was kind of the former, and I thought I was the latter, but I wasn't a huge fan of this book. (Also, I think I'm completely burnt out on first person.) It was okay, it wasn't exactly disappointing, but it felt a bit like work. Lila Reviewed from ARC. Reviews at www.nomdeplumepress.wordpress.com

Review also posted on my blog at: Kala's Book Blog I have really mixed feelings about this book. The first half is almost a clone of Beautiful Disaster with Jack acting like a huge player who "never sleeps with the same girl twice" and gets in fights a lot (aka Travis). Cassie acts exactly like Abby as the girl who can resist him, but not really, and he instantly falls for her. They start dating quickly and he becomes possessively obsessed with Cassie. He even gives her an arbitrary nick name the first time they meet - Kitten (which makes as much sense as Pigeon, but at least is something cute instead of the cockroach of birds). Jack also beats people up, treats every other girl (EXCEPT Cassie and her best friend) like a slut. Speaking of the best friend, Cassie's best friend is a clone of the BFF in Beautiful Disaster too. She fluctuates between warning Cassie off of Jack and telling Cassie to forgive Jack's constant bad behavior. Despite the similarities to Beautiful Disaster, I still enjoyed the story for the most part. The book starts deviating in plotline towards the middle when Jack gets drafted (for baseball). Major spoilers after this point! Jack cheats on Cassie, which I don't understand at all. I know he was drunk, but he was completely uninterested in this girl who won't leave him alone yet he KEEPS drinking until he's so drunk he goes home with her. Of course, the girl ends up pregnant. Then Jack, who is the biggest moron ever, decides he has to marry the girl. He can't stand her, is in love with Cassie (who is willing to forgive him despite him cheating AND getting a girl pregnant), but he insists on torturing everyone by marrying the girl. AND HE DOES IT. Despite Cassie coming down the day before to beg him not to. That conversation broke my heart and the way he treated Cassie during that conversation, especially when the other girl shows up, was unforgivable. Completely unforgivable. But then, of course, the girl was faking the pregnancy (and Jack, the biggest moron ever, can't wait to see a pregnancy test or a PATERNITY TEST... this girl is a huge slut and he doesn't wait for a paternity test?? So Jack dumps her and waits six months to beg for Cassie back. I admit he did it in a cute way, but I didn't care at that point. He was not redeemable at that point. He just wasn't. So I couldn't feel like it was a happy ending, despite it being a happy ending. I was impressed by the author's writing style though. The book was well edited, has a nice cover, and was formatted well. Though I had some issues with the story itself, the book flowed really well and was a quick and easy read. I will be checking out additional books by this author.

Silly me... I thought this would be a standalone book. I just read that this is a 5-novel series so hopefully I only have to wait one year for the series to be complete! I thought this was another great book in this series - this series has become one of my favorites ever! Eadlyn is 7 minutes older than her twin brother, Ahren. Which makes her next in line to be queen of Illea, a position she has been groomed for her entire life. Under the rule of her parents, Maxon and America, the caste system has been wiped out and everyone is now free to create their own lives. But a generation later there is still a lot of unrest in Illea. Her parents desperately need a distraction while they try to figure out what is going on. Eadlyn agrees to a Selection as long as she can refuse all the candidates in the end. And that is her plan because she doesn't plan to get married. Eadlyn starts out selfish, but as she interacts with more people and starts letting her defenses down, we see her vulnerability. She is extremely loyal to those close to her and to her country and she has to go through some tough challenges, which all help shape her and help her to start seeing herself as others see her. As for the 35 young men, I definitely have my favorite that I am rooting for. (I am Team Kile)  But there are 3 that I think have a great shot at winning her heart (and she's already hinted that she knows which young man it is, but it wasn't revealed to us in this book) so I can't wait to see how everything resolves in what I hope is the final book (please don't make me wait for a 6th book)! Content: Clean, a few mild swear words Source: Amazon.com

This was the first Bluewater Bay book I've read. It can definitely be read as a standalone but I enjoyed it so much I am going to pick up the rest of the series. Derrick is an ex lumberjack trying...and failing to keep his parents B&B running. Just as Derrick decides to give up, in drops Ginsberg. Ginsberg helps Derrick see the importance of love, happiness and keeping his parents B&B running. There is some angst here, dickhead Derrick makes an appearance, transgender sexy times (Ginsberg is F2M), and a frilly apron makes this novel a special treat :)

4 crazy mystery stars! The Murder of Roger Ackroyd, an exceptionally high-rated book in the Hercule Poirot series, lives up to its fame. I intended to finish this book in a day, as a part of a self-readathon, but I'm glad that I didn't stick to that. I could enjoy the book slowly to its fullest, which might not have been possible otherwise. The book starts off with a suicide and a murder. Plus, a mega congregation of characters, each of which added to the suspicion. The mystery builds up slowly in multiple tiers and is unfolded progressively by the Belgian detective with seamless method and precision. Lies, secrets, blackmail- each unravel under the strain of his keen observation, be it inanimate objects, like the occasional chair displaced in a corner of the room or the animated looks on many a face that crossed him by. He sets a new standard with his old-fashioned, curious, odd little ideas, all of which seem irrelevant to begin with, but soon fit in the major scheme of things. He searched for an alibi for each of the people connected with the case, holding them up as potential suspects till the end, never waving anyone into his full confidence. As has always been a reason for me liking Christie, she endeavors to elucidate Poirot's order of investigation in a detailed way, even here. That's something I admire in authors, and she comes in the list naturally. Reasons why I didn't add another star is because the end felt a bit rushed. A plausible reason might be because the narrator himself was the culprit and hence things were different. Poirot kept the ultimate revelation for the end, which though an indication of his supreme caution, kept a major part of the story obscure from the reader. Also because Poirot himself offered to let the man assist him in this case, people took the wise old man's decision for granted and scratched out one major figure from the whole picture. So many things which one might associate the murderer with never occur in the potholes of the story because of this reason. Not until Poirot reveals the meticulous working of his gray cells. When I tried placing my finger on the wrongdoer, the mysterious telephone call to Dr. Sheppard never fitted with any of them. No matter how close on track I was, that never brought me closer to the major discovery. Alas Christie! You win. Yet again. Also, I had issues with the motive. It wasn't THAT strong enough to imply killing as an ultimate option. Till now, all of Christie's murderers have had some very profound purpose behind a grave thing like murder. This one was less justified, in comparison. And Hastings! I skipped the previous book, an anthology of sorts, so unsure of why he needed to go away this abruptly. I missed him dearly, right from the very onset of the story. Young man, whatever you might be doing in Argentina, come down right now! This is unfair, Poirot is crippled without your pompous ideas, and so are we fellow mortals! Overall a great read. Recommended highly. 4 stars in all.

(2.5 of 5 stars) This feels like a standalone novella which the publishers pressured Spencer-Fleming into expanding to novel-length and cramming into this series, for reasons I can't even fathom. I can't think of any other reason why Clare and Russ would have so little screentime here, while the vast majority of time is devoted to a bunch of hapless characters bumbling around in the woods. In different hands it might have been a decent murder mystery/comedy - there are so many close shaves and near-misses as people wander into scenes, leap to all the wrong conclusions, and then pass the next incoming schmuck on their way out again, unnoticed. But instead it's played totally straight, with far too many convenient coincidences, and the mystery pretty much solves itself with no outside involvement whatsoever. I won't even get into the ending, except to say that the motivation for blowing up the hotel made no sense , and also suuuuure, Russ, what could possibly go wrong with that plan ?

Wow--great book. It sucked me in and didn't let go until I finished. This is writing at its best--powerful, persuasive, and textured--and I reveled in the author's ability to create a plot that both intrigued me but also got me emotionally involved. It had me on the edge of my seat. I was so engrossed; I finished Mud Vein in just over a day. First Thoughts: The situation the main characters, Senna and Isaac find themselves in is a strange, twisted but intriguing setup. Senna's story was heartbreaking, but she is cuckoo--no denying that--still, I loved how the author brought us through Senna's psychosis. I felt it. Lived it. Breathed it ... loved the all-encompassing, macabre, detailed effects of it, and emotional dramatic arches it took me through. Middle Thoughts: As much as I sympathized with Senna's situation, I didn't really get why she was so closed off. Though she had difficult relationships with both parents, they didn't sound abusive, and neither did her relationship with former-lover, Nick. I didn't exactly understand what made her like she was. Her resistance to letting Isaac in and allowing herself to trust frustrated me. At times, I felt beat up and tired of Senna's self-inflicted barrier, and I had to put the book down for a brief break from it. I craved for her to stop being silent and give Isaac some of her words. If I had one complaint, it would be that I would've liked to be more convinced of what led Senna to her state of complete emotional remoteness, prior to the rape and cancer . I tend to think she was OCD or mildly autistic. It didn't take anything away from the story, but if it had been explained a bit more in depth, I might have identified with, and had more patience, for her character. Final Thoughts: I found myself wanting Senna and Isaac to end up together, despite the fact that he was much too kind, much too good to be forever paired with her dysfunction. As good for her as he was, he deserved more. My over-logical, analytical thinking aside, this book is one of the best I've read in a while. It's easy to tell when a book really affects me--besides the fact that I ignore my work, family and life for the duration of reading it, I think about the characters even after I've finished reading the book. The bonus effect is that good writing is inspiring. It makes me want to get writing. Bravo author!

It's entirely possible that this anthology is more brilliant than it appears because I'm not familiar with the ACD canon and so stories that appeared to have little relationship with Sherlock Holmes (including an entire entry by someone writing about the fact that they didn't know anything about Holmes) are actually clever allusions to canon that I just missed. Or not. I did get that some were retellings of ACD stories with other people standing in for Holmes and Watson (why, I don't know). There were two stories that stood out. One is Neil Gaiman's The Case of Death and Honey (full disclosure: I'm a fan of Gaiman's other work). His dealt directly with Sherlock Holmes. I liked his portrayal of Sherlock's relationship with Mycroft. I also liked his suggestion of how Mycroft could have kept the Empire running on his own but that without it him it would crumble. I also liked his portrayal of John Watson fading away as he got older and suffered losses. And I definitely buy the idea that were Sherlock to discover how to reverse aging or how to make himself immortal, he'd do it to John without telling him first). The other was The Case That Holmes Lost by Charles Todd. It dealt with some of Doyle's ambivalence about Holmes and an intersection between (fictional) Doyle's life with Holmes. I'd like to read more about Doyle, I know he had something of a love/hate relationship with his creation.

A moment of silence please, for the first book in this series that seemed to be the beginning of a promising series. I think I may have figured out Jess Lindsay's problem: he can concoct interesting scenarios and outlines for plots. But his ability to write characters is almost non-existent. To combat this, he began by writing about a character who is a self-confessed 'non-human'. He has a girlfriend/wife whose primary function is to stay home and cook, be entirely naive and clueless, and occasionally talk to Dexter in a series of half sentences of "Really, Dexter?" and "Oh, but the kids..." (for real, the number of times Rita manages to get a full sentence out, and one that doesn't just paint her as a dithering caricature is... a very low number). And then we have Dexter's sister Deborah, whose only character trait is that she likes being a police officer and doesn't like looking feminine. And she says fuck a lot. (and spends a LOT of time at work). The rest of the cast are more or less invisible extras, with a couple of 'regulars' chucked in who has one line personalities (Vince Masouka likes sex jokes. That is his entire personality, and will be reaffirmed at least three times in each novel.) So, here we come to Dexter Is Delicious. The fifth novel in the series. And it is actually a very good novel... if we ignore the context of the preceding four novels, and those pesky characters. Right at the start, we have Dexter, who is now madly in love with his new daughter. I can understand this, and it could have been interesting to see how Dexter's world view shifted entirely with the existence of daughter - and it WAS interesting - until he became kind of obsessed, and incredibly fickle.I'm never going to kill again. I'm going to kill to protect Lily. He can't seem to make his mind up - almost as though Jeff Lindsay couldn't make his mind up (as he couldn't quite make his mind up with how to deal with child murderers in the previous book). We also have Dexter suddenly Feeling Things for other humans. He feels things and emotions, which is slightly weird after reading him berate the entirety of human existence for four books. And now let's start on  Brian. This could have been an amazing plot device, if it had been handled interestingly. Well, to be honest... if it had been handled ANY way, and if ANYTHING had happened other than what DID happen. Dexter just invites him in for a cup of coffee? And seems surprised when Rita takes to him? Does Dexter not think that, sine his entire life has been built on faking niceness, maybe his brother has done the same? And then rather than warning Rita about Brian (EVEN WHEN HE TAKES ASTOR AND CODY OUT TO KILL) Dexter just... lets it happen. No reaction. Why, Dexter? Why, Jess Lindsay? Why would that happen and why does it happen? And then the big twist at the end, which.. well no, was that even meant to be a twist? It was so painfully obvious from the very first mention of  Brian . But even after this unshocking reveal, the finale o the book was ridiculous. A serial murderer is in a gang of cannibals, and they have 3 police officers as hostages. I can believe that Brian would help Dexter, due to his sibling bond. But then he lets Chutsky go too? And he lets DEBORAH go? The last time they met, Brian tried to kill Deborah - he tried to get DEXTER to kill Deborah. And now he just lets her go? I don't buy it. I also don't buy that Dexter is happy to then just let Brian join the family with no worries. THIS IS BRIAN THE MURDERER. THIS IS BRIAN WHO TRIED TO MURDER YOUR SISTER A FEW YEARS AGO. Now suddenly, he has done a 180 and decided to help Deborah escape her kidnapping, and Dexter does a 180 and just forgets that a while ago he was feeling human emotion for Deborah, and is happy to let her attempted murderer join his family. And let's just hope Deb never finds out!! What a great plan. I mean, do Rita and Deborah never talk? (Probably not, Rita just faffs about the kids and burning dinner, because that is all her character is.) And then there is Deborah, and bless Jeff Lindsay for attempting to inject some character development into her. But... motherhood? Into Deborah? I would say that it seems highly unlike her character, but that would probably depend on her having had a character for the last four novels. The final thing that really got me was Dexter's extramarital sex scene. Dexter on ecstasy was never something I wished to see, and his description of love and beauty was more nauseating than his odes to Lily-Anne whilst sober. And that was almost as nauseating as the thought than he then had sex with an 18 year old, and almost as nauseating as Jeff Lindsay playing the 'girl threatens to call rape' card. Really, I am sure that there were a range of things that COULD have happened during their imprisonment that she could have held over Dexter's head. Instead, we got a whole load of nausea. And then, aside form our regular characters acting bizarre, we also get a whole load of new characters. Deb has a now partner, there are some random new sergeants, some FBI agents. And with little to no character description ("Deke thinks everybody loves him") they are really nothing more than extras. I especially like the female FBI agent who, in one throwaway sentence was suspicious of Dexter and his activities, and then 50 pages into the book is never mentioned again. Hooray for developed characters! It also occurred to me how often Dexter talks about cliches. Whether discussing that 'usually this cliche is wrong, but here it is!' or 'this cliche is totally true!' he just can't get enough of proving that he knows which things are cliches and which things are not. (Hint for Jeff Lindsay: constantly talking about cliches in a disapproving manner is not really any more acceptable than constantly using cliches) So yes. Apart from character issues, the plotline in this really IS good. And if it were a standalone novel, I would probably rate it 4 stars. Maybe 5 if it were a standalone novel with fleshed out characters. Jeff Lindsay CAN create good stories, but maybe it is time to stick to standalone novels where you don't need to build a whole cast of consistent characters. {{read 20/07/14}}

Disclaimer: I listened to the audio book, so I won't be commenting on the author's style or sentence structure. I can, however, critique the plot, character development, pacing, and other literary elements. Quick, non-spoiler review: It was entertaining and it had me thinking about all the things I've done, all the decisions made by my parents and me and others in my life, that made me this version of myself in this world. Quantum physics is always a fun and freaky concept and I do tend to gravitate towards stories that center around alternate realities. As entertaining as it was, the ending left me feeling unfulfilled. It left me a little angry. The characters were often frustrating, especially the female characters who catered to the main character and did not seem to have much personality aside from being smitten with the main character (so much that both Amanda and Daniella risked their lives to save/be with him). Often I found myself whispering, "Jason, you IDIOT!" because the way he conducted himself much of the time was, well, moronic. For a character who is described as a physicist who would have revolutionized his field of study, he didn't have a lot of common sense. I predicted a lot of outcomes right away, which isn't always a bad thing, but it did make it less exciting for me in the second half of the novel. Overall, I give it three stars, because it was fun most of the time, but disappointing in other aspects which I will go into detail about below, if you don't mind spoilers. Nit-picky review:  I had some issues with Jason as a character. At first I was rooting for him - I desperately wanted him to find his wife and son again. After he went to the apocalyptic world riddled with disease, AND THEN STAYED TO GIVE "HIS" WIFE MORPHINE, EXPOSING HIM AND EVERYONE ELSE (POTENTIALLY INFINITE WORLDS) TO A DEADLY BUBONIC PLAGUE EBOLA COCKTAIL VIRUS, I stopped rooting for him because it became very clear to me that he didn't care whose life or lives he would sacrifice to save Daniella. Under normal circumstances, I would be able to understand that and sympathize, if he, ya know, weren't this hot shot smarty farty scientist. But he is supposed to be somewhat aware of what his actions could lead to. He is insightful at times, knowing exactly what the consequences of his actions are, and at other times he is completely oblivious, arrogant, and downright reckless. That was a huge problem for me. I also want to know why the H E double hockey sticks he didn't destroy the confounded box of doom! I could understand why this course of action was not attempted if the author explained it couldn't be destroyed, but the thought never even crosses Jason's mind. Another aspect of the book I took issue with is the way the women are written. Amanda gives up literally everything to save Jason and is then written out of the book. I hate it when authors chicken out of giving a character we have grown to admire or love a real ending. And Daniella Daniella Daniella. Where to begin? She seems like every guy's dream girl... the manic pixie dream girl the main character gets to marry and keep. She's beautiful, from a far off land, an artist, endlessly compassionate, understanding, and self-sacrificing. Jason is so obsessed with her that he often forgets about their son, who was seemingly injected into this narrative as a plot device. She is everything but strong-willed. She is the damsel to be saved, starting with the moment her and Jason met at a party. Jason "saves" her from a notorious womanizer and then swoops in to snatch her up for himself. Le sigh. Jason is the epitome of the "nice guy" all women know a little too well. I couldn't help rolling my eyes as the actor described exactly how that scene went down. Later Daniella says, "Jason, do you remember when we met and you saved me from that guy?" Why are you reminding me of this Daniella? WHY DOES THE AUTHOR INSIST ON SHOVING THIS DAMSEL IN DISTRESS TROPE DOWN MY THROAT. It's not romantic, it's trite and annoying. Stop it! Furthermore, I will never understand why Daniella doesn't tell this guy she's had enough when hundreds of Jasons threaten their lives. She leaves everything - her whole world - to be with him, not giving a hoot about how it will affect their son. What? Is her love for him seriously that delusional? She barely questions their final decision before they plunge into the abyss of the box! I feel like there wasn't enough character building for that to seem realistic. I also found myself wishing we spent a little more time in the first world, or any of the other worlds really. The world hopping started to feel like Groundhog's day, which may have been the author's intention, but the tactic didn't allow for much development in any world Jason explored, which is something I personally would have liked to experience. Another thing I'm curious about: how did Jason killing Jasons not rip a hole in the space-time continuum or something? I'm no physicist, but I feel like that would have dire consequences. Maybe not. But the science could have been explained a little better, for me at least. I do like that the ending was ambiguous regarding what happens to the Dessens, but there were definitely some loose ends that leave me wondering about the state of the multiverse. Also, is that awful disease going to spread to other worlds and just completely obliterate all of existence? I sort of like to think that happens because if nothing exists, Jason doesn't exist either, and that's just fine with me. I'm sure there are more questions I will have about this novel that I would like to delve into, but for now this concludes my review.

One of few books of Agatha I guessed the murderer. Not because it was obvious , but because I understood murderer's phsycology. Even so, book was mindblowing. For me ending was little disappointment, i would expect drammatic explanation like all other her books. But what would you do if killer is 12 years old little girl? What could police do? They cant arrest her or let her go..Sadly killing her was best option

Read on a recommendation and I really really don't understand the hype. Sure, the concept was cool and intriguing and there are some interesting ideas here and there, but not only is the execution flawed (pacing and characters are off) but the final twist makes no sense? Why would a school for the blind be windowless? Is that a thing in America? I know for a fact schools of that kind have windows over here. I mean... Why wouldn't they? What about the blind pupils with residual sight? Disabilities are on a spectrum, it's not all-or-nothing! What about seeing teachers, staff, parents? I mean clearly, there's light in there since Malorie can see... Why would the school rely exclusively on lamps rather than use natural light? I don't get it, I am baffled; if you needed a windowless building, why not try a mall? In short: baffled. Also, I was disappointed to realise that the blind survivors were not, as I first thought, blind people from before who were naturally immune to the creatures and would be best suited to adapt to a world where seeing is basically a death sentence, but abled (or seeing, at least) people who purposely mutilated themselves. So, OK. But then what about the people who were blind before? What happened to them? Especially considering te survivors live in a school for the blind! Also also, afterbirth is a thing. I'm not gonna say anymore about that particular ridiculousness. Anyway, it had great potential but saying it fell short would be a giant understatement. It's bad. It's really just plain bad.

I didn't like D for Deadbeat as much as the other books so far. The whole story for this book seemed pointless. Kinsey gets stiffed by a guy who hired her to deliver some money to a kid. She didn't start doing any work of the case while she waited for the check to clear and it turned out that the guy didn't have any money to pay her. Instead of shrugging it off and going about her business, Kinsey puts a lot of time and effort into trying to track this guy down and then he turns up dead. I understand that there needs to be some mystery involved, but this just felt forced. Anyway, once you get past the fact that the whole plot felt forced, it's the usual PI stuff that she does, running around asking questions and making enemies out of suspects. There was not actually that much happening in this book, lots of her running around with no idea who did it and no real leads as to where to start to flush out the perp. It was still entertaining to read, it just wasn't as good as the first three books in the series. There is one other thing that really bothered me about this book,I was not that impressed with Kinsey finally sleeping with Jonah. It just seemed like a bad idea since his wife came back and he jumped when she called. But in this book, all of a sudden he seems to realize that his wife is a jerk and he wants Kinsey. Kinsey doesn't try very hard to get him to realize that he is still married and sleeps with him anyway. I am betting that this turns into a problem for them in coming books. One thing that I did like about this fourth book was the ending. It was pretty shocking and a little bit sad. But the thing that I liked the most was Kinsey didn't get into a life or death situation at the end, she just tried to talk the kid out of killing himself. I was afraid that each book would end with Kinsey in some kind of life or death situation and either have to save herself or have someone else save her. This ending was just as exciting as the others where she has to get away from the bad guy without being as ridiculous as that. Other than those couple of things that bothered me about this installment, it was still an easy and entertaining read. Kinsey is still the same tough girl character that is kind of manly. I am waiting for her to soften up a little bit and maybe act a little more womanly, but I am not holding my breath. Overall, this one is a 3 out of 5 stars.

I really enjoyed this. I'd watched the first season of the T.V. show and hadn't realized it was based on a book series. I'm glad I picked up the book and gave it a try. Aside from appearances, the casting for Vic & Henry were pretty good, personality wise (I could be a sucker for Katee Sackhoff & Lou Diamond Phillips), but the show leaves a lot of the humor of the books out and feels much darker. I enjoy the Longmire of the book more, as well, given we get a little more backstory (and less rage - the "Denver" storyline is not at all in the first book, if at all in the series - that'll remain to be seen). This may sound like a strange comparison, but if you liked Dresden files, you might like Longmire. Obviously Longmire is no modern day Chicago wizard and this is a perfectly mundane setting in WY with a perfectly mortal, normal human beings - but the snarky one liners and dark humor (with a splash of the absurd) will appeal to Dresden (and possibly Iron Druid) fans. It gets a touch immature, but there were some great "snort out loud" moments. I feel it could make a good crossover book if you aren't normally a fan of mysteries, but want to give one a try. I'd plant this in the "cozy" category, as well. We're pretty well shielded from the gruesome, though there is definitely dark subject matter. The book has a few rough edges - one enterprising person took the liberty of correcting a typo with a ball point pen in my copy - but nothing so much that I felt turned off. 1 star down for the rough edges, but otherwise, a fun sick day read. Side comments: Hmmm... on the murderer. I like putting SOME clues together... I kinda hate it when the mystery is solved out of left field and you don't get to play a role. Then again, I hate it when I have it figured out by the first chapter, too. I loved "George is gone again..." Turk's car. Turks Grand-Uncle... who is *hilarious* and horrible at the same time. Henry... and what an entertaining bro-mance he's got going with Longmire. ha Only in a book could someone like Vic get away with her language, but still, she cracked me up. Pretty much all the characters were quirky and entertaining, to me.

I do not often read short story collections. Not to say I have anything against the format; as a matter of fact, a well-crafted short story is often rather like instant gratification to a reader: it does not take the same amount of time to read as a novel, but can be just as fulfilling if it's good. But I find that, as a rule, I only enjoy short stories if they are in collections written by one author, and preferably linked to one particular world or universe. Lots of writers do this, especially those who have long-running series, as a means of filling in certain gaps in the series, or for telling stories they might like to tell, but which don't have the necessary substance for a novel. And then there are the collections that are meant to be tributes to a single author. This is usually done for authors who have had immense impact on the genre in which they wrote. After the King, for instance, is a collection of short stories containing works by some of the most notable fantasy writers still living, and is a tribute to none other than J.R.R. Tolkien himself (the "King" in the title of the collection). That one proved to be quite an enjoyable read - one story in particular, Peter S. Beagle's "The Naga," is one of the stories I ask my students to read for class. But it is very rare that short story tributes are made up for a fictional character - mostly because said character would have to be more influential than the writer who created him or her. However, that is most assuredly the case with Sherlock Holmes. Though a fictional character, there is no doubting that Holmes has a stronger grip on the imaginations of all those who encounter him, in his various incarnations, than his own creator, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. Indeed, so powerful is the presence of Sherlock Holmes in the minds of people that it's hard to think of him as fictional at all. Many people - mostly diehard Sherlockians, but oftentimes more run-of-the-mill folk as well - speak of Holmes as if he were a real person. They speak of Dr. Watson as real, of Moriarty as real, of Irene Adler as real. It is as if, through some mysterious, magical means, Sherlock Holmes and the characters around him have seemingly emerged and detached themselves from the fabric of Doyle's stories, and embedded themselves in that strange gray space between true history and speculation. So powerful is Holmes's hold on the imagination of all those who encounter him, that it seems only fitting that a tribute collection of short stories should be made up for him - not, it should be noted, for his creator. And that is what A Study in Sherlock is, essentially: a tribute collection of short stories honoring the most quintessential, most influential detective in fiction (and maybe history). The authors listed are notable, though I am only familiar with very few of them. I know who the editors are: Laurie R. King is the author of the Mary Russell series, and Leslie S. Klinger is one of the most famous Holmes scholars, not least because he put together the Sherlock Holmes Reference Library, which is an annotated version of the entire Holmes canon. I know Neil Gaiman, of course, being a fan of his work. I am also familiar with Lee Child, though I have not read his work; the Jack Reacher novels are really more my mother's thing than mine. The other authors are utter unknowns to me. None of this matters, of course. I am always happy to acquaint myself with new authors, and sometimes a short story is a handy way of doing so, especially in collections such A Study in Sherlock. However, one of the most common problems I have with these short story collections popped up almost immediately: a noticeable lack of consistency. Some of the stories were utterly intriguing. For instance, the first one in the collection, Alan Bradley's "You'd Better Go in Disguise," was interesting because it told a Holmes story from an utterly different perspective: that of the criminal. The reader does not know initially that the narrator of the tale is a criminal, but this is quickly revealed in the climax and denouement. This was an utterly diverting new way of looking at the classic Holmes story. Another excellent example of the above is "The Man With the Twisted Lips" by S.J. Rozan, which is a direct reference to the Holmes story of the same title - no surprise there, really, since this story is actually a behind-the-scenes look at what was going on in "The Man With the Twisted Lip." In Rozan's story, it turns out that Holmes and Watson's involvement was carefully planned by the Chinese immigrants who maintained opium dens in the area, setting the events up as a means of ensuring the lascar of the original story is chased out of their territory for good, but without calling undue attention to themselves. The way this story parallels Doyle's story is such that it is almost impossible to read the original without thinking of Rozan's, and how it fits so neatly into its fabric. Equally good is Thomas Perry's "The Startling Events in the Electrified City." Narrated (as expected) by Dr. Watson, it is a story that takes place after the events at Reichenbach Falls, and follows Holmes and Watson to the United States, where they receive a most unusual request: they are asked to help in the assassination of President McKinley - by McKinley himself. While there is nothing new with Holmes being involved in the affairs of famous historical figures (particularly those who were alive when he was), this one takes a whole new spin on things by introducing an element of conspiracy into the supposedly "known" facts of a historical event. All of a sudden it is tempting to look at certain historical askance and wonder if it were not possible that Holmes might have had a hand in them somehow. Equally interesting is "The Adventure of the Concert Pianist" by Margaret Maron. Though it is set during Holmes's time, this is one of those stories that does not directly involve Holmes at all - in fact, the case is solved by Dr. Watson (thus proving that he is not the bumbling, well-meaning idiot he is portrayed as sometimes), and the narrator is none other than Mrs. Hudson herself. Though the case is one of those unremarkable things that Holmes would likely have been able to solve blindfolded and with one hand tied behind his back, it was still a wonderful opportunity for Dr. Watson to take center-stage, and to hear (for the first time, I think) Mrs. Hudson speak on her famous lodger (and perhaps her desire for him as well?). A great many more of these stories, however, do not deal with Sherlock himself - in fact the connection is rather tenuous, like in "The Adventure of the Purloined Paget" by Phillip Margolin and Jerry Margolin, which involves a group of very wealthy Sherlockian collectors and a newly-discovered story, supposedly written by Doyle for Queen Victoria, and illustrated by Paget, hence the title of the story. Others are rewrites of Doyle originals, such as "The Eyak Interpreter" Dana Stebenow, a rewrite of Doyle's "The Adventure of the Greek Interpreter," but updated for an audience more familiar with the blog format. It even includes comments on blog entries, some of which have been deleted by their authors. "The Case that Holmes Lost" is a meta look into a Holmes story that will never see the light of day, with the focus on Sir Arthur Conan Doyle himself. And then there are the stories that are inspired by Holmes, instead of being about him or being a rewrite of his original advenures. "The Last of Sheila Locke-Holmes" by Laura Lippman and "A Spot of Detection" by Jacqueline Winspear are precisely that, with Lippman writing a coming-of-age story for a young girl who wants to be just like Holmes (and a great many other detectives, besides), while Winspear writes about a young boy who turns out to be a young Raymond Chandler, and how Holmes turned him into the writer he would eventually become. Some stories, though, are just totally out there. I was expecting this with Neil Gaiman, and his story "The Case of Death and Honey" is precisely that: it takes off from an interesting plot point in "The Aventure of the Creeping Man," with Holmes advising Watson to change some information in the actual facts of the case, thus allowing Holmes to freely pursue the real "rejuvenation extract" mentioned in the story - not an extract from langurs, as the story claims, but the elixir of life itself. Another story in this vein is "As To 'An Exact Knowledge of London'" by Tony Broadbent, which plays on the idea that Holmes and Watson are reborn, over and over again, even as their greatest nemeses, Professor Moriarty and Sebastian Moran. This one is interesting if only because it contains an up-to-date list of contemporary Holmes media culture, plus an image of Watson and Holmes working on computers and surrounded by all the technological trappings of the 21st century. Such a diverse selection of writers, all writing stories in their own style and each with a different take on Holmes and the culture Holmes has created, is great for gaining insight into the ways that Doyle's creation has embedded himself into the collective consciousness of all those who have encountered him. However, I find that not all of these stories are quite so fun. Some, like Broadbent's story, really aren't about mystery at all, and are only interesting for their connection (and manipulation) of Doyle's characters. Neither did I enjoy Lippman's tale all that much, since I was rather hoping for a child-sleuth story with coming-of-age undertones, not a coming-of-age story with child-sleuth undertones. I suppose my dislike of some stories is due to the fact that I was looking for a particular type, or types, of stories, and the ones I didn't quite enjoy simply did not fall into those types. Perhaps if I were to read the stories I did not enjoy some other time, when I'm in the mood for them, I might enjoy them then. But, regardless of how I might feel about the individual stories at a later date, A Study in Sherlock comes off as rather inconsistent to me - and probably always will. I would have appreciated a certain kind of cohesion to the types of stories that were included, and not just a grab-bag of Holmes-related, Holmes-inspired material. I did not particularly enjoy the uneven nature of the collection, jumping from one type of story to the other. Overall, A Study in Sherlock is an interesting collection: a testament to the power Sherlock Holmes wields in the collective imagination. But the grab-bag nature of the collection, and general uneven feel as one moves from one story to the next, might prove to be a bit irritating to the reader who sits down to read the collection in its entirety, and not just one or two stories because it is by an author the reader recognizes. Individually, the stories are quite good, but together, they do not make for a very cohesive collection.
Very well-written and definitely a page-turner but the main theme* is not really my thing. (*)psychopaths trying to outsmart and get back at each other

(Audiobook) 3.5 stars The most beautiful thing we can experience is the mysterious  - Crouch via Einstein This is a hard book to rate. Whatever Rating I give, I am not sure if I am being too hard or too soft on it. On one hand this is a really exciting book. You will not be bored. It is easy to get into and you will definitely want to find out how it ends. The audiobook is top notch thanks to Jon Lindstrom (General Hospital!) On the other hand this book is derivative, not just of other Science Fiction but of Crouch's previous hit song "Wayward Pines", it has gaping plot holes and made me irrationally angry with some if it's choices. I guess I enjoyed it as something of a guilty pleasure. So the plot immediately calls to mind various Star Trek episodes, "Sliders" and a very big nod to "Sliding Doors". If it reminded you of something else, tell me what I have missed. The central premise is diabolically brilliant to the point I can't believe no one has come up with it before. I really want to know whether the main twist has been done before. The main character has his life and wife stolen by another version of himself from an alternate reality   Have you read this anywhere before? If this is new it is a pretty fantastic riff on the *many* alternate realities stories. If it isn't, then the whole thing is a bit like a band of teenagers who never bothered to listen to any old records and think the 3 chord rock they are playing is original and inspired. I reserve the right to change my opinion here! So this book starts strong, there is really no effing around in it.
