I did immediately notice that like in "Wayward Pines" we have our hero waking up in a hospital where everything is weird and trying to rationalise the weirdness by wondering (again and again) if they are on drugs or are victim of an elaborate prank and generally taking way too long to realise they are involved in some really weird shit. New wrinkle this time "Maybe it's a brain tumour" It's not a tumour!! I was definitely in on the mystery....then the book commits one of my Cardinal pet peeves - it puts me in a "hard science fiction" state of mind with its dabbling in physics and extended explanation of "Schroedinger's Cat" - before throwing the hard science out the window in favour of going batshit crazy. I am more then happy with "magic" or "alien artefact" to explain just about anything. If you are going to try and ground the story in reality or in the realm of scientific explanation, I need it *kept* in reality. This is admittedly a very hard thing to do - which is why I appreciate/have a love-hate relationship,with authors like Kim Stanley Robison, Stephen Baxter and Neal Stephenson. Once an author tickles the "this is Science" part of my brain I am on high alert for anything ridiculous. I found one of the plot devices used so, so stupid it took me about 90 minutes to recover and get back into the story. Once I did, I started to really enjoy it again. I can't pretend that I didn't care what happened, I was IN, I just had to kind of tune out the flaws. I think this book is best enjoyed as a love story with some SF elements. If you don't expect too much you won't be disappointed. The book has been made into a movie. I cannot imagine how they will take some of the hokier elements that work as a book and make them work on screen. Everyone is going to be crazy hot though for Daniella, who's major character attribute is that she likes to drink wine what I wouldn't do for a wine drinking woman! As I mentioned Jon Lindstrom is excellent. The story is told in first person and I totally believed he  was  Jason. Many narrators overdo the "action" portions of the story  Look how exciting this is to me!!! Lindstrom was note perfect, with a lesser narrator I may have had a *harder* time buying everything. So this was a fun ride/guilty pleasure/mixed bag of trick or treats. Ityped this on an iPad while I have had as much wine as Daniella on a night out and will edit it again at some point. LETS GO SPOILERS. (/SOBER EDIT MODE ENGAGED) While it is beyond the scope of this review to go into all the plot holes and contrivances, the main problems I had were: Just shooting Daniella in the head then expecting Jason to cooperate blew me away with its dumbness. "The Jason I know would see the big picture" umm go eat a bag of unsalted monkey dicks - you just killed the only person I care about. I normally can never think of alternatives but in maybe 5-10 pages we could have had Daniella abducted and used as leverage. OR we could not know what happened to her and build a relationship between Amanda and Jason in captivity that leads to her revealing that Daniella and lover boy were killed by the evil people and she can't live with it and wants to help. As it stood Amanda throwing her life away on the spot didn't make a lot of sense. I know we are supposed to hate evil Corp and Crouch wants to keep things moving but this was so ridiculous I kinda zoned out for a good 90 minutes. So we get this speech about the superposition of the molecules and "science-science good-good" but THEN it turns out you have to "wish upon a star" to enter the reality of your choice. WTF has this got to do with anything scientific? You think happy thoughts like Peter Pan and enter your never never land of choice? Be careful about any underlying emotions? It just killed the "grounded in reality" concepts we spent our time establishing. Once I got back on board I didn't mind the ending. I don't want to get into the "many Jason's" issues and quibbles and I can't imagine how dumb this will be in the movie. Can we get M Night Shamalyn again? I would have thought though that the drama and intensity of planning your own murder the way Jason2 did to abduct Jason would have been a big enough climax to end the book in a satisfying way. I was good with what we got though. Obviously Crouch had to give us ANOTHER twist in the form of the many Jason's but I would have just gone with Jason vs Jason 2. Anyway it was good, I got my money's worth I can't complain.

I've been in a real reading mood lately. Today I absolutely earned it. With back to back labs all day, I wanted nothing more than to sit and devour a book when I got home. I thought this one would be the perfect one because that premise is absolutely killer. I was expecting the sort of dumb dares that teenagers do for vlogs taken to the next level, with high tech and every increasing bribes and escalating danger. But, uh, what I got was more cut out characters, meh dares and a game that somehow had weird total knowledge of the characters despite also apparently having multiple games and hundreds of players going on at once. That's a little savage, and I might be a little too harsh in this review, because I had high expectations... but missed potential hurts the most. To say Vee drove me up the wall is an understatement. At first she showed a lot of promise. I really liked the idea of a softer, quieter theatre geek with a passion for fashion and make up and exploring that whole how much she does behind the scenes. I really really liked the idea that this character would then be thrust into the spotlight. That whole conflict could have been really well played out, with her trying to balance her desire to be noticed with her real personality and, you know, maybe not liking what she had to be on camera. Instead, she turned into a whiny, spineless character who had one of the least compelling reasons for continuing in the competition. Like okay full ride to fashion school, but she gave no indication before it was offered that she actually wanted that? It is a good prize, but there was no real heart wrenching 'I have to take it' sort of stakes. I mean, if she lost, all that would happen was that her parents would have to help her with uni, and it might be a little tough. But still do-able. Because of this, when things started getting harder and 'out of character' her motivation to continue really didn't strike a chord... She seemed to continue because of Ian, but not because she wanted to save him from his dad, but because she wanted a hot boy's attention. And then, later when she rebelled against everything and tried to quit the game it just came off as selfish. Easy for her to decide when she wasn't facing the desperation the other characters were... Ian was another wasted potential. He could have been a really sweet love interest, with a nice conflict between the scared boy underneath and the pretty face on camera especially given that his motivations were very real and very compelling. Wanting to get away from an abusive father meant that it was realistic that he'd put himself through anything and everything, and made him so much more likeable. How could you really like Vee when he's fighting for a ticket on a bus to go away and camping gear to set up somewhere safe, and she wants new expensive designer shoes.....  Instead, he fell kinda flat. Without the proper time to develop, and insta love making it hard to really get to know him/want to like him, he didn't have a lot to him. Their whole relationship happened in the course of like maybe three hours, and I think that's what bugged me the most. I get that this had to happen fast because snowballing and building consequences work best on a deadline... but I think it would have been interesting to see the characters getting little tastes of what they wanted. It would have made them continuing even more believable because once you see you really can get what you want... well it seems a lot more appealing than these vague promises. That little dare here and there could have given time for Ian and Vee to actually get close (and build their motivations....) and then their relationship would have been something real. Instead we get insta love and really forced cute moments between strangers . I really liked the first dares. They made sense as sort of tasters, and would be tame enough to really draw people in. And actually, I think I disagree with a lot of other low rating reviewers when I say I actually liked the personal ones. I get that they're not as epic viewing, but that sort of pushing people in their own lives, with things like attacking people that have had a crush, or hurting old exes  it would actually draw viewers in to see if they would or not. But I do agree that these dares would only work so much, and that actual visual, physical dares would be a more realistic finale. The ending was...  a mess. I'm so confused. I read the scene over a couple times and I still don't get what the point was with the guns. I don't know how it would have worked for Nerve to get them to kill each other, and the stand off dragged on to the point where it lost tension. I don't know how she could just walk out like that, and there was no real look at the consequences at what the others lost. I'm not saying she should have continued, but she condemned Ian to living with an abusive father and it was never touched on even though they're supposedly so in love... Also, one final complaint.... what on earth did the prologue have to do with it? I spent the last third of the book looking for that girl, or some mention of what happened. I honestly thought the book would go back to that moment... For all my complaints, I enjoyed the concept of this book. I liked the world it was set in, and the mystery behind Nerve. I was just let down by my high expectations, and the thoughts of what I wished they would do.

I loved the concept. And the beginning was more than encouraging. The first scenes conveyed all the confusion, fear, and stress of a person who wakes up with no recollection of where they are, who they are, or even how old they are supposed to be. And then the book follows the standard bathtub curve. It slags, it picks up for an "intense" climax  and the same-old happy end. Which was not even unexpected  . But it was entertaining. And not bad at all. Most of the mediocre reviews I read on goodreads complained about the credibility of the medical condition. I admit that I didn't care about the credibility. I realize that the medical condition is broken on multiple fronts and it's plain wrong, but generally I leave a lot of creative freedom to the author. As long as they set their universe and rules clearly and follow them consistently (oops! is it too obvious I read way too much fantasy? ), I follow along. That is unless they decide to mess with computers and technology facts, in which case I get upset kind of easily. What can I say? Professional vices...  What I did care about (and I didn't like at all) was the way that the medical condition devolved and disappeared to give us the happy ending. And the sloppy at best explanation for its "cure"  .

This thriller, as advertised, was definitely a page-turner. The pace was quick and it stayed so throughout the narrative. The premise of a high-tech house that affects its occupants is interesting and unique. The structure was also unique: the story is told from the points of view of 2 women who lived in the house, one lived there "then" and the other lives there in the "now" of the book. Both narrators speak in the 1st person, present tense. This works for the "now" narrator, but it's a little jarring when the "then" narrator speaks in the present tense when we know early in the story that she's dead. She even narrates her own death. How is she able to tell her story when she's dead? She's not writing or recording it. And to whom is she speaking? I really struggled with this structure. Another aspect of the story I had trouble with was the characterizations. I think the author was trying to show that people aren't always what they seem. But in doing so, he had the 4 main characters behave in ways that seemed "out of character." I didn't find their behaviors to be consistently plausible. The ending contains some interesting twists, including one I really liked that gives a new interpretation of the book's title. But the ending seemed rather muddled to me. Some of the twists were marred by the "out of character" problem, which made the resolution less than satisfying to me.
not gonna review this thoroughly because: Too good. Prolly the best read of mine this 2014 (so far). Just too good. Speechless. to sum it all:

This is just one of those books that's fun to read. Yes, the Scooby-Doo nostalgia will get your attention, but the characters and their chemistry are what will pull you in. The mystery does get a little confusing, which is why I didn't rate it 5 stars. I'm also not sure how I feel about the  potential romantic relationship between Andy and Kerri . I like that everyone reacts realistically to it, but the way it's handled just comes across as odd. It's also written sort of like a screenplay in that there are "stage directions". What I mean is that it feels like it was written for a visual medium. All of these additions are great, don't get me wrong, but some people may not like it. Overall, a great read. One I'll definitely go back to in the future.

I'm holding off on giving this five stars, even though it felt, to me as a lifelong Stephen King fan, a five star read. Meanwhile back in reality, it's probably more of a three and a half star actual novel. It's the sequel to The Shining, and it's about grown up Dan Torrance who's back in New England, and meets a little girl who has similar powers (and even moreso) and she is being targeted by a bunch of crazy supernatural beings who travel around in RVs. The crazy supernatural people in the RVs, the True Knot, are awesome, and a prime example of what SK is best at, asking you "hey, wouldn't it be cool if there were a bunch of supernatural people traveling around in RVs?" and then goes on to sketch out a great scenario for them. Probably the best thing about this book for me was that I completely believed that grown up Dan Torrance was really and truly little Danny from The Shining. The parts I enjoyed the most are very plot dependent, so I'm putting them in spoilers. Ok, jumping to the end, EVERYONE IMPORTANT CAME OUT ALIVE, which feels like an amazing gift from Stephen King. I don't know, maybe in a first novel from an unknown writer I would be more critical of this ... but we are talking AN ENTIRE READING LIFE of being brutally traumatized by SK characters dying in ways that broke my heart. I was even trying to suss it out ... okay, it's possible Dan won't make it out alive (he does! ), and then I was figuring Billy would be the one to go, because he's a nice old guy, and his whole character seems to be set up as the sacrificial lamb, BUT HE MAKES IT! Maybe this isn't realistic, but I remember having to stop reading IT for like three hours while I sobbed like a crazy person over (okay, I said spoilers but I guess I shouldn't spoil IT so I'll redact the character's name ...) and trust me, having the crew survive this novel is something that I feel was owed to me personally. And I'm the kind of Stephen King fan who gets choked up over Dark Tower references, and there were just a few. And I loved being initially suspicious of the Tiny Town train, because I'm well-versed in Choo Choo Charlie ... and now we have a good train! Sweet! Oh, and although I already mentioned it, I LOVED the True Knot. They're horrible, you want Dan and team to win ... but there were moments that knocked me out. This book successfully puts this group of ... demonized humans out in front of you in a way that makes you kind of get it.

2.5 stars This was just a long sex scene. The only reason I will say I didn't hate it is because it was hot, mostly because of Dom, but even he disappointed me with time  I didn't expect a threesome  . I cringe just by remembering Seth, ugh... I hate people like him, with ZERO personality and a cheating, annoying douchebag. Another concern I had was: Where's the taboo? They are brothers for God's sake, explore that. But I won't continue reading to see if it gets better, I'm sorry, I just can't stand Seth.

Holy Crap, Dark Matter was amazing. Not without flaws, but by the nature of its premise I think it required flaws to work. Even so, it was nearly impossible to put down. First to the main character. We meet Jason Dessen. From tight first person perspective. He feels real. He has that rare organic feeling as written that he's a real person. I became very invested in this character, making this a compelling sci-fi thriller. I was on the edge of my seat...would he survive or not and at what cost? The voice, the voice of the character felt quite authentic. Admittedly, he fluctuates sometimes between being more human (at times less likable) and a bit idealized but despite that, it was a real human voice talking in my head. And that is what made the thriller so thrilling. The plot was hot. Never slowed down. Unexpected turns and twists, without a doubt, and with one major exception they all felt natural. The minor flaw: Jason idealized his family when it actually sounded like his marriage was extremely mundane and had lost its luster. And he never really confronts that reality even though his wife does, and the author brings it up. It's a dead end issue that the character does not confront emotionally, and I think the book would have been improved if at some point he had acknowledged and considered this issue. The major flaw (a spoiler): Jason does NOT seem like a murderer, yet he and all his quantum doubles rather quickly turn to murdering each other to eliminate the competition for his wife, some even putting his wife and son in the crossfire. There are many aspects to consider around this revelation. First, I think the author needed to do it to really pump up the drama of the last quarter of the book. Second, why would he believe his wife would accept someone who was actively looking to kill another man even if that man is "him?" Or even worse because it's him? Crouch has her look the other way, as if they aren't all equally insane going to buy weapons to kill each other. She could have chosen, NONE OF THE ABOVE because they were all crazy. They all seemed completely insane to be going on such a killing spree. No matter how wronged you are, killing a living human is a huge leap to make and the fact that Dessen went open season on "himself" to gain exclusive rights over his wife was creepily patriarchal in a disturbing way. It wasn't that I thought it unbelievable that a man might be driven in rage to kill. But the fact that all the Dessen's were, even the central Dessen figure...turned into madmen is not fully confronted. There was a moment where he told his wife that he had gone to the sporting goods store to buy a handgun and that was where he learned all the other quantum doubles were running around also trying to buy guns...and she never comments on it, Crouch just glides over this issue. Third, the logistics of murdering a bunch of people, even if they are all the same person...it's gonna leave bodies all over Chicago that are going to destroy his life with his family anyway. It's all a messy paradox, of course, but...frankly I had expected the central Dessen to confront the old Dessen directly in front of his wife and attempt to get her back through essentially dramatically stating his case and explaining what happened. I found the twist to attempt to kill each other...while not unbelievable, it to me turned him into a madman who didn't really deserve his wife back. And that is a flaw that bothered me. The science of this thriller is fascinating. I love cutting edge physics, such as that found in Our Mathematical Universe, which I reviewed here. One fantastical leap aside (and a farfetched one too), the core premise of this novel is on-the-money theoretical (hypothetical more accurately) quantum physics. Not only is it incredible smart in the way it's brought to life, but it's integral to the story itself without being mechanical as it was in Seveneves. Crouch confronts the core conundrum of Quantum Mechanics head on in a way that is comprehensible to the layperson. Dark Matter is quite an achievement and highly recommended.

This was so close to a good book. I expected more of a thriller since it opens with a girl's death, but it's not. It's a quiet look at one girl's summer after high school, when a girl gets murdered. It looks at how people in small towns deal with death and murder and insiders vs. outsiders. Parts were confusing, and I always felt like I had missed something. Now, sure, part of that might have been because I was reading it between episodes of an anime during the opening and closing songs, but even when I was focused solely on the book for a long time, I still felt like there were details that were missing. Like why she hated her boyfriend's friend so much or  why she was so sure he had something to do with the death of the girl. Really, the most interesting parts were Amelia's chapters. It was horrible reading those, seeing how full of life she was and knowing that she was about to die. I wanted more from her, why she was with her boyfriend, what happened in her classes, how exactly she decided to pursue acting and what the reactions were from everyone else in her life. I didn't like the ending. I had guessed part of it, but it also seemed like way too much of a stretch.

<> I would have given this two more stars, had it not been a bit of a let down at the end. The atmosphere was built up quite nicely, albeit punctuated by a romance plot between the two primary characters - which I feel, was a bit of a distraction to the overall horror. The romance, somehow, did not gel with the theme - it was a little forced and contrived, brought in, as it were, as a literary lacunae where the reader can breathe a little from the horror of Heptonclough. To put it simply, it damn well diluted the horror. This is not to say that Ms. Bolton does not provide some creepy moments with her descriptions - some are good enough to linger in your mind. But the overall denouement was a big letdown - well, extremely cliched, to put it accurately. The complete lack of supernatural elements at the end was reminiscent of something out of Anne Radcliffe or Jane Austen, where every horror is a red herring; although the setting had amply built up to a pastoral horror that could have been made all the more unnerving. The theme, overall, reminded me of the folk horror tropes of British horror, like Witch Finder General or The Children of the Corn with its agoraphobic horror of open spaces and the piquant thrill of what might lurk in open view. The final revelation was nothing new - the skeletons are thrown out from everyone's closet in a hackneyed and tiresome way - something that was done with aplomb in Dolores Claiborne or Chinatown (if you catch my drift). But here they fizzle out like a bad drama series on a Saturday night. It will be some time before I decide to read another Bolton novel - if at all. My final verdict - yes, read it. But don't expect Poe or King or Bloch.

Hum... this is a tricky one. On the one hand, I love-love-love that we get to see more of Detective-Robin, instead of just Secretary-Robin. Yes, I know, she's cool either way - this series should really be about Robin, with Strike as a sidekick - but I like seeing the growth she's had since the first book, seeing her develop her detective abilities and her kick-ass (!) persona. On the other hand... I really disliked the emphasis on Robin's relationship problems and the will-they-won't-they story with Strike. I don't like the idea of the two of them together, I much prefer them to just be partners, in a work kind of way. Also, the rape backstory? This series did not need a rape backstory for Robin, not at all! Still, the murder-mystery was engaging, as always, and this time I almost didn't catch the murderer before the big reveal. Nice one, RG, nice one!

Spoiler review. I loved this more than the movie because I didn't have to deal with the obnoxious way the old woman neighbor (Minnie Castevet) talked in the film! It's basically exactly the same as the movie, which I saw first, but I didn't even feel spoiled because the writing is wonderful. Guy is a horrible husband, and I seriously wanted to smack him across the face every time he talked to Rosemary. I thought he was worse than the Castevets, because when you're supposed to love and protect your wife but instead give her up to be impregnated by the devil...well, you win worst husband award.

I had heard that this hearkened back to old school Stephen King horror but readers beware: the creepiness doesn't really set in until the last 50 pages. It is an interesting story that spans most of the life of one man. It delves into some deeper themes and was interesting enough to keep me reading but I just kept waiting for the creepiness which was so long in coming that much of the book felt like a slog. Standard case of expectations getting in the way of reading. The ending was pretty horrifying, maybe even too much. As a person who has lost two of the most important and beloved people in my life, the idea that they are in another place but that that place is constant pain and never-ending drudgery enslaved to intelligent ants was borderline traumatic. Would recommend for dedicated Stephen King fans but would not be the first book I recommend to a horror fan who wants to try King.

3.5 Stars Ally Carter is a beautiful weirdo. "Who are you? Am I going to regret not breaking your hand? Because it's not too late. I can still totally break your hand." Embassy Row. What a great idea. The girl shrugs. "I'm Rosie. Germany. Twelve." The way she says it, I know these are the facts that matter here, the embassy-kid equivalent of name, rank, and serial number. "Grace. United States. Sixteen," I tell her. She nods as if we've bonded. A perfectly possible dystopian in the real world. I love it. "We do not go past the fence. I mean, we could. But we don't. Because none of us are superexcited about starting World War Three. So we do not go past the fence." He stares at me, as if waiting for a protest that never comes. "Say it with me, Grace. We do not go past the fence." "Noah." "Say it." "We do not go past the fence," I tell him. "Because we do not want to start World War Three." "We do not want to start World War Three," I add. "Good girl." Embassies all lined up in a row so that the German soil can be next to Canadian soil and the world is suddenly so much smaller. We were not friends. We were simply what becomes of kids who are thrust together so often that, eventually, they run out of reasons not to go play. Ally Carter is good at describing the cliche community in the most eloquent of ways. "New blood, Grace," Noah explains, his voice soft beneath the ever-stronger pulse of the music. "The sharks can smell it. Now come on. It's time for the real tour." She still does fall into plenty of other eye-rolling cliches though. A ball? Really? Do we have to do this? Grace Grace is both adroitly capable and accident prone - an interesting combination. She's scrappy and feisty. I'd rather live in a war zone with my father than with people who call me sweetie. She likes to take risks without thinking about the consequences. She's definitely a tomboy troublemaker. "That's okay," I tell her. "I don't have a home there either." For a second, she looks at me like I'm the saddest little orphan in the world, so I point at myself and say, "Army brat," as if living on ten bases in fifteen years has left me impervious to change. Ally Carter has a way with words. His English is as good as mine, but he likes to play this game. They all do. I don't play any game that I can't win. As the book goes on I became less and less impressed with Gracie. I'm a little on the fence with the mystery. It's nothing brilliant and a little disappointing because I know how clever Ally Carter is. The execution could have also been miles better. It possessed the characterisation but not the punch. Romance He nods out the window toward the Russian embassy. Because that's the thing about Embassy Row. The boy next door is probably Russian. The romance is barely there but it's lovely. I really liked it. It's been a while since I've read a will-they-won't-they and I really enjoyed how sweet and yet deep it is. "Whatever you say, Gracie." "Don't call me Gracie." "Okay." Alexei slowly nods. "It's okay. At least, I hope it's okay."

After being exposed to Sherlock Holmes through many of the adaptations, I finally read about the original. Sherlock Holmes is indeed insufferable, but I found Doyle's conception of the character far less unpleasant than, say, Cumberbatch's incarnation in the BBC series. While Sherlock is an obnoxious know-it-all, he also possesses powers of emotional observation that prevent him from being, in short, a prick (or at least an oblivious one). Doyle's prose is enjoyable and pushes the story forward without digressing into much flowery language, although Watson's reaction to Enoch Drebber's corpse borders of the absurdly melodramatic. Holmes' powers of observation and deduction (both are crucial, of course!) are on full display from his start; this is hardly an origin story in the standard sense. Listening to his summaries after his examinations is always a fast-paced journey through perfectly logical -- if sometimes necessarily speculative -- reasoning, but the inherent limitation of Doyle's mysteries is also apparent here: the reader does not have access to all of the clues. Thus, whether the book counts as a true mystery (in the Agatha Christie sense) is debatable, because the focus is not so much on the solution to the caper as on Holmes' ability to observe that which no one else -- including the reader -- is able to see. Perhaps the oddest feature of the book is the abrupt transition from Britain to America (and the Mormons), which occurred with no warning whatsoever, with the result that my friend and I thought that there was a problem with the audiobook. Over time, I actually grew to like this section, even if it could hardly be called historically or culturally accurate. Still, it was actually a pleasant episode that did eventually tie into the main story. The other issue I had with the novel was the extended narration by the culprit once caught . I hardly ever mind a good embedded narrative, but if the author sees no better way to relay crucial information without devoting ~10% of the novel to a character just describing his history, something related to the narrative probably went wrong somewhere along the way. In other words, the structure of the solution was a series of speculations by Holmes without interviewing anyone followed by a very, very long speech about what happened by a single individual. Later mystery authors justifiably took a different approach, weaving in that background information throughout the various interviews conducted throughout their novels. The story does not drag on, and was quite enjoyable throughout. The novel was even more enjoyable because I listened to it while driving through Yosemite National Park, which was not so far from some of the action in the book. I would rather give 3.5 stars, but I had to pick.

I have such mixed feelings about this book. Hidden Bodies is the sequel to You, which was an enthralling tale of a sociopath stalking a girl, while trying to get her to fall in love with him. If you haven't read You, go pick it up right this second. It's truly a great book, and you wouldn't enjoy this one as much without having read its predecessor first. I was very excited when I heard Hidden Bodies was coming out, but a little nervous, as well. You didn't really need a sequel. I wasn't sure how well a second book would compare to the first. Hidden Bodies did hold up well. I enjoyed it. The book made up for a few of the nitpicky issues I had with the first one. But at the same time, it kind of lost the magic and creepiness factor of You. So, this is a hard review to write. It was good, but not great. I liked the plot of Hidden Bodies. Essentially, after the mess with Beck, Joe falls for Amy (who makes a brief appearance at the end of You). Only, Amy doesn't love Joe. In fact, she's scamming him. She steals his rare books and goes off to California, in hopes of an acting career. Joe can't just let this slide, so he follows her with the intent of tracking Amy down and killing her. Along the way, he struggles with paranoia over getting caught (remember that mug he left at the murder scene in book one?) and meets a new love interest. I loved Joe's commentary on Los Angeles. It was hilarious, but still rang true about some aspiring talents. One of the things I didn't like about You was, despite the fact that it was edgy and written in an amazing tone, it did follow a predictable plot line-- bad guy likes a girl, stalks her, gets her to like him, she finds out he's crazy, etc. The surprises were all about the inner character of Joe, but there weren't any big plot twists. Hidden Bodies is very different. I had no idea what was going to happen next. The plot did kind of meander around in places, but I liked that. I didn't predict any of the twists. The writing itself was great. Kepnes does a fantastic job of getting into the mind of a sociopath. Joe's character is so complex-- he has no problems murdering people who he deems deserving, but still has a moral compass. He is pretentious and cruel, but still relatable and funny. The author makes it easy for readers to root for a serial killer. It's crazy. At the same time though, there were flaws. Joe is all about repetition. He repeats his thoughts quite often-- to convince the reader or maybe himself that he is right. Or sometimes to cover up something. But it did get a little tiresome this time around. I understand why it was there, but I wish it was toned down by maybe 25%. I also missed the second person narration. Kepnes pulled it off flawlessly in You. I see why she dropped it, because the character it was directed at wasn't around in Hidden Bodies. But the first book was so creepy partly because of the second person narration. I thought she could have written this one directed at Love (the new love interest) brilliantly. I think one of my biggest complaints about this book was just that it wasn't as creepy. It was still dark, but it was missing that spine tingling sensation that the first one gave me. There was murder, but the murders were committed more out of necessity (or what Joe thought was necessity, at least) than out of hatred. Joe feels emotions so intensely. In You, he was murdering people because he wanted to. This time around, it was because he felt that he needed to, to avoid being caught. Reading it was kinda like, "Oh... here's another person that needs to be killed. Okay, let's get that out of the way, so we can get on with the plot." It wasn't bad. It was just different (and less scary). I also wasn't a big fan of the side characters in this novel. In You, I didn't like Beck, but I liked Ethan and I was intrigued by Mr. Moody. All of the minor characters in this book were either unappealing or boring. Everyone Joe interacted with, from the guy he worked for to Love's brother to Milo, were all douchebag wannabe celebrities. Love was alright, but I never got enough of a grasp on her character to feel connected to her. She was better than Beck and Amy, but she still came off as a spoiled rich girl. Finally, the ending of this novel irritated me a bit. There were a few things that weren't very believable. I didn't think Love would have stayed with Joe after he confessed everything to her. And they were both a little too happy and excited about the baby . There was also a bit of a redemption arc in the last third of the book, with Joe, that I wasn't fond of. Kepnes made a point of showing some cracks in his idea of becoming a better person (such as him warning a character that the last person who was mean to him wound up dead), but I still thought it was an odd 180 degree turn from Joe. The ending wasn't bad... just a little weird. It's very open for a third novel, so I hope the author takes that opportunity to write a good conclusion to Joe's story. Personally, I wanna see him fall back into his dark, murderous mindset. It would be cool to see him face a true antagonist, such as a really intelligent bad guy, who could give Joe a run for his money. Right now, most of Joe's struggles stem from his love life or people who could turn him in. Despite my complaints, I still did like this book. I enjoyed reading the entire thing. These books are a little longer than they need to be, but I love every second of them. Joe's mind is so fascinating to me. I think that most of my issues with the book were things that Kepnes intentionally added in, rather than a careless mistake on her part. My tastes just contrasted with hers. That being said, many readers might have completely different opinions than me and love this novel. It just depends on your own tastes. I definitely would recommend it to anyone that enjoyed You. It's an interesting sequel. It just disappointed me a bit in some areas, so I couldn't bring myself to rate it higher. Kepnes's books always have great quotes, so I'm going to put some of my favorites below. 3.5/5 stars. "I gave her as much as I had, but it's like the difference between a movie and a book: A book lets you choose how much of the blood you want to see. A book gives you the permission to see the story you want, as your mind directs. You interpret. Your Alexander Portnoy doesn't look like mine because we all have our own unique view. When you finish a movie you leave the theater with your friend and talk about the movie right away. When you finish a book you think." "My heart beats faster and faster, and I wish I could carry it around in a rolling suitcase. It's annoying, the way it's connected to my other bodily functions, the way my little motherfucker pores allow sweat to weep upon my forehead, the way my asshole pupils shrink and expand and I can't control them. I'm not a fucking sociopath." "The real horror of my life is not that I've killed some terrible people. The real horror is that the people I've loved didn't love me back."

This book is a rush. Fast paced and intense. I was kept reading quickly and guessing up to the end. I was right there along with Winter trying to figure everything out. This girl has gone through a lot and because of that finds it easier to participate and record extreme sports and other dangerous activities than get close to people. It was both painful and rewarding to watch her begin to open up and face her past in this book. Especially as that happens when she discovers her beloved sister Rose had been murdered. Rose has always been the rock in Winter's life, a constant presence through everything. Winter is devastated when she discovers that she's been killed, and determined to do everything she can to find out what happened. Gideon is Rose's ex boyfriend as well as Winter's boss and owner of the company that produces ViSEs. When I started this, I was worried he was going to turn into a love interest, and I was very happy that doesn't happen at all. Gideon is like an older brother to Winter, and very protective of her. We find out a lot more about Gideon through this book too. He definitely surprised me in places, but he is one of my favorite characters. Jesse is Winter's ViSE partner. They work together recording extreme activities like bungee jumping and shark diving. I like Jesse a lot. It's clear he cares about Winter, and I liked that when the book begins they already know each other. The romance isn't by any means the focus of the story, though it is an important element. Jesse and Winter spend a lot of time together, and I really enjoyed seeing them begin to open up more to each other. They are both a little damaged and make some mistakes with each other, but I really appreciated the rawness in their relationship. I didn't expect how heavy this book would be when I started it - in terms of what Winter goes through and the things she faces about her past and herself. There were some elements of this story that were hard for me, and I'm still not sure what I think about them. The revelations at the ending were also tough. It's going to be difficult to wait for the next one, but I am desperate to read it! Love Triangle Factor: none but DM me directly if you are hyper sensitive to them Cliffhanger scale: on the higher side of medium.

This is a first class read. Absolutely top grade. Since I judge a novel by: 1. Entertainment value, 2. Writing excellence, 3. Literary coherence, I'd vote for this book being the best of 2012, in my opinion. Having listened to it instead of reading it meant I couldn't skip ahead, so I ended up listening to it almost for two days without pause. Plus, as the chapters ping-ponged between Amy and Nick Dunne's first person narration, with two smooth-voiced, engaging and beautifully expressive voice actors (Julia Whelan and Kirby Heyborne ), my enjoyment was INTENSE. This is the first book I've ever read where almost everyone, including characters I liked, is unlikeable for varying reasons, yet the tension, suspense and caring about what happens next never let's up. One of the main reasons is everything you think you understand about Nick and Amy is quickly turned 90 degrees around in the next chapter, and then the next, and then the next, yet it is done so skillfully that loss of respect for the characters is tempered by their humanity, or because of their fantastic raw audacity and originality. Rhonda Boney, police detective, is one of two 'good' persons in the book, but she is simply a secondary character although I admired her the most for her decency. Nick Dunne's sister, Margo, is also nice, and a welcome relief for the reader as much as she is for Nick, providing succor and balance at moments that would be too full of misery and confusion, otherwise. Remarkably, every character is absolutely necessary for atmosphere, further information, or plot twist. I did not notice the slightest wrong note or lack of emotional believability in a single word - until after I was almost finished with the book. However, there is absolutely no way to review this book without spoilers. Not a single way! Nail-biting tension is maintained at the highest level! Do yourself a favor and don't start this book until you have the time to read it straight through! The plot twists SCORCH the brain with deep, concrete-breaking stops like tight brakes on a speeding car trying to make a sudden and definitely unexpected turn of the road. But like any car race, you must go on! I'm not a doctor or a detective, but it seems to me that if the police did an autopsy on Desi, who would certainly require one because of his murder, wouldn't they have found the presence of sleeping pills in his blood? That would have exposed Amy's lies. And it seems to me the frozen vomit would certainly have been degraded over time. After all, it was full of stomach acid, as well as being frozen. Its age, if not its condition and having been saved by Amy while continuing to live with Nick despite her having comparatively rich parents would have invited questions. Why would Amy keep such valuable evidence in the same house she shared with Nick in the freezer/refrigerator in the kitchen? And I never could understand why when she ordered several hundred thousands of dollars of stuff to harass Nick with debt that everyone also thought it was proof of Nick having murdered Amy. To me, it wasn't proof of that at all. Amy was the spoiled spendthrift, not Nick. Even if it looked like Nick had decided to buy all of that stuff, why on earth would he then hide it in that shed, and create a financial condition of bankruptcy and ruin? He would have lost his half-interest in the bar, the house, his sister's financial status would have been ruined, and she was the only person he loved. Besides, buying stuff like golf clubs is not the same as buying bomb-making supplies. How was this an indicator of planning Amy's murder, if he had bought it during the year before her disappearance while he was already financially shaky? The life insurance coverage revision did not ensure Nick's future, with his bar, his sister and his father, and of course, certainly not with that kind of credit card debt! Amy is a really fun psychopath Valley Girl character. Vengeance drove her to destroy anyone who she felt either embarrassed, annoyed or bested her to the exclusion of everything else in a very believable brain-damaged way - with the exception of her proposed suicide after she saw Nick's execution. That certainly indicated the depth of her rage, but did not fit her long-range planning, list-making, selfish intelligence. Amy seemed remarkably a small picture thinker to me, focused on how the world should obey and fulfil her, even if her brilliance was like a laser beam. In addition, Nick really surprised me at the end. Being that he was apparently forged into a new person that was allowing his formerly deadened, passive internal self to come alive by the danger of being with a psychopath didn't ring true - Nick appeared deadened because of depression and failure, not because of boredom and malaise. Since it seemed misery was the cause of his passivity, it didn't feel right that Amy proving herself to be a pregnant murderer would be the thing to attract him and make him feel empowered with the challenge. Despite the utter nihilistic, over-the-top solutions that the main protagonists decided on, I felt all of the other characters were spot on in that their personalities led them to their natural, normal conclusions and actions because of who they were. Since Gillian Flynn obviously can suss out expected personality reactions, I can only conclude that the wild way Amy and Nick responded to each other was intentionally world-destroying cataclysmic. This book requires some suspension of logic on several levels. It reverberates black humor, I think, but if so, the deadly seriousness on top is a cover for the author satirically mocking marriage, love, desire, and most of all, crazed American celebrity culture, with bulls-eye accuracy. 'Amazing Amy' could be any current reality star from the Jersey Shore to Dallas, Texas to Orange County, California. Wake-up call, or is Flynn having fun? Whatever. I certainly had fun with Nick and Amy!

I actually enjoyed this book quite a lot. The first 350 pages are great, with interesting character development and engaging moral dilemmas. Moriarty's writing just pulls you along, and I never wanted to put the book down. Then the ending. Why did they have to take Polly's arm? I'm not saying Cecilia made the right decision-- I'm not sure there even is a right decision-- but what she did definitely isn't horrible enough to warrant that kind of punishment for her daughter. Plus, I don't want to read about amputation on children. I don't care what it means in a literary sense. I read this book for fun, and that wasn't fun. And the epilogue? Way to rub salt in the wound. So Polly would have been a pro tennis player? Great. Except that maybe not because a thousand other things could have stopped that from happening, but throwing it in the epilogue like that encourages the reader to blame Cecilia for it. And the heart disease? That was a cool concept. Maybe she should have put it in the actual book. If you haven't already read Big Little Lies, go do that instead. It's so much better.

I picked up Truth or Dare hoping that it would read like a teen thriller movie. After a party with an intense game of truth or dare, three girls get menacing notes continuing the game long after its closure. Only after I got the book home and started reading it, did I realize that it was actually just a cheap rip off of Pretty Little Liars. I'll admit that I do like the PLL books, but I read them purely as a guilty pleasure-- I know they're bad, but I read them to get a trashy escape from my own life. Pretty Little Liars already fills up my need for bad YA books, though. I don't really wanna read a copycat of it. I was hoping that even if Truth or Dare borrowed the same premise, it would be a better written novel, with higher stakes, and a unique twist on that concept. Unfortunately, I was let down. The book dragged on for far too long, and by the end, I was skimming through sections just to finish it. The book wasn't necessarily terrible, it was just boring. And it brought absolutely nothing new to the table. The game of truth or dare hinted at in the summary is really minor and only lasts about 50 pages. Nothing exciting even comes of it. The dares afterwards, sent by an anonymous darer, are lackluster at best. They're pretty much the same sort of blackmail that you see in PLL. The dares do get more dangerous as the story progresses, but that's just it-- it drags on far too long. By the time things started getting more serious, I was already 200 pages in and ready for the book to be over. The secrets that the girls are protecting also seem to be too silly to warrant performing these life-risking tasks. I suppose high schoolers do live their lives by obsessing over minute drama, but I feel as if they should at least be smart enough to realize that the drama isn't important enough to risk hurting someone else over. The characters were alright, but nothing special. I could literally pair each one with their Pretty Little Liars counterpart. You have Tenley, the rich popular girl (Hanna in Shepard's books), Caitlin, the future Harvard student (Spencer), and Sydney, the artsy loner (Aria). They were all huge stereotypes. I feel as if Sydney was written to garner sympathy from readers, but I thought she was just annoying. She was supposed to be this outcast, who is above all of the high school drama. But her stereotype was too in your face for me to like her. Within the first chapter or so, she rants about how stupid pop music is and how petty high schoolers are. Why does every outcast in YA have to feel as if they are above whatever's popular in society? It's used far too often. Caitlin was fine, but boring. I ended up liking Tenley's sections the best, because even though she was a mean girl, she was the most interesting to read about. They all kinda blended together by the end, without enough personality differences to make each character distinct. Again, I really just felt as if I was reading a Pretty Little Liars wannabe. I was hoping that the writing would be more mature, but it was still pretty similar to Shepard's. There was too much repetition for my liking. It makes it seem like some YA authors think that teens are too stupid to pick up on little hints, so they have to repeat the same thing over and over. There was a little less brand dropping than in Shepard's books, but I still felt as if the characters were just as shallow. A few edgy ideas came up, such as Tenley flirting with her stepbrother and Sydney's pryromania. But it still all fell flat for me in the end. I did like how the author tried to portray anxiety disorders with Caitlin. Her descriptions of Cait's panic attacks were very realistic, but she kept repeating the same details over and over of her flashbacks. This often happens in real life, but it's not incredibly interesting to read about (especially when the flashbacks are hiding a mystery, it becomes frustrating). This novel isn't all bad, despite my many complaints. If you gave it to me when I was sixteen and obsessed with these types of storylines, maybe I would have liked it more. The love triangle thing between Tenley, Sydney, and Guinness was interesting. I didn't like Guinness's character (he was a jerk), but I wanted to see what happened with him, so he kept me reading more than most of the other plot elements did. The romantic bits were well-written and seemed genuine. And the big reveal, while predictable, had (somewhat) believable motives behind it. Finally, I did actually like that the author killed off one of the main characters. I personally wish it wasn't Caitlin, because I don't think she deserved it, but I commend Green for taking the risk to do it. Many YA authors won't kill off the MCs, even if it would make their books more realistic by doing so. I always wished Sara Shepard would in her books, because I felt as if it would make the stakes so much higher. But, for me, the good parts were not great enough to outweigh the negative aspects of the novel. This book wasn't for me, but others might like it. I do find it really frustrating that this had to be a trilogy. The first book ends with too many loose ends, which I'm assuming will be picked up in the sequel. But after 400 pages, I wish there was more closure. Maybe one day, after I finish reading the Pretty Little Liars books, if I get a craving for trashy YA, I'll pick up the second one. But I doubt it. The pacing was just too off. If the book had been about 150 pages shorter, it might have been a lot better. It was way too slow. I had to skim to make it through this, so I doubt I could make it through the sequel. 2/5 stars.

3 stars. "My brain tells me to run because you"re trouble, but my gut tells me something different." "What does your gut tell you?" "That you"re a lot of trouble." For all intents and purposes, this was a pretty good book. Cole McGuinnis was an ex-cop turned PI after losing his lover in a shooting, and got roped into investigating the suicide of a Korean businessman, which was how me met Kim Jae-Min. The mystery aspect was well done and engaging, with twists and muders and Cole getting himself into trouble. The cultural backdrop was really interesting. It's not often you find a book with this kind of diversity, and it seems like that auhor did a really good job in her portrayal of Asian-American families. Although the use of Korean terms that were usually left without explanation did make things a bit harder for me since I don't know the language. All characters were likeable, but I have to say Claudia was my favorite. She was a no nonsense kind of woman, and I loved that. Cole was a good lead character, with his own personal struggles and obstacles to overcome on top of the investigation he was doing. Jae, though, was kind of like a damsel in distress most of the time? Getting hurt and having Cole take care of him/want to protect him/etc. Cole and Jae's relationship also lacked development. One word: instalove. The amount of time they spent together didn't validate the strength of their feelings for each other, which made me unable to care much about their relationship. Overall it was a good book, but I was bored sometimes. And I didn't really connect to Cole and Jae, which wasn't good since the entire book is told from Cole's POV. Not sure if I'll continue the series, but we'll see. Series: #1 in the Cole McGinnis series. POV: Told from Cole's POV. Content Warnings: Suicide. Prostitution. Homophobic slurs. Mentions of past statutory rape. Instalove: Yes. Steam: Kind of badly written, but still steamy. Love Triangle: No. Cheating: Not between Cole and Jae. Cliffhanger: No. HEA: Almost. Up Next: Dirty Secret

I love Doug & Christhoper! They hot and sweet at the same time. Also Christopher - Ray relationship wasn't like what imagined before  yes, they're in love to each other, but never dare to cross the partnership line  . This story has so many dark part, and a character like Ray is one to lightening the story. I'm satisfied with the ending, but I guess this story needs a sequel. I meant, there's still a lot of things between Doug and Christopher to work on and also I want to read Ray's story. So yeah, I hope there's a sequel ^..^

3.5 stars Tucholke's writing is beautiful, lyrical, just the kind of narration I love, and it held it's own up until the end. While the writing pulled me in, I can't justify giving this five or four stars, even though the prose deserves it. The plot was somewhat lacking, which is fine, I love character driven novels, but reading reviews on this "psychological thriller," had me expecting a more exciting ending. The mystery was done well, as were the unreliable characters, but I wanted something more at the end. More of a twist. More of a reason. More worth. Something that left me just as breathless as the prose. Instead, I was left feeling disappointed; feeling that such beautiful writing should be backed by a deserving story, and it could have been if not for the much lacking end. Prose, no matter how well written, cannot hold up a story on it's own. The twist was what made this novel go from a 5 star to a 4 star rating, and the lack of believability/reasoning behind the prank dropped it even lower. I was so hoping for that psychological aspect; that maybe Wink and Poppy were one person, that Midnight was seeing Poppy's ghost, or that Wink and Poppy were really in love. But to find out that it was just a trick by Poppy and Wink, and to not have that justified is frustrating. Why did Wink need to do this? I never got the sense that it was something of great importance, even with the fact that she is supposed to die young--this was underdeveloped, and could have been stated earlier to grant more sympathy and to understand her character a little better. Instead, it was as if Tucholke saved every secret for the end. As in "Surprise! She's really dead. Oops, just kidding! It was all a trick! Oh, and Wink might die young, but you'll never know." I can't even say I was awed by the twist, because it lacked so much purpose.

This was not at all what I expected. After loving Dangerous Girls so much, I expected something similar with Dangerous Boys, but boy was I surprised! The story centers around a recent High School Graduate, Chloe, who starts dating Ethan as an escape from home where her mother is depressed. I have to say, Chloe truly did strike me as a good person from page one. She put her college plans on hold, despite wanting nothing more than to leave Haverford, just to care for her unwell Mother. There aren't many teenagers who would put someone else first like that. Even at the end of the story, after seeing a different side to her, I still believe Chloe was a good person who just made some bad decisions. Trouble arises when Ethan's brother Oliver comes to town. Oliver is charming, I'll admit it. Even I started to favor him over Ethan. But that all changes, fairly quickly, when we readers see that Oliver is completely and utterly crazy. Seriously, I went from being totally enchanted by him to actually scared of him- and I'm not often scared of book characters. Was that hunting chapter creepy or what?! This story was so well written. I felt every character was written exactly how they would be in real life- they all reacted to each event exactly how I would expect them to. The only reason I'm giving this four stars instead of five, is this: At the moment when Ethan and Chloe broke up, I felt like Ethan was acting like a completely different person that didn't fit wit the rest of the book. I thought perhaps he'd figured out that Oliver/Chloe were sneaking about behind his back, but realized he hadn't when he walked in on them  but that's my only criticism. I would welcome a sequel to this one. I'd like to see for sure if Chloe is who I think she is, and see how she and the remaining Reznick brother work things out- if they do at all.

Gillian Flynn is so skilled at writing unlikable characters, which is the real draw to anything she writes. The ghostly bits are deliciously creepy but I thought the book as a whole ultimately suffered from the brevity of the short story form. The potential explanations at the end came too fast to really pay off, although the final few sentences were still perfectly unsettling in the way one expects from Flynn. (Because I know many people who will care: the first part of the book deals with pretty frank depictions of sexual acts, although they're not really graphic. It was used more for humor, but if you want to avoid that, this probably isn't the book for you.)

This book was just so good!! Each character's story was so intriguing, and I was desperate to find out how things turned out for everybody! The female characters were strong, unique and believable. And I can't deny that having Bonnie be the one to push Perry to his accidental death, then have all the women decide to unite together and deny they saw what happened was just the perfect climax! Books with happy endings and great twists are always what I'm looking for. I highly recommend this and can't wait to read more from this author.

Ahh, so good! So far I've really loved the books I've read by J.L. Merrow. I was a little hesitant to buy this book because its overall stars are lower than I like when buying a book (I generally like to buy 4* books; I've found 3* books to be less reliable in relation to whether I'll like them or not) but I've read Merrow before and I like her stuff, so I trusted her here. It helped that I downloaded a free sample from Amazon and got hooked, although sometimes those free Amazon samples are not to be trusted. I really liked the feel of the book, the way that Paul wasn't sure where he was going or what was going on or what had happened, and often who he could trust or who he couldn't. It made the read very fun for me, and I flew through it like a bird through the sky. I liked the way he worried about whether or not he was reacting appropriately to his amnesia and reacquainting himself to the world around him. I loved discovering Viggo and how Viggo related to Paul, and that Viggo had been saving up to go visit Paul in Britain after Paul's injury. The downside to this book is that I sometimes felt that I shouldn't have liked it as much as I did (the inverse to what I sometimes feel with other books, when I feel like I should like them more than I do), so I would entirely understand if others didn't like this book as much as I did (and I adored it). There were clearly flaws to it. The mystery around what happened before Paul's injury could keep one from connecting to the characters enough to really enjoy the book, for example. The ending where Paul regains all his memories  can seem overly convenient. But honestly, I loved the book to pieces, and GoodReads goes based on how you felt about the book, not based on how good you felt the book objectively is, so I give it all the stars!
Went through it like a breeze. Simple easy read. Liked the story. Read a lot about the appalachian regions and the coal mining because of this. Nothing happens in the end.. :-/

This is the first time I've ever said this, but I actually liked the movie better than the book. It took so long to get to the point. The book did not get good until the halfway point. Amy is a freaking psycho. I can't believe the lengths she went through to get back at him for cheating. Then she gets pregnant and forces him to stay with her. I'm sorry, but I don't think I could do it. I'd have to figure out a way to get her arrested or something. My point of view on Nick is that he is just as crazy as Amy. I did not really like either one of them. Amy is really scary. She was willing to go through anything to get what she wants. She even poisons herself. How crazy is that. Nick is a cheater, and a coward. He is also addicted to Crazy Amy. I'm just happy to be done with this long, drawn out book.

I decided to get myself a library card, and this was the first book I chose to read. The cover drew me, and then when I saw it was set in Japan and written by a Japanese writer, I knew that I had to at least try. The summary made it clear that it wasn't going to be a simple book, but I was ready for the challenge. But I just never expected this book to break my hear, and change the way I see the world completely. This book is divided to very few chapters, and each of them is told from the point of view of one of the main characters: A group of four teenage girls and worm, a guy the same age as them. This is more of a philosophical book, that shows what we usually enjoy swiping under the rag. Voyeurism, self destruction, depression, sexual behavior. And everything is told through teenagers. And let's face it, adults love pretending that their children are innocent and that our world is simple, and our biggest problems are what we're going to wear to school, our grads, and whether or not a certain person likes us. But teenagers are probably the most complex people around, because we don't know much and we haven't seen much, but some of us had seen things that most people would never experience. On the surface, Toshi and Terauchi look like the more complex girls, but in a way, they all are. Yuzan is dealing with the death of her mother while trying to hide her sexuality. Kirarin's heart was broken by her first boyfriend, and she since had decided that being with a lot of guys might make her feel better and would make her life more exciting. Terauchi found out that her mother cheated on her father, and that shattered the glass that shielded her childish innocent and threw her harshly into the world of adults. They're all dealing with problems, and they all do it alone. Worm, even though he basically the reason this whole story started, feels like a really minor character. He's the instrument that helps the girls acknowledging their issues, but necessarily in a good way. This is a book that start with a matricide, continues with assistance to a fugitive and ends with a death in a car accident and suicide. It's a hard book to connect with because it's hard to accept the simple truth everything is written in. We all want to believe that the world isn't all that terrible, but it's not true. And the writer isn't trying to sugar coat everything, or write in some sophisticated way about pain and suffering. It's just a sad story about a group of people who ruin themselves till the point of no return.

Sometimes it is so damn hard to put your mindspace in the right place to enjoy a piece so far out of your frame, and this is definitely one of those books. I knew a bit of what I might expect, after all, I did enjoy reading Drood and so I got a real hankering to read an actual extremely popular novel by such a wild character in a modern book about Wilkie and Charles. But that's neither here nor there. I probably wouldn't have ever picked this one up without it, though. On to the novel at hand. It's a mystery! And if I can believe wikipedia, it's one of the very first ever written, and considered to be one of the top 100 novels ever written! Whoopie! I mean, that's all great and all. But did I enjoy it? Actually... I did. To a degree. Of course, the mental gymnastics were pretty strenuous. After all, I have to suspend belief that Laura was NOT TSTL. Tstl? Yes. Tstl. Every step of the way, she made the most horrible decisions, either by not listening to her heart or not having a brain in her head. If this were a mystery novel of even 20 years after its written date of 1854, we'd have killed this one off like a redshirt for sure. Therefore, I am UTTERLY AMAZED by the ending. I've never seen such brilliant contrivance to make such an unlikable airhead pull through to the very end, have her love, her fortune, and her unwitting revenge upon all who had assailed her. I mean, WOW. Wilkie Collins is a MASTER. That being said, I thought the Count was pretty much awesome. Everyone except for Laura and Walter managed to transform themselves from cardboard cutouts into genuine people full of both good and bad. Sometimes the descriptions were cumbersome and made me wish for a bit of a Hemingway Edit, but that's a complaint I can make about any of the literature of that day. There was one notable exception. I loved our enlightenment of Count Fosco's animals. It's details like this that turn a sensational-ish novel into something a bit more memorable. I swear, though: Laura was consistently tstl. Thank GOD for her half-sister. Miss Halcombe was pretty damn awesome from start to finish, and I agree 100% with the Count's esteem of her. The one thing I cannot be more pleased about, after finishing this, is the fact that there wasn't some long-drawn-out court scene so reminiscent of modern police drama or mysteries. We had the hint of it in the beginning, and it could have gone that way, but I can't be happier with the outcome as it actually occurred. There was a hell of a lot of expanded plot in this novel, and it was all so logical and well thought out. I'm just so damn AMAZED that the whole society in which they lived was actually able to FUNCTION, ya know? How could people trust each other as much as they did? How could people be so INNOCENT? I mean, really? Really? Was it a function of the black and white nature of the novels of the time to pop all of these features out at us in stark and glowing detail? Or was it just Wilkie? Or was it in actual fact, a real piece of the society in which they all lived? I'm primarily a sf/f/horror fan, but I truly HAVE read a ton of traditional classics. And yet, I'm still forced to set myself into a Victorian England as if it is some truly alien society so foreign and strange to us. It's funny. I should know better. Life is WEIRD.

This book is enchanting. That's the first thing I admit. These are why: the cover design brings the mood already; that whimsical title; and the author's name that rings a bell (turns out I have her anthology book on my TBR list). It drew me like a magnet yes, I was drawn. I don't mean to compare the quality per se, but I personally can relate this book to my previously read novel, This Is How the World Ends by Amy Zhang. Like, similar. Both of them were marvelous in writing style. The feelings were different though, but I sensed the same fairy tale, under-the-spell kind of atmosphere even though both of them are completely contemporary, don't be tricked . Magical realism, if I'm to take the 'modern' term. I can't lie--I was mesmerized the whole journey. The words took me to another realm, yet I could sense it through my own skin. It was real and dreamy at the same time, definitely my kind of favorite read. I felt the same way with TIHtWE. No matter how bizzare it turned out and how confused I was in the end, I still devoured the story and let the characters take me wherever they lead me. I believe it was also because of the short chapters and strong voices for Wink, Poppy, and Midnight. I read the author's interview that she initially wrote only Wink and Midnight's PoVs, but her critique partner suggested to write Poppy's also, and she enjoyed writing Poppy the most. And I could feel that. Poppy was the easiest narrator to read to despite the fact that she was the most annoying. I mean, who proclaims themselves proudly as bullies? Contrary to some opinion about poetic-words-no-plot, I could actually see the highs and lows of the story, the red herrings and twist and climax. No complains about it. Although it's true that the wordings took more place than actual action so it looked like a bunch of beautiful passages describing settings, and pretty quotable sentence coming from characters sounded unnatural, it wasn't what made it receive three-star rating instead of 'perfect' four stars. It was this. Why was Wink quickly forgiven?! I got why they do that. But I didn't get that one only. It was just too fast, too happy-ending a la fairy tales that Wink memorized outside her head. I didn't understand why they had to pretend the whole seance so that they (or Wink) can burn the house and scare the hell out of the Yellows and Midnight. The scenario was too big and risky for a simple reward, and what's with Hero and Villain after all? And now if I read a pitch with We Were Liars comparison in it, it's definitely, surely, absolutely about the fire. My favorite character was Leaf. I liked him form the start and I wish he came up more often. His personality was strong even though he didn't really present on the story, just from Poppy's tale. He was the real male lead character I wanted to see instead of Midnight. (One more thing... Midnight's habit to always tell about his family and their pet peeves and their preferences in the middle of something even if it didn't add to the plot. Was it important to insert chara trivia like that, or was it just the way Midnight speaks set by the author so his vulnerability was shown ad sounded different?) I enjoyed this. I truly did. I was just bothered by 'that' one thing that managed to ruin a half of the book. But that's okay, because the ending was fortunately less confusing than TIHtWE and I still consider this book as likeable, very readable novel for melancholy souls.

I always enjoy Jeffrey Deaver's books. Rhyme and Sachs are not my favorite protagonists. But they always have help from some fascinating characters. In this book, I really enjoyed meeting Kara and exploring her insider's view of prestidigitation. I thought the entire storyline about magic was very compelling, and I slowed down toward the end of the book because I wanted to make it last. There are some twists that were entirely too difficult to swallow (Really? They don't check the pulse of the dead serial killer magician prisoner?) , but overall, it kept me entertained enough to forgive some moments of incredulity.

Another quality book, even if 'my sex' popped up (though just once). The story felt like it concluded an arc. I supposed it did, relationship wised. More details were revealed regarding Ben and it was a surprised that it wasn't more well-known. Jae revealed more regarding his family. His mother did not sound like a real motherly not to mention she seemed to hardly had any redeeming quality. It seemed like she could compare notes to Cole's parents. I supposed Claudia is enough to mother them both *sigh*  Claudia did not have a lot of on pages time in this book but she was endearing whenever she was on. Her clan was also entertaining to meet as well. I am curious to see what will happen next. I would imagine that Cole McGinnis would be a well-known name with in the K-Town by now.

Mind of Winter would have been much more successful as a novella (it reminds me very much of "The Turn of the Screw"); its beginning and end were fantastic, and they will haunt me for months. Kasischke is a master at creating scenes that elicit high emotion (dread, fear, horror, sorrow) from her readers, and she should trust her images and scenes instead of piling words on top of words on top of words to over-describe them. The narrator became nearly insufferable as the novel progressed, and if I had to read about the narrator encountering and waxing poetic about that stupid latch on Tatiana's stupid door one more time, I was going to break down both the fourth wall and the flimsily latched door. We know the latch is a symbol. Do not beat us over the head with the narrator talking about how it's a symbol, please. I received an advanced copy of this book from its publisher.

I enjoyed this, though not as much as Gone Girl. It was a little disturbing, and I found it hard to picture what Camille even looked like, since  I can't imagine a person with scars of words all over their body. I thought it was a little predictable, in that I did guess part of the end, but not the entire thing, pretty early on, but I still thought it was an enjoyable read and it was really unique. Sometimes, I think it's okay to have a predictable story as long as it's told in a unique way with good writing that keeps you reading, and that's what this was. Like most mystery/thrillers, it's pretty easy to point to one or two people and say "Aha! You're the killer!" For this genre especially, if my standard was that the book would only be good if it wasn't predictable, I think I'd have to stop reading these books entirely, because I almost always guess who the killer is pretty early in. In any case, I think this was a good book with really interesting characters, and I would recommend it to people who enjoy this genre and who, like me, are okay with guessing what's going to happen without knowing exactly how you'll get there.

I went into Please Don't Tell not knowing what it would be about, and I do not regret it one bit. Reading it reminded me how important it is to read out of your comfort zone, even if it is a genre I would have never picked up! Please Don't Tell follows Joy and Grace, twins that are surprisingly very different from each other. Although Joy is a little obnoxious, she views herself as a protector, both of her sister and her friends. Grace on the other hand is a straight A student, and there's no doubt in anyone's mind that she'll be going to college. Unfortunately, the same can't be said for Joy. The POV not only switches between the sisters, but it also switches between the past and the present (or more accurately, the "before" and "after"). In Joy's POV, we see her struggling to not only deal with the aftermath of Adam's death, but also a blackmailer who apparently saw her murder Adam. In order for the blackmailer to not turn her in, Joy has to pretty much do whatever the blackmailer says. In Grace's POV, we see how the sisters were before, which was vastly different from the present. I had much less tolerance for Joy then, and Grace was like me in high school. Always studying, never really breaking out of her shell. Not until Joy comes along to drag her off to be a party animal. To be honest, this is a very hard review to write because I don't want to spoil anyone. I went into this book completely blind, not knowing it dealt with a some hard topics, along with it being a mystery. The most I can say is that I kept on trying to guess who the blackmailer was (and failed to guess right). I really was just pointing fingers at everyone. Most importantly, I loved how we can clearly see the changes in both Joy and Grace after what happened. It reminded me a little of The Way I Used To Be, where one event can completely transform a person, for better or for worse. I can't hold it in, so highlight for spoilers! Let's talk about the reveal! I think something in me knew it would be Grace, although I was stuck on the blackmailer being Preston for a very long time (hey you never know). But wow, I can't believe her own twin sister blackmailed her! Makes me really glad that I don't have any siblings, though I'm sure that would never happen haha. I feel like the last half of the novel was much more fast paced, as the beginning was a little slow for me. But very much worth it. I really enjoyed Please Don't Tell, even though it doesn't seem like a Val book at all. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys a good mystery, or likes reading about darker topics. I received this ARC in exchange for an honest review. Quotes taken from ARC may or may not be in the published edition.

Well, I couldn't resist and I read the book. Now I have to wait for the next one for who knows how long.... silly me! >.< I decided to read it because someone says it gives them Corrupt vibes (by Penelope Douglas). I would say that it remind me of Tijan books too. It started a little slow but I was drawn to it with every page. It's a good story but pretty safe. Futhermore I didn't feel on the edge and itchy.
