I had high hopes (like Corrupt high hopes which blow my mind) but unfortunately it wasn't crazy enough, fucked up enough, insane enough... Although I liked Madison, I found her immature. Actually that goes for the other characters too. Their personalities were rather simple. About the ending... finally something I didn't expect. Still what the hell is The Silver Swan? What Bishop's dad want to do with her? Argh... I'm not really impressed though I will probably read the next one just to find the answers to my questions. Anyway... the love scenes were hot.as.fuck!

It's a good book. A really good book, actually. But it feels just like the rest of Dan Brown's books. Robert is once again going on a mission to save the world, with the help of no other than a beautiful young woman. *yawn* Yes, there was a huge twist in the plot, but it was really close to the end and for me it just came too late. Because up until that point, it really felt like I was reading the same old book, just with new characters. Also, in some parts it felt like Robert was just vomiting unnecessary information. I don't need to know what every church he visits at reminds him of, and what childhood nightmares he's still suffering from if it's irrelevant to the plot. I loved it when Robert realized that Sienna might actually be the bad person in this story. But she ended up being just confused, and unsure of what she believed in anymore. It's a happy ending, albeit a bit annoying because I REALLY WANTED HER TO BE THE BED PERSON.

https://anaslair.wordpress.com/2017/0... I struggled with suspension of belief on this one. I just did not get how someone could be fully conscious and no doctors realise it. Surely there are brain exams that were performed where the brain activity would be noticeable? Also, she needs a machine to breathe for her but somehow she is able to identify scents and she has her eyes open (who has their eyes open in a vegetative state??) and is able to focus on details such as a doctor's open pores but no change occurs in her eyes? It took me a while to warm up to it but once I did, about halfway in or so, I flipped the pages as quickly as I could. I enjoyed how the narrative was presented, with different voices - even little Evie's - and mysterious character(s). The suspense built up. Then at the beginning of the last fifth of the story we get the much advertised shocking plot twist (I truly dislike seeing that by the way, it was even in my ARC book title). It is shocking indeed but I for one did not find it believable at all. There was nothing in that character's past or later explained that would justify that she would view Evie as her own. Actually, pretty much the only background we get is that she had money issues . Only when I got to the end did I notice I had read a previous novel by the same author and had felt pretty much the same. The books are so emotionally and psychologically charged that the characters' actions need to be properly backed up and I just don't feel it happens. It's almost as if the book is done for shock purpose, all explanations for what had happened felt that way, as well as extremely rushed, and I have to say I don't really appreciate that. Still, Blink was very exciting at some points so even though I was not entirely sold I am rating it up. Disclaimer: I would like to thank the publisher and Netgalley for providing me a free copy of this book in exchange for my honest review.

I found myself with an odd sense of deja-vu throughout the reading of this collection. I've also just finished Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, and so comparisons are inevitable. Both books deal in part with the abuse, torture, rape and murder of women. However, where King excels far above Larsson is his depiction of "ordinary people in extra-ordinary situations". His characters are believable, and I found that he evoked more emotion in 100 or so pages than Larsson did in his entire book. The female characters - Tess and Darcy - in their respective stories, are both kickass and completely ordinary. These stories are dark, "harsh" - King himself admits they were hard to write. However, they are not without hope. There are - please excuse the awful pun - a few stars left in the dark at the end of the last three stories at least - I will admit I found none in the first. For example, Tess's life may be irrevocably changed after not only being raped, but committing three somewhat brutal murders. However the end of the story indicates that she will recover, in time. Same with Darcy (who I felt the most sorry for, in the end. Her story came across as the most believable, maybe that's why). On the (ever so slightly) bright side, Fair Extension is darkly humorous in its portrayal of a man who sells not his own soul, but another man's life to the devil (or "Elvid"). I have so far only ever enjoyed or appreciated King's writing, and this book is no exception. I will definitely keep an eye out for more of his short stories.

Fascinating reading. I have to say, I wasn't very enthusiast at first, mostly because the story made me feel unease, anxious, trapped as the protagonist is in that prison of a foreign country. But once the story unfolds, I inevitably got caught up in it: in the borderline relationships among the protagonists, in the swirling of raw emotions and their inevitable conclusion. The ending is powerful. (Not real spoiler, but spoiler-ish considerations) It makes you realize you've been seeing the truth all along, but not in the way you thought. I guessed it somewhere along half the book I think, yet it still managed to surprise me because it was not in the way  I guessed it. So, even if it has some flaws, it is a story that left me with a lot of thoughts, and wanting to read it again. That must count for something.

According to the dust jacket, The Retribution is "the ideal introduction or reintroduction to the world of Tony Hill and Carol Jordan." Well bloody hell, if this had been my first outing with Tony and Carol, I don't think I'd be coming back for more. McDermid's books have always been shocking - borderline grotesque in places - but for me, the stakes were just too high here. Carol's brother murdered, Tony's beloved house razed to the ground, Chris blinded and horrifically scarred for life... Often I can't put McDermid's book down. This one I had to put aside in favour of watching a few hours of How I Met Your Mother, because it was just too flipping grim. Not to mention the Tony/Carol element. After a few books of total stagnation in their relationship, the last instalment gave me some hope for forward momentum. And instead, here we take a step back so enormous, it's hard to see how the lost ground can ever be recovered. On the whole, it's hard to say I enjoyed this book, because it was just so distressing. The pacing in the second half was tense, edge of seat stuff, but the first few hundred pages were dismayingly slow - particularly when we spent a chapter with Vance escaping, a chapter with Tony learning Vance had escaped, then a chapter with Tony telling Carol Vance had escaped... Eesh. The secondary plot started out with promise, but fizzled out by the end. I know for a fact I'll be back for the next Tony and Carol book, but after this, I'm really not looking forward to it.

Bought this in Den Haag because I realised I was going to run out of reading material before I ran out of travel! And then left it with Manuela. IT WAS ACTUALLY REALLY AWESOME OMG! I grabbed it because it was half price and I loved Libba Bray's Great and Terrible Beauty trilogy, but I'd never been certain enough of Going Bovine to actually get it until it was that or twiddle my thumbs on a dozen different trains. I mean, there's a cow on the cover. That's kind of not me at all. It started off okay... I was a little unsure, Cam's voice was just a bit too much at times, a little over the top/try-hard or something, I wasn't sure if I liked the way it was written/told. But I was still at least curious, the story seemed an interesting enough one. And then it started to get really, really weird. Like, fire giants and shit. And I was thinking three stars, maybe two if it went even further like this. I mean, it was all too much and so not ME. But then... it actually started to grow on me. I loved Gonzo and Balder, and the road trip was really exciting - the whole following random shit which made me go wtf at first started to build up a lot, and the places they went to were, for the most part, really interesting. I had a mild thought in the middle that it was probably all going to just be a dream, since Cameron kept having dreams of being in the hospital, but then it began to just be SO real that I knew he really was on this road trip, you know? Everything was so detailed and so realistic, his parents/sister calling him etc - even the weird fantasy shit felt real. And Dulcie, omg Dulcie. Such a crush on her! I was really shipping her and Cam and I don't usually do that. The universe just felt like a bizarre one where this could all happen - I mean the SPEW tests at school were real, so why not the snow globes? So I was heartbroken to find out at the end that it really had just all been one long dream :( Gonzo and Drew, that was a dream... everything. Great characters, great story, so much better than I was expecting :D

Colie has low self-esteem. She was fat, so was her mother and now that she's lost the excess weight she still feels ugly. With the help of friends, a crazy aunt, and a guy who is interested in her, she discovers that she can be beautiful. What I didn't like about this book is that Colies eventual acceptance of herself seemed to stem from how the people around her saw her instead of from what she saw in herself. This did bother me, but not enough to dislike the book. How is it that Sarah Dessen knows teen girl angst SO well? She can, and has, taken every psychological issue known to the female teen life and created stories around them. She could not possibly have gone through each of these issues herself yet in each one, that I'VE read so far, she seems to know exactly how a girl will feel in that particular situation.

This is a tricky one to rate because I found Will's story fascinating, his interpretation of the world before his surgery and his adjustments afterwards, realizing that he needs to learn how to see and interpret what he's seeing with how he's always learned without sight before was all very interesting. And it seems well researched, though I still don't know how accurate Will's descriptions of blindness and experiences might actually be since the author himself has never been blind. But I enjoyed reading about Will. But I didn't actually like Will or much of the rest of the book. Will fat-shames the vice-principal and grabs a girl's boob (by accident but brushes it off as being totally acceptable because he didn't mean to and he is blind, after all, but thoroughly enjoys being able to get away with these things because he's blind and doesn't even apologize) all in the first chapter. He didn't improve much for me after that. I think I enjoyed him most when he was around Cecily and she was explaining art and perspective and many other things about the world to him. But Cecily, and the rest of the characters, were very flat and underdeveloped. Even his parents were a little all over the place depending on how the scene needed to work for the story. In fact, he makes his mom stay outside in the car during his pre-op appointment where the procedure is explained and most of his post-op therapy sessions, even the ones when his medications are changed yet Will describes her as a helicopter parent. But I don't see that behavior anywhere. I cannot imagine my mom being okay sending me into those appointments on my own. Also, I don't believe for a second that she would sell her brand new car for thousands less than what it's worth to fund a road trip for her son and his friends when her husband is a fancy doctor. Are there no other funds? Is there no credit card she can send with him? How about a debit card? Or sell the car to a dealer? I don't know but there are about a thousand other ways I'd find to do this before doing it that way. Though I do fully support her wanting her son to see the world at this moment in the story. But the selling of the Tesla for cash to a fellow country club member just doesn't fit. So overall, the story was interesting and the writing was fine, it just wasn't what I had hoped for. I was excited for an interesting look at the definitions of traditional beauty from someone who hasn't been inundated with these "beautiful" images all his life. I wanted him to grandstand about how unfair society is to those who don't conform or who are born different. But I seemed to get more of a childish tantrum over something else ( Cecily failing to mention to her new friend Will that she has a birthmark covering half of her face? When all Cecily wants after a lifetime of being made fun of is someone who doesn't notice her birthmark right away and wants to fit in, just list Will who doesn't like to wear sunglasses inside and freaks out when he finds out people saw him go into the girls' bathroom. ) instead. I wanted more meaningful relationships between Will and his parents and his new friends. And while the moments between Cecily and Will were among my favorite (tantrum not included), I really wish she had been more developed as a character. That they all had been more developed and complex and been given more time to really deal with the issues the book tried to address. But overall, it just fell short for me.

Loved the story. Read it in one gulp. The only star loss is because of the constant jolt-out-of-the-story "lame"s. (And a "spaz".) And it's not like Rowell doesn't understand that "lame" is about disability - the very first use of it in the story is a riff on that meaning. ETA: One of the things I loved the very most about this book is the "lack of character development" that others are criticising. This book is, above all, a subtle book. No big sweeping Coming-Of-Age complete character transformation is to be had. Instead, Cath evolves in fine-drawn ways, as she gets to know herself and her place in the world better and better. In the beginning I was cringing: we had a deeply introverted young woman who valued her internet friends and who above all loved to write, and the last thing I wanted was for that to all change in the name of "character development", as though being introverted and having internet friends and loving to write was something that was wrong and needed fixing. I adore Rowell for not fixing those things, and for finding Cath a partner who didn't just tolerate her writing but appreciated it.

I think the only saving grace of Requiem was it's predecessors. I loved Delirium and Pandemonium so much that I HAD to know the outcome, and I already loved the world and characters. However, I'm going to say it... this was the worst end to a dystopia that I have ever read. And it hurts me to say that after I had been SO impressed with the other books. There are a couple of things I liked: I liked having Hana's insider POV. I finally felt like I understood how the cure changed people. However, her POV mostly didn't advance the plot at all, so it felt useless. I also loved the fact that Lena is still a relateable character. I understand her emotions, and the way she handles jealousy and throwing herself at one boy to make the other jealous, it felt like something a teenager would actually do. Lena's strength comes in ordinary ways, through courage and loyalty to her beliefs. She didn't go all "Mockingjay" - meaning, she wasn't turned into the one and only possible savior of the Resistance. She was simply a player, involved, but not on the main lines. I actually appreciated her small part in the battles because it was more believable to me than the endings of other popular dystopia series. What I had the biggest problem with was that NOTHING GOT RESOLVED. We have been building a love story, and a government resistance conflict for 3 books now. Neither of these things gets the attention it deserves. The 'love triangle' I was expecting was non existent, as one guy dropped out on page one. Then Lena's surviving relationship was fueled by leftover feelings it seemed. And in the end when she finally ends up with somebody, it's so lacing in anticipation, they are just like 'ok, we're together now'. None of it was satisfying to me, neither guy got the attention that a story about fighting for love deserved. I think both Julian and Alex supporters will be ultimately let down. As for the Resistance aspect of the story... it was the main focus and the action scenes were the best in my opinion. They were the only times I felt exctied and gripped. But I really hated how this book ended. Not that it had a 'bad' ending, just that the main conflict was one battle, in one city. We don't even get to find out what impact this had on that city's leaders, much less the rest of the country. We really don't know what the outcome will be. Even worse, I felt no closure with any of the characters, not even the two narrators. What will be the fallout of the love triangle? What the heck happened to Hana? What will happen to Lena and her whole group, where will they go now? Will the government topple and the cure be eradicated? One of the biggest disappointments to me was Raven. In her short story it was revealed that  she was pregnant. This is never mentioned in Requiem! And then something happens... and there is just NO closure to her storyline at all. Overall this book felt like a lead up to a conclusion, like there should be a fourth book. It would rate higher with me if that were the case, but as the finale, it fell flat.

Actual Rating 4.5 The Cage was exactly what I wanted to read, it was twisted and I couldn't put it down. Now I'll be honest, I went into it ready for this to be a 3 star read for me since that's what the The Madman's Daughter was for me and I was pleasantly surprised. The first 40% of the book was kinda boring and not very interesting, and then the last 60% was amazing. Really the only thing that makes me not want to give it a five star rating is the fact that in the whole book I really only liked Cora and Cassian. So, all in all this was a great book! Also, that ending! When I found out that Cassian was the warden I was in total shock and I couldn't believe it! This was basically me:

I liked this a lot. It felt very recognizable, in a way most YA I read these days doesn't. I talked like these characters did, dreamed like they did, FELT like they did. (And, well, that doesn't need to be past tense! I may be 10 years older than them, but it's still relatable.) Slight spoiler! I'm not sure I entirely bought--or maybe understood?--their relationship. It felt like a friendship and I thought that was the point, but . then it seemed to be something more? But good. I'd recommend it, especially if you're like me and maybe a little burned out on current YA.

Challenge #17  A book a friend recommended (popsugar 2015 reading challenge: http://tinyurl.com/mmbkthd) I think this book broke me Update: This book was recommended to me by Raeleen What to say about this book? It is a weird mixture of contemporary and science fiction. I feel like this book should be like oil and vinegar, where the two elements of this book don't work. However, this is not the case! Adam Silvera was able to make a dark drama about a boy trying to figure out who he is. I compare this book to darker Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (which is a fantastic movie) mixed with the love story of Ian and Mickey from Shameless. The information and development of the story is so carefully revealed so that the reader doesn't know what is going on until Silvera wants you to know what is going on. The main character is an asshole. He has a lot of horrible things happen to him, but he tends to blame the wrong things. He messes up all of the people around him, but doesn't really give them a second thought. His love is shown in strange ways, and he just can't really comprehend his feelings. I didn't think Aaron is a good person, but that doesn't mean I don't like him. I got so attached to his character, by the end I was crying because his life was so crappy and I wanted him to be happy. This book is a lot of things: a love story, a coming of age story, and a poverty story. It was able to pull of my emotions so much for such a small book. I definitely recommend it, and it will be on my favorites shelf for years to come! Spoliers: The horrible ways Aaron is treated throughout the book are realistic in a poverty ridden place. The reason why I love this book was it took a coming out story and put a science fiction twist on it. Adam Silvera used the treatment that he made up in a realistic way, which is what gave the book so much depth. The prejudice against gay people and homosexuality is such a known concept, that a gay boy who was raised with those ideals would jump at the chance of turning himself straight. Adam Silvera is making a pretty big statement on what our society thinks towards sexuality, and how in this new age of technology it could severely go wrong. The book is a very good comment on sexuality, and it is aparent that Adam Silvera is very passionate about it!

4 stars. This book is exactly what I needed after reading really huge, intense fantasy novels. This book is light and fun but it also expertly hides deeper scenes and important moments in coming out to your friends, family, and to your school. Simon was a great main character. His wit and humor had me laughing but he was also incredibly smart and really understood all his emotions. I appreciated that in his character. This is a minor issue but Simon says the word "freaking" way too much. I know he is seventeen but I was getting so annoyed with how much he used that word, I know it's a nitpick. I really enjoyed all the characters, actually. I think they fit the story well and weren't just "plot moving characters". I think that they fulfilled their purpose and I genuinely liked all the characters. So, I figured out who the mysterious "Blue" was about halfway through the book. Just from the way Simon would describe this character, I knew he was "Blue". When Simon realizes who it is and they have their meeting, it couldn't have been more cute. I loved this pairing. I also really loved that it is a interracial couple. I was happy that we got resolution with Leah. For awhile I was worried that Simon and Leah were not going to talk again and I was happy that they talked and forgave each other in the end. The Martin situation, however, I can completely see why Simon is still angry with him. I was happy that Martin apologized in the email and I can see a friendship for them in the future. I would recommend this to anyone who has a pulse, honestly. It's light but really deep and opened my eyes to new things. This book is definitely worth your time.

I can't believe I finished The Giver, Gathering Blue, and The Messenger, all within the same night! The first time I read these, there was a span of several years between my reading and I can honestly say that you get so much more out of these when you read them back to back. I like that we finally find out what happens to Jonas and there is a brief mention of Gabe (who will finally get his own story in  Son ). While I enjoyed the book overall, it did leave me with some kingering questions. Jonas mentions that he receives a barge filled with books as a "gift" from his old city. That confused me completely because a.) How would they know the books would find him? and b.) If their society really was getting better, why would they willingly part with thousands of books? We were led to believe that the Giver was one of the only citizens with books so why would he part with them willingly?? I guess the librarian part of me can't understand loading your book collection on a barge and sending it off down a river. I thought maybe the society was regressing and the books were sent away to "save" them...but I'm probably overthinking it! I also wondered what happened to his sister Lily. Jonas/Leader makes an offhanded comment about missing her. We just know so much more about the changes within Kira's village but we only get tiny speculations about Jonas's. I'm really hoping that the next book will let us know what has happened there. The other thing that bothered me about this book was that the Trade Mart situation was never really dealt with. While Matty was able to heal the forest and the people within the Village, the lasting effects of his sacrifice are debatable. There was no interaction with the sinister trader man and his black book so it makes you wonder if the same situation would eventually play out again when he eventually comes back. I just hate that Lowry's endings are always so fast! You finally figure out what's going on, the problem is solved, and it's over! I tend to like more "and this is what happened next." I do think that her style does leave you with unanswered questions, and this is why these books have been talked about for years and years. Although I will be sad to see the series finally end (maybe? ), I am looking forward to reading Son.

This review was originally posted on Bedtime Bookworm Loving Patrick Ness! I've been fairly obsessed with Patrick Ness ever since I read the Choas Walking trilogy back in October of last year. I wasn't planning on reading more Patrick Ness so soon, but one day I was at the library picking up a different book when I saw this one out of the corner of my eye. It was calling my name and I couldn't resist checking it out right then and there. I'm so glad that I did because I loved this book. I went into this book pretty much completely blind - and that's how I recommend you go into it as well! All I knew was it was about a boy who died and wakes up, which happens in the very first chapter. I recommend going into the book knowing only that because I personally enjoyed all the surprises in store for me as I went along. Therefore, I'm using a lot of spoiler tags in this review to mark things that are true spoilers and things that are mild spoilers Mild spoilers are for those people who want to know a little more information before diving in (but I think its more fun to read without knowing those things...hehe) I hope that makes sense! The Characters I connected with Seth from the very beginning. About half of the story is about Seth's experiences after his death and the other half of the story is told in flashbacks to when Seth was still alive. He doesn't have the greatest life while alive and these flashbacks help you to understand Seth better. Mild spoiler --> Seth is gay and this book is partly a coming out story. We follow Seth as he falls in love and see what happens when his friends and family find out. I haven't read from the POV of many gay characters, so I loved that! I'm glad to see this book add diversity to my reading. True spoiler --> I was NOT expecting the appearance of more characters! My jaw dropped when we discover there are others in this after-death world. It added a whole new twist to the book. Were they real? Were they imagined? I had no idea! I did feel that the young boy was a little wise beyond his years (which made me question if he was real!) but it didn't really bother me much. Seth's family life and relationship with his parents is complex - there is some heavy stuff in here! This book made me feel genuine feelings for Seth and what he went through. True spoiler --> I absolutely hated Seth's parents - mostly his mom, but his dad enabled his mother, and I blame him for that. What terrible people! But then again, some part of me wonders if subconsciously I would feel the same way if the situation had happened to me. Would I be able to forgive completely, or would I on some level always blame my son for what happened? The Story and Plot This is the type of story where the reader is kept guessing constantly throughout the book. Although I typically HATE not knowing what is going on (especially by the time I'm more than 100 pages or so in), I actually enjoyed the guessing game in this book. I think it's because the main character also doesn't know what is going on and you, as the reader, get to experience exactly what he is experiencing, as he experiences it. The whole idea behind this book is so interesting to me - it's the first of it's kind that I've read. I'll admit there are similarly themed books out there - I've just never read any of them. Mild spoiler --> I wasn't expecting this book to be a dystopian story, but it is! Although this isn't technically a spoiler, I enjoyed being surprised by this aspect of the story. True spoiler --> I was NOT expecting a virtual world to be what was going on here. That was a big surprise for me! I know there are other books out there where people live in a virtual world (Ready Player One comes to mind) but I haven't read any yet. One tiny complaint I have is that the book has one of those "open to interpretation" endings that I have recently mentioned I don't love. I almost loved this one though - and Patrick Ness can make it up to me by writing a sequel *wink wink*. But seriously - I WANT TO KNOW WHAT HAPPENS!! WHAT DOES IT MEAN? In Summary This book is about some tough stuff guys (trigger warnings --> This book explores suicide and emotional abuse. ) and it makes you ask yourself some hard questions about life. Just like in the Chaos Walking trilogy, this book isn't just a story - it's so much more! It makes you think and ask questions about life, death, and morality... and I don't know what else. Stuff! This book is very thought provoking and I enjoyed every second of it. I think I'm gushing now. I encourage everyone to read this book and I hope you fall in love with it like I did!
I really enjoyed this book. I thought it did an excellent job of wrapping up the series. I just wish she had managed it without killing off Tibby .

This book was crazy. Micah is a pathological liar who is dealing with her boyfriend's sudden death. The book is divided into three parts, Part One: Telling the Truth, Part Two: Telling the True Truth and Part Three: The Actual Real Truth . It's a big guessing game from start to finish. The book goes back and forth, before Zach's death and after, as well as short glimpses into Micah's early childhood. After reading about her childhood, her family history, her personal 'truth', and all of her inner fears, doubts, and feelings of loneliness, I still didn't feel like I truly knew Micah. And the reason for that is simple: I can't trust her. This lack of trust is not a coincidence. It's clear that the author meant for it to be that way. That's what the book is about. Micah has lied for what seems like forever, and she's finally ready to tell you the truth. Will you believe her? Even after unraveling the mystery and navigating the crazy twist (I avoided spoilers to I could really enjoy the story, and it was definitely an interesting twist), I still felt a disconnect. Not only did I feel like I didn't get a chance to truly know Micah, but I also didn't get a good feel of her parents or Zach. Just bits and pieces of them. The same goes for all the minor characters in this story. I don't know if this was done on purpose or what. The book is written in such a way that events are clouded in mystery and all you're left with is random fragments that you later have to fit together to make sense of what's really happened. There were some things I didn't doubt or question in the story. Micah's love for Zach, for example. Or her feelings of loneliness. But I can't ignore what I do doubt: Is the Actual Real Truth the truth? Can I believe? I felt the foundation of the book crumbled for me towards the end, after everything was revealed, and it affected the way I felt about this story as a whole. Once I finished the book, I was left with questions that will never get answered: Why were we introduced to Micah's brother Jordan when we never find out what big accident caused his death? Why were her parents so affected by it? Why is Pete practically absolved of all guilt after his role in Zach's death? The lack of answers is disappointing and left me dissatisfied. While I appreciate that Larbalestier attempted something different and introduced a unique narrator, the twist and the overall plot was overshadowed by skepticism and wariness on my part.

Simon's a junior in a suburban Atlanta high school, he's gay and he's in the closet. He's playing the only boy pickpocket in "Oliver." He's e-mailing another gay kid from his school, and he's falling in love with him, but he doesn't know who he is. Meanwhile, there's a kid blackmailing him -- the kid playing Fagin. Then the blackmailer ups the stakes and puts on a public school forum that Simon is gay. And Simon tells no one. What the kid did besides being awful, is sufficient to send him to jail for a long time in many states. Simon's parents, sisters, his drama teacher and friends are great and overwhelmingly supportive, but he told none of them about his cast mate. Maybe it's realistic, but as a sometimes teacher, director, as an adult who cares about this fictional character, I wish he told someone. Maybe the kid playing Fagin needed help, that he didn't get because Simon didn't speak up. There's a charming love story here about good, nice kids getting together. I liked this book a lot, but the antagonist's actions -- and the protagonist's-- are why it's not a 5 star book for me, though I certainly understand why so many people gave it more stars. I borrowed this from interlibrary loan.

Ahhh Percy Jackson, how I've missed you. Having read the first series so long ago, I knew exactly how Percy felt trying to get his memories back. I loved Frank and Hazel and all the new characters, as well as the old ones that resurfaced. Nico has always been fascinating, so glad to see him again. But poor Percy, the kid can't catch a break. I hope he gets some peace with Annabeth one day (although rather unlikely in the world). Percy himself thinks about that a lot in this story. But it will be a long road ahead... I can't wait to see what happens when all seven demigods get together. There are so many personalities that I'm going to need a chart to remember them all! I am amazed by Rick Riordan's research. Not only is he dealing with Greek gods, he has Roman ones going as well and there are so many myths it's incredible. Questions for next book: How will Hazel loose her curse? How/did Sammy turn into Leo (I read The Lost Hero, but I don't remember if there was anything weird about when he lived before camp)? Will there be a Frank/Hazel/Leo love triangle? What's this new prophecy about Annabeth? How will she cause problems (I hope she and Percy stay together! What will happen when Percy meets Jason? Will there be a Reyna/Jason/Piper fight/triangle? That 'an oath to keep on final breath' part is making me nervous... What is this big sacrifice that Percy isn't going to be able to make - so Frank will have to make it for him? Does it involve Annabeth? Something to do with loyalty?

Well, I finished the series. I'm glad I read it all. I had a few issues with MockingJay - though I do feel it wrapped up the trilogy well. This book had the biggest kick in the teeth for me when Prim dies at the end. I cried for a solid 10 minutes. Finnick, Boggs - I was prepared to lose all of them, but not Prim. Everything after that kind of didn't really matter. I'm glad she ends up with Peeta and I find their relationship very plausible. But there is so much lost at the end. Overall, I felt that for most of the book Katniss was just wandering around clueless a little too much. I would have expected her to take a more active interest in what was happening. I know she was a pawn in all this, but I did expect her to figure out a bit more and have someone to talk to about it.

4.5 stars "Everything happens for a reason. People say these things to make sense of the world. Secretly, in their hearts, almost everyone believes that there's some meaning, some willfulness to life. Fairness. Basic decency. Good things happen to good people. Bad things only happen to bad people. No one wants to believe that life is random. I am a realist. It's better to see life as it is, not as you wish it to be. Things don't happen for a reason. They just happen." I wasn't expecting to love this book as much as I did. This book was like a breath of fresh air. This book inspires me so much and I absolutely love Nicola Yoon's writing style. I read Everything, Everything last year and I wasn't a huge fan of it, I thought it was just okay. But this book is easily a new all time favorite of mine. This book follows a Jamacian girl named Natasha whose family is getting deported in twelve hours. She wants to be a scientist and she doesn't believe in love or God or anything really except or sceince. I really like Natasha's character because she's so strong and she's such a realist and she is desperate to have a future in America. On the day her and her family are being deported she meets Daniel, a Korean-American boy who is a hopeless romantic and a poet and he's rebelling against his family's wishes for him to become a doctor. I love Daniel's character because he's so optomistic and he believe sin love at first sight and he doesn't really know what he wants to do with his life at the age of seventeen years old. I really appreciate the diversity in this book. I've never read a book like this before, a person of color and a korean. I just love seeing diverse books like this in YA because there isn't nearly enough of it. This book reminds me a lot of Eleanor & Park, not only because Daniel is asian just like Park, but because of the way the chapters are written from both characters perspectives and the chapters are short and sweet. It also reminds me of November 9 with the way it follows a couple who meets and falls in love on the same day. The one down side of this book is that it has some serious insta-love. I usually roll my eyes at insta-love but this one was just written so well I honestly believed it myself, which is crazy for me because I hate insta love 99% of the time. I love how Daniel believes in love at first sight and how he tries to use sceince to prove that love at first sight exists. I love one of their first converstaions in the cafe when Natasha says love doesn't exist. It reminds me of that scene in 500 Days of Summer when he tells her love isn't like Santa Clause, love exists whether we want to believe in it or not. I love the way the romance is written, it's so passionate and beautiful and it never feels forced. With beautiful quotes like this: "Touching him is order and chaos, like being assembled and disassembled at the same time." I also love how well-devloped their families are, and each member of their families have fleshed-out, interesting back stories. I especially enjoyed the back story with Natasha's Dad and his dream of becoming an actor and how their whole family suffered because of his unwillingness to let go of that dream. I also loved seeing the relationship with Daniel and his older brother Charlie who is a complete douche bag, and Daniel's Father who desperately wants him to become a doctor and be successful in life. His father is protective of him and doesn't want Daniel to grow up poor like he did. I love getting to read from the perspective of two families who moved to America to start a new life, and the struggle of never truly feeling accepeted in a new country. Daniel talks about how his parents want him to act more Korean but everyone else expects him to act "more American". It's such an interetsing perspective. This book brings up a lot of things I think about a lot. Daniel doesn't know what he wants to do with his life and he questions why should we know what we want to do with the rest of our lives at seventeen years old? I completely agree and relate to this, as I felt the same way at seventeen. It also talks about fate and coincidence and whether or not things happen for a reason or if things just happen. I like this quote: "Life is just a series of dumb decisions and indecisions and coincidences that we choose to ascribe meaning to." In a way I think that is true. Maybe things don't happen for a reason maybe things just happen and that's life. I also liked getting chapters form random characters that would appear throughout the book. Like Irene, a security guard at the building Natasha is going to. It's so increidbly random and at first I didn't like it, getting random chapters from the perspectves of ranodm characters - but some of the short stories were so interesting and heart breaking. I like the idea that every single person around us is living a life as complex and vivid as ours. I'm a curious person and I always wonder about other strangers lives, so to actually get little glimpses of the strangers in Natasha and Daniel's lives is really interetsing. I love that Irene's character is who brought them together in the end. Natasha saved Irene's life years ago in New York, and now in a way it's like Irene is saving Natasha's life, by bringing her and Daniel back together. It's such a beautful full circle. I also loved the side story with the lawyer leaving his wife for his paralegal. I loved how Hannah, his paralegal talked about how she wanted to be like a fairytale and then her final chapter was: they all lived happily ever after. I also love that scene where Daniel and Natasha both see a flash mob on the subway and as a reader you are hoping they see ecah other, but they pass right by each other. I also love their first kiss scene when they are singing kareoke. That is one of the most passionate first kiss scenes I've ever read in a book and I enjoyed it a lot. I felt so bad for Natasha's family at the end when they did end up getting deported. I thought the pacing of the last two chapters was weird, considering almost the entire book took place in one day and then those last chapters skipped ahead by five years or so? And then THAT ENDING. I almost threw the book across the room. How could it just end there? I was so shook. It was beautiful but tragic at the same time. Overall, I'm very impressed with this story. I'm still shook by that ending, and I can't even believe it ended like that. I really love this story and I will read anything Nicola Yoon writes. Knowing this story is personal to her because she is a woman of color who is married to a korean makes it even better. We need more diverse books like this in YA (and in general). I just really like books that make me think about life and force me to consider things I never thought about before. I will be thinking about this book long after I finish reading it. This book is just insanely beautiful and I recommend it to everyone.

When I was 13, my uncle killed himself. We'd known for a long time how sick he was, but barely in my teens myself I didn't understand the full consequences of his actions till several years later. The reason behind my bringing this up is if time travel was possible, as it is in All Our Yesterdays, I could conceivably see my aunt going back to make her husband take his medication, to not leave her and their two beautiful children alone. Only what would doing that do to the future? Would it alter my cousins' fierce motivation to be the best at school just to ease my aunt's burden? Terrill provides a different yet clear approach to travelling through time/the possible paradoxes created from time travel. For a YA sci-fi centered around a romance, the book doesn't cut any corners. I'd hesitate to classify it a dystopian, given that future events in half the book haven't exactly happened (yup, I spent a fair amount of time getting my mind blown), but the world Em and Finn live in is certainly drastically altered from Marina's and Finn's. The pacing was right on the money, the relationships between Em/Marina, James and Finn both tragic and lovely. It also made me think about how I'd react facing my future self... probably freak the fuck out. JAMES, POOR BABY. :'( There's something to be said about such a solid debut novel. I really don't know how you can top this. That ending had me writhing around in bed wanting MORE. I went into this with relatively high expectations after reading several positive reviews, and emerged feeling, for once, like they'd been met and more. Two thumbs up!

Official Rating: 5 Thoughts: I mean, there's no way to be subtle about this. This book fucked me up, in the best way possible. Normally when I write reviews, I have specific things that I want to talk about, but I only finished this monster literally five minutes ago, so coherent thoughts I do not have. I've read a couple of not-so-kind reviews from other people, who were a little dissatisfied with the ending and how it's very fairytale, happy-ending-y . Personally I thought it worked very well - appropriate tension had been introduced at appropriate times, but resulted in a satisfying enough conclusion in regards to gratuitous character and emotional payoff that I'm left bursting to read the sequel to see what happens next, and not caught up in heartbreak. I think one of the reasons why I adored this book so much from the get-go was not only the fact that its epistolary format kept things dynamic and fast-paced, but also how much it spoke my language. See, I've put a LOT of hours, and a LOT of money into understanding tech-speak. Literally, I'm doing a degree in it. So when I opened this novel and, for the first time in my entire life, saw actually complicated and (Lord help me) accurate tech-speak, my ego gained about fifty kilos. Beyond my own narcissistic tendencies, however, it showed just how much research and time had been dedicated to getting these details right. The inclusion of binary code, of programming lines, of the concept of executing and debugging programs before they actually make sense and do what they're supposed to - THESE are the tiny details which so many sci-fi and technology-based books so often leave out. And the best way to make something so inherently inhuman seem organic? Add in these details. Don't make it seem like technology is all wizz-bang wonders and miracles, and once you've got the skills, you can do it all perfectly first-go. I'm gonna try to make this review a little more coherent now; because holy cow we gotta talk about those characters, man. Look, I'm not going to lie, when I first read what Illuminae was about, and how it was structured, I was very concerned as to how Kaufman and Kristoff were going to craft characters that we as readers would not only relate to, but somehow become attached to - and I honestly don't think it could have been done better. These characters felt real. They were interesting, and they felt different. Kady was flawed - she was abrasive, and insubordinate, and cold, and arrogant, and damaged. But she adapted to her situation in a way which felt so very, very human to me. Her lack of connection to the fleet gave her a perspective which enabled her to ask those questions which rippled into the Illuminae files. Her part in, and emotional and psychological reaction to every breath-stealing event in Illuminae felt genuine, and felt real. Ezra was delightful - I wish we'd gotten a bit more of his 'perspective' (as much as is possible in an epistolary novel), because I feel like there was a lot of untapped potential there. But at the same time, I'm glad that some parts of him remain a mystery - not just so that there's room for further exploration in the later books, but also because that makes him seem even more like Kady's person. His character didn't belong to us, the readers - he was a person who was Kady's to love, and to loathe, and to grieve, and to rediscover . It added a very human element to the text, and had the bonus effect of helping to add to the somewhat mysterious element of the documents. Byron was just. sob. Incredible. Keep it up, buddy, you're doing a great job. AIDAN was on a whole other level - a point at which I'm no longer talking about how phenomenal the characters were, and talking about how mind-blowing-ly amazing the themes were. I don't think I've ever read a novel which has forced me to confront the concept of humanity and morality and understanding and perception and creation and every other philosophy-questioning topic as intensely, and as gloriously as this before. By the end, I was crying. As in, there were actual tears. Because of course AIDAN would come to consider these higher-level things. If you create artificial intelligence, and you put it among living, breathing creatures and give it a job - no matter what kind of restrictions you place on it, eventually it's going to ask the questions that human kind has been asking since day one: who am I, what am I, why am I? The evolution of AIDAN was one of my favourite things about Illuminae. Besides it being one of the best representations of an AI in general that I've ever read, its progression from mindless, order-following AI, to pre-teen temper tantrum AI, to thinks-it's-a-deity AI, to self-questioning AI, to the final product was so deliciously organic that I honestly don't have the words to describe how much I loved it. And the final product - a creation which was somewhere between human and artificial, somewhere between being and not being, somewhere between a rock and a hard place, made it the number one thing that I loved the most about Illuminae. Overall, my feelings for this book could be summarised by the fact that by the end, I was feeling so many wonderful and horrible things that I was completely crying, but so absorbed by the break-neck pace and wonderfully, gorgeously juxtaposing moments of silence that, despite literally not being able to read the page sometimes thanks to those wonderful tears, I kept fucking reading. This book was one of those phenomenal, gorgeously intricate novels in which the language on the page made my head spin and my heart pound and my ears rush and my fingers twitch and my hands cramp and my breath quicken and my eyes spill and so many other fantastically, fantastically human things. Illuminae's words were its own soundtrack, its own music. I was so, so happy to sing along. Read this book. Read it.

Okay, I have a lot of mixed feelings on this book. I think that there were both good and bad parts of this book, and I feel like everything that I liked, I also didn't like. I'm not sure if that makes perfect sense. Basically, I liked the characters--they were fairly interesting to read about and fairly different from one another--but at the same time, they felt very typical of this type of book; the brooding boy who'd suffered, and was artistic and different than everyone else, and the tragic girl who had been through a lot and didn't know how to deal with it. This strange juxtaposition is something that flowed throughout the whole book for me. The plot felt the same way; on the whole, engaging, but at the same time nothing particularly fresh or original; it almost feels like a rewritten draft of a John Green book. Essentially, it wasn't boring to read, but I was invigorated by the freshness of the plot. Again, for the writing--the writing wasn't bad, but it was a bit grandiose in the way that writing in contemporary love stories between two troubled teens tends to be. To reiterate, I didn't dislike the writing, it just had those traces of inflated importance that I feel like plague a lot of books similar to this. The last thing I'm going to comment on about this book is the mental illness part of it. This was one of the main reasons I read the book--mental illness is something I've dealt with for me whole life, and many people around me are in a constant battle with, so I'm infinitely searching for good representation in mainstream books. While I can say that in All the Bright Places, mental illness was definitely represented, I couldn't personally relate to it despite also having depression and anxiety disorders. NOW, that's not to say it is a bad thing--everyone experiences their mental illness in different ways, and that's perfectly fine. The only bit of the mental illness portrayal that I'm still wondering about is if it's glorified. I don't think it's overtly glorified and I actually did feel like the suicide was treated well, and Violet's reaction of anger and sadness is fine  but I do feel like because of the grandiose nature of the story, it makes the suicide and mental health seem somewhat attractive, which I didn't love. That sentiment might not make perfect sense, because I'm still really unsure on whether or not I feel like it's glorified, because in certain ways I think it is, in other ways I think it's not. But essentially, I liked this book, but I didn't love it. It was, as a whole, what I'd expect from this genre, and from the description.

-- 5 stars -- Wow, I really enjoyed this!! I think the plot was so unique and interesting, and really fast-paced! Wren is such a kick-ass character, and I loved her relationship with Callum - and he was SO cute by the way, I'd definetely fall for Callum as well. :P I have to say there was some times that I was just waiting for Callum to get more badass as well, and it was a bit of a dissapointment that it never happened...  But oh well, this was still a great dystopian story, I can't wait to read the next book and see what will happen to the Reboots.

August 2- Even though I've heard that this was the worst book out of the trilogy, I felt like it was the best. Of course, I hated The Hunger Games, but loved the movie. Perhaps the movies shed a different light on the books? Well, whatever the reason, I felt that this was a really great ending to the trilogy. It's still not a great book by itself, but it's good compared to the first book. >I know a lot of reviewers have complained about how Katniss hides for half the book and is generally a wimp. However, I feel like it strengthened her character for her to lose so much. Suzanne Collins did a wonderful job portraying the aftermath of war and how even the posterchild of the rebellion can end up in a bad place. >The epilogue was probably my favorite part of the entire book. I don't want to say it was satisfying exactly, but I felt like it was a good ending. The fact that Katniss doesn't even mention her children's names shows how little she cares now that Prim and Gale  have been taken away from her. The only reason she even has children is to make Peeta happy. She's a truly selfless character--even to a fault. >Now that Katniss has had a chance to share her story, I feel a mighty need for Peeta's side (also Finnick + Annie, Gale, and Katniss's mother).

Pretty good, although I could hear Collins' voice in my head, saying "Everybody loves the Hunger Games, but they're over. What can I dooo?!? I know! I'll redo the games ." And I didn't buy Haymitch's final actions. In a sense, Katniss is about the worst heroine ever. She is good at everything -- even the things (like healing) that she hates -- and everybody loves her and pins their hopes on her, but she is so distracted by her personal worries and the fascination of hunting that she's completely unaware of what's going on around her for the first book, and mostly ignorant (despite copious signs) through the second.

The Way We Fall was a very solid addition to the bloated young adult apocalypse/dystopia genre. The Lives We Lost demonstrated why the fate of the world should never be left in the hands of teenagers (they're nothing but angst and love triangles and poor foresight). The Worlds We Make is the conclusion and has all the same flaws as the second book. I do give a lot of kudos for the covers and the titles of all three books. They are all very lovely and intriguing. Kaelyn and the gang are still on the run from the (evil?) Wardens, who are trying to capture the vaccine for the friendly flu that Kaelyn's father created. Kaelyn is desperate to get the vaccine to the CDC so it can be given to all of humanity. Like in book 2, there's lots of roadtripping, Kaelyn feeling angsty/guilty, and romantic entanglements. The highlight of this book was Kaelyn's conversation with Michael, the supposed Big Bad of the series and the leader of the Wardens. Michael is more of an anti-hero than a true villain. He has consolidated power in his effort to save humanity. The world needs leadership, and he's going to give it, by the gun if necessary. He's not a bad guy, just a guy in desperate circumstances trying to hold things together. I liked this characterization, and kudos to Crewe for not just making the Big Bad evil. Kaelyn's contact with the CDC is more frustrating. The CDC doctor decides, against all better judgment and the Hippocratic Oath, to withhold the vaccine from anyone she deems unworthy. Because that makes sense. When the world has been destroyed, you want to make sure that there is MORE chaos and violence by withholding a necessity from terrified, dying people. As this is obviously a stupid plan, Kaelyn & co. disagree. And actually figure out a solution so that everyone can get the vaccine. Huzzah! So happy endings all around, except for the fact that society is in shambles and there's no getting it back. I predict Michael will continue to be the warlord the Americas need (because even if everyone can get the vaccine, Michael still controls other resources, like food and medicine). But at least Kaelyn can go back and live on her island with Leo, especially since Gav is conveniently dead so she doesn't have to make any difficult decisions about who she should make out with.

AWESOME! I love when crazy people do crazy stuff and then hallucinate about crazy things. The audiobook was beautiful and the dramatization nearly perfection. In the beginning, I was confused if the twist would be something like "Soul Survivors", Les Liaisons Dangereuses or "The Sixth Sense". Actually it was a mix of all of them with a cherry on top!

So I decided to rewrite me review to restate how much I hate this book and why is deserves a spot on my 'ugh' shelf. Now as I said in my original review I only got 1/4 through this book. I thought I could get through this in like two days, maybe three. I mean I was going to be in a motel with slow internet so I might as well get a lot of reading done. Thank god I didn't bring it with me because I hated it before I left the house and opted for Something Like Spring (which turned out to be my favourite as of far in its respective series so that was lucky). But no, this book isn't about a gay character that exists outside of its gayness (though very likeable) like the book I decided to bring instead. I'm coming from this from two perspective, a perspective as not only a lesbian but a feminist. I'll get on why the feminist part matters in a moment. As from the point of view as an actual lgbt person, Ryan Dean could not shut up about how gay the one gay character is (hey authors, please write in gay characters for no reason, we are not plot devices). Literally, every second he appeared Ryan Dean reminded us that this guy is in fact  gay and how  find and dandy that is to him . You know, despite feeling uncomfortable he was alone in a room with him. He pointed it out at the most  unnecessary times, like giving him a high five and calling it the 'best gay-straight high five ever'. Not only that, he made sure to tell us how much of an upstanding heterosexual he was. And that brings in my perspective as a feminist. He made sure to tell us how goddamn hot  every girl he knows is (except for the woman downstairs who is probably a witch). His crush on his best friend was so superficial, I may have only seen a bit of her character but she didn't seem to have anything to her. And since this is from Ryan Dean's perspective, this would mean he only likes her for her looks. I felt like I knew nothing about her. Over all, he just objectified women and it made me so uncomfortable. Oh, and the fact he got so upset she called him 'little boy'. That was irritating and is really why I don't like reading characters under the age of 16. They have this problem, where you can tell how young they are and are just so irritating (there are exceptions obviously but this was a real drawback for this book). I had heard it had a shocking ending and I guessed it and I was so mad that the only gay character was used as a plot device. He seemed to only have the purpose to die and it is so irritating. So don't read this book, and instead read books where lgbt characters are the main character and are well written, characters are likeable, and the gay characters exist outside of their gayness. I'll even make you a fucking list Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe (my favourite book!) Openly Straight (hey another one of my favourite books!) Beauty of the Broken More Happy Than Not Almost Like Falling in Love Proxy duology (sci-fi with gay main character just because) The Something Like series Everything Leads to You One Man Guy

Going between 4 and 5 stars for this one which is a bit strange because if something is amazing for me, well, it is amazing and that is that. I did read this book during a really depressing point in my life-- right after my grandma died who I was really close to-- and it managed to make me laugh, so I am immensely grateful for that, so that is what is giving it 5 stars right now. Just that really personal reason. What about the story is it that would cause it to lack a star? I guess because I expected it to be a little more nerdy than it actually was, first of all. The main character, Cath, is nerdy in that she writes fanfiction for her favorite book series growing up, Simon Snow, which is basically very similar to Harry Potter. She is more introverted and socially awkward than her twin sister, Wren. I relate to loving a book series (Harry Potter), and I am introverted and socially awkward, but I also am a fangirl for several other things. Cath just likes one series while I like a lot more as well as being a nerdy fangirl for TV shows and movie other than Harry Potter. Yes, Cath is a fangirl but not quite in the same way I am. I am more into other sci-fi and fantasy things, and I think that makes me more nerdy. I would've liked it a little more if Cath was just that much more like I am, but overall it isn't a huge deal. I think Cath was written into one fandom to keep it simpler as well as relatable to more readers. Secondly, I don't think an important plot point was fully addressed. There was almost a complete and final confrontation with Cath's and Wren's mother at the hospital, but the mother just runs away and Cath doesn't bother after that. Later, Cath, when talking to her writing professor about the story that she did not write at all yet, freaks out and says it is about her mother. I thought oh okay, we will get a little more resolution from her short story which will somehow reflect her mother, but then her short story ends up being about Wren (though we don't get to read much of it, but the little we do is clearly about Wren.) The whole mom issue is almost resolved when Wren says that she is just on speaking terms with their mom (who she calls Laura and not mom) but their mom doesn't want any sort of motherly relationship. Cath should be hearing this from the mom and not her sister. It just left me unsatisfied. I didn't mean to start it off with my complaints, I did like this book. It made me laugh (as I said) and the love interest is adorable. Though my boyfriend is very different than the love interest in many ways in others I totally can see him do some of the things that the love interest did. I don't read much contemporary, but this is definitely a favorite contemporary since I can relate so much between the fangirling, social awkwardness, and nice love interest, and that is probably the case for several other readers of this book (since fangirls probably have these qualities). The book also deals with several mental health issues very nicely which was unexpected from the plot. I want to say more nice things about this book to equal out my complaints, but really that sums it up quite nicely. Anything that is funny and relatable to me is always a good book. I am sticking with 5 stars.

This was funny and had great character voices--I loved Stephen and Marco's friendship and squabbles. It's like a combination of Winger and The Great Greene Heist? Another way this reminded me of Winger is that I thought it was a Fun Guy Friendship story but SURPRISE IT'S ABOUT HATE CRIMES! Ultimately it's nice to have another good, fun, realistic MG-appropriate story about a gay (multi-racial!) kid in my mental arsenal.

"No one wants to hire an underage, inexperienced, tatted-up Mexican girl. Even McDonald's turned me down." About : Elena Martinez has slipped through the cracks of California's foster care system. Desperate for money and a future, she signs a contract with the corporate tech giant Aether in exchange for money and a college scholarship: time-travel to the future for 24 hours and bring back info about future technology. The only catch? She can't look into her own future. It might mess with her mind or keep her from returning safely home. If she just gets the technology and gets back through the time portal, she'll be set for life. Elena signs up and, of course, ignores the prohibition on researching her fate. But she doesn't expect to find herself enmeshed in the mystery of a murder: her own. YA science-fiction authored by Elizabeth Briggs and published April 1st 2016 by Aw Teen. Thoughts : Future Shock is perfect for romantic sci-fi junkies, and I flew through it despite a few worldbuilding and research goofs. It starts off a little rough, even helped along by Elena's strong, captivating voice. The problem is Elizabeth Briggs' outdated description of the current foster system in California. To give Elena strong motivations and high stakes for accepting Aether's offer, Briggs puts her in a desperate situation: "In two months I'll be kicked out of foster care, forced out of my current home, and most likely will have to drop out of school...Once we turn eighteen, they're done. The instant checks stop coming, we'll be out on the street." Thankfully, I happen to know that this is no longer the case, although it used to be true. My husband works as a juvenile probation officer and he deals every day with kids who've been raised by the CA state system. They do have access to financial and college aid, now, after they reach the age of 18. Elizabeth Briggs is describing the system of a decade ago, in Future Shock. But, hey, this could easily have been set a decade ago, and thankfully the story moves fairly quickly into more plot-relevant terrain. I raced through the story, from here on out, because the pacing never slows and the mystery just gets better and better. After Elena signs on the dotted line, she and four other teens prepare to travel one decade into the future. They will arrive in the future Aether headquarters and have twenty-four hours to gather as much technology as they can. Sounds almost too good to be true...and Elena knows it. She's a street-smart Latina and she asks good questions: Why teenagers? And why foster teenagers, at that? I very rarely found myself ahead of the technical thriller plot. And within the first forty pages, we're in the future! The teenagers are extremely, entertainingly proactive--wandering into shops and exploring the tech--and I love how Briggs imagines the future with lots of cool goodies and sharp edges. Driverless cars rule the road, and they appear to be a government monopoly, as other types of cars were made illegal several years before. Unfortunately, a few notes ring false in this future world, such as the fact that prostitution appears to be legal, but cigarettes are banned. I think a future that legalizes prostitution will likely legalize more drugs instead of criminalizing more, although I could be wrong about that. CA did just make cigarettes illegal under age 21, so perhaps Briggs' future LA is spot on, in this regard. A few other sketchy points jumped out at me. For one thing, a big plot points involves a cure for cancer. It's a nice thought, but I sincerely doubt it's medically feasible that we'll find a generic cure for every kind of cancer. There are too many different kinds . Also, the author has apparently never watched Cops. In several action scenes, her cops seem to lack knowledge of basic police training and strategy. For example, in one instance, the police shoot at teenagers who are running away from them. This would be a major exception to police training, which teaches cops not to shoot at suspects who are running away. In several other instances, these teenagers escape situations in which police could have easily radioed in backup to contain the area. These oversights definitely neutered the action scenes, for me. I was also hoping that Elena's eidetic memory would play a larger role in the book. Considering how the whole first scene is built around her amazing memory, I was expecting more from that angle. Maybe book II will deal with it more. But even when I hit hiccups or areas that could have used further development, I never wanted to stop reading Future Shock. The tech elements are a lot of fun, the pace stays in high gear and the mystery just gets better and better. Every chapter ends with terrific motivations to keep reading. Overall : If you just read fast and don't look too hard at the deets, I guarantee you'll have a good time with Future Shock. I do have high hopes for a high-concept series or trilogy. I loved the premise, the mystery, the Latina narrator, the lightning pace, the imaginative setting of a futuristic LA...I hope this series continues. It's a good thing. I'll probably pick up book II, at some point. Recommended To : This can be a great, fast read for romantic-sci-fi junkies. For someone who has stuck mostly to Fantasy, this YA sci-fi thriller could be something really new and fun. Thanks so much to Elizabeth Briggs, AW Teen and Netgalley for this e-ARC! If you liked this review, you can read more of my speculative fiction reviews on my blog

Well, I think that this novel is one that I can qualify as having a good idea in principle, but bad in execution. Thirteen Reasons Why is a novel that displays the effects that we all have on different people through the suicide of the main character, Hannah Baker. After her suicide, she proceeds to send out 13 reasons why she did it on cassette tapes, and each person who supposedly caused her to kill herself receives these tapes and they are then supposed to send them on to the next person. So how does this idea work in practice? Well, it has some flaws. First, the good in the story: With the exception of the cassette taps being used, the rest of the book feels timeless. I could read this book ten years from now and it would still sound like how teens talk and act, for the most part (we'll get to that later). Then there is the message. This novel's depiction of how actions have consequences is displayed well, certainly better than other books I've read that try to tackle the same subject. Then there is the confusing portions of this novel. The premise is one that just makes me scratch my head as to how it was to be accomplished. Firstly, we know that Hannah Baker says, early on, that each person must listen to the tapes, and then send them on to the next person to listen to them. If they do not, then a 2nd copy of the tapes will be made very public. My only questions is, how would someone know if they listened to all the tapes? That is briefly mentioned in the novel, but it has too many plot holes to count And considering what happens at the end of the novel, which I won't spoil, I would say it is a good thing that these tapes re released. But that leads me into question number two: if the tapes are released, so what? What is to stop the people named from lying, or spinning what she said? She is not around to be questioned, so how would this be seen as evidence in an open court? I'm no expert on the subject, but it seems like it would have been better had Hannah told someone about what happened to her/seen by her. And that leads me to Hannah herself. Now, before I get into her, let me say that, so far as I know, I have little to no experience with suicide. I do not know anyone who has tried to commit suicide, nor have I tried to do so myself. Killing one's self is never the answer, and if you or anyone you know wants to kill themselves, then you should get help, either by calling the Suicide Prevention hotline, or by talking to someone who can help you. With all that said, the way Hannah is portrayed here, it felt like, with the exceptions of a few 'reasons', I felt that her killing herself seemed an overreaction. Before you grab your pitchforks and torches, let me explain. In another book I've read, Speak by Laurie Halse Anderson, the main character Melinda has something horrible happen to her at a party. She then does not tell anyone what happened to her, and she is then bullied at school because she called the cops on that party and everyone got in trouble as a result. In that book, her attempting suicide is an unwanted, but not a surprising reaction, because, not only can she not escape from the event of what happened to her, but she must also endure the constant bullying at school and her parents unstable marriage at home. Here on the other hand, many of the things Hannah goes through that she lists as reasons seem somewhat trivial by comparison. She and her friend break up, rumors are spread about her at one point, and she gets passed a note that makes a comment about her body that could be considered embarrassing. Things like these make up a majority of the list of reasons. As for the other more extreme reasons, well, these are actually hurtful, and they may cause a person emotional, physical and psychological pain. However, she does almost nothing to tell anyone about what happened to her. With the exception of the very end of the book, she tells no one about what has happened, and even when she does it is in the most vaguest of terms. And she does not even give that confidant a chance to help her. Lastly, regarding Hannah, there is the event of the end of the book, and how it is written from her perspective. I guess that I'll have to tell you what happened for it to make sense, so I'll do so in a spoiler section. Hannah witnesses her ex-best friend Jessica be raped at a party. Jessica herself does not know that it happened because she was passed out at the time. During the sexual assault, Hannah does not do anything to stop it because she is to scared to do so. . After the event detailed above, Hannah is still written like she is the victim that we should be sympathetic towards, even after, so far as we know, she has done nothing to tell the police about what happened. I'm sorry, but this makes me dislike her SO much. I don't know if she was written that way on purpose, but here Hannah comes off a selfish and uncaring. I don't care how many rude notes you get, or how many bad rumors are spread about you. You lose sympathy points with me when you not only don't tell anyone about what you witnessed, but you also still say that the girl listed above is one of the reasons for your suicide. That does not fly with me. In the end, I liked what this novel was trying to do, but many of the reasons to me seemed trivial to me, and I also found major holes in how she was going to spread the tapes of her reasons for her suicide around. Still, as I understand it, I am in the minority. If this book helped you in some way, great, that is excellent and I am glad that you are better off for it. For me however, there was never anything for me to latch on to, and it is for that reason, and those listed above, that I give this book a two out of five. Still, I would consider this a case of 'it's not you it's me" syndrome. If you think this book might interest you, then by all means, check it out. It just didn't work for me.

I'm struggling with getting my feelings about this on paper. As a child, I loved the Giver. As an adult, I still love the Giver. I feel like it was such an integral part of my growing up, that I can't fully put it into words. I think the reason why it was so important to me was party due to the ambiguous ending, and how it left it up to the reader as to if it was a positive or a negative. That said, I was pleasantly surprised with how much I loved the companion novels, Gathering Blue and Messenger. I will admit, I did see the religious parallels that other reviews have mentioned, and that may have turned me off a bit, but that's my own issue, and it is not overtly done. Well, Matty sacrificing himself at the end of the Messenger for the good of the community was a bit Messiah-esque. Especially considering he died in a crucifixion style pose in the dirt. Gabriel and his angel of God name, vanquishing Evil with compassion. Yeah, I see the allegory. I was excited to see how the stories all matched up in the end, with Gathering Blue seeming the most off topic of the three. I absolutely fell in love with the character Claire. She was lovingly fleshed out in the beginning, and I could easily relate to her - but maybe only because I am an adult; most teens aren't yearning for their children. Returning the story to the original community was a surprise to me- it took me a while to catch on, but it was a throwaway line about the aging ceremonies and how some children were graduating to jackets that buttoned in the front that finally clued me in. I struggled with how everything was wrapped up so neatly at the end, and that seems to be a theme present in a lot of the reviews I've skimmed. I give this four stars for the reason that it serves as a satisfying conclusion. But the part of Lowry's writing that I enjoy is missing. She answers too many questions. She completes the thoughts for us. The reader has little to ask or wonder in the end. Too tidy. As a writer she allows for the questions to linger. I think that's the power in her writing. But it also felt so much like a long awaited reunion. It is a satisfying closure to a long journey. I will say, that out of all the books, the characters that I wanted to read more about were Einar and Claire. Einar... never have I been so in love with a character. My heart hurts thinking of him and his sheep, missing Claire and living out his lonely little life. I'm happy Claire and Gabe were reunited, but throw a dog a bone, will you?

Inevitably, this book will be compared to The Fault in Our Stars. Both came out in early 2012 and both are about teens with cancer. However, besides these few similarities, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl and TFIOS are very, very different. While TFIOS is a deep and emotional read, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is hilarious and light. And when I say hilarious, I mean seriously funny. It is a universally acknowledged truth that high school sucks. In fact, high school is where we are introduced to the basic existential question of life: How is it possible to exist in a place that sucks so bad? See what I mean? Greg Gaines, the "Me", is fantastic. Not only is he funny as all hell, I could easily see him actually existing somewhere in some high school out in the world, unlike many male characters in YA novels these days, like Augustus Waters.
