(I still love you, Gus!) He's only out for himself and wants absolutely nothing to do with Rachel and her leukemia. In fact, he mainly only spends time with her to make himself feel better. Rachel, the "dying girl", and her leukemia do not actually take center stage. A lot of it is glossed over, and mostly when we see her, she is very quiet. I think the author purposefully didn't let the reader get too attached to Rachel to keep this book lighter and less depressing. In that way, it's very much different from TFIOS. While I wouldn't totally describe this book as "light and fluffy", it is very funny and keeps from being your typical depressing cancer books. If you're looking for something lighter and more realistic than TFIOS, Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is for you!

Basically during this whole book I was eying each page and waiting for them to die. plot Honestly?? The middle kind of lagged for me. The writing was great, the characters was great, but the plot wasn't that exciting until the ending. It mainly consisted of Mateo and Rufus walking around the city (and at one point, they go to a restaurant and eat chicken and stuff. BUT WHY DIDN'T THEY EAT EVERYTHING??? THIS I DO NOT UNDERSTAND. IF I HAD ONE DAY TO LIVE I WOULD PIG OUT??????) And while Mateo is pretty much a smol boy who is precious, that doesn't mean I want to read about him crossing the road and everything? characters MY CINNAMON ROLLS. Especially Penny. Or Penny's mom. I FORGOT WHAT HER NAME IS. (I love the mom who Mateo is best friends with!! AHH!! She is great and everything and can we make a spinoff about her please?) MATEO. Ahhhh he is so nice and quiet and he liked staying indoors. (Samee.) He was just so cautious and carefree and I loved his character development. He became more carefree and less cautious as the book went on. He never really felt like he's LIVED his life, but after that day he has experienced love, friendship, jumping off a cliff into water, skydiving (although that was virtual reality) and content. RUFUS. He kind of annoyed me sometimes?? At the beginning of the book, he felt so possessive about Aimee, his ex-girlfriend that it was just... like. no. Aimee had broken up with him, and although Adam's writing let me empathize with him, I didn't understand how he could beat up Peck (Aimee's current boyfriend at the start of the book). He might have KILLED Peck. Killed. Killed. Killed. Excuse me???????????? The character development was GREAT, though. It just.. ahhh. It made Rufus so kind and he started caring for others, and not just doing things for himself. His connection with the smol bean Mateo was so sweet, as was his family- The Plutos. During the book he kept on snapping photos of things and posting them to Instagram and while that's relatable (and useful at the end of the book since Mateo's dad is probably eventually able to learn about what they did but STILLLLL ) WHAT THE HECK ARE YOU DOING, MATEO??? YOU'RE GOING TO DIE AND YOU'RE ON INSTAGRAM?? writing Adam's writing also included some chapters where it showed snippets of others' lives. And honestly I did not enjoy those. WHO IS THIs RANDOM PERSON NAMED DELILAH. I DO NOT CARE IF SHE TALKS TO HOWIE? However, his actual writing style was great and flowy and I LOVED IT. It pulled me in at the first chapter. overall I mean.. read this book, I guess.

I really, really enjoyed this book, but unfortunately there were a few things that stopped me giving it the full 5 stars. These all somewhat followed the same theme - lack of clarity, and slightly forced writing. Firstly, there was the issue of Dane. It is made very apparent that he is "bad" - but more because we are told this, than from being led to really feel this way. There's a reason "show, not tell" is so often cited as a rule of good writing! I found his rather sudden, violent attack on Jenna  a surprise, and not a "wow, that was a significant plot-twist" sort of a surprise, but more of a "why exactly did that just happen?" moment. Also, Jenna's romantic relationship with Ethan  seemed forced, like it was happening because that's what the author wanted to happen, rather than through the characters' actual desires. There was no chemistry between them. However, the story was captivating and thought-provoking enough to keep me hooked, and I would happily read it again. I'll probably read the sequel too, just to see what happens to her dead friends...

I feel kinda guilty about the two star rating. I loved this book's writing a lot, I liked the premise, and I liked the setting (I love Seattle), but I had a hard time getting into it. I didn't find myself connecting to the characters, or caring about them very much, so it wasn't the type of book I was dying to get back to. A good portion of the time I had to make myself pick it up, even though I really enjoyed the author's writing. Also, I'm not a fan of open endings. They bother me a lot. I think that's what pushed this book from a 3 or 2.5 to a 2. All in all, I can totally see why some people would really like this book. But it just wasn't for me.

Loved to read this book, even better than the first installment. First of all I think it's an interesting concept, to introduce after a patriarchic society a matriarchic society, to reveal that both in fact are evil - justice is if men and women are both equal. The injustice of the matriarchic felt even more real and harsh, as you are not used to it. Describe anything you want for a patriarchic society and the reader will believe it in a heartbeat, because in the end this is history and well, the the present too (woops by feminist view came out, sorry). I liked the humor, the plot and the characters. I liked how morally grey everything was. Nothing is more disappointing to me than if the main character is always 'stalwart and true'. Gaia really gets to think about her action, and sometimes none of them seem to be ok. Even though some of the reviewers don't understand Leons POV, I can. He goes to hell for this girl, probably idolizes her while those months while they don't see each other and when he finally does, she's not the big damn hero anymore. Ouch, that must sting. So I am very interested in how the story continues. Will there be a happy ending? As the author does not fear character deaths, I feel everything is open. I particularly I guess we should watch out for the younger brother...a spurned love is an incalculable thing and the people are on the verge of rioting...still. Hope the story does not end predictably - Leon dies a hero's death and sacrifices himself for Gaia, which ends up heartbroken but still marrying Will. Something like that. OR: She solved the puzzle in the 1st book wrong and Leon is in fact her brother. They share more similarities and the brother she discovered looked nothing like her parents. Besides rioting in the enclave, Gaia now also has to lead a whole town to the desert. Has something like religious leader, right? While this is always the point with YA books - they try to make the MC so plain that the reader can still identify them, although they need to be special enough to make them an MC after all. Here it is done by giving her a scar, a good story behind it to. The job as a midwife, the authority that comes with it and the courageous action she takes when she sees something wrong make her unique.

This is a reread. You can find my 2015 review below. 2016 Review. Still two stars. UNDER THE NEVER SKY is one of those books that I really want to like, for some inexplicable reason. I know that I love the atmosphere of the story, and I know that I love the potential. But on the whole, the execution itself just falls flat for me. Maybe this is a personal issue, but I just can't see past all the weaknesses in the plot. However, that being said, it does feel rather weird to rate this book only two stars, since I don't dislike it. In fact, I would probably rate the experience of reading it closer to three stars, which is what I usually give a book I love but have major issues with, versus two stars, which is what I give a book I mostly hated. But again, I can't quite see past all the major flaws in the story itself, despite my enjoyment, and I think it would be more honest to rate this one according to the merit I see in the story, rather than the enjoyment I get from it. If that makes any sense. I realize my rating system is horribly inconsistent, and I'm sorry. I am trying to find a good middle ground so I don't confuse anyone, but it may take some time and some tweaking. I still would recommend this book to people who love dystopian literature, because I do think it captures some of the important elements that I love in dystopians. Again, this is probably just a personality thing, so if you want to read this book, by all means, do so. My rating is rather an unpopular opinion anyway, and I'm aware of that. I have the two sequels now, and I plan to read those soon. Hopefully I will enjoy those more. I do think Veronica Rossi has a lot of potential as an author, and I do plan to keep up with her writing as best as I can. Content Warning. Two of the characters do have sex in a rather vague, non-explicit scene. 2015 Review. Two stars. On the whole, I don't think UNDER THE NEVER SKY lives up to its potential. While there were things I genuinely liked about it, I spent most of the book feeling disinterested and disappointed. I mean, the first bit of action with Aria is great and I was all excited for a sci-fi, dystopian with lots of mental landscapes and hordes of people who can't bear reality. Then the narrative switched to Peregrine's view point, and I just got kind of...bored. Sure, he's a cool guy who can smell people's emotions and see well in the dark. Plus he's hot (according to Aria). What's not to like about him? But he lives in a village and hunts for a living and deals with typical medievalish problems. That's not to say I don't like stories about that sort of thing, but I was expecting UNDER THE NEVER SKY to be techy and cool and futuristic. I was not prepared for chickens and blood lords and savages with weird super senses. Probably this is my fault, because if I had read enough about the book before I started, I would have known what I was getting into. My bad. However, I was thrown off for other reasons as well. The romance is creepy and weird, and the transformation between "I hate you" to "I love you" hinges on a rather superficial event. Not to mention, it's a tad upsetting to know Perry can smell all of Aria's emotions (and he won't stop sniffing her #awkward). Give poor Aria a little privacy, please and thank you. What disappointed me the most, though, was the dystopian element itself. For one thing, Perry's culture, which takes up most of the book, doesn't feel hugely dystopian. I mean, sure, Perry and his brother (who happens to be in charge) don't get along, and the Aether might possibly torch the place, and the people might starve. But none of those things are characteristically dystopian, in the strictest sense--they just happen to be obstacles in the way of happily ever after. For another thing, I wanted to spend more time in the Pods. The people of Reverie (one of the Pods), always wear Smarteyes, devices that allow them to live in hundreds of virtual realms while they go about their daily lives. Aria has been told that people began using Smarteyes as means of entertainment because the Pods are super boring. But that feels like an overly simplistic answer. I want to know why people chose unproductive technology over other forms of entertainment, such as invention and industry and physical play. I want to know the deep hurts in society--the roots of this issue. The Smarteyes--the need to constantly daydream and the fulfillment thereof--are a symptom, and I want to know the cause. Rossi doesn't dwell on that. Maybe she expands the sci-fi and psychological elements further in the rest of the trilogy (which I do plan to read at some point), but I would have appreciated a more solid first book.

*4.5 stars* There's a lot to love about this book! Simon is a high school junior, gay but not out, who has the misfortune of leaving his email open on a school computer. Martin takes advantage of the email he reads to blackmail Simon into playing matchmaker. This email? It's to "Blue," a young man also going to the high school, for whom Simon has a LOT in common. But Blue is far from being comfortable with coming out, much less letting Simon know who he actually is. I really liked Simon, "Blue," Simon's friends, and his sisters. Everyone was interesting and authentic, with even Martin showing there was more to him than evil blackmailer (not that that excuses blackmailing. Nope nope nope). They're into drama, rehearsing for a play, and Simon's still adjusting to one sister leaving for college, and the other being largely unavailable. There's also Abby, a newcomer to Simon's group of friends, straight from DC and full of ideas (and songs! I liked the romance between Simon and "Blue," and how most people had Simon's back  when the blackmailing inevitably went sour, and Simon was outed at school and home . What did make me uncomfortable, and turned this from a 5 star read to a 4 1/2 star one, was Simon's surprise that "Blue" ended up being Gram, soccer player extraordinaire and person of color. I DID like that Simon examined this bias, just for a moment. But then there were many, many descriptions of Gram's brown skin, how tantalizing this looked from a pair of torn jeans, how much Simon liked his skin, that felt a tad like exoticism. That said, Gram isn't the only POC in this diverse cast of characters, so maybe this deserves a pass . Overall, I really enjoyed this book. It was a refreshing change from all the grim psychological thrillers I've been reading lately!

This is a laughably silly and implausible dystopian world, that doesn't even seem to have an internally consistent set of rules -  just one e.g. you can choose your faction against your natural aptitude, so why is there such a focus on people in each faction thinking and acting in predictable ways? . However, it's also fun, action-packed, and a fast read.

Holy wow. I liked Unwind but I liked UnWholly even more. As the second book in a series, it is amazing. I'm in awe of Shuesterman's talent in creating such a complex, intricate world and such complex and interesting characters. Seriously. IN AWE. I loved loved loved the Cam/Risa story line. Then ending of the book gave me goosebumps! I can't wait to see what Cam does in the next book.

I read the reviews that my GR friends wrote about Panic -- and even though I didn't look at the blurb between deciding to buy it and reading it (only three months but my memory is terrible), I do agree that the blurb is quite bad compared to what the book is actually about. Sure, it says that Panic is a game that is played... but the blurb does not capture any of the outright terror that Panic causes... the adrenaline rushes that the reader feels along with the contestants. Nor does the blurb really talk at all about how very dangerous Panic can be. I really enjoyed Panic, but I kind of wish that it hadn't ended quite so abruptly. I loved the final image -- when Heather won Joust, survived the bomb that she didn't know was in the car, and stood there with her hand on Anne's lost tiger's head. It just seemed so... fitting. Now I'm curious about Lauren Oliver's other books... :) Definitely recommend.

I'm a writer. And when I read a book, I often notice little writery tricks. I can see where the story is going, and I can appreicate it on a technical level. But, what sets a story/book apart for me, is its ability to make me forget I'm a writer. Make me forget it's following certain paths that stories take. Make me hope and wish for something that the logical part of my brain knows can't happen. Make me forget I'm reading a story but instead glimpsing a slice of some other place. Flesh & Bone did this. This was the follow up to Rot & Ruin I wanted Dust & Decay to be. R&R wowed me with story craft, clever characters, and a brutal world I wanted to see more of. Flesh & Bone took me there emotionally. I hung on the edge of each page, devouring the story. While not a perfect piece of literature, there is something raw and powerful in this book. And crazy cults help too. The book starts one month after the events of Dust & Decay and happens over the course of a very eventful day. Characters struggle with depression, zombies, and crazy death cults, all with a hint that maybe, just maybe their quest isn't worthless. The fact that the events in this book took place over a day didn't bother me. (Usually it does.) This is primarily due to the POV shifts throughout the book. I do have one complaint: I really didn't care for the POV of our villains and various cult members. I sort of wonder if it was padding to expand the story. But I do think that because the book is a record of the course of a single day that keeps it from suffering the middle book syndrome that drove me nuts in Dust & Decay. It's the time frame that makes it a complete book, though, there's clearly still story to tell. Flesh & Bone also recaptured what I loved most about Rot & Ruin - the world building. We've finally expanded beyond the borders of the Nine Towns and a small part of California. We learn that there is much moving in the world, and the world is struggling to continue. These details are so well constructed that it makes me excited just to know more. More of this world Benny, Nix, Chong, and Lilah inhabit. But what really brings Book 3 into the spotlight is how it excellently handles the themes of grief. Everyone around them is dying, and they are struggling to keep a float. There are many who keep strong, and many who succumb to darker desires. It's so beautifully portrayed and it gets to some of the core of being human. The will to live. And isn't that what zombie books are about? Though, I did learn that the thing I hate most about zombie stories is that someone has to die. And I knew from chapter 1, that it was going to be Chong. Chong's death and Sanctuary are so beautiful, so moving, it's hard for me to describe. I get misty-eyed just thinking about it. When does the next one come out? Please tell me soon. (Probably not.)

i still don't understand how she claims to "love" Gabriel and vice versa. There is still no connection between them. No chemistry whatsoever. just STOP STOP STOP with the BS and everyone swooning over Gabriel.... um he has no depth or personality at all. how in the world can you all love him so much? I KNOW i'm not the only one who noticed that. you honestly know NOTHING about him from the books. and the "he loves rhine for who she is" stuff makes me laugh. at no point in the book was there any kind of revelation or connection showing some deep love between them. Everything in the book was so predictable, with the exception of  Linden dying   and let's face it, that came completely out of left field. of ALL the things that could happen  he dies crash landing in an airplane? at least make it something even remotely related to the plot of the story. WTH is up with that? and of course stupid Rhine blames herself, when in all actuality it was Cecily's fault. The villain ended up not even being a villain at all, and yet  he still ends up getting killed off, too Cecily is STILL an obnoxious little brat that I want to hit upside the head. I knew that  Madame was rose's mother   before they even said it, because it was just that damn predictable. i'm just so disappointed because I really wanted to like these books, but quite frankly, they just sucked.

I received a free copy via edelweiss for review purposes. I was initially drawn to One because of the cover, because it is lovely. Then I read the synopsis and I knew I needed this book in my life. I'm a twin myself, though not conjoined, but I really did feel connected to both Grace and Tippi. One is an emotional and moving story of two totally connected girls. It is written in verse, which is a first for me, and so One is a quick and easy read - but tissues are required. Tippi and Grace share everything, even their body. They've lived their entire lives together, so being so close is normal for them. They don't know any different. And they love each other, so why risk separation when it is so dangerous? But then their bodies are fighting against them and they have no choice but to face up to the thing they have been avoiding their entire lives. It is rare I find a book that captures the essence of twins so honestly and realistically. I'm not conjoined, and I don't know what it is like. But I do know what it is like to have that one person you are so undeniably close to. That you don't know what you would do without them. In that respect, I totally understood Grace and Tippi. How much they adored each other. So naturally that ending left me in tears because it was such a horrible thing to happen and I feel for Grace so much. I don't want to say much else for fear of spoiling so I'm jut going to stay how much I loved this book. Such a great, honest, raw and moving account of two girls who can't live without each other.

It's been a long time, probably since I read The Hunger Games, that I blew through a book so quickly. I couldn't put it down! I love dystopian and/or post-apocalyptic stories anyway, but this was one of the best I've read. It was dark because of the actions of the Erudite and how they used the Dauntless  but it wasn't dark like, say, The Hunger Games where children are systematically and dogmatically placed in danger for the sick amusement of the masses. I am starting the next book right away, and plan to burn through the rest of the trilogy in no time.

What I Liked These days, a young adult novel written in third person is difficult to find. And Lauren Oliver nailed this POV. Panic is not a sci-fi, dystopian story. It's set in a real-world small town that is riddled with relative poverty and all the issues that come along with that. The characters living in Carp are realistic and tangible. Even the kindest characters Anne  have deeply-etched flaws. The character development in this novel is striking and intensely psychological. I appreciated how Panic portrayed life in a poor, small town. Everyone is desperate and struggling, unable to get by and also unable to get away. $67,000 means everything to a teen who has no chance of a better future without some kind of stepping stone. Nat's story was perhaps the most compelling of the entire novel. What I Didn't Like Even though the intense depth of the characters in Panic was amazing, I never actually liked any of them very much. Instead of finding myself rooting for a winner of the games, I found myself distracted by the extreme selfishness and foolishness in every single character I encountered. There never seemed to be a pure motivation behind anyone's actionsuntil Bishop announcing why he was judge, but even that caused extreme property damage and injury that the reader was basically supposed to ignore . I found myself irritated with Heather, Nat, Bishop, and Dodge more than I found myself rooting for any of them. At times, the challenges seemed a little too extreme to be real, especially if this is an annual thing that police had never stopped before. Burning a house down? Playing Russian Roulette? Really?

This book isn't fun, it isn't happy and it isn't nice. But this book gripped me hard and didn't let me go until I finished it. It's incredibly disturbing, dark, and sad. But it's also so important. Only Ever Yours Sketches a world where women are treated as objects and used only for sex and creating children. They're raised from birth for this role and their entire life is shaped around being as attractive and obedient as possible. They grow up in a world where they're constantly judged for their looks, compared to eachother, and shamed for being "weak" or different. A lot of what happens in this fictional world strikes awfully close to home, it's a lot like our world in many ways and that's what makes this book so very important. I want to tell everyone to read this but it does come with a warning. Do not read this book if you're triggered by rape, sexual assault, or eating disorders. The weight loss comes up a lot and it gets really disturbing. (spoiler for another trigger that doesn't come up until the very end:  suicide  ) Also, do not count on a happy ending.

I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this one. I can't remember the last time I read a book this modern and found myself as invested as I would be a fantasy book. Granted, by no means was a this a contemporary. This is a weird mixture of sci-fi, modern young adult love, and historical fiction and somehow it works. The author does a really making sure you don't get lost in all the different dimensions or feel overwhelmed by all the jumping around, which I feel is commendable considering how easily it would be to get lost in a plot like this. I also really enjoyed how she started this book and introduced you the world and its characters. You're thrown right into the action and the history you need filters in later, very timely and cleverly, I might add. My favorite aspect of this book had to be in the Russian bit. Which doesn't surprise me one bit because I have an extreme fascination with royals and anything excluding modern technology. But more than that, the characters that were introduced in that portion of the book were wonderful and this was the part that got the most emotionally invested in the story. I loved Lieutenant Markov. If I had to choose between him and actual Paul, right now, I'd pick him. And I was so shocked and upset when he died. I felt so bad for the Grand Duchess and it took me a second to read on after that. I hated leaving that dimension so quickly after the fact. I really hope we get to go back to that dimension somehow. If only to see how those characters were affected by what actually happened. The only thing that kept me from giving this a full five star rating is the romance. Don't get me wrong the romance is good and I do love Paul. It's just... complicated. The whole I'm in love with this Paul who might be my Paul but isn't really and I can't be with my Paul because I'm still mourning the Russian Paul even though technically he wasn't mine to love because he loved the Grand Duchess. It's a little strange and I hope she gets over it fast. You'll have to read it to understand but I have a feeling I'm in for a long, drawn out bit of pinning and pain until the end of the series. Authors really do love to torture their readers. Overall, I really did like this book. It was a good break from the heavy fantasy I've been reading lately while still keeping enough of the unbelievable element as not to bore me with standard contemporary. This book is really just fun and perfect story to just go along for the crazy ride.

Even though I've really enjoyed Kimberly Derting's other novels, The Taking ended up being a middle of the road read for me. Even though the premise sounded like something that would be perfect for me, there were little things about the characters and their reactions that really put a damper on things. That said, the ending was strong enough that I am very curious about where the story will go and will probably read the next one for that reason. While I'd love to say it took a while, The Taking went sideways on me almost immediately. Kyra gets into a fight with her father and insists that he let her out of the car in the middle of a highway. And he complies. What? Who is the authority figure in this relationship? If I was throwing a tantrum, 18 or not, my parents would never have let me out on the side of a highway. I don't know anyone else whose parents would have either. It just started the novel out on the complete wrong foot for me. Then, almost immediately after this fight when Kyra wakes up 5 years later, she ends up falling for her now ex-boyfriend's little brother. Most of you probably know how I feel about sibling triangles. HATE. Hate, hate, hate. And then when you consider that from Kyra's perspective, she was dating her ex-boyfriend just yesterday that makes it so much worse. She was convinced she was going to marry him, and while high school relationships hardly ever last, even though she is upset that he's gone she moves on pretty quickly with HIS BROTHER. Ew. Aside from the issues I had relating to the character's actions, I did really like the plot. The mystery behind Kyra's disappearance was interesting, and I wan't expecting it to work out the way it did. Can't say that much more about it without ruining the plot, but it definitely saved the book for me. Even though I was really frustrated with the characters throughout the entire novel, the plot did a pretty good job of redeeming the novel. I'll be able to look past my frustrations and pick up the next book because I'm genuinely curious about what will happen next.

Okay, so I loved this. I have a bit of a weird relationship with John Green's book. I really like him as a person and enjoy watching his videos, but his books... Looking for Alaska and Paper Towns were just okay to me and I absolutely hated An Abundance of Katherines. I loved TFioS when I first read it, but reviews etc have made me wonder whether I'd still like it if I ever reread it. This book, though, was really great. The star of this book was without a doubt the descriptions of Aza's mind. It was fascinating and terrifying and it felt entirely real. Aza is very different from me, but I did recognise a lot of her thoughts about her mental state and the consequences of it. Like not being able to control your thoughts and the fear that it's never going to get any better. I loved that the consequences for the people around her were also discussed. Because yes, mental illness can make someone self centered. And yes, relationships with people with mental illness can be hard. This was really shown in Aza's relationships with Daisy and Davis. The friendship with Daisy was great, I love how that was explored. I really liked Davis and Aza together but I loved that they didn't end up together. I don't think Aza was ready for the kind of relationship Davis wanted and sometimes it's just better to not stay in each other's lives, even if you love each other. Their relationship was just a part of Aza's story and I loved that. I didn't care all that much about the plot concerning where Davis' dad was, except for what it meant for the characters. The mystery really wasn't the point anyway, though. Just a base to tell this story around. There were a few small things that bugged me a little: - Davis giving Aza 100.000 dollars felt weird. It was basically hush money and I didn't really know how to feel about that. - Aza didn't consistently take her meds for most of the book. Overal the book was positive about medication, which was great, but it always frustrates me when a character doesn't take her meds and then says they're not working. But I guess that was part of her journey. I absolutely loved the ending. No magical fixes, no unrealistic romantic bliss, no bullshit. Just life. The good and the bad of life. Beautifully narrated by an older Aza who found happiness in her life while still struggling with her mind. It's realistic and hopeful and I loved it. The audio for this was really great too. Especially the parts where we're inside Aza's head and she's arguing with her intrusive thoughts. Those scenes were really intense to hear out loud. Oh my god, that scene in the hospital was so hard to listen to. All in all, a beautiful book I can definitely see myself rereading.

Don't get me wrong: this was a very good book, but I felt that it had a lot of potential which was not fully used. THE GOOD: The DIVERSITY! Oh, how I love diverse YA books. In this, we have a plus size girl of colour and a gay protagonist, whose whole characterisation is not based solely on his sexuality. There is also a young Polish boy. The characters themselves were quite likeable, particularly Tomasz the young Polish boy and Gudmund to begin with (before he slept with Monica  ). I also found myself really liking and sympathising with Seth's dad. The BEGINNING! Oh my gosh, what an intriguing way to start a story. It ensures you are engrossed straight away and remains that way. The writing style in this book was perfect. It was to the point and avoided becoming too descriptive in order to sustain an air of suspense. The subsequent plot twist that is revealed was also intriguing and full of potential, which I feel was not properly used, bringing me on to... THE BAD: As you may have noticed, the main character (Seth) was not on my list of likeable characters and that's because he seemed like such a shadow. I disliked Seth. I felt nothing towards him. If anything happened to him, I didn't feel any sadness or worry. He didn't have much of a personality apart from the fact that he moaned and whined a lot. He felt more like a detached narrator than the person whose point of view this story was being told from. I found the first part of the book where Seth is alone and confused  really boring and repetitive, only enjoying the flashbacks he had. After Seth finds Tomasz and Regine, though, things started to get far more interesting . After that we find out far more, but there is still so much that is left unanswered:  why were Seth and Regine alone in their houses but no one else was? Will the driver come back? If not, who is going to look after the people who are online if something goes wrong?. I guess the answer is supposed to be that life does not always have the answers, however I felt as thought there was just no closure. Despite the negatives this was an incredibly engaging book, shown by the fact that I am writing this review retrospectively and I still remember almost all of what happened. This is an encouraging sign of a memorable story, for which Ness is gifted for writing. He disallows his ideas to leave your mind and has you constantly questioning things even after you've left the world of his book. (TOOK ME SO LONG TO FINALLY WRITE THIS HAHAH OOPS)

Seriously dunno what to think.. This was my reaction to most of this novel. While the concept of this book tackles a philosophical issue, is it possible to still be alive and conscious in a divided state? I along with the three heroes of this book thought being unwound (having your body more or less cut up and your body parts used on other people) meant death for sure. But it was revealed at the end when a lot of people with the parts of one boy came together and all the people experienced the feelings and thoughts of the unwound boy. So Neal obviously thinks it's possible to live in a divided state . Even with this book being "right up my street", I didn't enjoy it that much. Or at least not as much as everyone else. I felt like it went on for too long, especially at the Graveyard. But this book promises a real "change the world" adventure with more epicness to come. So, while I found the conclusion of this book a little far fetched, it definitely had me wondering and thinking about what unwinding would do to one's soul... So I will continue reading this series... Eventually.

Possible trigger warnings: abuse*, teen pregnancy, suicide*, transphobia, cancer, parental death* *these don't happen during the course of the book, but are mentioned This review was originally posted on my blog. Why have I not read Emery Lord's writing before?! I own two of her other books and yet this is the first time I'm actually reading something she's written. Let me say, though, that will certainly be fixed very soon. After reading The Names They Gave Us, I have fallen in love with Emery Lord's writing and will definitely be reading more by her. I'll admit that I was a little nervous that the religious aspects would ruin it for me. I'm an atheist and tend to get annoyed if books (or any other media) try to push religious beliefs. But I'm very happy to say that this ended up being a totally unnecessary fear. Lucy is religious, yes, and it does play a role in the book, but the book never felt "preachy" to me. None of the religious characters try to push their faith on other people which I really appreciated. I actually really enjoyed reading about Lucy's faith and felt her questioning of it felt real and authentic. As you might expect with a book that takes place at a camp for troubled kids, there are some tough subjects that come up. Off the top of my head, some of the topics that I remember coming up were abuse, suicide, transphobia, and parental death (I promise I'm not spoiling anything by mentioning these). I felt that all of these subjects were handled pretty well (although I'm not really the best person to talk about most of these issues). They aren't done for shock value nor are they handled insensitively. They're really just a part of these characters and help explain why some of them act the way they do. This cast of characters is 100% what really made this book for me. All of the characters are so wonderful in their own ways. The other camp counselors are especially great, as they're all so supportive of each other and of the campers. Lord really wrote some fantastic friendships in this. The characters are pretty diverse too. There are several POC in the main group as well as a trans girl. Racism doesn't really become incorporated into the book, but transphobia is mentioned at times, but again, I didn't notice any big issues with how it was handled (but like I mentioned, I'm not the best person to speak on that as I'm cis). There were some pretty funny little comments made, especially when Lucy first arrives at the camp and the others are trying to figure out what kind of person she is - is she judgmental? accepting? They aren't really sure what to expect from her and seeing the characters try to figure her out was quite entertaining at times. One thing that could have been improved is the way the whole "family secrets" thing was handled. It's not that it was portrayed poorly, but it really didn't come into play until the very end of the novel. Based on the blurb, I expected it to be more integrated into the story and so I was a little thrown off by how late in the book it actually comes up. I'll also admit it's pretty easy to figure out what the big secret is if you know to look for clues. Ultimately, though, I loved the story we got so much that I really didn't care. I cannot close out this review without mentioning how much I adored the romance between Lucy and a fellow counselor, Jones. I won't go into too much detail because I don't want to spoil anything for people who are planning on reading this, but man, were they adorable. I was smiling uncontrollably reading some of the scenes with them. They were just so freaking cute!! And extra bonus points because they're an interracial couple. I really can't do justice to The Names They Gave Us in this review. This book will have you laughing in one chapter and crying the next and you'll love every minute of it. It's been awhile since I've so thoroughly enjoyed a book. If even a small part of this book has you interested, you must give it a try because chances are you'll really end up enjoying it. Thank you to Bloomsbury Children's for providing me with an eARC via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

I really loved this! "To all the boys I've loved before" is such a unique and diverse novel and a wonderful addition to the YA contemporary genre. All the characters felt very well developed and I connected to most of them, except for Kitty who was kind of annoying. But all in all, the relationship between the Song sisters was one of my favourite parts of this book! Everything about this story was just so cute and relatable. I loved all the smaller plot lines that went into it and made Lara Jean's life so realistic because this book doesn't only focus on romance. Of course, the love story is the main part of this book but it also deals with family, friendships and some highschool drama, which may seem annoying but made this book even more enjoyable for me. I completely understood and agreed with Lara Jean's feelings and uncertainty towards the boys and her fear of losing people and growing apart, which is an important topic in YA literature. The thing that probably stuck out to me the most was that being uncertain about love and maybe having feelings for multiple people at once was never portrayed as a bad or reprehensible, but as a natural part of life. I'm looking forward to continuing with the series and can't wait to get my hands on the next book! And hopefully she'll end up with a boy nicer than Peter, even though I highly doubt it. (For some reason, I always prefer the love interest that the main character doesn't end up with.)

I wanted to give this book three stars, and I thought I would throughout the first half/three quarters of the book. I am NOT a John Green fan. I understand why his writing is appealing to some, but I tend to find it pretentious and filled with characters that I can't relate to. But SO many people urged me to read this one and ultimately it got to me. There was one laugh out loud moment when Hazel and Gus place an online ad to giveaway her old swing set (I was hoping for more): "'Lonely, Vaguely Pedophilic Swing Set Seeks the Butts of Children.'" Anyway, I ended up liking the characters, empathizing with them, and attempting not to cry through the last quarter of the book.

This review is also featured on my blog, the Snark Theater. 2.5 stars So I had this whole rant planned about how this book was like a reverse Song of Achilles for me. Deeply personal, just...in all the worst ways. I also had this really great metaphor planned about the mirror from the Snow Queen, which only shows you the bad parts about yourself, and how this was how reading this book felt like for me. Ari Mendoza is a lot like teenage me. Well, teenage me, if I'd been Mexican American and if I'd been born some fifteen-ish years earlier. If you've read my reviews and think I'm overly verbose, well be glad you don't hear my inner monologue. Though you can get an idea by reading this book. I could have written a check list with everything Ari thought or did and I'd probably have checked most of them as things I did or thought as a teenager. And probably even as things I do now. But...none of them are things I'm proud of. I also had a few more rants in mind, like talking about the fact that contemporary/non fantasy books aren't for me, but that this is one of the better iterations of that genre. Or talking about the fact that this book doesn't have a very structured plot, and that yes, real life can be like that, but at the same time not really. I even planned to tell the story of my first and currently only crush as an example that stories do in fact have beginnings, middles and ends, but you can only identify those with hindsight. But that is all rendered irrelevant by the ending. Oh god what the fuck was that. Ari's parents sitting him down and telling him "you're in love with this guy because you saved his life and beat up this guy who put him in the hospital"? What? The fuck? What are friends for? And Ari claiming that all his angst and misery was caused by refusing to acknowledge his feelings for Dante? Feelings that weren't foreshadowed in any way as anything else than platonic? While on the other hand his angst and misery were established as being there before he even met Dante? Yeah, I call bullshit. You know, I should probably take down another star to my rating just for that, but I won't, because I feel like it wouldn't be fair to the book, hence the "2.5 stars" thing. Beware the incoming tangent, but...see, I hate Cassandra Clare. I've said it before, and it has to do with her online history and the cult-like way she's still dealing with her fandom. But I don't hate her books so much as I regret their lost potential. However, I do hate elements about her books. At the top of that list is Alec's coming out in City of Glass, because 1) consequences, but 2) Alec is described as happier and more comfortable and better for it. Well, this is the same problem. Coming out doesn't solve anything that is unrelated to your sexuality. I would know. I was out as bisexual at the age of fourteen. I pretended to date a guy at the age of fifteen (it was complicated and messy but for other reasons), that's how out I was. And yet, as I said when I began this review, I still had the same teenage angst Aristotle Mendoza has. So, no, I don't believe that him accepting his feelings and getting a boyfriend is going to change any of that. And I feel somewhat insulted by the very notion of it. So...in conclusion. Yeah, it's a cute book, with a cute romance (though the resolution comes straight of nowhere and is completely divorced from the protagonist's agency, which is never a good thing in my book), and teenagers who sound like teenagers. Sometimes I got a hunch of the "what teenager speaks like this? ", but the truth is, I spoke like that. If anything, it's only weirding me out because Ari supposedly has bad vocabulary (hell, I had better vocabulary in English at the same age and it's not even my first language), and it strikes me as something that would be related to being so "deep", introspective and pseudo-philosophical. But whatever, I don't mind that. And it's a deeply unsettling book, in a way that I think is intentional, and thus, mostly a good thing, even if I don't particularly like it. But I can't endorse it any more than that. The ending basically made the whole thing fall apart. Fuck you kind sir, I'm not here for this "Come out; you'll be better for it!" bullshit, which to me will always reek of bad straight allies (disclaimer: I don't know the author's sexual orientation, nor do I really care). Especially when the story arc that preceded that moment was about Dante getting beaten up for being out. What the fuck even.
